Topic 1: "The use of surveillance technology such as RFID to track people should be banned ."
The competitive world has caused technologies to improve rapidly in the 21st century .
One of the advancements in technology would be surveillance technology .
The concerns for safety and security have increased the extent of use of the surveillance systems .
Despite the proper usage of surveillance technology , there is a widespread abuse of the technology by some criminal organizations .
Hence , the potential for abuse increases .
Surveillance technology has been used as a tool for illegitimate activities which in turn threatens public safety and security .
This issue has become a main topic in public discussion .
Thus , due to the risk of misuse of surveillance technology , I fully concur that the use of surveillance technology should be banned .
First and foremost , surveillance technology such as Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) has been used as a tool for hackers and identity thieves to commit " 'contactless' "crime against victims without their consent (Lewan , 2009) .
RFID chip is largely used in some official identification documents such as driver's license and passport in America .
Once the RFID number is intercepted , it is possible for the criminals to track the movements of their targets without their knowledge .
Additionally , it has been concluded that the use of RFID has no benefit on the achievement of national security , but it resulted in an increment in risk of personal privacy and security (Lewan , 2009) .
Hence , the use of RFID should be discontinued .
Secondly , online behavioral tracking is another main issue of how surveillance technology has been misused .
It tracks users' online activities and collects their electronic information and makes the information available to parties other than their initial correspondents without their consent (Report on Consumer Watchdog; Consumer and Privacy Groups Urge Congress to Enact Consumer Privacy Guarantees , 2009) .
Hence , the consumers' privacy is invaded .
The online behavioral tracking can also be used to target vulnerable consumers for deceitful advertisement .
Thus , the security of the consumers is at high risk .
Thirdly , the improper use of this surveillance technology will bring about the consequence of privacy invasion .
Different people define privacy differently .
An anonymous author once defines privacy as " 'the claim of individuals , groups , or institutions to determine for themselves how , when and to what extent information about them is communicated to others' " (Bogonikolos and Holdsworth (Ed .
) . , 1999) .
Hence , everyone has the right to protect their privacy .
In conclusion , surveillance technology should be banned as it has been misused by people for illegal activities .
The misuse of surveillance technology not only invades users' privacy but also increases the risk to personal and national security .
There are many types of genetic testing , such as late-onset disorders and newborn screening .
Genetic testing allows early detection of diseases , which  may be useful to mankind .
However , genetic testing has brought about issues if such genetic results are revealed and abused .
Thus , I agree that the individual requesting genetic testing should have the final say in whether to reveal the results of such testing .
First , we will discuss  the relationship between employees and their employer's organisation .
There is tension between employees and employers regarding genetic testing .
(Stephen , 2003) .
If genetic testing indicates susceptibility  of an employee to diseases , there is a  chance  that the employer will dismiss the employee .
This is supported by the fact that most people with disabilities or diseases are discriminated against .
Most companies are not willing to employ them as they may be seen to be inefficient because of their disabilities .
Thus , genetic results should not be revealed to protect people from losing their jobs .
Opponents to this position may argue that such results should be revealed to protect the employer from an employee who is vulnerable  to illness .
(Stephen , 2003) .
However , the primary basis of employment should be work performance and efficiency , rather than on genetic testing .
(Kankowski & Capron ,1991) .
Hence , individuals should have the final say to protect them from  that may harm them .
(Stephen , 2003) .
Next , a further difficulty issue involves revealing of genetic results to insurance companies .
(Stephen , 2003) .
Applicants will be at a disadvantage when applying for insurance .
For example , if genetic results are revealed , the cost of the insurance will be expensive such that it may not be worth it .
Critics of this position claim that insurers will also be at a disadvantage if such results are not revealed to them .
(Stephen , 2003) .
I must admit that the insurer will be at a disadvantage if the situation is switched .
However , the cost of insurance should be on the current medical status of the applicant and should not be on the results of the genetic testing .
In conclusion , I believe that the individual requesting genetic testing should have the final say in whether to reveal the results of such testing as it will affect both the relationship between employees and employer and issues involving insurance .
Genetic testing is a test performed to allow genetic diagnosis of inherited diseases .
Not only so , genetic testing (fingerprinting) is also used to determine the child's paternity .
[1] Genetic testing does have many advantages in today's society .
In the society today , many have debated whether we really have the right to have the final say whether to reveal the results of the testing as many will think that it will lead to many ethical and social issues .
Or is it that it is a must to reveal it due to reality and we , individuals do not have the final say to reveal our testing to the public .
In my  opinion , in the high technology society we are living in , we do not have the final say in revealing of our genetic results to the public .
Companies do have the right to know the genetic testing results of an individual who is applying for the job offered by them .
For companies that offer jobs that require physical strength , it will be necessary to obtain the genetic testing of the individual .
For example , if one have inherited genetic disease like muscle dystrophy , it will be dangerous for them to work in the construction site .
Accidents might occur and it may also result in death .
Although many have debated that this is discrimination as companies may not employ those who has inherited diseases , but companies do have the right to choose employees with concern for their profits and the safety of others .
Individuals that may inherit genetic diseases should not choosejobs that are beyond their reach .
Hence companies instead of the individuals have the right to know the genetic testing of the individual .
A spouse does have the right to know the family disease of their partner .
If a couple is planning to have a child , it is best for them to go through genetic counseling if the parents are carriers of genetic disease [2] .
It will be unfair if the one kept the truth from their spouse .
The spouse does have the right to know whether the child will suffer from the genetic diseases .
This is a basic respect towards your partner in a marriage .
It is a must to declare it  and thus individuals do not have the final say in revealing of their genetic results to the third party .
The education sector  does have the right to know the genetic testing of their  students .
Those with genetic diseases like mental retardation and Down syndrome are asked to be enrolled in schools like MINDS and bright sparks .
Some may debate that this is a form of discrimination and violates the human rights of these children .
However , according to the American Association for mental retardation AAMR [3] , revealing of genetic testing results is not a form of discrimination but it is to be fair to those children with these genetic diseases as the children will be enrolled into the school that provides a better environment for them to study in .
It is a must to provide the school with the genetic testing result .
Hence individuals do not have the final say in revealing of their genetic results to the public .
All in all , in my  opinion , in the high technology society we are living in , we do not have the final say in revealing of our genetic results to the public .
It may not be a disadvantage and can even benefit many people based on the points mentioned above .
Thus individuals requesting  genetic testing do not have the final say in whether to reveal the results of such testing .
Use of Surveillance Technology such as RFID to track people should be banned
With rapid technological advancement , myriad forms of surveillance technology have surfaced and people are using it both intensively and extensively .
From forms as high level as satellite surveillance to the common Radio Frequency Identification Device (RFID) , surveillance technology has served us well .
However , due to the improper exploitation of it , surveillance technology has become more  detrimental than beneficial .
Intrusion of privacy and upsetting of the various balances in society are concerns people are increasingly worried about .
Hence , with so much discomfort people are experiencing with surveillance technology , it should be banned .
Due to the immense usage of surveillance technology , the society has become relatively transparent .
On the intangible aspects , information of individuals can be easily retrieved with the ease of data mining (Easton , 2006) .
With high speed connections and data transfer rate nowadays , an enormous bulk of data can be moved around in a very short period .
Classified information like credit card , banking and medical records can get into the wrong hands , producing many repercussions .
(Easton , 2006) Identity theft is flagrant and many more will suffer from financial losses .
Moreover , as RFID technology becomes increasingly popular with the retailers , privacy of consumers is again compromised .
(Hariton , 2006)The tags are usually not "killed" and this allows consumers' movement to be tracked and habits to be observed .
(Hariton , 2006) This thorough understanding of consumers has certainly gone overboard .
Last but not least , biometric surveillance has given checkpoints the capability to monitor people down to the skin .
(Monahan , 2006) Evolved surveillance here is so revealing that people appear literally naked on screens .
Furthermore , surveillance technology has created many  and upsets in the balance of our society .
Society will see the rise of discriminations since the entire background of an individual can be easily traced .
Dates cancelled , different standards in pricing of insurance premiums and harassment of political dissidents are just a few to mention .
(Easton , 2006) Next , surveillance technology also widens the gap between the rich and the poor .
The rich can afford to encrypt and protect their data while engaging in better surveillance over the less well off .
Moreover , by selling information (Easton , 2006) , the rich will get richer .
With regards to RFID , usage mentioned earlier  will reduce the variety of products available in stores because retailers will only consider the better selling items .
Society will witness a smorgasbord of changes in the various balances and the birth of more deviants such as stalkers .
Therefore , with all the worrisome disadvantages  surveillance technology will bring , we ought to ban it .
It makes privacy lose its meaning and is unhealthy for our society .
Consequences will be disastrous if we do not put an end to it .
With the revelation of human's DNA structure by Watson and Crick in 1953 , it shows that there will be a totally new science and engineering related subject being brought to the world , which is genetic engineering .
By utilizing the sophisticated technology tools , together with the perseverance of researchers , many genetics related approaches have been made possible .
One of the noted breakthroughs is genetic testing .
However , the advent of genetic testing does not bring unanimous consent from the public .
There are uproars regarding the moral and ethical issues which cloud the topic of genetic testing from time to time .
Some think that the individual requesting genetic testing should have the final say in disclosure of the results .
In fact , individuals requesting genetic testing should not have the final say as they would possibly make wrong decisions .
First of all , if the individuals get diagnosed with hereditary genetic disease , they will probably be overwhelmed by guilt or anxiety , thereby making a wrong decision , which is nondisclosure of their results within families .
It is primarily caused by the desire of protecting family members from troubling information .
Conversely , siblings of the subjects should be told immediately as they may carry the same genetic disease as the subjects' .
Some diseases are treatable in the presymptomatic stage .
Therefore , the siblings must know it so that treatment could be administered as soon as possible .
The general practitioner , who is the one they are consulting and also experienced in handling this kind of case , definitely has the final say to make a more rational decision for them .
After that , parents who request genetic testing for their children must provide the genetic information of their children to school authorities for the enrollment .
This aims to divide the group of children according to their learning skill and to ensure that every single child is provided with the most appropriate education .
Individuals requesting genetic testing usually decide not to disseminate their genetic information as discrimination may be put forth to their lives .
In fact , there is one of the federal laws that has been applied to genetics nondiscrimination which is Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act of 2008 (GINA) .
Besides forbidding the employers making adverse employment decisions , GINA also prohibits insurance companies reducing their coverage and pricing on the basis of information derived from genetic tests .
Thus , there is no fear of revealing the genetic results .
On the other hand , individuals are responsible to inform employers about their genetic conditions so that a better and safer working environment could be provided .
Finally , it has been said that individuals should have the final say on not disclosing their genetic information for research purposes .
Indeed , research teams should have a direct access to the genetic results so that the further genetic sequence on DNA could be unmasked in a faster pace .
As a result , individuals must provide their genetic information .
Ultimately , individuals requesting genetic testing should not have the final say in disclosure of their results .
This is because individual  is less capable of making a suitable decision .
It may end up with not only affecting one's life , but also influencing a few generations .
Hence , by having a requirement to reveal the genetic results , rational decisions will often be made to the benefit of the individual as a group discussion always comes up with fruitful conclusion .
The rapid development of medical technology has made it possible to diagnose disease inheritance or determine genetic disorders by using genetic testing .
Unfortunately , there is pro and con among the public about the disclosure of the result of genetic testing , whether it should be revealed or not .
Then , who will be the one who holds the right to do it ?
On one side , some people think that the individual who requests it has the final say for the revelation .
On the other hand , others reason that the genetic inheritance is something that is quite crucial , thus it should be discussed with the family first before reaching the final decision  .Therefore , the final say does not only depend on one person but also his relatives .
withholdIn conclusion , the result of genetic testing that inprivates about our herissue disease , will not only affect us as individual but also our family .
Therefore , the final say should not be in individual but the whole family .
Genetic testing has become a common practice in the modern society .
Its general purpose is to check if one has the potential to develop certain genetic diseases .
However , this has brought about many debates on  ethical issues in  society .
Some argued that individuals who have requested the genetic testing should have the final say about revealing their test results so as to preserve individual's rights .
However , this will have a  negative impact on  society .
Thus , they should not have the final say .
In conclusion , individuals should not have the final say about revealing their genetic test results since it will be more beneficial to the society .
By revealing the results will benefit the majority  .
After September 11 2001 , surveillance became important as it is one of the tools to prevent terrorism .
This then brings about the debates on whether surveillance technology should be banned  This is because surveillance could provide security , and it could also invade our privacy and disturb the society .
In my view , surveillance technology should be banned as the disadvantages clearly outweigh the advantages .
In conclusion , surveillance technology should be banned as it invades our privacy and disturbs the society 
The past two decades have brought about huge technological advances in the areas of nano-engineering and information systems .
With the help of  modern technology , humans are able to create increasingly efficient devices which are able to store relevant personal information or to trace one's location .
The use of sophisticated personnel tracking devices has long been an ethical quagmire , with people holding polarizing views debating if  surveillance technology can be  allowed to track people .
Proponents for the use of tracking devices on humans assert that patients can be easily identified in cases of emergency with their medical profiles easily accessible , since information is stored in a database that can be accessed via the internet (Lewan , 2007) .
Administrative procedures are greatly reduced , and the patient's vital records , for example drug allergies are readily retrievable .
Patients will be able to receive immediate and proper medical attention , which in certain cases can be a matter of life and death .
Moreover , tracking devices are able to assist law enforcement personnel to monitor suspects closely (Michael , K & Rose , G , 2007) .
Unknowing crime suspects can be monitored closely by the police over a period of time .
This allows discovery of new evidences through observation of the suspects; and to  prove if one is innocent or guilty .
Some arguments brought forward by opponents states that tagged identities could be easily duplicated by identity thefts (Lewan , 2009) .
This argument is flawed , as there is no concrete evidence showing the existence of such crimes .
The argument also blatantly ignored the fact that there are additional measures being taken to preventing such crimes .
Opponents also claim that the government will be able to use such devices to monitor , instil fear , and ultimately control the users (Lewan , 2009) .
This assertion is a fallacy , as it is based solely on foresight , and is cynical and biased .
In conclusion , tracking devices should be allowed in tracking people , as it is able to change human lives for the better , and it may even prevent or reduce crime rates .
Should the use of surveillance technology such as RFID to track people be banned ?
Nowadays , advances in technology have made tracking people no longer an uphill task .
Due to this , many surveillance technologies have been created in order to make the tracking job efficient .
A controversy on the benefits of the surveillance technology and the effects of the surveillance technology has been aroused .
Nonetheless , the use of it has brought along significant benefits and therefore it should not be banned .
There are two main benefits that the use of surveillance technology has brought  .
Firstly , it helps to tag "high-risk" patients (Todd Lewan , 2007) .
A microchip is implanted into the arm of patients who had heart diseases , diabetics or Alzheimer's disease .
For the Alzheimer's patients , it helps to track them in order to ensure their safety .
By using this technology , the location of the patient can be easily detect by a reader and immediate action can be taken if the patient is in risk .
This system really benefits the Alzheimer's patient who are often lost due to their degrading memories .
In conclusion , the use of surveillance technology to track people should not be banned .
It benefits not only the individual but the whole world .
Surveillance technology is being widely applied in the post-9/11 world .
Above all , the use of sophisticated surveillance technology , such as RFID and GPS by the law enforcement agencies to track people has raised many eyebrows and faced criticism .
However , human tracking technology is essential in preventing terrorism and reducing crime rate , subsequently ensuring the safety of lawful citizens .
Therefore , the use of surveillance technology to track people should not be banned .
There are two major advantages of using surveillance technology to track people .
Law enforcement agencies are able to identify terrorists and put a stop to their plans .
Recent happenings show that a number of terrorist plots have ceased because of  surveillance technology (Michael & Rose , 2007 , p . 8) .
It consequently helps to prevent major catastrophes ,  which involve the loss of human lives (Michael & Rose , 2007 , p .8) .
Other than that , the technology also helps in reducing crime rates all around the world .
It is especially useful in stamping out "transnational crimes such as drug and people trafficking , money laundering , and the smuggling of things" (Michael & Rose , 2007 , p .8) .
Besides that , surveillance technology also enables the tracking of criminals who are on the run  , and  even kidnappers .
Once being tagged , the lawbreakers' positions can be monitored and crimes can be solved within a short period of time .
Critics argue that such surveillance technology is able to track an individual on a regular basis , thus there is a compromise of one's privacy (Michael & Rose , 2007 , p . 2) .
Similarly , the United States has been criticized for promoting the use of human tracking technologies after the 9/11 event (Michael & Rose , 2007 , p . 8) , as it indicates the beginning of an Orwellian era as claimed by many privacy advocates (Lewan , 2007 , para .
7) .
However , this unfounded argument is not adequate to outlaw the use of human tracking technology .
Jacques Ellul noted that "to be sure of apprehending criminals , it is necessary that everyone be supervised" (Lyon , as cited in Michael & Rose , 2007 , p . 20) .
Safety of mankind is not worth being sacrificed just for the sake of their privacy .
A balance should be reached between the two extremes - the banning of human tracking technology and privacy being stripped away from innocent citizens .
"The individual requesting genetic testing should have the final say in whether to reveal the results of such testing"
Genetic testing is designed specifically to detect differences in deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) segments .
The history of genetic testing dates back to half a century ago where diseases such as PKU (phenylketonuria) , an "inborn error of metabolism" in which mental retardation is caused by an amino acid buildup in the blood , was tested on newborns (Lewis , 2008) .
While genetic testing presents healthcare benefits , it could bring possible harms if misused .
Therefore , the decision to reveal the results of a genetic test should remain in the hands of the patient .
Easy access by third parties such as insurance companies or healthcare professionals to an individual's genetic information may cause invasion of privacy and discrimination .
Although medical personnel are entrusted with the ethics of genetic testing , commercialization and easy access to certain genetic testing may lead to compromising situations for members of the public (Bioethics Advisory Committee , 2005) .
For instance , genetic information that falls into the hands of insurers and employers without the consent of individuals will be used to prejudice against the tested individual .
Society might treat the person differently or even deny basic rights to equal job opportunities , income , education , mental well-being , housing status , health , and medical treatment .
Racial discrimination still exists today in various parts of the world despite government efforts to eradicate it .
Who can say what will happen if a patient's genetic information falls into the wrong hands ?
In conclusion , the patient of genetic testing should have the final say in  revealing the results  .
Until proper steps such as enactment and reinforcement of laws are taken by the governments , genetic information of individuals should be kept private and confidential to avoid exploitation by unscrupulous parties and also to avoid the disintegration of family relations .
The release of genetic information of a patient has wide and lifelong implications on his or her life , and therefore this vital decision should be made after careful thought .
"The individual requesting genetic testing should have the final say in whether to reveal the results of such testing"
Genetic testing includes special techniques to examine the information carried by DNA which are held in the sequence of pieces of DNA called genes .
DNA is taken from a person's blood , body fluids or tissues .
By analysing an individual's specific genes , some diseases such as cystic fibrosis and sickle cell anemia may be detected .
An individual can prevent some diseases or get the appropriate treatment for the diseases after getting the results of genetic testing .
However , if the result of the test can be easily assessed by a third party , a lot of problems will occur .
Therefore , the patient should have the right to decide whether he or she wants to reveal the results of the genetic tests .
This issue will strongly affect the relationship between employees and employers .
Generally , all of these genetic results will be revealed to the employer and if the employer knows that some of the employees  are prone to certain diseases , it is likely that the employees will be fired .
This is because people with disabilities are often being discriminated against .
These people have to look for other alternatives to earn a living .
Once the results are revealed , employees will have difficulties finding other jobs .
Hence , results should not be revealed to protect employees from environments that might harm them .
Another difficulty involves the disclosure of genetic information to insurance companies .
Applicants for insurance will be under increased pressure to undergo genetic tests and those prone to diseases are less likely to be eligible to buy insurance .
In conclusion , genetic testing results are a matter that should be kept private for the benefits of the patient and should only be released under certain extreme circumstances . .
Genetics plays a role in every disease .
Genetic testing informs individuals and families of their genetic status; this knowledge may enable them to take adaptive measures against a genetic disease (Jacobs , & Deatrick , 1999) , if the disease is treatable .
However , as technology advances , exploitation of genetic testing increases , resulting in the breach of human rights of privacy .
Removing individual's control over the results will in turn lead to freely accessible genetic information , which may cause social problems and family dilemma .
Firstly , every human's gene is unique and personal .
The sharing of personal genetic result is akin to being exposed to public scrutiny . .
It is undeniable that one is morally obliged to inform the relatives of the patients about the genetic test results .
However , one has the rights to confidentiality and decision on what information to reveal and how to disclose it .
Moreover , relatives , being the recipients of the bad news should have their choice whether to remain ignorant  .
Therefore , one has the rights to one's genetic privacy .
Thirdly , family members generally inherit the same set of genetic codes from their parents , and may be susceptible to similar diseases (Jacobs , & Deatrick , 1999) .
However , one would not be able to determine their preparedness for such information .
It may cause not only unnecessary distress and anxiety to relatives , but will also unravel family secrets; namely adoptions and parentage (Doukas , & Berg , 2001) .
Thus , it is still up to the discretion of individuals to go for genetic testing if they are at high risk .
Therefore , individuals who have requested for genetic testing should have the final say in whether to reveal the results of such testing .
"The individuals requesting genetic testing should not have the final say in whether to reveal the results of such testing ."
Genetic testing has made it possible to identify individuals who are at risk of having a disease , and to test the probability of them passing on a disease to their offspring .
There is an ongoing debate in whether these individuals should have the final say in whether or not to reveal the results .
This is because these results will affect not only the individual , but also his family , offspring , the future generations and even the society .
Thus , individuals should not have the final say in the disclosure of genetic testing results .
Secondly , individuals can receive better family support and further harm can be prevented .
If individuals do not have the final say in revealing genetic test results , their family members will know their condition , and they can be more sensitive to the individual's feelings , such as giving them better support and encouragement .
Also , people diagnosed with chronic diseases are more prone to getting depression (IMH) .
Bottling up emotions will worsen the condition , and in severe cases , will lead to suicide (IMH) .
This will do more harm than good to the individuals .
"The use of surveillance technology such as RFID to track people should be banned ."
In modern times , there is an increase in the types of threat that can affect a nation's security .
People need to collect intelligence about a situation before they can act against it; and this has led to the increasing employment of surveillance technology .
The use of surveillance technology has raised concerns over the intrusion of personal privacy (Sim , 2006) .
However , since surveillance technology can help to identify problems , a solution or preventive measure can be formulated to prevent these problems from occurring , and this in turn lead to the protection  of people's health and the country's socio-economic stability .
Hence , the use of such surveillance technology  to track people should not be banned .
Firstly , the use of biometric surveillance in the form of a biometric passport will make it more difficult for terrorists to travel in and out of different countries , due to increasing passport security and border surveillance .
Furthermore , this information which is kept in a central repository can easily be updated and shared among other government agencies by wireless internet , making biometric surveillance timely and accurate (Sim , 2006) .
This method is highly efficient compared to traditional passport controls and surveillance methods .
Not being able to track terrorist movements could allow terrorists to enter a country and possibly carry out a terrorist attack; and it also makes it easier for them to escape .
In conclusion , surveillance technology should not be banned as it could result in a compromise of the nation's security and could pose a danger to people and their health as well as the country's socio-economic stability .
A better solution would be the introduction of a privacy act .
Over the years , there has been an increase in the use of surveillance technology .
This has brought about a wild debate on the banning of the use of surveillance technology to track the movement of people .
While most propositions agree to ban the use of surveillance technology , they have in fact overlooked the actual and potential benefits of the surveillance technology .
These benefits include disease surveillance and private surveillance on family members .
Thus , the use of surveillance technology should not be completely banned .
In conclusion , surveillance technology should not be banned as it can help to control the spread of diseases and also protect our family from harm .
Furthermore , the banning of this technology may cause more harm to society .

Secondly , revelation of one's genetic status subjects the individual to many social issues related to genetic discrimination (Bereano , 2000 .
For instance , insurance companies would reduce healthcare coverage , increase health premiums or terminate the health insurance policies for individuals with potential genetic risk (Bereano , 2000 .
Furthermore , discrimination imposed by employers and colleagues could influence an individual's self- esteem and psychological well-being .
In conclusion , individuals should have the privacy to determine whether to reveal their genetic results or not since it not only inflicts emotional distress on their family but also subjects them to social discrimination .
Advancement and breakthrough in technology has now made tracking individuals using surveillance technology a reality today .
This has sparked many controversial debates on ethical and moral issues on using such technology .
Some have highlighted that usage of such technology infringes on individuals' personal privacy .
On the other hand , surveillance technology can also protect the well-being of people .
Since the advantages of surveillance technology far outweighs the disadvantages , it should not be banned .
There are many factors that support the use of surveillance technology to track individuals .
Firstly , surveillance technology such as biometrics , aids national security in areas like terrorism (Sim , 2006) .
Surveillance of terrorist focus on countering terrorist threats and allows the government body to intervene before a catastrophe takes place .
If not controlled appropriately , it may lead to chaos and instability of the state .
Arguments presented for the ban on the use of surveillance technology to track individuals are totally flawed .
For instance , the existence of surveillance technology in the virtual world helps to curb crimes against copyrights , piracy and bank frauds .
Copyright protection such as the TurnItIn Online Programme , is designed to detect unreferenced copying or plagiarism in individual's work .
In addition , illegal file distribution , sale and download are acts that tantamount to promoting piracy .
Individuals can be sued by the relevant distribution companies and authorities .
Moreover , surveillance technology helps protect against bank frauds and illegal activities , such as hacking into personal Internet banking accounts .
DBS Bank has in place security surveillance systems that regularly "monitor and detect any potential form of illegitimate activities" ( , 2007) .
In conclusion , the use of advanced technology to track people should not be banned , as it promotes and enhances the protection of people in many aspects , hence , contributing to a better society .
As  genetic testing is making rapid progress on providing information on the hidden DNAs which might cause diseases , the techniques have also aroused a large amount of heated debates on the ethical and moral issues surrounding the control of final say of the testing .
In terms of individual rights of privacy and long-term social influence , the one requesting genetic testing should have the final say in whether to reveal the results of such testing .
First of all , the individual has the right to determine whether or not it is necessary to make the genetic testing results public .
According to the definition released by Bereano (2009) in his article Does Genetic Research Threaten Our Civil Liberties , the right of privacy "involves notions of the dignity and integrity of the individual" .
The individual who received the genetic testing should determine for himself or herself how and to what extent the relevant information is communicated to the public .
Although it cannot be denied that the other family members to some extent also have the right to know whether they share the same suspected genes as the tested , they can choose to test their genes by themselves , rather than to depend on other people's testing results .
If one's privacy cannot be protected so that the result might be made use of on any purpose , the human rights are endangered and hence this decision should be made by the individual requesting the genetic testing .
Secondly , social problems such as genetic discrimination tend to be implemented .
For instance ,  insurance companies can require the testing result before signing for a contact with a client who may be potential carriers of diseases .
Despite taking the risks of catching a disease , the client should  own the right to buy the insurance .
Nevertheless , insurance companies judge clients on the testing result and either refuse the healthcare coverage or even transfer this suspect diagnosis to the next generation" (Lynch & Lynch , 1996) .
This kind of problem will be wide-spreading .
Thus the individual should have the right to decide whether to reveal the result  , considering his own benefits .
To conclude , the one who requests genetic testing should have the final right to determine whether this result should be made public or not .
Surveillance technology was first introduced in the seventies where video tape surveillance became the global norm to watch human behaviours in a small area .
Over the years , advances in science and technology has empowered surveillance technology by introducing many forms and magnifying the scope of surveillance .
This has brought about many controversies on the ethical , health and social issues surrounding the notion of mass surveillance .
While supporters argue that surveillance technology brings benefits to the human race , the harms it causes when it is excessively misused outweigh the benefits .
Thus , due to the implications of surveillance technology , it should be banned .
Firstly , the use of surveillance technology invades our privacy .
Privacy is a  fundamental fundamental human right and we have the right to lead our lives without public surveillance .
In Britain , there are 4 .2 million CCTV cameras on the streets , about one for every 14 citizen ( , 2006) .
Mass surveillance has infringed our rights to lead a personal life as all our  actions and behaviours are being watched and tracked .
Therefore , surveillance technology should be banned as our basic right is being infringed upon .
Secondly , surveillance technology does not necessarily reduce the rate of terrorism .
September 11th would force world leaders to rethink their policies and implement all forms of surveillance .
Supporters suggest that surveillance technology provides a sense of security and helps to detect potential terrorist acts early by criminal profiling .
However , the truth is that surveillance technology does not prevent terrorism from occurring at all .
Surveillance technology also has loopholes and it is like a double- edged sword as anyone can use them for their own intentions which mean that terrorists might also use surveillance technology to observe their next "victim" .
Hence , it should be banned as it is redundant and a waste of resource .
Lastly , surveillance technology , such as RFID , might cause health problems in human implants .
Research shows that that implanted RFID tags are associated with tumors in rodents , mostly sarcomas (Foster & Jaeger , 2008) .
This result is alarming as it suggests  the possibility of a similar effect in humans (Foster & Jaeger , 2008) .
In conclusion , surveillance technology should be banned as the implications are menacing .

Surveillance technology has advanced rapidly over the years and is commonly seen in many places , from leisure places to workplaces and even to our lifts and homes .
This monitoring of other people's behaviour , activities , or information has brought about many debates on ethical issue , security issues as well as individual's health issues .
Though some suggest that surveillance technology benefits us  the negative implications outweigh the benefits .
Therefore , surveillance technology should be banned .
Firstly , the use of surveillance technology has dehumanized and violated our most basic right which is privacy .
This is because surveillance technology such as closed-circuit television (CCTV) allows others to watch and track our daily activities .
We have lost our rights in leading a personal life and have to live in  constant fear that our every movement is being monitored .
Furthermore , unethical companies could easily obtain our personal information through social network and use it to manipulate us .
When we lose our privacy , we become vulnerable psychologically and easily manipulated by others .
Therefore , it is ethically wrong to invade other people's privacy and there is a need to ban surveillance technology to protect our own rights .
Secondly , surveillance technology has failed to protect us .
Many countries use surveillance technology to prevent terrorism attacks but terrorists also use surveillance technology to plan their attacks .
Terrorists are able to track down the security system in other countries using computer monitoring and then launch their attacks successfully .
As a result , surveillance technology provides minimal prevention or protection for us .
Therefore , surveillance technology should be banned as it poses threat to us and is ineffective in protecting us .
Lastly , surveillance technology such as implantable radiofrequency identification technology (RFID) brings about potential health hazards .
Today , the use of RFID offers important health benefits such as convenient access to patient's contact information and medical history .
However , it has also been testified that RFID brings about other health complications such as infections , especially in elderly and weak individuals .
Therefore , surveillance technology should be banned as it may do more harm than benefits .
In conclusion , surveillance technology should be banned as it is not only ethically wrong but also poses threat to our security and health instead of protecting us .
The individual requesting genetic testing should have the final say in whether to reveal the results of such testing .
Secondly , it lowers the level of security of a country when terrorists are able to hack into their system and take control of the country's well-being .
As we know it today , the use of surveillance technology is globally used as a mass communication .
It is also  used as a safety to watch over one's power grid just like what US is doing now .
"According to officials , cyberspies from China and Russia have hacked into the US electricity grid and hidden software that could be used to disrupt power supplies ."
( , 2009) .
This imposes a high risk to the US in a time of war or even crisis due to the disruption of network by these cyberspies .
Thus , it is ironically contradicting the purpose of having a surveillance technology to secure us which in fact is back-fired .
Finally , critics have argued that by implanting a biochip (eg .
Radio Frequency Identification , RFID) into a dementia person , it eases the hospital authority to locate the  patient's whereabouts .
However , there is often a health issue that is involved in this implantation which causes complications to patients' health .
In late 2007 , an anti-chip activist  an important point that for more than one decade it has been known that implanted RFID tags are associated with tumors in rodents , mostly sarcomas (Blanchard et al .
1999; Elcock et al .
2001; Tillmann et al .
1997) .
This causes a controversy about possible carcinogenic effects; a substance or agent that tends to produce cancer () , that may occur in the implantation of chips on humans .
Thus , this affects patients by adding a new disease to them when they are already ill .
In conclusion , the use of surveillance technology should be banned as it brings negative implications not only to the citizens but also the world and thus poses a high risk of insecurity to the world .

Today with the recent spread of SARS , H1N5 (bird flu) and the latest H1N1 (swine flu) , having surveillance technology helps us to  battle these disasters .
In 2003 when SARS spread causing thousands of deaths all across the world , the temperature radiation surveillance technology was invented to help identity those possible infected people from those who were not , and to separate those who are likely to be infected from the healthy population .
home tracking devices  implemented especially for those who were quarantined for the 10 days duration to ensure that they did not break the rules and venture out of their homes into the community .
Critics of tracking devices have lobbied for tracking devices to be banned as they have  been said to invade privacy .
However in this  , although the tracking device ia an invasion to a person's privacy , it serves a good cause to ensure the safety of the general population . 
Wellbeing of a child has been a major consideration and concern for most parents .
One of the advantages of advance surveillance technology is that it allows parents to keep track of their children regardless of where they are , and to have some ideas of what is happening in their children's lives .
Critics have argued that by this , children have lost all form of privacy and that they are under the control of their parents .
Arguments for the surveillance technology agree that although it invades the children privacy , if the child does not do anything that causes their parents to be worried about , invasion of privacy should not be a major issue .
Recently SingTel mobile launched a mobile plan called the "Permission-based location device" where it addresses the issue of invasion of privacy and at the same time gives parents and guardians a peace of mind by allowing them to know the exact location of their loved ones to have an idea of what is happening in their lives .
As shown , surveillance technology and it uses' benefits can outweigh the cons that it can bring .
To conclude , surveillance technology should not be banned as they have more positive advantages compared to its downside .

Motion: The individual requesting genetic testing should have the final say in whether to reveal the results of such testing .
Over the years , genetic testing has become more available to the public .
An individual can request and afford to undergo genetic testing to find out whether or not his body houses a defective gene .
When the results of the test are given to the individual , the question of whether the results should be revealed or not arises .
Although the individual may feel that he should have the final say on the revelation of the results , in fact , having the physicians decide whether the results should be revealed would be much more beneficial to the society and the individual himself .
Therefore , the individual should not have the final say on whether the results of such testing should be revealed .
Firstly , the physician is in a better position to decide if the results should be revealed .
This is due to the physician being more knowledgeable about the results , especially if a defective gene is detected in the individual .
The individual is unlikely to reveal their results to their family , potential and current employers , insurance companies for fear of discrimination from them ( 2007) .
However , by doing so , he is actually putting his family at risk as they will not know whether they too carry the defective gene which would put them at a higher risk of developing the disease associated with the gene () .
Furthermore , the physician would not be able to determine if the defective gene is hereditary and whether the other family members have that gene or not .
Secondly , for his own reasons , such as family disputes , the individual may choose not to act responsibly and withhold the results from family members .
In such cases , the physician would have the right to reveal the results to the family of the individual , especially if the test results indicate that the defective gene is present , there is the possibility that others in the family have the gene as well .
Also , with regards to the problem of discrimination , which is the underlying factor for the individual not wanting to reveal the results , there are laws in place in many countries that states that it is against the law to discriminate against people who have tested positive for a particular defective gene .
The physicians also have their medical code of conduct that states information about the patient which is confidential unless it poses threat to others ( 2008) .
In conclusion , the individual requesting genetic testing should not have the final say as to whether the results should be revealed or not as the benefits of revealing the results is substantial to the individual and his family , and it cannot be assumed that the individual will be able to act responsibly to his family in the face of his own interests .
Genetic testing has made possible the determination of genetic diseases .
However , the release of genetic testing results has brought about a controversy .
If family members havesimilar   genetic background , individuals may feel the need to disclose their results .
However , being likely to face discrimination from society , individuals should also have the choice to conceal the information from others .
This freedom of choice provides respect for their basic human rights .
Thus , individual consent should be obtained before the release of genetic testing results .
Firstly , the disclosure of a positive test result for a certain genetic disease may cause an individual to be susceptible to discrimination .
He may be treated less favourably than others due to his genetic disability .
For example , employers may prefer to employ individuals who are not predisposed to genetic diseases  , 2005) .
Health insurance companies may also avoid clients with genetic disorders ( , 2005) .
Thus , the discriminatory treatment an individual may be subjected to makes it essential that their consent be obtained in advance .
It may be argued that the legalization of the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act (GINA) may solve the problem of discrimination ( 2008) .
However , limitations in this policy may still subject individuals to discrimination due to the exclusion of those applying for life insurance , disability insurance or military benefits  , 2008) .
Thus , the ability of GINA to solve the problem of discrimination may be limited .
In conclusion , only the individual concerned regarding the genetic testing results may make the decision to reveal his results .
The violation of human rights and discrimination he faces may cause it to be unjust for the individual to feel compelled to reveal his results .
Therefore , it is of importance that confidentiality of the individual be preserved .
As a type of surveillance technology , RFID (Radio Frequency Identification) is drawing increased attention and has caused many conflicts with regard to privacy , security and health issues .
Advocators suggest that using RFID to conduct social control and tracking of suspects could benefit the whole society .
However , RFID in fact is not as ideal as they thought .
On the contrary , it not only leads to an invasion of privacy and identity theft but also poses health risks .
Hence , the use of RFID to track people should be banned .
Using RFID to track people raises many issues .
Firstly , the abuse of RFID invades privacy .
It is hard to guarantee that every tracking is innocent and conducted in proper ways and .
For example , overzealous employers and criminally intent people could take advantage of the RFID readers to track employees and victims' movement (Jean 2007) .
In this case , victims may lose their privacy even without awareness .
Secondly , because a RFID embedded card can easily   be skimmed and cloned , to some extent , it is a loophole for identity theft .
by using the cloned card , anyone could pass into a restricted area through the secure and locked entrance (Jones 2008) .
Hence , using a RFID equipped card to track and control entrance is not secure and effective at all .
Thirdly , implantable RFID chips have connections with health issues .
Research showed that "implanted RFID chips caused cancer in mice and rats and may cause cancer in cats , dogs , and humans" (Jean 2007) .
Additionally , "although an RFID chip in particular may not cause cancer , the inflammation caused by surgical implantation of a foreign object can increase the instance of tumor development" (Jean 2007) .
sacrificing the health of people when conducting tracking is therefore unacceptable
However , RFID advocators may argue for the purpose of alleviating the fear of privacy invasion .
For instance , the reader needs to be within about ten feet of the chip in order to extract data , so it may not handle long-range tracking (Jean 2007) .
However , it is still highly undetectable if the reader is installed inside doors or walls .
Furthermore , within such distance , RFID readers could still function (Jean 2007) .
Hence , people are still under the risk of being tracked and losing privacy without knowledge .
To conclude , since using RFID to track people raises the possibilities of privacy invasion and identity theft and causes health problems , the use of it should be banned .
Genetic testing is a test whereby the individual is tested for any deficiency in the genes that could indicate the presence of future diseases .
But once the result is out and the person has some defective genes , different issues starts to surface .
The person might be subjugated to discrimination and not even the Genetic Information Non-discrimination Act (GINA) would be able to solve the problem .
Furthermore , the individual has the right to decide on whether the result should be disclosed or not .
Hence , I strongly agree that the person should have the final say on whether to reveal the genetic testing result so as to avoid these problems .
Secondly , critics at the other end of the table may argue that there is the Genetic Information Non-discrimination Act (GINA) in the US that was passed down by the former US president , Mr . Bush on 21 May 2008 which states that 'the genetic carriers would be protect against discrimination when it comes to work and health insurance' (Kaiser Family Foundation , 2008) .
However , these laws generally fail to offer comprehensive protection to all people at risk for genetic discrimination .
Tera Eerkes , founder of personal genetic testing company  states that 'this measure does not prevent genetic discrimination against people when they are applying for life insurance , or long term care and disability insurance' .
Moreover , the insurance companies will be forced to hike up the cost of their premiums and might result in healthy individuals being quoted the same rate as the genetic risk group (David , L .V .
2008 , ) .
Thirdly , the individual should not be denied of his rights in the decision on whether the result should be disclosed or not , or else , problems might occur .
The European Convention on Human Rights states that "Everyone has the right to respect for his private and family life , his home and his correspondence ."
(Patrick , N . ,1993) .
If an individual is denied of his right to decide on the disclosure of his test result , probably no one will dare go for testing since they know that they do not possess the right to decide whether the result stays secret .
This will result in dire consequences , for example; there will not be proper family planning since genetic disorder is not taken into consideration , which might result in continued breeding of undesirable genetic traits in one's offspring .
In conclusion , the person who went for genetic testing should have the final say on whether to reveal the genetic testing result so that he will not be discriminated against or even denied of his basic human rights .
Recently , Radio Frequency Identification technology , also known as "RFID" has been a hot topic for discussion .
In the past , it was used to track equipmentequipment and data and this did not create much controversy with regard to the issue of privacy .
However , as technology improved RFID is now more frequently used to track people .
While some argue that the use of RFID to track people is unfavourable , it in fact not only ensures one's security and safety but also saves time and cuts cost for an industry .
Thus , due to the immense benefits of RFID , it should not be banned .
There are two important benefits of RFID .
Firstly , RFID is used in hospitals to keep a close watch on people for their own safety .
(Getz , 2009) .
This reduces the need to hire full-time nurses to accompany the Alzheimer's patients wherever they go .
When these patients wander around and get lost in an unfamiliar place , we are able to track their whereabouts and know where they are immediately .
Secondly , RFID is used to monitor employees' movements .
(Getz , 2009) .
This is especially useful in hospitals during emergency to track the whereabouts of doctors .
In life and death situation , doctors that are in the vicinity of the operation theatre can be called in for help instantly , hence saving time .
Arguments put forth to ban RFID are faulty .
For instance , it has been argued that the excessive use of RFID tags result in deterioration of personal privacy .
(Ward , 2006) .
However , for the group of people who requires constant attention , safety outweighs privacy issues .
Furthermore , RFID tags can be snapped in half to prevent the transmission of data when it is no longer in use .
Thus , this will not threaten individual's privacy .
Finally , there has been greater concern about RFID not only tracking the data of the patient , but also tracking the patient's actual whereabouts .
(Getz , 2009) .
On the contrary , this is a minor issue as only those with access to hospital's database can interpret the information .
Otherwise , this information is purposeless .
In conclusion , RFID should not be banned as it not only saves time and effort but also ensures one's protection from harm under close surveillance .
Advances in technology have made mass surveillance possible , even to track humans .
However , this has stirred up much controversy due to the privacy , security and health issues surrounding its use .
Supporters claim that surveillance technology can increase efficiency and effectiveness in tracking criminals and potential terrorists , and decreasing crime rates or track runaway or Alzheimer patients in hospitals to provide better care for every patient (Jean , 2007) .
In fact , it causes more security than health threats thus using it to track people should be banned to ensure their safety .
Threats discussed here would be with reference to Radio Frequency Identification Device (RFID) .
The main argument to support the banning is the risk of identity theft .
RFID tags and cards can be easily hacked and cloned and used immediately to get past what we presumed to be secured (Jones , 2008) .
If one had their pocket picked , he would know and can take measures to prevent it .
However , if one's personal information had been stolen without one's knowledge , one is completely vulnerable .
It is against the law to steal another persons identification card but not the information by "skimming" (Jones , 2008) .
The problem is worsened by the fact that these RFID tags and cards carry unlimited information and there are no regulations to include these virtual crimes .
RFID has enabled potential criminals to commit crimes more easily than ever with technology that is so readily available and surprisingly inexpensive .
Another argument to oppose the use of RFID to track people is the possibility of contracting cancer with the implantation of the chips .
"Research in the 1990s showed that implanted RFID chips caused cancer in rats and may cause cancer in humans" (Jean , 2007) .
Though rats are more likely to develop tumors regardless of the type of injection , "inflammation caused by surgical implantation of a foreign object still does increase the instance of tumor development" (Jean , 2007) .
Therefore , for the sole purpose of tracking , this sacrifice is not needed .
In conclusion , the banning of the use of surveillance technology such as RFID to track people would be essential to protect vulnerable civilians from security and health threats .
The rapid advances in medical technology present genetic testing that is used , to identify specific genes responsible for a significant disease in an individual (Centre for Genetic Education , n .d .) .
The perception of whether an individual should have the final say to reveal the results of genetic tests has lead to an ethical dilemma in  society and amongst individuals , particularly in family-relationships .
Since , the advantages of revealing the results of genetic tests outweigh the disadvantages in most situations ,  an individual should therefore not have the absolute authority to reveal their test results .
Finally , the potential discrimination in the society upon revealing the genetic test results is faulty .
This is because , the Insurance and Financial Services Association (IFSA) in Australia have a policy that states , genetic testing or having family members at risk for certain disease , will not be required for assessment in the insurance companies (Centre for Genetic Education , n .d .) .
It has been suggested that there should be respect for individual health condition .
In conclusion , the individual requesting genetic testing should not have the final say in revealing the results since , the advantages of revealing the genetic test results outweigh in most situations .
Radio-frequency identification , more often known as RFID in short , is one of the most pervasive technologies developed since the late 1940s .
Today , enterprises found the use of RFID chips in a wide variety of places including hospital , transportation system , corporations , schools , and worryingly , human beings (Andrea Jean , 2007) .
In this paper , I would like to discuss some problems in the use of RFID chip on human beings .
Human implant is experimented and studied deeply in many countries .
However , this has  proved to have huge problems unfortunately .
Volunteers participated in a controlled experiment on skimming  proved that a hacker is able to skim and clone an access card in a split second and using the card to get entrance to a "secure and locked" entrance (Jones , 2008) .
This absurd result brings into question  the security use of the human implant .
Looking at this piece of fact closely , it is not hard for us to see the more serious problem behind it .
RFID chip is able to store much information on personal identity .
Skimming from a skilled hacker is possible for the leaking of one's personal information to unfriendly parties he or she is not willing to befriend with .
This may lead to wide ranges of problems such as blackmailing , complication of crime investigation , duplication of identity , and in some cases , it can even be used as a political weapon .
Human implant of RFID is against human right in this sense as there is a huge risk of losing one's personal privacy .
Though outlawing skimming on RFID tags can be a possible solution , no one can be sure that it would not turn out to be like the case of computer hacking .
Though RFID has proven to be useful in many places , human implant will surely brings us more problems than benefits .
No doubt , under special circumstances , example implantation on babies and mentally disabled will make it easier for us to monitor them , RFID implant on human , however , is generally inappropriate .
With the advance of technology , surveillance technology has become prevalent in the society .
Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) as one type of surveillance technology is used as a tool to track people .
Although concerns on privacy issues are raised , RFID benefits the society by ensuring safety among people .
Hence , since RFID brings about positive benefits , it should not be banned .
One area which benefits greatly from RFID technology is the health sector .
Firstly , due to RFID , the safety and security of the patients are ensured .
RFID is used to track patients' locations in order to make sure they are safe .
This is especially true for elderly patients with Alzheimer's disease .
Patients suffering from Alzheimer's have the tendency to wander .
Hence , RFID will be able to lookout for these patients and ensure they do not go missing , making them safe (Getz , 2009) .
Also , RFID technology can prevent newborns from being kidnapped .
With RFID , the locations of newborns can be monitored .
Thus , if there are to be unauthorized movements , immediate action can be taken (Getz , 2009) .
With the newborns' safety being ensured , their parents will not have to worry constantly when they are not able to take care of their infants around the clock .
Thus , RFID technology is able to protect the patients and ensure a safe and secure environment in hospitals .
Proponents for banning of surveillance technology in particular RFID argue that the privacy of people is invaded as people's specific locations can be identified (Getz , 2009) .
If there are standard laws put in place , so that information from RFID tags can only be obtained by authorized people , then , there should not be privacy concerns due to RFID (Getz , 2009) .
The user can choose whether or not to give out his or her information , as an RFID tag can be broken into two so that information will not be transferred (Ward , 2006) .
Since , privacy concerns are not much of an issue , RFID should not be banned .
In conclusion , the use of surveillance technology particularly RFID should not be banned as it results in a safe environment and the privacy concerns regarding it are not much an issue .
The completion of Human Genome Project has contributed significantly to the rapid development of genetic tests , a valuable tool that aids in diagnosis and prevention of genetic diseases .
However , due to the nature of the information generated , there have been many debates over who should hold the final decisions to the disclosure of genetic test results .
While some propose that giving individuals the authority to decide curbs arising ethical implications like discrimination , this in fact stops physicians from preventing illnesses and saving more lives .
Thus , the final decision should not be made by the individuals tested .
An important reason why patients should not be empowered to make the final decision is that it prevents doctors from tending to potential patients who could be at high risk of developing a disease if disclosure is not made .
Due to the need to maintain confidentiality of results , doctors will be compelled to watch patients with the defective gene fall ill when appropriate intervention can be done to avert  harm .
This  has gone against their 'proper medical and ethical practices' (Minkoff & Ecker , 2008) of preventing harm or avoiding serious jeopardisation of the health of others ) .
Considering  these competing obligations faced by physicians , the genetic care and counselling organisations have devised guidelines which accept disclosure to relatives without the consent of those tested when there is going to be a high degree and immediacy of risk faced by them (Minkoff & Ecker , 2008) .
It has been argued that genetic discrimination will arise in the context of insurance and employment if the decision is not made by those who are tested .
However , there has been limited evidence of genetic discrimination in both areas of insurance and workplace based on recent research .
(www .genetics .edu .au) Moreover , a policy statement by Insurance and Financial Services Association (IFSA) in Australia have made it mandatory that genetic testing will not be considered a requirement for policy risk assessment .
The statement also claims that the insurance industry will not utilise the genetic information of one for risk assessment of their family member (www .genetics .edu .au) .
In conclusion , individuals requesting for genetic testing should not be given the full authority to make the final decisions in results disclosure as it coerces doctors from fulfilling their duties in promoting the wellbeing of the society .
Modern advances in genetic research have helped scientists and doctors learn more about genes and how they affect us .
This has made it possible to know whether a person has inherited a disease before the symptoms start and show if a person is a gene carrier for a certain disease through genetic testing .
This brings up several issues , should the patient who tested positive for the disease be granted autonomy ?
[2] Lastly , should the patient be allowed to withhold the information from his/her family ?
[1] Due to the ethical and social issues genetic testing can bring , the individual requesting the genetic testing should not have the final say in revealing the results of the test but the medical professionals .
In the event in which the patient tests positive for a particular terminal illness , and refuses to receive the results , should the physician then respect his/her wishes although it violates the physician's ethics of putting patient's safety first ?
[2] Physicians trained to deal with the emotional burdens of a positive test result , are capable of properly counselling the patient of the implications of not knowing the test result and also providing the needed medical treatment for the long run .
[1] As the medical professionals would know what medical treatment the patient would need , and also understand the encumbrance such knowledge would bring , it is best that the medical professionals decide whether or not to reveal the test results .
Lastly , patients may , upon knowing the results of the test , refuse to share the results to immediate family members who will then be at risk as there is a chance that the same gene causing the disease runs through the family .
In this situation , the patient is unduly putting others at risk as knowledge of inheriting a disease could help to save a patient if diagnosed and treated early .
[2] Patients may also argue over the right to withhold the information as they have a right for privacy and autonomy .
Therefore medical professionals being experts in handling such situations would be able to recommend several other alternatives if the patient is insistent on withholding the test results .
[1]
In conclusion , the medical professionals are able to appropriately handle the delicate issues of genetic testing .
Hence , they should have the right in whether or not to reveal the results of genetic testing .
Technology has made our life so convenient that we have overlooked the {repercussions that comes with it .
An example would be the use of surveillance in this case radio frequency identification (RFID) technology in our everyday life without considering the health risks , consumer privacy rights and also its vulnerability to information thefts .
With that the usage of RFID should be banned so as to safeguard the general public .
Firstly the health issue poses a big threat to the usage of RFID as these chips are used in close vicinity to our body .
Patients who wish to keep their medical information might choose to have the chip implanted right under their skin .
The safety of using these chips is still uncertain even its exact position as the chips "(could) migrate under the skin and become difficult to extract" (Bacheldor 2007) .
Another concerning issue is that the "RFID tags may electromagnetically interfere with electrosurgical devices" (Bacheldor 2007) with particular attention at magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans .
Instead of aiding the patients to recuperate , the tags might in turn cause further deterioration to the patient's health .
Secondly , consumers might be ignorant to the fact that the products they purchased could be tagged so as to provide companies with the sales data and for market research .
Customers could also be tracked with the products anywhere so long as there is a right reader that could read the frequency (Free 2007) Consumer privacy will no longer be existent as consumers lose freedom of choice and also consistently losing personal information to marketeers .
Lastly as another information-carrying device , the RFID is also vulnerable to cyber criminals out to steal information about the users .
The attempts on hacking and spoofing the RFID tags had already been successful and so long as the frequency is replicated , the hacker would have access to the functions the RFID tag was made for (Halamka , Juels , Stubblefeild and Westhues 2006) .
The user might lose his password for access to areas or monetary items and also his identity .
The possibility that the RFID technology would prove to be more of a hindrance than a convenience is evident .
Therefore it should be banned in order to protect us from such vulnerabilities that the RFID would cause ,
