One of the policies introduced by the government in tackling the aging population is the Baby Bonus Scheme .
However , despite being implemented for several years , the scheme has yet to produce satisfying results .
This is because many young Singaporeans are now leading a different lifestyle and adopting different ideologies about the concept of marriage and family .
For example , some of them do not see the need of having babies and view having children as a potential source of problem to their ever-stressful life .
Also , many feel that the scheme is not attractive enough to offset the cost of having more babies .
With the relentless rising cost of living and competition , Singaporeans now have to work harder just to meet the ends .
Thus , many are put off by the idea of having more children due to the accompanying life-time commitment of raising a child .
Therefore , due to these worries , many couples are not responding to the scheme despite the continuous efforts made by the government .
To lengthen working lifespan , the government introduced policies to reduce elder dependency by raising eligibility age for public pensions and government incentives .
However , depending entirely on legislation will not bring about substantial improvements in boosting employment prospects for the "silver population" .
For example , the employment rate for workers aged 55-64 was only 57% in 2008 , a slow increase from 38% in 1991 .
For those aged 65-69 , the employment rate was merely 27 .5% .
Thus , even if the legal retirement age was raised , it has clearly produced limited results .
The main reason is that even if older workers want to work , the deciding factor still lies with the employers .
In fact , stipulating higher retirement age can have an adverse effect .
Employers now think twice before employing or retaining older workers due to the potential higher liability and costs such as retraining programs and insurance benefits .
As a result , employers tend to shut their doors to older workers .
In line with the above efforts to tackle the problem of the graying population , the government introduced the Parents' Maintenance Act in 1996 to impose on filial piety .
However , the government cannot simply legislate filial piety .
Law alone cannot be used to solve the problems that cause some children to abandon their parents .
In fact , the Act is likely to cause even more distress among children who are already overly burdened with the ever rising cost of living in Singapore .
Family ties may be further strained since the children are not taking care of their parents willingly .
Also , the government will be seen as shirking its responsibility towards the elderly citizens by pushing the load of parental care to their children .
Taking it from the parents' perspective , some of them may not even consider the act of being abandoned by their children  a shameful matter .
These parents may want to protect their family's name and want their children to take care of them out of gratitude instead of legal obligations .
Therefore , while it seems that the Act is based on well intentions , it is certainly not the solution to the root of the parents' maintenance problem .
Clearly , the rise of the aging population brings about complex and multi- faceted challenges to the whole of society .
The government should first understand and address the changing mindset and values of today's society towards problems created by the fast aging population before implementing the policies .
Merely depending on legislation will not help to improve the attitudes of the society towards the elderly significantly .
Instead , this will bring about further resentment and result in a strain of relationship between the young and the old .
In all , moving beyond the law to enhance the perceptions of the elderly is a more practical way to increase the ability and willingness of the society to coordinate with the government in tackling the "grey tsunami" .
With the growing population and various problems that the present government face today , the governments are finding it tedious to balance the budget to ensure that all areas of development are being met .
No country or state is able to provide unlimited funding to the providence of the aged .
Besides this , there are also other areas of the country which require more monetary spending to ensure the future of the country such as Education and Research and Development (R&D) .
However , public spending on the aged should not take a backseat .
There should be a sum of money which is set aside for the welfare of the aged .
After all , they were once a pillar of the country and helped to perpetuate growth of the country economically .
Basically , from the moral viewpoint , regardless of race or religion , filial piety is an important moral value that should be inculcated into us .
By having the government to set the standard of caring for the elderly , the public should also share the economic burden of caring for the aged .
Thus , the society should be magnanimous in spending in areas of healthcare or recreational programs .
For example , pumping money into R&D of illnesses like dementia , osteoporosis and Parkinson's disease will benefit the aged because these illnesses are more apparent as people grow old .
This prepares the medical sector to handle these illnesses .
The government could also conduct recreational programs such as medical talks on the possible health problems that could arise in the aged .
This will help the elderly to understand the causes and effects of these health problems which encourage them to adopt a healthy lifestyle that reduces the risks of contracting these illnesses .
Therefore , we should spend on the aged .
However , economic benefits will be minimal if the state decides to be a welfare state and compromises the economic development of the country .
Suppose a country were to provide full support to the elderly , other developments like education and public housing would be costly .
People will be discouraged to study and will be in a state of chaos as the standard of living is too high for people to cope .
Even though this policy largely benefits the elderly , the rest of the society will suffer .
If no money were diverted into education , the country will suffer economically as there will be insufficient "intelligent" resource to promote economic growth .
When there are few to sustain the high cost of maintaining the aged , the aged will eventually suffer .
It will be like a vicious cycle .
The situation will be made worse if the country faces declining birth rate such as Singapore .
There are lesser young people to support the aged .
This increases economic burden for them .
Therefore , unlimited spending on the aged would be clearly unthinkable .
It will be more realistic if a calculated amount of spending is being distributed to the aged .
Areas like education and R&D help to fuel the economy .
These two areas are considered to play key roles in the growth of a nation .
For example , in countries like Singapore where there is a lack of natural resources , with only human resource , it is important for most Singaporeans to be educated .
Having received education increases the probability of one being employed which helps to promote economical growth .
With economical growth , the standard of living will also increase for people living in Singapore .
Furthermore , Singapore depends largely on international trade for growth .
Exports in Singapore comprise of over 130% of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) ever since mid 1980s .
The main products being export out of Singapore are integrated circuits , computer parts and accessories .
Since export plays a significant role in contributing to the GDP of Singapore , a vast amount of finance should be diverted to R&D .
Therefore , by providing education and investment into R&D help generate capital for the country .
Economic growth leads to an increase in standard of living which benefits the whole society including the aged .
A budget should be set for the public spending on the aged .
In fact , the governments should adopt and develop appropriate systems and programs customized with respect to their cultural , economic and social context .
Furthermore , it is beneficial for governments to exchange pointers and assist one another in coping with the effects of greying population .
This help to ensure that majority will age with security .
Keeping the aged in mind , we must never neglect the future generations since they will be the ones who will support the nation .
Therefore , we should first cater the needs of the younger ones .
Public spending on the aged should be limited as there are other areas that are of equal , or even greater , importance .
A substantial amount is spent on the elderly annually , and this sum of money can be put to other uses .
Maintaining and sustaining a country is not just about looking after the aged , but also about developing growing sectors of our nation .
Although it is essential for the government to spend on the graying population , there are ways to minimize this spending , and this amount can then be used on other areas of the country's growth and development , such as maintaining our country's defense and improving the education system .
Furthermore , lengthening the working lifespan of our citizens might be another viable solution in dealing with an aging population .
This is , however , hard to achieve in our present day society as employers , given a choice , tend to avoid hiring the elderly as they are thought to be less productive when compared to younger workers .
Therefore , there should be some government intervention with regards to employment of the elderly , as this will assist them in securing a place in the workforce .
Not only does it benefit the government as spending on the aged can be reduced , it also benefits them both economically and socially .
Longer working years will allow the elderly to accumulate more wealth for future use in times of need .
With this accumulated wealth , they will then be able to meet their basic needs and be less dependent on the government when they retire from the workforce .
Furthermore , working can help to decrease boredom in retirement , as time will then be spent engaging in productive activities at work , and not be whiled away doing nothing .
These benefits of longer working lifespan can be made possible if employers are willing to hire the aged , who can then be self-sufficient with minimum , or no , help from the government .
The benefits of limiting public spending on the elderly is seen when this amount of money can be channeled to other areas of our country's development .
One such area is defense , which is exceptionally important to an island country like ours .
We have to be prepared against terrorism and external attacks by other countries , at all times .
Apart from defense , the government needs to invest in our country's development as well , and this includes improvements in our education system .
This will then ensure that our future generations will learn more and benefit from it , and it is of great importance as they are the future pillars of our society , who will lead our country to greater heights in order to be a successful and progressive nation .
There are clearly many areas that the government has to spend on annually , and the graying population is one of it .
However , other areas should not be neglected , as our nation's growth and development are of vital importance as well .
Many ways are , indeed , present to help limit public spending on the aged .
The goal of limiting public spending on the aged will be made possible if the proposed measures are strongly enforced , and high cooperation among citizens of our society will help to deal with this issue too .
It is well-known that people's life expectancy is increasing , leading to the pressure of expenditures on the elderly who are considered to be weak and non-productive .
However , what we do not know or are still confused about is an effective way to both take care of the aged and enhance the development of other fields .
It is a matter of money usage .
There is a suggestion that  governments should limit  expenditures on the aged so that they will have money to spend on other areas to develop the countries .
To some extent , I agree with this statement but it should be clarified at some points .
The first point needed to be clarified is how limited  government funding on the elderly should be and what will happen if the expenditures are below an acceptable level .
-----------------------
[1] "Because capital is a produced factor of production , a society can change the amount of capital it has .
If today the economy produces a large quantity of new capital goods , then tomorrow it will have a larger stock of capital and be able to produce more of all types of goods and services .
Thus , one way to raise future productivity is to invest more current resources in the production of capital ."
(Mankiw  , N . Gregory & Taylo , Mark P . r .
(Eds .) .
(2006) .
Economics .
Cengage Learning)
With fast-aging population and the restricted national budgets which do not allow spending generously on the elderly , this limit should be maintained at an acceptable level which ensures that the basic needs of the aged such as food , clothing , housing , transportation and healthcare are met .
However , in some nations , especially developing countries , in order to meet the need of investing  in other areas to push the countries forward , the governments cut down the basic expenditures on the aged .
Is it a wise choice ?
Cutting down the fiscal costs on the aging population to support other areas does not mean that those areas will receive all the benefits .
Imagine a situation in which without sufficient support from the government , the aged become a burden to their families . .
In that case , if the fiscal costs on the aged are cut down to spend more on the young generation , it can lead to the result that the money aimed to support one target in a family -  the young - will be shared to partly meet the demands of both the elderly and the young .
In other words , the purposes of investing in other areas of development by using money saved from the fiscalcosts on the aged cannot be fully fulfilled .
In developing countries , decreasing the basic expenditures on the aged can lead to a worse situation .
The aged in these nations , especially in rural areas , do not merely need money to lead the rest of their lives , but also need money raise their children or grandchildren .
They share with their younger generations their limited monthly retirement pensions or allowances to cover all the costs of living , but usually , they would run out of money before the pensions/allowances of the next month come to their hands .
Living in poverty , the younger generations grow up with poor opportunities to accumulate wealth to support themselves , let alone supporting their next generations when they become old .
And sadly , the circle of poverty goes on .
The second point needed to be clarified is in which areas the money saved from maintaining the fiscal costs on the aged at the satisfactory level should be invested and how to make use of the money earned from these investments to benefit the aged .
One of the productive areas to invest in is economy[1] since economic development helps to raise the national budgets and thus raise the public expenditures on the elderly .
Money earned from investments in economy should be partly used to support the aged not only to lessen the burden on the families and to alleviate  poverty from generations to generations , but also to ease the elderly's lives .
The increasing size of the economy could be relatively limited , but spending more on the aged does allow the government to have more choices to take care of the aged in a better way .
In other words , what the government should do is not merely promoting  economic growth but also taking action to link each increasing level of economic growth with a correspondingly higher level of the quality of life for the elderly .
In conclusion , limiting  fiscal costs on the aged without thorough considerations could lead to unexpected results which directly affect the elderly themselves and their families , as well as indirectly impact on the society and the country's development .
In cutting down the spending on the aged ,  governments must ensure that the basic needs of the aged are still satisfied and the money saved from fiscal restraint should be efficiently invested to be partially plowed back into the elderly .
The gap between theory and practice could be hard to close .
However , the way of taking action will be easier if the plan is well prepared .
In addition , governments should put more effort into and invest on those areas that are productive .
This will help  the country's economic growth .
For example , Singapore's casino-resort project will bring many employment opportunities and it is estimated that there will be very high returns in the future for both Singapore as well as the investors of this project . .
Thus the income of citizens will rise and  lead to increased savings .
Citizens will have an easier life after their retirement .
This will reduce their reliance on others like the government and their families .
On the part of the government , they will be able to develop medical technology and provide more medical schemes to help the aged .
Furthermore , the rate of poverty will be lower .
People would be able to afford to look after their elderly .
Clearly any further expansion of financial schemes on the elderly will only impoverish future generations and limit future public spending .
Spending on elderly , especially healthcare , can continue indefinitely because of the continuous introduction of new technologies and treatments that are beneficial but expensive .
Governments and policy makers have to decide  what is essential and should be supported by the public sector .
In brief , leaders in governments must  and implement practical measures to cope with the problems of a fast aging population .
Education plays a very important role in a nation's development , as it is the most basic platform for a society to learn and improve .
The government should allocate more funds to  building a higher education system , which will lead to more educated and productive future generations .
As the future generations will be more educated and productive , they will be able to contribute more to the economy and this , in turn , should get them a higher income .
A higher income will allow the younger generation to support themselves better and therefore provide for their own parents , so that the government can spend less on caring for the old .
Another outcome of better education standards is that both the younger and older generations will better understand what could happen to them when they grow old .
This means both the younger and older generations will be able to better plan for their old age and the problems that come with it , for example , deteriorating health .
To stay healthy , they can exercise more and have a good diet .
This makes lower health subsidies from the government possible as more people know how to stay healthy .
Other than concentrating on better education , the government can also build on better communication and transportation infrastructure which will then attract more investors and foreign talent to Singapore .
With an improvement in education standards , more students will pursue their studies in Singapore , creating a chance to convert these visiting students into local citizens  , which will in turn increase the tax base for the future .
And with a better communication and transportation infrastructure , Singapore will be a place where global companies will start investing and opening branches or offices .
This will then increase job opportunities for the people and also the country's income .
Both the above improvements will boost Singapore's income , allowing the government to use more money to address various national issues , be they economic development or social problems , such as an aging society .
While the idea of improving education to ease the aging problem in the future is workable , there may still be a problem of individuals who will not be able to  .
In a society , there will always be different people with different backgrounds , for example , the rich and educated versus the poor and illiterate .
But the illiterate will not stay illiterate always; if they put an effort to improve and are given a chance for good education , they can still develop into a group of productive Singaporeans .
This makes the 'unproductive Singaporeans' , who cannot take care of their elderly , a minority group of the whole society , therefore , subsidies for such families to take care of the elderly will still be minimal .
By allocating more funds to education and infrastructure , governments can ensure effective development in the country , thereby increasing the standard of living .
This will also lead to a society with more educated and self-sufficient families , where minimal subsidies are needed to help a minority of the population , thereby limiting spending on the problem of the aged or an aging population .
We all know that the elderly have devoted all their intelligence , knowledge and strength to our society  .
So should we abandon these people when they are not as strong and perspicacious as they were before ?
Basically , it is the moral responsibility of our society to do  its best to support the elderly even at the expense of other areas of the country's development .
There is no denying the fact that each country has a limited  budget , so it can not afford to spend too much on the elderly because it also has to spend on other areas of the country's development .
For example , there are also many other needy people like orphans , the disabled or unemployed that want to be subsidized by the government .
They are all feeble and vulnerable people .
It is very hard for them to earn enough money for themselves .
The fact is they cannot compete with others  .
Therefore , it would be a huge financial burden for their relatives to support them .
Unless the government spends more money to support them and create more job opportunities for them , they will be left to fend for themselves and  .
However , we should consider who should be given priority and who deserves a share of the national budget the most .
The elderly usually do not have enough strength to do manual labor whereas mental work requires perspicacity and concentration  , areas in which they cannot compete with  younger candidates .
For example , in Singapore , I have seen that almost all cleaners are the elderly .
Nevertheless , they do not look strong enough to do such manual work , but they still have to do it , to earn  their own living .
Obviously , old people have fewer chances to work for their own living compared with other needy people who still have physically healthyphysicallybodies .
What is more , the elderly should be respected and  for their contributions in the days of their youth .
What we have today is partially an inheritance from previous generations .
The elderly were once hard working not only in raising their children but also in devoting their strength and intelligence for a better society like the one we have today .
Now when they are old , they cannot continue to do productive work , so it is our society's responsibility to support them .
Although there is a limit to the national budget and the government has to balance spending in different areas for the country's development , subsidy for the elderly should not be cut .
If each person has a sense of responsibility towards increasing the size of today's economy and tax base , then it will not be a big problem for us to spend more money on the aged .
The Ease Of The Aging Process : Through Research & Development and Government Policies
Nowadays , nobody can deny that an aging population is becoming one of the most serious problems to developed countries , including Singapore .
Recent research studies have shown that the proportion of the country's residents aged 65 and above can reach the rate of 18 .7% in the next 20 years .
Population aging has become a cause of concern in the realm of finance to the government .
It seems inevitable that we must spend more on the aged .
But what are we getting for all that money ?
Should we limit  public spending on the aged so that the money can be diverted to  areas of the country's development ?
Answers to these questions are not easy to find .
However , in my opinion ,  public spending could be more productive if the government knows how to control the money spent on the aged and also how to invest in other areas of development .
Among several areas of public spending on the aged , such as medical subsidies , public infrastructure , pension schemes , and financial aids , healthcare must be considered the most important area .
As  healthcare costs are now getting more and more expensive ,  it becomes harder and harder for poor , old people to fulfill their payment for their medical bills .
Based on this situation , some claim that the government should automatically spend more  on the aged , who deserve to be helped .
However , the national budget will come under pressure when growing numbers of elderly persons are supported by relatively fewer young persons , which leads to the question  , "Can we really afford so much health care for an aging population , or are we heading toward a healthcare crisis in the near future ?"
Once again , the answer is not easy to find .
Nevertheless , the budget for healthcare is not infinite , so the government and policy makers must decide to which extent they willsubsidize the healthcare cost of an individual , and this would probably depend on his own financial capacity .
The government needs to know how to set limits on the healthcare budget for the elderly .
The second reason is that public spending is not the only solution to the problem of population aging .
Researchers and policy makers have made a lot of suggestions and developed a lot of strategies to help buffet the negative impact of an aging population on our society .
Some of these include encouraging later retirement ,  , encouraging the elderly and their families to take more responsibility for their health , etc .
Therefore , instead of spending too much money on the aged , the government can think about realizing some of these  policies , or or developing  policies to solve the problem .
Last but not least , Singapore must spend money on a large number of other essential areas of development , such as education , infrastructure , defense , investmentsand so on These areas of development are  the key  that a country needs in order to become a developed one .
Without a good education system , there will not be a well-educated intellectual generation for the country .
Without good infrastructure , there will not be sufficient facilities for the country  .
Without a good defense system , people will live in the danger of terrorism as well as of being invaded by enemy nations .
Therefore , these areas of development must be well invested in .
Moreover , when all of these areas are developed enough to fulfill  , the living standard of Singaporeans will increase .
Consequently , , the aged will receive more help and budget from the society , and they may even earn more money to support themselves too .
In conclusion , Singapore , as well as many European and North American countries , is facing the problem of an aging population .
If we do not put enough effort to solve the problem right now , it will be a problematic issue in the future .
As the problem is controversial and there are a lot of different opinions surrounding it , the government and the policy makers must know how to make the right decision to come up with the best solution for the country .
The most essential thing is to think out of the box .
We  need to consider  many factors that affect our decision , such as whether we have enough money to afford all the healthcare cost , or whether there are any other areas of the nation's development that really need our investment .
Therefore , setting limits on the public spending on the aged , I think , is a much better and wiser choice .
Demographic changes have recently caused many controversial issues .
Among these , the increasing number of aged people as well as the decrease in fertility rate as a new way of living is  a challenge that the world has to face in the next decade .
, especially in developed countries like Germany or Japan , where the aged population will make up a large proportion of the population soon .
, the elderly is receiving more and more support from the government , which is a strategy in social welfare development .
Ironically , these policies not only bring benefits for the old people but also partly have a negative impact upon the socioeconomic development of the country .
In other words , the public expenditures on the aged have created barriers which limit the improvement of other fields .
Therefore , this spending should be reconsidered carefully to avoid financial shortage in other areas of the country's development .
As part of the effort to enhance  social welfare , a lot of schemes have been adopted and operated in recent years for the sake of the elderly population .
Truthfully , these policies are significantly beneficial to senior citizens especially with respect to health , a problem induced by the physical aging process .
Some intermediate and long-term care facilities like community hospitals , services like home medical and home nursing services , and aid like public subsidies in Singapore are perhaps good examples of support from the government .
Some statistics have showed that the government expenditure on community development , youth and sports went up by about 57% from 2005 to 2008 while that on health rose dramatically by 128%(1) .
In reality , theschemes below certainly accounted for not a small percentage of the increased public spending .
This growth in number of projects put heavier pressure on the government budget , which consequently created an imbalance in theexpenditurefor different domains .
This spending , furthermore , is likely to increase more and more in the next few .
Also , it is not all the government's duties to take care of the elderly .
Firstly , at the personal level , the aged have to be responsible for themselves .
When individuals are still at the working age , they should provide in advance for their life after retirement .
Saving and investing more of their income , for instance , are some ways to prepare for their old age .
Secondly , at the social level , it is  the filial obligation of  children to take care of their parents when they grow old .
This will obviously help to reduce the expenditure by sharing  between the government and its citizens .
The most important reason why the government should limit spending on senior citizens is that it will constrain other sectors from taking advantage of the government budget .
Once the support for the elderly takes up too much of the budget , then other sectors of society cannot receive adequate financial assistance .
Take education for example .
Compared with the rise in expenditure for health , community development , youth and sports as mentioned below ,  government investment in  strategic sectors like education in Singapore between 2005 and 2008  decreased from 994 to 856 million dollars (nearly 14%)(2) .
In addition , there are other sectors such as industry ,  transportationand information technology which also play an important role in building a solid infrastructure for the nation's development and which thus require proper concern from officials .
However , with a limited budget , the government is not capable of covering all expenses .
To a certain extent , restriction on  is reasonable and necessary so that  can be used to expand many other crucial areas .
This will contribute more to the progress of the society than  .
In short , the government and policy makers should come to a reasonable decision on all projects .
In the face of a limited budget ,  public spending ,  should give priority to necessary schemes and identify which cost can be reduced in order to  .
Clearly , the government can cut down on excessive support for the elderly because there are many other ways  .
In this way , the money saved can be used to implement more urgent and practical policies that also contribute to the nation's strength and potential .
*  , (2) Statistics Singapore .
Theme on Public Finance .
Government Development Expenditure .

According to the United Nations , 1 in every 5 persons throughout the world would be aged 60 years or older by the year 2050 .
In the more developed regions , the number of persons aged over 60 would increase by 70% from 231 million in 2000 to395 million in 2050 .
These alarming statistics would bring about economic and societal problems to many developed countries .
One of problems is that the government might need to channel more revenue to meet the demands of the elderly group .
In the long run , this can lead to shrinkage in the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of the country or even affect the other sectors of development .
To prevent such situations from happening , different governments of the developed nations have come up with policies to confront the challenges of an aging population .
However , these social policies that have been implemented are not effective in easing the aging process as they do not fully cater to the demands of their targeted group .
Firstly , the means-testing policy fails to protect every citizen that requires public funding in practical realities .
In the context of Singapore , the means-testing system carried out in nursing homes assesses the financial status of the entire family .
Under this system , if the family has a high income level , the government would provide lower subsidies to the patient .
However , this is not a fair assessment because there are elderly patients that have been abandoned by their children .
The elderly patient would not be able to afford the bills .
The flaws in the execution of the mean-testing system do not only occur in Singapore .
In Australia , even though the means-testing system is deemed as an important way to help the government to redistribute the money to those who are in need , it fails to protect all the elderly .
This is because some of them might find means testing humiliating as it forces people to declare themselves to be in poverty .
These examples go to show that the means-testing policy has not fully catered to the demands of its targeted group .
Secondly , population growth policies do not meet the demands of married couples .
In view of the graying population , many developed nations have come up with policies to encourage childbirth .
In the case of Japan , the government introduced its Tokyo Plus One Policy to attract married couples to give birth to more babies .
The policy included measures such as increasing the number of nurseries and making new changes in the child welfare law .
Despite the government's effort in promoting childbirth , the total fertility rate of Japan remains low .
In addition , there are many considerations that married couples have when it comes to childbirth .
One of these considerations for couples is the need to strike a balance between family and work life when a new member is added to their family .
These obstacles show that population growth policies are not effective in meeting the demands of married couples .
Lastly , the policy to raise the retirement age in developed nations does not serve as a long-term solution in meeting the needs of the elderly well .
In Singapore , the government intends to raise the retirement age of the working group to 62 so that the elderly can continue to support themselves financially .
However , it is undeniable that age discrimination is still evident in work places .
An employer would prefer to hire a young adult as compared to an elderly as the former can contribute to the company for a longer period of time .
Some might argue that even though the elderly cannot compete with the younger generation for jobs , the government does organize job fairs to help the elderly seek jobs .
However , although these job fairs provide more working opportunities for the elderly , the success of such job fairs is largely dependent on the receptiveness of the elderly's expectations of the scope of the new job .
Furthermore , there should be a maximum cap to the increment on retirement age as we also need to consider the physical capabilities of the elderly .
All these obstacles show that raising the retirement age does not address  the concerns of the elderly .
Therefore , it is clear that social policies do not always meet the needs of the groups they seek to cater to .
No matter how well a social policy is constructed , there are still loopholes that are often overlooked by policy-makers .
This shows that much more can be done to improve the different kinds of policies .
Furthermore , it is important to note that social policies should be flexible so that they can make suitable changes to meet the demands of the society at different points in time .
Once the demands are met , the route to easing an aging population would be much more smooth-sailing than it is being thought .
It is common to see a society aging with the elderly population rising rapidly in  recent years .
Although the society has a moral obligation to do all that it can to help the elderly , there are still limits to the budget the government can allocate to help the aged .
When there are limited resources , scarcity is unavoidable which leads to a situation where not everyone will benefit and there will be those who are in need who will be left out .
When policies are constrained by a budget  .
To minimize or eliminate the occurrence of this phenomenon there should not be a limit to government spending on the elderly .
One of the examples is the government plan to extend the working lifespan of the elderly .
However , this is not a practicable and long-term solution to the problem .
Firstly , to what limit should the government delay their retirement ?
A year or two or more ?
With every year that by , they face the limitations of their physical and mental strength .
loss in sight , hearing and mobilityas well as the development of are very common .
They also have to face the fact that they are unable to keep up with the workload they used to handle in their younger days even if they want to .
Although delaying retirement can help the elderly to accumulate some wealth , reality speaks differently when it comes to elderly people .
No matter how experienced or skilled an elderly person is , he or she will always be at a disadvantage  compared to those who are younger , more energetic and most importantly , more productive than them .
Therefore , spending on the elderly should not be limited in order to better them .
Besides that , what  the Singapore government did was introduce the Baby Bonus scheme to the public with the objective of encouraging the public to have more children .
This is important , as having more youths will increase the productivity of the country as well as spread the cost of development over a large population .
However , this scheme has not worked as well as predicted even though the government has put efforts into promoting it .
The scheme netted only a gain of 129 citizen births last year in 2008 compared to the number of births in 2003 .
Such a scheme is impractical even if it may work in the long run .
The reason is that not everyone is willing to have a baby just to get the benefit offered by the scheme .
Having a baby is a long-term responsibility and burden not many are willing and prepared to take .
Therefore , resources  should be diverted directly to help the elderly to be able to cope with their problems immediately .
If we spend less on the elderly , children will have the filial obligation to take care of the elderly .
This may sound good and interesting but with the current economic status , where is less economic growth , tougher choices need to be made to cope with the demand of the society .
Even if the economy improves , the expenses of the elderly will just keep on getting higher; it seems to only benefit the government and not the elderly .
Furthermore ,  will heavily burden those who have an elderly person at home and such stress leads many of them to abandon their elderly .
Besides that , there are still a segment of people that have no job , no savings nor even   no family that we often .
If expenditure on the aged is cut off , how would we expect them to be able to survive and it is supposedly the obligation of the government to provide shelter to these people .
As such , it is important for the government to spend more to help these people .
Although there are other areas such as education , infrastructure and defense that require our attention , it is also of equal importance for us to have the same concern for the elderly .
These people are the ones that have dedicated themselves to the development of the country in the past .
It is their right to enjoy the privileges provided by the government after their retirement .
As such , my point of view is that the spending on the aged should not be limited .
If the expenditure towards the elderly is limited , many will be left in a lurch and thus  among the elderly .
Old age is a reality that we all have to face one day .
The tremendous improvement in nutrition and medication has led to life expectancy in the developed world increasing significantly .
As the elderly population soars , the demographic changes that occur will cause increased public spending on the elderly in different fields such as medical care and public infrastructures .
Thus , many national budgets and economies will come under pressure as growing numbers of elderly people outnumber the number of younger people .
Despite all that , public spending on the elderly should not be limited as society has the moral obligation and  to assist them in all aspects .
The elderly have contributed much to the country's development so public expenditure on the elderly should not be limited .
It is undeniable that the elderly have made immense contributions to the country and their sacrifices create the relative social and economic comfort we enjoy now .
The elderly have become bright examples for the younger generation in various domains .
Many of them have made valuable contributions to the country in different fields such as politics , science and technology  , economics  and culture as well .
On top of that , most importantly , they have contributed to the nation by imparting their knowledge and experience to the younger generation .
For instance , over the years , the elderly have helped to build up the economy of Singapore by developing several policies and they have worked hard in securing and maintaining the stability of the country .

Although many may argue that public spending incurred to support the elderly should be limited , this will create an impact on the society and increase  .
The limitation in public spending on the elderly may cause family members and individuals to shoulder a bigger responsibility in taking care of the elderly .
In addition , some of those expenses on the elderly will end up getting shifted back to the public sector through less direct and more expensive means .
For example , the rising cost of healthcare  for the elderly has taken its toll on  and many can not afford it .
Thus , family members may need to fork out their own money to support their elderly parents .
Consequently , conflict and arguments among family members may occur in this matter .
Also , many other issues related to housing and transportation cannot be resolved .
Families and local communities will have to deal with those by restructuring welfare programmes .
Furthermore , the limitation in public expenditure on the elderly  will also affect the level of physical , mental and emotional well-being of an elderly person .
With the decrease in public spending on the elderly , many elderly people will come under pressure as they will have greater financial dependency on others .
Subsidies on health care and treatment at community hospitals and nursing homes for the elderly for instance will be cut off , hence leaving the elderly to fend for themselves .
All this pressure  could make them suffer from mental illness as their children may not look after them  .
For most of the elderly , family members are the major source of social and financial support .
Without that support , the elderly may start to spend time reflecting on their past , remembering disappointments and that stage of life may turn into a time of despair and loneliness , with only little positive meaning in life .
All this could eventually lead to suicide and depression among the elderly .
On the whole ,  government and society should support public spending for the elderly because the aged have in the past contributed to society and have made Singapore what it is today .
The elderly should benefit from the government , family and community care in all aspects to help them to ease their burden after what they have done for us over the years .
public spending on the elderly constitutes a safety net for them and all parties should work hand in hand to resolve  .

The aging population has of late become a subject for discussion because the growth of an aging population has brought about serious health issues and social problems in the developed nations .
National budgets will also come under pressure as a growing number of elderly are supported by relatively fewer younger people .
Thus , to deal with such challenges , research has been carried out anddevelopment as well as policies have been developed to help the elderly .
The development in the field of economics has surprisingly contributed to easing the aging population problem .
Researchers believe that the critical challenge of an aging society is not only about how to accommodate the older population , but  about how to ensure the productivity of future workers , regardless of age .
Thus ,  have been done by the government in encouraging the economic growth in our country in order to decrease the problems that may arise from the aging process .
To encourage the economic growth of our country , our government has worked hard to develop the tourism industry in our country .
Tourism in our country has successfully created a wide range of occupations for our citizens , such as tour guide , airline staff , drivers , hoteliers , caterers and interpreters .
The lower barrier to elder employment which has been set by the government has allowed employers to take in older workers to work in the jobs mentioned above .
Thus , more people have the opportunity to work .
The rate of unemployment will decrease .
People can work longer , accumulate more wealth and increase their savings .
At the same time , the poverty rate can be decreased .
People can also afford to look after their elderly .
After retirement , the elderly can also use the money that they have earned to support themselves without depending on their families .
By improving the business environment , our country has also undergone a dramatic climb in our economy .
This has created more business  for our local traders .
Thus , taxes which are collected have increased and the income of our country has also risen .
These taxes have been used in the development of medical technology to help  cure the incurable , such as heart attack , tuberculosis , cornea impairment and cataract .
There are also medical facilities and systems which have been lately introduced , such as laser therapy , dialysis machines and microsurgery .
With all these modern technologies , human life can be extended and people can live more healthily .
The elderly can be stronger and fewer of them will be suffering from medical conditions , such as stroke , diabetes , cancer and high blood pressure .
Employers who claim that the elderly are restricted in ability and mobility will also no longer have any excuse to reject elderly individuals who wish to work in their organization .
The government has worked hard to create opportunities for foreign investors to encourage foreign investment .
This has increased the foreign currency exchange and stopped the outflow of our local currency and hence strengthened the value of our money .
As a result , there has been a significant growth in our economy that has increased the income of our country .
The income that our country has earned is then being spent on the welfare of the elderly .
The government has used the money to build more community hospitals and nursing homes which are well-equipped with  elderly-friendly facilities .
They also provide a range of services to meet the needs of the elderly , such as  medical care , nursing care , physiotherapy , dietary services and dental care .
The elderly can be admitted into the community hospitals or nursing homes if they need daily skilled nursing care or assistance in the activities of daily living because they have no caregiver to look after them at home .
Society has fewer choices on how to care for those who are least able to care for themselves when there is only little economic growth .
On the other hand , there will be more choices and fewer people in need when there is  sufficient economic growth .
The growth of the economy can solve many problems which arise from an an aging population .
Abandoned and unmarried old people can stand on their own feet without relying on others .
Excuses such as high cost of living making it hard for working adults to pay for their elderly's living expenses will not exist too .
Obviously , efforts that the government put into developing the economy of our country have resulted in  successful growth and inevitably , this has contributed to easing and solving the problems of aging population .
Many developed countries are now facing the same crucial issue: an aging population .
Take Singapore as an example; she will be witnessing a drastic demographic shift in history , with the age population ratio predicted to change drastically from one in twelve residents being over the age of 65 in 2005 to one in five residents in 2030 (Community on Ageing Issues , 2006) .
Hence , there would be a need for governments to increase expenditure on the aged to accommodate  this burgeoning age group .
, the crux of the issue here lies in how much this spending on the aged should be capped at .
For instance , health care now accounts for 4 .5% of Singapore's gross national expenditure (Wijaya , 2009) .
If there is no limit set to this figure , it can continue indefinitely , perhaps up to a double-digit figure , and may even cut into the state budget for other areas of development .
Therefore , public spending on the aged should be limited so that there would be adequate resources available for other areas of the country's development .
critics argue that by limiting the amount spent on the aged and diverting the resources to other areas of the country's development , the essential needs of the elderly would be neglected .
One such example is the healthcare needs of the elderly .
It would hardly be a surprise that healthcare costs for the elderly would continue to escalate in the decades ahead .
With the never-ending introduction of new medical technologies and the seriousness of prolonged illnesses associated with old age , medical treatments for the elderly would be increasingly expensive .
Furthermore limiting of  public spending on the aged would  shift more of these healthcare costs to the elderly themselves , causing the elderly to shoulder a heavier financial burden .
The elderly would therefore be at the suffering end .

While this may indeed happen , the situation can still be remedied .
Additional profits reaped from the investment in other areas of the country's development could in turn contribute to on the elderly significantly .
In fact , it is inevitable for the government to divert money to the other areas of development as an aging population affects these areas significantly .
One considerable implication of an aging population is its possible impact on the country's future macro-economic performance (Schuiz , Borowoki , & Crown , 1991) .
As the baby boomers ,  , begin to move out of the workforce , the country will face the problem of a shrinking workforce .
In Singapore , there are currently 8 .5 economically active persons to support one elderly person .
By 2030 , the labour-dependency ratio will drastically drop to only 3 .5 persons supporting one elderly person (Central Provident Fund [CPF] Board) .
This shrinking workforce may signal the advent of a less productive workforce and greater financial strain on the members of the workforce as they need to produce adequate amounts of output to support the burgeoning elderly population (Schuiz et al . , 1991) .
On top of that , a shrinking and less productive workforce could have an adverse impact on the country's economic growth .
Therefore , the government should divert more resources such as increased investments in human capital to improve , or at least sustain , the productivity of the workforce and the country's economic growth .
sufficient economic growth would bring prosperity to the country and in turn benefit the society as a whole .
The additional profits reaped from this investment may in turn be re-channeled to the public funds to help the needy ones , including the elderly .
Hence , the investments in other areas of the country's development would not be at the expense of the needs of the elderly; in actual fact , they could create a win-win situation .
In addition , limiting the public spending on the aged and diverting resources to other areas may not necessarily mean that the government is neglecting the needs of the elderly .
The government is still taking care of the aged in various aspects .
One aspect is the formulating of policies with the elderly in mind .
For instance , the Singapore government has passed the Maintenance of Parents Act to allow elderly parents to file lawsuits against their children for financial support (Khalik , 2009) .
This legislation would help to discourage adult children from shirking their responsibility of looking after their aged parents .
In addition , the government has long enforced individual savings through the mandatory CPF , compelling the population to save for their old age (Wijaya , 2009) .
This approach taken by the government would enable the individuals to accumulate wealth , and hence depend less on their family and the government financially in their twilight years .
these various aspects show that governments have taken a more well-rounded approach in taking care of the needs of the elderly; and that public spending on the aged is not and should not be used as a single depiction of how governments can express their concerns towards the elderly .
In a nutshell , limiting  public spending on the aged and diverting resources to other areas of the country's development do not necessarily mean that the government is neglecting the needs of the aged .
One should note that setting limits on  public spending on the aged  reduces the over-dependency of the aged on the government while diverting resources to other areas of development  allows the country to prosper and subsequently benefit the whole community , which includes the aged .
It is through this approachthat pressing issues such as the economic implications of an aging population can be resolved and at the same time , more revenue can be generated to help the needy  that includes the elderly as well .

Moody , H . R . (2000) .
Aging: Concepts and Controversies (3rd ed .) .
California: Pine Forge Press .
Public spending is defined as the amount of funding the government channels into the society from the monies it collects from the society .
This fund is generated through various economic activities , usually in the form of taxation .
The debate often revolves round how the government utilizes this fund , which is contributed by the citizens .
The total amount collected from an economy tends to be more or less fixed in the short term .
Therefore , if one group of people gets more , the others would get lesser .
Thus , by limiting the spending on the aged , it would mean that other sectors of the society would get more than before .
This essay will discuss  the limit that should be imposed on the amount of funds that should be budgeted for  the aged that would constitute  a fair distribution of government resources .
This is due to the fact that the aged is not the only dependent group in society .
If there is a tendency to spend more than necessary on the aged , other sectors of the economy might find that they lack finances to function adequately .
Some might say that it is immoral to deprive the aged of the help they need .
They tend to support this argument by considering the contributions made by the aged during their hey-days and the level of their dependency in this season of their lives .
However , this school of thought focuses on only one aspect of the issues of society .
There is no doubt that some of the aged need help .
However , they are not the only dependent group .
A country is likely to also include the poor , the uneducated , the physically disabled , the intellectually underdeveloped , and many others who require constant monetary aid from the government .
Thus , it can almost be called an ill-informed decision when one claims that the government should take care of the aged without limits .
There is no doubt that we should ensure that the aged can age with dignity .
However , not only  the aged , but who are dependent on the government's help should also have the right to live with dignity  .
Thus , while the government educates the aged about their rights and campaigns about health maintenance methods , the other sectors of society in need of help should not be left out .
Therefore , public spending on the aged should be limited so that other citizens of the country who are in need can also receive aid .
In conclusion , caring for the elderly is only right and necessary .
However , it should be within limits so that other parts of society would not be deprived of the help that is necessary for current support and future development .
Everyone is dependent on government aid to varying degrees .
A good balance must be struck to ensure that as few people as possible are deprived of government support due to poor distribution of state monies .

This essay will discuss   current political research and development that help to ease the aging process in the context of Singapore .
The aging process , which involves  physical , psychological and social changes among human beings , often brings about the deterioration of physical and mental health and loneliness .
These will increase the nation's health expenses and pension fund .
To a large extent , the aging process has been alleviated by  current social policies and implementation that emphasise individual responsibility , familial commitment and residual model policies- often known as government intervention .
Government has placed policies that emphasise individual responsibility and which have been proven effective to ease the aging process .
Every working Singaporean with a minimal income of five hundred dollars will have to contribute to the Central Provident Fund (CPF) .
With this compulsory saving scheme , Singapore citizens will have to save up for three accounts , which are the Special Account , Medisave Account and Retirement Account (CPF , 2009) respectively serving different purposes .
These accounts are meant for medical expenses , investments , emergencies and retirement  to ensure that the citizens have sufficient money when they reach old age .
However , despite having these accounts , senior citizens may still face problems with paying their medical bills and daily expenses as these accounts are subjected to withdrawal limitations and high eligibility age barriers .
Therefore , it is vital that senior citizens have a healthy lifestyle and to be active in the workforce in order for them to be in good health and have the ability to self-provide .
The Singapore government has been actively educating  senior citizens about the importance of healthy living and  community activities and campaigns .
For instance , the Health Promotion Board has introduced healthy aging programs and formed  interest groups like Tai Chi and Karaoke Singing Clubs among the residents in the communities .
These activities promote physical and mental wellness for  senior citizens as well as enlarge their social circle by making friends  .
The Singapore government has devised plans and policies to develop a strong sense of familial commitment in order to ease the aging population burden of the state .
Evidently , these policies are deemed to work as statistics (Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports [MCYS] , 2005) have shown that the majority (76 .4%) of senior citizens live with their children (p . 10) and 44 .7% of  senior citizens depend on their chilchildren for financial support (p . 28) .
Policies include tax relief for taking care of elderly parents or grandparents taking care of grandchildren while both parents work , and public housing schemes like  grants to citizens to purchase flats in  areas where their parents live .
Indirectly , this will strengthen  family ties and allow the senior citizens to seek companionship with their children or grandchildren .
However , there are still cases whereby children refuse to support their parents though they are capable of doing so .
With the introduction of Tribunal for the Maintenance of Parents (Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports [MCYS] , 2009) , parents who are over 60  and incapable of supporting themselves can file petitions  to seek financial support from their children .
Nevertheless , the pillars of the future are further instilled with the importance of moral values such as filial piety through moral civics lessons in schools to highlight the importance of familial commitment .
Lastly , Residual Model policies are in place to ease the aging process as they act as the last straw of the social safety net when the elderly lack self-reliance or have no familial support , for instance , the Public Assistance Scheme whereby senior citizens are given cash grants and free treatment at polyclinics and government or restructured hospitals .
Another example is the Medical Endowment Fund (Ministry of Health [MOH] , 2007) , which is known as Medifund and Medifund Silver , whereby the elderly are given provision for medical funds due to not having a Medisave or Medishield Account ,  not having accumulated enough in these accounts , or having no immediate family member to pay their hospital bills .
This enables every senior citizen to  to receive medical attention when needed .
An argument against these assistance schemes is that these will increase the dependency of  senior citizens on the government as they know that  they will be provided if they are unable to pay for their medical bills .
However , government stresses that these policies do not entitle all citizens to share the same benefits through mean testing , whereby the individuals are assessed according to their financial situation and bill size .
Affordability  is now dictated by the government and the patient who is considered not qualified for the fund will end up paying more .
This will in turn highlight the importance of self-reliance .
The aging process is the process of becoming older .
More countries are facing  problems brought about by the aging process in the social as well as the economic aspects .
Over the years , the life expectancy of people increases due to factors such as better hygiene and improved healthcare .
Vaccination  prevented people from getting life-threatening diseases in the past , such as tuberculosis , which is no longer a big threat today .
Increased life expectancy coupled with decreasing birth rate as shown in some first world countries such as Japan , where the country's fertility rate was 1 .23 children per woman and 21% of the population 65 years old and older (Cardiosk , October 2008) , led to aging population .
Despite the perplexing issues arising in the process of aging , the government has put in much effort in developing policies and aiding in research to alleviate its negative impact on society .
With an aging population , less people are able to work and the development of the economy is likely to decline .
Faruqee and Men (2002) wrote that declining and aging population would cause the level of Global Domestic Product (GDP) to fall by twenty percent annually in the long run .
To increase the number of people in the workforce , countries such as Singapore encourage foreign talent to contribute to her economy .
The government also implemented "baby bonus" to encourage couples to procreate which would increase labour in the long run .
However , the Singapore government has increased the retirement age to 65 years old so that the elderly can continue to contribute to the economy .
Reuters (2007) reported that Singapore plans to raise the retirement age for citizens from 62 to 65 by year 2012 to account for the higher life expectancy of the population .
Despite increasing the retirement age to reduce the pressure on economic development , the children of the elderly might not be willing to let their parents continue working at such an old age .
Hence , Japan invented robots to replace the lack of manpower due to the aging population .
These robots can also play a role in taking care of the elderly in the ; for instance , the wheelchairs that operate using buttons can replace humans pushing them .
With technological advancement , pressure on economy can be eased .
Statistics (2008) Retrieved 15 September 2009 . httpand-statistics .html (International Osteoporosis Foundation)
The next problem that arises in the elderly is their reduced mobility .
The elderly are less flexible and their movement is limited especially when they are facing a stage in life when they are more susceptible to suffer from movement-restricting diseases like osteoporosis .
Bone density of people would reduce overtime as the body is unable to absorb calcium with old age .
On the other hand , improved healthcare has also cured or prevented some of these diseases from plaguing the elderly , allowing them to enjoy active lifestyles .
Statistics show that elderly still engage in exercises and the elderly who take part in tai chi are 47% less likely to fall down due to  increased balancing ability and confidence .
Moreover , this research also shows that exercises reduced hip fracture rate by 25% in postmenopausal women .
However , despite some elderly being more active than others , most elderly find it difficult to move about .
Therefore , the Housing Development Board (HDB) in Singapore has proposed to build lifts that stop at every storey in the Life Upgrading Programme .
In addition , more ramps and slopes are to be built to ensure the mobility of wheelchair-bound elderly and also the physically disabled .
Public transport is also becoming more wheelchair-friendly with similar upgrades over the years .
Most elderly live alone as their children move out after they have a family .
The psychological needs of these elderly are not met especially when the problems of old age are catching up with them and they need someone to share their thoughts with .
To solve this problem , the government proposed to build more community hospitals .
These community hospitals focus more on the psychological well-being of the elderly rather than the physical one when they are recovering from an illness .
However , the elderly might prefer to stay at their own home or recuperate under the care of their children .
The government supports this move by issuing tax relief for sandwiched families , giving priority to these children who are buying new flats within close proximity to their elderly parents and giving subsidy to singles who buy a resale flat to live with their parents .
These singles would get $20 ,000 grant , up from the $11 ,000 subsidy .

The rise of aging population has become a major issue in most parts of the world .
According to  United Nations statistics , by 2050 , one of every five people will be 60 years old and above and the total number of people who are 60 years old and above is projected to be around 2 billion .
It is a cause for concern , as  more elderly present in the society will affect our economic and social development significantly .
Therefore , in most parts of the world , governments are coming up with policies and sponsoring research to ease the aging proces .
The aging process can be eased by increasing birth rates , increasing workforce productivity and reducing the physical and psychological aspects of aging .
Currently , governments have helped to ease the aging process in terms of  economic  , social  technological developments .
Firstly , an aging population greatly threatens a country's economic development because with more elderly retiring ,  workforce productivity falls sharply .
Therefore , in most countries , governments have increased the retirement age in order to encourage the elderly to continue working to increase productivity .
In Finland , which has the most rapidly aging population in Europe , has successfully raised the retirement age from 60 .1 to 60 .7 in 2004 , together with a pension reform introduced in 2005 to ease pressure on the state pension system (Kunz , 2007) .
Another method to increase the workforce productivity is to invite foreign talents and immigrants to stay and work in order to counter the low birth rate of a country .
For instance , one of the main factors for Spain's rising birth rates was due to a huge influx of immigrants from Latin America and North Africa (Spain-Demographic Trends) .
However , these policies may not be effective because  locals view foreign workers as a threat and may cause social unrest .
For instance , in Australia , there is a rise of hate crimes against  immigrants .
Even so , employers should hire their employees based on their capability and not nationality in order to avoid such crimes and through this policy , it will increase a country's competiveness , which will increase the country's workforce productivity and boost its economy .
Therefore , by increasing the retirement age and recruiting immigrants , we have partly eased the economic aspect of aging process .
Moreover , with current technology advancement , we can tackle the physical barriers of aging problems such as low birth rate , increased productivity and reduced physical effects of aging , which may partly relate to elderly low self-esteem .
With current technology , infertile couples can have a baby through In-Vitro Fertilization (IVF) .
In addition , in Japan , researchers and scientists have invented robots to replace older workers in order to increase the workforce .
With potent medicine , the aged are able to live longer and healthier .
Others may argue that the main cause of the aging problem is actually longer life span itself .
However , it does prove that current technological advancement is indeed effective in prolonging the population's life span .
With longer life span , people can continue to contribute to society by imparting their knowledge and skills to the next generation .
By doing so , the aged will be more appreciated by the public; it also does help to improve the country's economy with an increased workforce .
Therefore , having longer life span does help to ease the the aging process .
Hence , technological advancement does help to ease the economic , social and physical aspects of aging process .

Moreover , the elderly are not the only members of society so public spending on aged should be limited so that money can be spent on children .
Children are considered as the foundation of a country as they will grow up to be leaders in the future .
Therefore , government needs to pay more attention to children's welfare .
Children need good education  so that they can become well-versed and contribute to the country"s development .
In addition , public commitment to children has been threatened because of increased spending on the elderly .
According to an analysis done in the United States from 1980 to 2000 , the number of children living in poverty is almost three times  the number of elderly over the past twenty years (Organisation for Economic Co-operation Development , n . d .) .
Hence , diverting money to children should help to improve their quality of life .
Some critics argue that limiting  public spending on the aged will become a financial burden to low-income families .
Their low wages are only sufficient for household expenses and children"s school fees .
As prices are rising acutely , family members will face difficulties to support their elder parents .
However , low-income families can still obtain financial aid from government despite limitation to public spending on the aged .
Allowances and incentives are available for the needy .
Moreover ,  a tendency shows that elders themselves decide to have  longer working lives .
Although they already reach the retirement age , they still decide to continue working so they will be able to support themselves in their twilight years .
For example , Japanese usually continue working until 70 years old(OECD ,n .d .
) .They will continue to be financially secure , instead of starting to depend on their family .
In conclusion , limitation to public spending on the aged and diversion of money to other areas of development should be implemented .
Money diverted into the business domain will be able to stimulate economic growth .
In addition , children are at a disadvantage if too much money is spent on the elderly .
Despite limitation to public spending on the aged , the real needy will still be able to obtain financial aid .
The consequences resulting from an unlimited increase in public spending on the elderly will become a financial burden to a country in long run .

Singapore's life expectancy at birth for males is 78 .4; for females it is 83 .2 (SingStats , 2009) .
Total fertility rate per female is only 1 .28 .
These statistics explain why Singapore is no doubt one of the fastest aging populations in Asia .
The problems associated with the aging process can be categorized into five aspects , namely economic decline , mental agility , health , emotional and social problem .
Among all , economic and social policies  are widely discussed in  society .
Although it is impossible to increase the fertility rate in the short run , the problems of aging process are still alleviated by research and effective development and policies .
On the economic aspect , an aging population leads to shrinking workforce , low productivity and slow economic growth .
The annual inflation rate of Singapore has been increasing from 2 .1 to 6 .5 from 2007 to 2008 (SingStat , 2009) .
The old age dependency ratio last year was 11 .9 (SingStats , 2009) which shows that 11 .9 working persons would support one elderly .
Together with the problem of low fertility rate , government encourages Singaporeans to work longer to earn more for the future .
In order to encourage late retirement , the Singapore retirement age has been increased from 60 to 62 .
The the CPF contribution rate for employers has been increased by 1 .5 percentage points in 2007 in order for citizens to better prepare for the aging problem .
However , for older workers , CPF contribution by both employers and employees has also been reduced in order to help the workers remain competitive and increase their take-home salary (Channel NewsAsia , 2007) .
Research on how to cater for elderly needs on public facilities has also come into action .
There are ramps for people using wheelchairs; in most of the buildings , toilets and buses are specially designed to accommodate the elderly and the handicapped .
The Singapore social service sector has been taking care of the elderly with current housing , healthcare and job support policies .
HDB encourages children live in close proximity with their parents so that children can take care of parents during emergency .
Under the Single Singapore Citizen Scheme in 2008 , single Singaporeans aged 35 and above are able to apply for higher CPF grant of $20 ,000 if they want to purchase HDB resale flats to live with their parents (Channel NewsAsia , 2008) .
Moreover , upgrading of housing lifts on every floor would make elderly life easier .
The Healthcare 3Ms , Medicare , MediShield and Medifund also provide subsidies for the elderly .
In order to benefit those who need help more , subsidy for hospitalization in public hospitals has been adjusted so that 60 percent of workers are able to enjoy full subsidy for type C and B2 wards whereas those have higher earning power will receive substantial subsidies for both C and B2 class wards (Khalik , 2008) .
NTUC , WDA and employers have worked on the Job Re-creation Programme (JRP) to recreate and redesign jobs targeting older workers and providing training opportunities for them to take up new job openings .
Besides , SPUR focuses on retraining for older workers whereas ADVANTAGE !
encourages businesses to employ older workers .
Opponents of this position will argue that healthcare cost is still the main problem for the aging population .
A Medisave account may not be sufficient for many Singaporeans once they need to pay the medical bills for their parents , spouses and children .
Although most of the Singaporeans  not only pay for their own medical bills , there are other subsidy schemes which may lessen their financial burden .
Eldershield is designed for elderly who need long-term care or cannot afford the expenses on severe disability .
The elderly will receive monthly cash payout ,  therefore their children's Medisave account can be used to pay for their own bill .
Other than that , the Interim Disability Assistance Programme for the Elderly (IDAPE) and Primary Care Partnership (PCPS) are other subsidy schemes available .
To summarize , government encourages later retirement in order to reduce elderly dependency and implement social policies such as subsidy on housing medical fees .
At the same time , more and more facilities are designed to meet the needs of the elderly and the disabled .
Therefore , current research and policies are able to cater to most of the needs of Singaporeans to prepare for old age .
Also , individuaindividuals have to keep fit to reduce the probability of getting ill in order to avoid expensive medical bills during older age .
