The world is still recovering from the aftermath of the recent market crash .
Many economies have dipped into recession , job losses are prevalent and many countries are experiencing social instability .
Fortunately , with the introduction of multimillion rescue packages , the situation seems to be hopeful .
Slowly and steadily , the world's economy will pick up again .
However , the world must address yet another dire issue:  an ageing population .
According to the United Nation's prediction , by 2050 , 22% of the world's population of 9 billion will be over 60 (The Economist , 2009) .
Such statistics are indeed worrying .
The world will experience slow growth , shrinking labour and rising public spending .
Such cost even micrifies the impact of the recent financial crisis .
As stated in the Economist , the current crisis makes up about 10% of the future ageing-related costs (The Economist , 2009) .
However , leaders of the world have stepped up measures to combat this unforgiving phenomenon .
Ongoing research and implementation are initiated to allow the world to accept such emergence comfortably .
Reducing elderly dependency is one way in which governments can tackle the worrying phenomenon of a greying population .
One possible strategy is to enhance the opportunity of elderly employment .
In the past , the elderly were often labelled as slow and inefficient .
However in recent times , such stereotypes have been shelved away as the younger generations learn to embrace the wealth of experience , the elderly share , thus increasing the likelihood for elder employment .
In Singapore , the ADVANTAGE !
Scheme (Ministry of Manpower , 2007) is an initiation to help employers financially in hiring and retaining older workers .
This will open up more opportunities for the elderly to support themselves without burdening the tax-payers .
It also increases the labour force and tax revenue .
Therefore the elderly should not be deprived of employment by providing more incentives for employers to attract such workers and help for those seeking employment opportunities .
As such , the exchange of experience and skills will only benefit the workforce and hence reduce the effects of a greying population .
Another problem which the older generation may face is social discrimination .
Mental and physical health will inevitably deteriorate as one ages .
Such liability will only discourage the older ones and thus create an invisible segregation between the strong and the weak .
Thankfully in Singapore , such issues have been ironed out and certain measures have been carefully implemented .
Under the Main Upgrading Project (MUP) , grab-bars in the bathroom and non-slip floor tiles have been installed in upgraded sold flats .
Recently , recreational facilities such as exercise corners and elder-care centres have also been built in the neighbourhood to provide social interaction opportunities among the community .
Also , the Housing Development Board (HDB) has introduced Married Child Priority Scheme (MCPS) to grant privileges to married children to live near or together with their parents .
These policies would greatly foster ties and improve communication between the young and old , in hope to eliminate the social discrimination and bolster the well being of the elderly .
On the contrary , as much as solutions are sought to reduce the effects of an ageing population , the rate of replacing the world's population is not desirable .
According to the Economist , the fertility rate in member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development fell sharply from an average of 3 .2 children per female in 1960 to 1 .6 in 2009 , which is below the recommended replacement level of 2 .1 (The Economist , 2009) .
Women now are more career-proactive and hence delay marriages and family formations .
Additionally , the number of children in a family has been limited to two due to individual family's preference and financial ability .
However , there are many ways in which governments can compensate for the falling birth rate .
Longer paid maternity leave , more childcare leave and greater incentives for working mothers are some possible corrections to the problem .
In France , such policies were implemented and were rewarded with a near replacement fertility rate (The Economist , 2009) .
Although this may increase the government's expenditure , it is a necessary investment for a better future of the country .
For many decades , the world has been taking a lot of beating .
From the economic crisis in 1997 to uncontrolled viral spread such as H1N1 pandemic in 2008 , the world survived all these obstacles .
The repercussions of an ageing population are tirelessly being subdued by various helpful and effective solutions .
These are proved successful in certain countries but with a necessary cost .
Results may seem moderate and unprogressive .
Nonetheless , with much support in place , the future of the world may not be as bleak as before .
Aging is a difficult process as the elderly are more inclined to get sick because of a lower immune system so having to recuperate longer would be financially draining .
They also face difficulties in finding and retaining jobs .
Under the seniority based-wage system , it is more expensive to hire older workers; and  the perception that older workers are inefficient resulted in low employment rate among the elderly (Lee , 2009 , para .
6) .
However , policies on the aged in Singapore have significantly heled to reduce the problems they face .
In recent years , the Ministry of Manpower has been working closely with its tripartite partners to enhance the employability of  older workers (as cited in NTUC , 2007) .
One of the schemes that were developed was the 'Advantage !
Scheme' .
In this scheme , companies are given a grant up to $400 ,000 to encourage them to retain its mature workers .
Coming in 2012 , the government will enact the re-employment legislation to enable the elderly to work beyond the retirement age of 62 (as cited in Re-Employment of Older Workers Portal , 2008) .
This is preferred than increasing the retirement age because a higher retirement age might cause older workers to be less employable as they are no longer cost competitive which may result in them being laid off even before they are 62 (cited in MOM , 2008) .
With re-employment , employers can provide jobs to their mature workers and also offer them a different job position with different salary and terms .
Here , both employer and employees can negotiate the terms and companies can remain competitive by adjusting the wages and benefits according to the value of the job .
In terms of healthcare , the government has come out with a few financial assistance schemes to ensure that the citizens are able to afford healthcare and are prepared during their old age .
Other than the basic healthcare financing schemes like Medisave , Medishield and Medifund , the government has come out with another scheme called 'Elder Scheme' .
This is an insurance scheme where those eligible pay premiums and they can claim benefits at any age of their life and receive monthly cash payout up to 72 months .
This would help support them should one day they stop working (as cited in MOH , 2007) .
Other than financial schemes , the government also provides subsidies for patients who require intermediate and long term care .
The subsidies given could be as much as 75% of the total bills depending on the family income and it is extended to community hospitals (as cited in MOH , 2007) .
This is beneficial as sick elderly require long term care and they might choose to recuperate at community hospitals .
However , even with all of these policies and subsidies , there is no guarantee that the elderly are able to pay for all of their living expenses .
Even though they have worked for many years , they might have little or no savings because they might not know how to manage their money .
It is essential that they learn how to not only manage their wealth but also expand it so that when they choose to stop working , they would have enough money to pay for their necessities and have enough for any unexpected expenses .
To ensure that its citizen will be financially prepared when they reach their retirement age , the Central Provident Fund Board (CPF) has came out with a learning portal called 'Retirement Ready @ my cpf' to help citizens to plan for their retirement (as cited in CPF , 2009) .
Here they show a step-by-step process on how to achieve the desired retirement lifestyle a person wants .
They teach from how to do basic budgeting to doing investments .
This is one of many ways to ensure that Singapore citizens will live a better life when they get older .
Clearly the government and its related agencies have been working hard to help ease the aging process through many of its policies .
Through these , the elderly not only will be able to continue working; they also need not worry much about their health expenses .
These policies along with early retirement planning would help to ensure that the elderly will be economically independent and lead a better life .
Singapore is facing a shift in the distribution of the population towards older ages , where the median age of population  increase , as well as a decline in fertility rates , resulting in a rise in the number of elderly in Singapore .
Aging impacts a person's well being in many ways , with both psychological and physical changes , including chronic diseases associated with it .
The labour age composition has thus shifted towards the older workers , where implications towards the competitiveness of Singapore's economy will occur , especially if older workers do not make significant contributions to the productivity growth in the economy (Thangavelu , Yong , 2006) .
Hence , more support and care for the aged should be provided which in turn will pose a strain to the younger generation .
As of 2008 , '8 .4 economically active persons are supporting one elderly' (Singstats , 2008) and 'by 2030 , only 3 .5 persons will be supporting one elderly' (CPF , 2008) .
This has reflected the importance for individuals to have the ability to support themselves through their golden years .
In order to do so , Singapore has introduced policies that worked to ease the aging process .
Facing high cost of living , Singapore has moved up from the 13th position in 2008 to the 10th in 2009 , in the worldwide cost of living ranking (Mercer , 2009) , especially for the medical cost , where each household spends an increasing amount of expenditure in health care , with 3 .3% in 1998 to 5 .1% in 2003 (Singstats , 2007) , and is expected to further increase in the future  , with more aged citizens in Singapore .
Hence , Singapore has introduced policies to ease healthcare financing , such as Medisave , Medishield , Medifund , and Eldershield (MOH , 2007) .
Singaporeans have recognized the need to prepare for aging in terms of escalating medical costs , thus net withdrawal from Medisave scheme , including Eldershield , has dropped to 213 .6 million in 2009 , and 62 .5 million from the Medishield scheme (CPF , 2009) .
A drop in withdrawal of healthcare schemes has thus reflected that more Singaporeans have felt the need for such policies .
Singapore has not only faced an aging population resulting from low fertility rates , but also longer life expectancy for individuals .
With rising life expectancy , given only a 2 .5%  annual interest in the Central Provident Fund (CPF) , and with most funds in the CPF used to fund housing or tertiary education , the CPF figure left is no longer sufficient to last through retirement (OCBC , 2005) .
"The best way for people to adjust to longer life spans is to continue working for as long as they can" (PM Lee , 2009) , as working provides a source of income; more savings can thus be built up .
Increasing the retirement age is insufficient to encourage individuals to work longer , hence the Re-employment policy will be enacted in 2012 .
In order to ensure that older workers are not at a  disadvantage , Singapore established schemes such as smaller CPF contributions to the aged (CPF , 2009) , as well as the Advantage !
Scheme introduced in 2005 (MCYS , 2009) to lighten the cost of hiring the aged as well as to move away from the seniority-wage system and provide assistance in funding to re-employ mature workers .
And as of 2005 , 1 ,142 companies have benefited from this scheme .
In addition , retraining programmes were also introduced; an example would be 'Skills Programme for Upgrading and Resilience (SPUR)' (MCYS , 2009) .
Through amelioration and subsidizing of healthcare and public facilities the process of aging population has been eased .
Through amelioration and subsidizing of healthcare and public facilities ,  the problem of aging population has been eased .
Over the last 5 years , Singapore government health expenditure for  citizens has increased from $1 .53 billion in year 2002 , to $1 .93 billion in year 2006 which is an average growth rate of 6% per annum (as cited in Ministry of Health , 2007) .
Through the increment on healthcare expenditure , we can see that the government is bringing in better technologies and focusing on  Singaporeans' health .
With advanced healthcare facilities , preventing or curing  diseases has been made possible .
One of the most common diseases associated with  old age is  Senile Dementia , where the patient encounters mental deterioration (loss of intellectual ability) .
Two major types of senile dementia are Alzheimer type and those due to vascular problems .
Studies show that of  people over 80 , 20% suffer from Alzheimer's disease (as cited in health-cares .net , 2005) .
Researchers have come up with several ways to improve and slow down the deterioration of elderly brain .
For instance ,  researchers have invented medications such as tacrine and donepezil which are used by patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease (as cited in health-cares .net , 2005) .
Researchers not only focus on inventing new medications , they also hope to protect people against mental decline through aerobic exercises and getting a dose of the sun - vitamin D (as cited in health-cares .net , 2005) .
In Singapore , having one of the fastest aging populations in the world , with an estimated 23% of the population to be over 65-year-old by the year 2030 , there is a need for more hospitals to be built to meet the needs of the aging population (as cited in Singapore faces 'silver tsunami' , 2009) .
Hence , Jurong General Hospital which will open in five years and Khoo Teck Puat Hospital which will open next year will be linked to a community hospital next door .
This is to ensure that older people will have the right health care treatment at the right place and in return help them to cut costs (as cited in The Straits Times , 2009) .
It is understandable that older people often require more medical care , but they need not remain in the hospital for this care .
Thus , it would be much cheaper for them to get such care from a community hospital - hence the idea of "stepping down" the care is needed .
Public transportation systems must continue to expand in order to deal with an aging population .
In June 2006 , Singapore Bus Services (SBS) Transit launched Singapore's First Ever Wheelchair accessible buses - Service 21 (as cited in SBS transit , 2006) .
Similarly , another public transport operator Singapore Mass Rapid Transit (SMRT) came up with its first wheelchair-friendly buses on June 2009 (as cited in Wheelchair-friendly bus , 2009) .
With these buses , the elderly and wheelchair bounded commuters could travel conveniently to hospitals and polyclinics for their medical appointments .
Even with government funding , not every Singaporean is able to luxuriate in the use of better healthcare and public facilities .
Even with government subsidies and paying  their CPF they might still find it difficult to handle hefty medical bills .
Hence , even a small family with a monthly income of $10 ,000 might also find it difficult to cope with a big hospital bill , if it has to support one or two elderly people with a chronic illness (as cited in The Straits Times , 2004) .
Hence , policies such as senior citizens' bonus  where lower-income elderly aged 55 and above with an annual income of $100 ,000 or less will receive $200 to $1000 over a period of 4 years (as cited in GST Offset Package , 2009) to lighten the burden of lower income families .
There is no need to worry as statistics shows that direct subsidies to patients have increased from $850 million in 2001 to $1 .6 billion in 2007 and it is projected to increase to $2 .2 billion in 2012 (as cited in Ministry of Health , 2009) .
In conclusion , amelioration and subsidizing of healthcare and public facilities has eased the problem of aging population .
Therefore , maintaining a healthy lifestyle , saving up for the future and contributing monthly to their CPF account assist citizens to prepare them for better retirement and lower their economic burden .
One in The Agingresidents in Singapore will be 65 and above by the year 2030 (Yap , 2009) .
Singapore society's aging process brings on numerous set of challenges for the government .
The effects of aging process in Singapore are as follows .
First , economic decline would occur as the size of the working force shrinks .
Second , decline in the citizen's health due to weaker immunity system and age related illness .
Third , social problems brought on by the living environment .
Fourth , emotional problems caused by the different mindsets of the young and old generations and connections to family and society .
Last , the decrease in mental agility affecting active aging .
Therefore , the government has embarked on reforming its older policies and implementing new ones to cater to and prepare for the trend of population aging in Singapore .
Critics might argue that the government iwillucing policies encouraging eeconomic and social problems because of the problem of agingworkers does not mean compaif onesn Siysgapore would follow suit .
Also , not all the workers would benefit from the policies mentioned above .
However , in evident of the above policies , Singapore was the only Asian country which won the AARP International Innovative Employer Award (Yap , 2009) .
The award is given to companies in countries for showing innovative Human Resouritsactices that deal with matters related to the workforce , age 50 and older (Yapy , 2009) .
Also by the end of 2008 , 700 unionised companies have already committed to re-employ close to 5 ,000 workers above the age of 62 (Yap , 2009) .
The statistics show that the reemployment is a useful tool and the government's policies have had a positive impact on the companies .
Furthermore , workers can refresh or upgrade their skills from more than 800 SPUR rses (Yap , 2009) .
This benefit is not limited only to employthe Sd workers but unemployed workers also can turn SPUR to sharpen their skills while they search for jobs .
Moving on , Singapore wants for its seniors , even the less mobile to have a safe and accessible environment .
As such , a Barrier Free Accessibility Masterplan was executed (Yap , 2009) .
The plan is for all our public housing estates to be barrier-free by 2011 (Yap , 2009) .
Also by 2as4 , eligibfrom HDB blocks would have lift access to all floors .
In the past , there was no exact emphasis on structure for all ages .
However , since July 2006 , HDB's new public housing projects are built are all people (Yap , 2009) .
For example , switches and sockets low enough to be accessiedle from a wheelchair and toilets being wide enough and having hand rails .
Moreder , our government is not only building barrier-free estates but also concentrating on public turn tosportation .
By 0 , pedestrian walkways , public roads , taxi and bus shelters and access to MRT stations woule barrier-free , using a $60 million programme started by the government (Yap , 2009) .
We can also observe that wheelchair-accessible buses are progressing gradually .
Thus , Singapore's environment and transportation services for its citizens are transforming in line with the changing needs of Singapore society .
withtoilets have been madeOur government's constant review of the policies , setting up ofe ,many specified committees to head particular goals in relation to changing times , and counter measures to external and internal factors have been impressive .
It has also gained recognition in local and abroad .
In conclusion , our current policies clearly have helped to ease the aging process in Singapore .
It has enabled our society to be better prepared for the aging trend in Singapore .
When Singapore's Ministry of Finance unveiled the government budget for 2009 , it was stated that an estimated total of S$66 million or 0 .15% of the total government expenditure will be spent on establishing various programs and upgrading facilities for the elderly (Singapore Budget 2009 , 2009) .
As the problem of aging population intensifies throughout the years , there will always be a debate on how much of  public spending should be allocated to the aged .
While it is important to provide funds for implementing policies to support the elderly , it is plausible for the government to work on areas which can aid both the country's development as well as provide support towards the aged .
Firstly , it is vital to develop the country's economy .
A sustained economic growth improves the level of business activities , ensures a low unemployment rate and increases government tax revenues .
More funds are thus available to finance additional projects for the needy including the aged .
Also , more people will become self-sufficient and therefore able to support themselves , even without government aid .
Hence , more funds can be directed to other economic development areas (Friedland and Summer , March 2005) .
Contrarily , with slower growth , more people will be unemployed and more money would have to be spent on unemployment benefits .
This will inevitably constrict  public spending on the aged due to a smaller pool of resources .
Secondly , the funding spent on the education sector cannot be compromised .
Cheney (2007) wrote that children are the pillars of the nation .
This means that the country's progression will depend on the next generation .
If the young are not well educated , there may be social implications such as increasing crime rates and unemployment .
In a research done by Shirley (2007) , crime rate and education have an inverse relationship .
This is due to the increased opportunity costs involved with a higher education level .
Adversely , there is a positive relationship between higher education and employment opportunities (Harvey , 2000) .
This is because employers tend to link working abilities with academic qualifications .
Hence , reduction in education expenditure will put the country's progress at risk .
Critics may argue that even if the country is performing well economically , she may not be progressing socially if she fails to address the people's needs , especially the elderly's .
This is because the elderly have once contributed to the country's economy and their well-being should not be overlooked when they age and are unable to work .
Thus , it is justifiable that the society should give in return and support the old members of the workforce , on the account of their past contributions to the nation .
Furthermore , aging is a natural process and everyone will grow old one day .
When the time comes , it is man's instinct to hope that more efforts will be invested to help him .
Therefore , it is pertinent that the government does not overlook their needs .
However , it is essential to regulate the amount spent on assisting the aged .
Some fear that with government aid , some may in turn become over-reliant and fail to be self-sufficient .
Therefore , it would be better for the government to offer the basic infrastructure and introduce policies to help the aged gain independence while receiving necessary help .
For example , one feasible policy is to encourage companies to provide extra training for the older workers to stay in touch with advanced technology , thus increasing their working lifespan disregarding health factors .
Not only will the elderly become more financially able , they will also attain a sense of belonging in the society and purpose in their lives .
Concurrently , the government can invest in other sectors , such as the research and development sector , which will indirectly aid the aged .
For instance , public facilities , such as buses , are being upgraded and improved to facilitate easier movement for the elderly and handicapped .
Also , there is ongoing medical research on senile dementia and Parkinson's disease .
All these will improve the lives of the elderly significantly .
In conclusion , public spending for the aged is a necessity but should be regulated .
In order to strike a balance and better maintain the state of the economy , the government has to prioritize the country's needs and analyze the current problems the country is facing .
Resources are always limited , thus the government has to allocate them cautiously for the continuous development of the nation .
Aging is an ongoing process .
Everybody will grow old and is bound to experience the effects of it at one point in his or her life .
Although we cannot escape from it , we can certainly make the process a less painful one to go through .
Indeed , current research and development/policies have greatly contributed in easing the aging process .
Research and development (R&D) is essential to help improve the lives of an ageing population .
Only through research and development will we be able to gain knowledge on the issues circling them and come up with ways to overcome it , for example , the development of humanoid robots in Japan which promises to free us from physical labor and help us with our household chores such as folding laundry , doing the dishes , cooking , etc .
(Adams , 2004) .
This will therefore ease the burden of people from all these time-consuming chores .
In addition to this , there is also development on robots serving as companions .
A robotic companion could add a lot of fun and excitement to the life of a lonely retiree especially .
Another R&D policy that has played a role in easing the aging process includes buses that are elderly- and handicapped-friendly .
An example would be the new SBS Transit single-deck buses that are capable in accommodating two wheelchair-bound passengers at any one time .
These new buses are also "low floor" and  for the elderly and handicapped (SBS Transit , 2007) .
Thus , by coming up with new technologies , research and development do help in easing the aging process .
Apart from research and development , policies with regard to ageing population have also helped to ease the ageing process .
These policies help the elderly to age with grace and dignity .
For example , HDB has been actively implementing various policies and improvement programs in making the elderly feel more comfortable .
One such program is the Lift Upgrading Program where the lifts will now land on every floor as compared to the past where not all public housing was provided with  access to lifts .
This does not only benefit the elderly , but the disabled as well as families with young children as well (Housing and Development Board , 2001) .
In addition to this program , HDB has also come up with a policy which encourages children to live in close proximity to their parents .
This policy provides the children to buy resale flats with a housing subsidy of $40 ,000 higher-tier Family Grant under the CPF housing grant scheme .
For singles aged 35 years and above who wish to buy a resale flat , they will be provided with a housing subsidy of $20 ,000 higher-tier Singles Grant under the scheme (Housing and Development Board , 2009) .
These policies all have the common intention of promoting the value of an extended family staying together for mutual care and support which will in turn ease the aging process of the elderly .
Research and development/policies are not the only ways in easing the aging process though .
Palliative care is now getting the recognition it deserves together with professional training and more funding .
On top of relieving a patient's pain , palliative care also lightens the emotional burden of the patient's caregiver too .
In light of the increased awareness and growing importance of palliative care , demand for it has increased .
For example , there has been a rise in the number of patient referrals to Dover Park Hospice from 680 in 2006 to 750 in 2008 ("Lifting Spirits" , 2009 , p . 13) .
By becoming more affordable , it helps to ease the financial burden of the patient and his or her family .
Although palliative care does not prolong life , it helps the ill to live meaningfully by helping to manage their pain and discomfort .
To conclude , research and development/policies have no doubt managed to ease the aging process but on top of that , palliative care also has a role to play in relieving suffering and improving the quality of life of people facing serious illnesses .
Singapore is one of the fastest ageing countries in the world .
In the year 2000 , Singapore has 7 .2% of its population aged 65 and above .
By 2030 , the ageing population in Singapore is predicted to increase to 18 .4% of the total population (as cited in Koh , 2002) .
This is a pressing issue which may lead to an economic decline as the workforce is affected .
The current research and development as well as the policies drawn are effective in alleviating the ageing process such as decline in health , economic downturn and  emotional problems of the elderly .
In this rat-raced world , everything seems to be progressing rapidly , leading to a higher standard of living .
Better medical facilities allow people to live longer but at the same time increase their cost of living as well .
As people age , their health starts to deteriorate and their savings will also decrease as the years pass .
They will not be able to afford the high medical costs and thus are unable to get proper treatment for their illness .
In this aspect , some critics argue that development in the medical field does not help address the ageing process .
However , one of the policies in Singapore includes healthcare subsidy for the elderly .
The Singapore government will provide up to 75% subsidy for the elderly provided that they are either Singapore citizens or permanent residents ; this also depends on the income of the family (Ministry of Health: Subsidies for elderly , 2007) .
This aid enables medical treatment to be more affordable .
Hence , the policy is able to ease the ageing process through care for the deteriorating health of the elderly .
Current research in the medical field is conducted to find out the causes and cures for common illnesses among the elderly such as senile dementia and Parkinson's disease .
One example is the Dementia Research Centre located at the National Hospital for Neurology and Neurosurgery in the United Kingdom .
It is the lead centre for finding new drugs to delay the onset of Alzheimer's disease (Dementia Research Centre , Queen Square , London , UK- about the DRC , 2008) .
When such research is successful , it will benefit humanity and better  medical treatments in the world .
This will decrease the suffering of the elderly , making them less susceptible to diseases  , thus helping to abate the ageing process .
There are a few measures taken by the Singapore government to ease the ageing process .
One of the measures taken is to encourage the elderly to undergo training and upgrading of their skills .
This will enable them to enter the workforce again and increase their retirement age .
The 'ADVANTAGE !
Scheme' was implemented in 2005; some companies such as  retail and logistics have adopted it to help them recruit and retain workers aged 62 and above (Ministry of Manpower , 2007) .
This will increase the retirement age of the elderly and thus improve the economy and workforce in an aging population .
Another policy is the 'Central Provident Fund (CPF) Housing Grant Scheme' which is a subsidy given by the government to encourage children to live in close proximity with their parents .
They will receive a  grant if they live in the same town , or 2 kilometers apart from each other if they are to stay in different towns (Housing Development Board , 2009) .
When the children live near their parents , there is a higher probability of them visiting their parents often , hence making it easier for them to take care of their parents .
Moreover , the family is able to provide emotional support for the elderly .
Hence , these development plans and policies will help to ease the ageing process of the elderly .
In conclusion ,  research conducted to discover more about the illnesses of the elderly and the policies implemented which provide subsidies as well as schemes to aid the elderly , will help to ameliorate the ageing process .
An ageing population will still be a problem in the future .
Hence , such developments and policies are vital to ease the ageing process .
Family might be a better solution to abate the process , as it is the main emotional and financial support for the elderly .
An elderly is an irreplaceable and valuable  asset that acts like glue which holds families together .
These valuable assets are deemed to increase in numbers globally .
Having one of the fastest aging populations in Asia (Chan , 2001) , Singapore faces a huge challenge in developing infrastructures and public policies in terms of healthcare , housing , re- training , transportation and financial aid to accommodate this changing age structure .
Despite the large expenses in the various aspects for the aged , these implementations would also benefit the younger generations in due course .
Hence , the government and society would have to do everything that is possible to support and prepare for the inevitable increase in the aging population even at the expense of the country's development in other areas .
Currently , the main concern for Singapore is the overwhelming baby boomers that are progressing into the senior status .
Nevertheless , the government should prioritize its spending and not neglect this aging population .
Reports have shown that (Cire , 2009) in mid 2008 , an estimated 506 million population worldwide are above 65 years old .
However , this figure will reach 1 .3 billion by 2040 .
In the context of Singapore , the aged above 65-years old are projected to represent 23% of the population by 2030 and this would be the second highest percentage in Asia after Japan (Wijaya , 2009) .
The repercussions following the aging population would be social and economic concerns as the younger generations would have to struggle to support their families .
Moreover , with less working population , Singapore's economy would be greatly affected .
Therefore ,  society should be aware of its situation and address  this problem before it becomes a severe issue for the country .

Subsequently , public spending on the different policies and infrastructures would benefit  society and support the economy in the long run .
The different policies include financial aspects like the reinforcement of individual savings through the mandatory Central Provident Fund which helps the population save for old age (Central Provident Fund Board , 2009) .
This would ease the burden on the younger generations having to support the aged .
In relation to healthcare , Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated in his National Day Rally Speech (Channel News Asia , 2009)  the development of step-down care and the strengthening of 3Ms (Medisave , Medishield and Medifund) .
The step-down care involves the government's support to the voluntary welfare organizations (VWOs) and linking community hospitals , nursing homes , general practitioners and home care together to cater to the aging population .
These policies would eventually apply to all individuals as aging is part of the human cycle .
Furthermore , it was recently announced that the government will be spending millions to encourage more people to upgrade or learn new skills by building training centres and providing training programmes (Channel News Asia , 2009) .
The government will also introduce  legislation in re-employment by 2012 (Ministry of Manpower , 2008) whereby the older workers will be able to remain active in the workforce for a longer period and save more money for their retirement .
Thus , public spending in these three important aspects of finance , healthcare and employment would be beneficial to everyone .
All in all , it is important that the government addresses  the needs and issues of the aging population .
More public spending on the aged is critical as this expenditure on implementation of policies or infrastructures would be an advantage to all .
Finally , this would also ease the impact of an aging population on the economy and society to the minimum .

With a paradigm shift in many countries towards a greying population , many governments are confronted with the responsibility of implementing policies that assist the ageing process .
The elderly often face emotional , mental and physical problems and if these issues are not addressed , there will be economic and social implications for the country .
Different countries respond to this problem differently and the ease with which the elderly are living their lives is evidence of the creative policies that many governments have introduced to benefit them .
As with countries face the daunting task of ensuring that the needs of their elderly population are met , Singapore is not spared .
The government estimates that by the year 2030 , 23% of its population will be over the age of 65 (Wijaya , 2009) .
Among the various policies introduced to allow the elderly to have an easier time aging include housing , employability and healthcare which will help to ease their ageing process .
Enhancing the employability of elderly workers by improving skills and retraining elder workers ensures that they have the relevant skills to take on different jobs should the need arise .
The government has also encouraged employers to be more welcoming in employing the elderly .
One such example is the Tripartite Committee which introduced the ADVANTAGE !
scheme in 2005 (Minister Gan Kim Yong , Acting  ,Minister for Manpower , 2009) .
This scheme was introduced to support companies to recruit and retain older workers as well as to re-employ them beyond age of 62 .
This ensures that companies are willing to review their work process to cater to older workers .
By introducing such policies , the government ensures that the elderly do not have to be afraid that they might face difficulties at work with rising competition from the younger generations .
Housing has always been a key issue for elderly during their years of retirement .
The government thus introduced the Lease Buy Back scheme in 2009 .
Through Singapore's successful CPF scheme , many elderly have been able to become flat owners .
They may be asset-rich but many are cash poor .
Therefore the government introduced the Lease Buy Back Scheme this year to ease cash flow .
This scheme allows the government to buy back the HDB flats of the elderly by first giving them a lump sum payment of $5000 and a monthly income for the rest of their lives (Chen , 2009) .
This eases the burden of the old as they are ensured they receive money every month .
As with old age , there is always a possibility of illness .
Therefore the government has introduced holistic affordable healthcare and eldercare .
Singapore's government introduced Singapore workforce skills qualification (WSQ) to train more than 900 therapy assistants and patient service assistant over the next three years (Minister Gan Kim Yong , Acting Minister for Manpower , 2009) .
These training programmes ensure that the elderly are properly cared for with upmost professionalism and efficiency to make certain that they do not face any obstacles .
Furthermore when the elderly are in good care of such trained professionals , families do not have to burden themselves with worry the of whether the safety and wellbeing of their elderly is being taken care of .
As much as government policies have been beneficial to the elderly , critics may state that by increasing the age when elderly can withdraw their CPF , the government is taking away a good few years away from the elderly which can be spent either relaxing , holidaying or purchasing something they have yearned for .
While this may be true , it is essential to remember that these retirement funds are meant to last the elderly till the end of their lives .
The earlier they receive the funds , the more the likelihood the funds may be depleted well before their actual intended duration of use .
Thus the intention of the government to increase the CPF withdrawal age has proved to be a wise decision .
In conclusion , it is of upmost importance that the government keeps coming up with new and improved policies to ensure that our elderly stay active for as long as possible and are able to fruitfully enjoy their old age .
It is only through policies such as these that the elderly will ensure that our future generations do not have to fear the process of ageing as they are certain that with continuous implementation of such policies , growing old would be a graceful process .
Singapore: The fact that the majority of the elderly is reliant on their children for financial support still remains .
In 2005 , it was 31 .9% among those aged 55 to 64 , 55 .8% for those aged 65 to 74 and 63 .7% for those aged 75 years and above .
Shockingly , the age-support ratio has declined from 10 .4 in 1998 to 8 .4 in 2008 , resulting in a situation in which the current caregiver generation has fewer or no siblings with whom to share the burden .
Furthermore , the percentage of elderly persons aged 65 and above has increased from 6 .8% in 1998 to 8 .7% in 2008 .
Thus , the government has to critically consider these worrying demographic changes and allocate a satisfactory portion of the national budget to lighten the burden of the caregiver generation .
The first approach to reduce elder dependency is to ease barriers to elder employment and encourage the elderly to work longer and retire later (Peterson , 2001) .
According to a national survey conducted in 2005 , more than half (65 .9%) of the elderly population aged 55 and above were economically inactive .
The main reasons included retirement and a drop in their fitness and agility levels .
It was reported that the government will be raising the current retirement age of 62 to 65 by 2012 and ultimately to 67 and has also made amendments to the Retirement Age Act which increases the employability of elderly workers .
By working longer and saving more , the elderly can build up their retirement nest egg much faster than before .

Secondly , couples are encouraged to settle down early and set up families , hence , expanding the economy's size and tax base .
Meanwhile , the cost burden of providing for the elderly can be spread over a larger future generation .
(Peterson , 2001) However , the first barrier of starting a family among Singaporeans is the immense costs associated .
The housing policy alone affects the young couples' choices .
During the process of house-hunting , the initial excitement to starting a family among couples might to fade .
Bigger families require bigger homes at steep prices which force couples to reconsider  the decision to have more children .
Is it possible for a couple to purchase a spacious and comfortable place at an affordable price for a family of five ?
To make matters worse , if the retirement costs and providing for aged parents are added into the equation , having children will be the last thing on the couples' minds .
Last but not least , the strategy of emphasizing filial obligation and increasing the willingness of grown children (Peterson , 2001) is not an easy feat .
It is heartening to read that almost fourth-fifths of the elderly (76 .4% in 2005) live with their children .
However , the children are not always the party at fault .
In fact , there are some parents who do not welcome the prospect of having unmarried children in their 30s living with them as they have the perception that living with more people under the same roof requires some sacrifice of personal space and freedom .
The truth lies in the fact that singles below the age of 35 are not eligible to purchase resale flats and are not able to move out of "Hotel Mama" , their parents' flat .
In any case , humans tend to be self-centred and less obliged to give of their time beyond personal pursuits .
In any event when the government cuts down or eliminates welfare benefits due to rising elderly-related expenditure , it ought to bear in mind the net effects of such actions (Friedland and Summer , 2005) .
It is obvious that the daily lives of the families will be adversely affected and the living standards will deteriorate , particularly the low-income families .
Consequently , there will be a surge in family and social problems .
The children may isolate the fragile elderly , leading to higher suicide rates and psychological problems .
Bringing the issue closer to the government ,  by the citizens will plummet and they would rather render their support for opposition parties .
In essence , while the education and defence still remains as the government's priority , it does not simply mean that expenditure for elderly welfare can be diverted to other areas .

Robert B . Friedland and Laura Summer (2005) , Doomsday Predications about Population Aging Are Exaggerated
