Nowadays , the ills of old age" is no longer a topic that "only poets and philosophers" would be interested  in .
"Governments and policy makers are now confronted with the unprecedented problem of a fast an aging population ," claims Peter G . Peterson , (2001 , p66) .
Although problems related to aging population have become increasingly severe , with more  priority , governments should limit its spending on the aging population .
This is because of three reasons: an increasing spending in dealing with problems with regard to aging population would probably affect other objectives with higher priority; the  cannot solve the "ills of old age" alone; and the cost of unlimited spending on aging population cannot justify the benefits in the long run .
Secondly , the answer to the problem with regard to an an aging population should be the cooperation between the elders themselves and the government , not simply by a given priority in terms of unlimited government spending .
For example , the government could help in training elders and engaging them with more jobs .
A new welfare law with higher retirement ages could also be passed so that the elders would have more time to accumulate wealth in preparing for the future .
By doing so , government spending on aging population could be effectively reduced .
With larger part of welfare supported by elders themselves , more elder citizens would have access to limited government budget .
With a relatively higher income and a broader base of beneficiaries from the government financial support , the average elder citizen should be able to enjoy a better living quality .
Meanwhile , governments could invest more money in economic development , which is the governments' first priority , and generate more revenue to support the aging population in the future though a larger scale of economy instead of an unlimited percentage increase in government spending .
Last but not least , with an increasing aging population , the cost of easing aging-society problems through larger government spending cannot justify the benefits in the long run .
A government's first priority should be the economic development and the overall improvement of the citizens' life quality .
These goals cannot be achieved with most of the budget transferred to take care of the elders in the short run .
Thus , governments should deal with objectives with first priority and limit the budget for aging population .
In conclusion , it is clear that the problems generated by an aging population cannot be ignored .
However , government should limit the spending on aging population and take care of the objectives with higher priority first .
This is because , due to the limited budget , in order to make the cost justify the benefit for the whole society in the long run , governments have to ensure a growing economy through continuously invest in infrastructure and advance technology with most of its budget .
The problem with regard to aging population would eventually be eased through more financial support generated from a larger scale of economy instead of increasing the percentage cost of the budget and participation of the elders themselves .
''It is well known that our society is aging .
Media stories and political rhetoric abound concerning the impending demographic challenges as the population aged 65 and older is anticipated to more than double by the year 2030 ,'' (Friedland and Summer , 2005) .
An increase in the population of the aging group implies there will be more government spending on the  aged .
If the population of the aging group is still expanding , the national budget will soon be drained  by supporting the  aged group with welfare treatment .
The nation will be affected if this practice continues   .Therefore , the government should amend the policy by limiting public spending on the aged so that the money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development which will benefit the nation .
In my opinion , limited public spending on the aged enables the government to divert the money to other areas for the country's development  .
Money could be diverted to develop agriculture , medical and healthcare services , welfare program and others .
For example , the money can be used to support research such as research on hybrid seeds plant .
This will promote economic growth and increase the national income as introduction of hybrid seeds plant can increase the productivity of the crops .
There are criticisms that the  government's spending more money on the country's development will set aside the welfare of aging group .
However , if the government spends more money on the aging group , the country's development will become stagnant and imbalanced as there is a lack of funds to run the country's development projects .
if t public spending is diverted to other areas for country's development , the nation including the  aged will both gain benefits from the country's development and economic growth .
Besides that , there are other groups of population which need more money than the elderly such as the orphans , the handicapped and others .
These groups of people have to struggle for their living resources and cost of living as they are vulnerable in the society .
Often , the handicapped can hardly make a stand in applying for a job if they are to compete with the others because of their physical weaknesses and lack of living skills .
public spending will come in handy to support their living .
Some may argue that the  aged need more money as they are unable to earn income to support their living .
However , the  aged are still be able to be involved in the work field by extending their working lives and accumulating wealth for their later years .
In  contrast , the handicapped can hardly get a job , not to mention that they can accumulate wealth through working .
Therefore public spending should be diverted to other areas to help the needy and unfortunate .
Furthermore , limited public spending on the elderly can encourage the grown-up children to take up their filial responsibility .
If the government reduces public spending on elders , those whose living cost depends on the public spending have to rely on their children for support .
In the past , the elders have worked hard to raise their children and provide the best for their children .
Hence , the grown children should appreciate their upbringing and take good care of them in return .
There may be opposing views which claims that the grown children do not have much money to support the elderly as they have their own families to support .
Nevertheless , the grown children can actually do some adjustments to their monthly expenditure by practicing cost saving to have sufficient money to support their own family and their elder's living cost .
This will increase the willingness of the grown children to take care of their parents and realize their obligation to their parents .
In a nutshell , government should change their mindset and policy in order to meet the modern challenges .
Policy maker should limit public spending on the aged and divert money to other country's development to maintain a balance development of the country .
Or else , the country development would be stagnant and the nation would not have to live in a comfortable life .
If the government helps the senior citizens with public spending by constraining the fiscal cost on other areas of country development , the government would actually put the country in a straggling condition .
Due to poor fertility rates and late marriages , the government is now confronted with the problem of an aging population .
This is a phenomenon with dire consequences , such as having to direct large amounts of money to take care of the elderly .
Examples include a need to build facilities that are elderly-friendly and heavy subsidizing  their medical fees due to their poor health and low income .
Although forking out a lump sum of money for medical fees is inevitable , the government should not neglect the economic growth of the country .
Thus funding for the elderly medical fees should be limited so as to divert funds to other areas which are more necessary for improvement .
We cannot deny the fact that what we have today is a result of the hard work of the elderly in their prime years .
It is only right that the government takes care of them , and spends vast amounts of money on them with no questions asked .
Critics of this approach have argued that if the government continues spending , more tax will be imposed on each working individual and elder dependency will rise .
It would be very stressful for them , having to keep up with both the pace of work and tax expenses .
Furthermore , there are key areas such as tourism , education and technology which will produce significant results if enough resources are channeled to them .
Other than the government spending  , there are other alternatives which can be implemented to remedy the situation .
Firstly , it is through stressing filial obligation and increasing the willingness of tomorrow's grown children , however numerous or productive  , to support their own elderly parents through informal and familial channels .
(Peterson .P , 2001) .
This is a social responsibility for each working individual , and it is often easier to get people to be socially responsible than to increase their tax contributions .
The government should give incentives to children who live near their parents , such as cheaper housing , or give priority to them when allocating flats .
Secondly , it is by requiring people to provide in advance for their own old-age dependency .
They should be encouraged or compelled by law to save and invest more of their income earned while they are active in the work force .
(Paterson ,P . ,2001 2001) .
Minor monthly contributions made during their working years will definitely accumulate to a substantial pool of wealth for their retirement days .
Diverting funds to other more vital areas of improvements has its benefits too .
Firstly , there will be economic growth and country prosperity .
Singapore has strived hard to achieve the status as a tourism hub , and the revenue that could be generated from it alone should never be overlooked .
Therefore , if more funds are diverted to it instead of to the  elderly , there is no doubt that the country will experience tremendous economic growth and be prosperous .
Secondly , the future workforce of the country will be very productive .
A productive workforce is often defined as one which possesses the best qualifications , and education emphasis is the only way to go about it .
Thus , expanding the current budget on education will surely result in a larger and more affluent generation in the future .
Spending on the elderly is necessary , and it could be done on a ration basis .
We've discussed the far-reaching effects of diverting to other more vital areas of improvement and it outweighs any existing issues .
There are also other available alternatives which could be implemented to deal with the medical needs of the elderly , such as stressing filial obligations and introducing retirement schemes .
The limit , however , should be duly considered by the government in line with its current policies .
In a survey conducted by Manpower Incorporated , 40% of global leaders felt that introducing population was to be one of the most crucial problems in the future (AARP Multinational Survey of Opinion Leaders 2006 , March 2007) .
Thus it comes as no surprise that governments around the world have stepped up their efforts to alleviate the effects of global aging .
The social policies adopted have greatly introduced the older population into the workforce and the volunteering sector , thus keeping them actively involved in the community and easing the aging process to a large extent .
Firstly , governments have reduced the dangers of an ageing population by encouraging retirees to participate actively in volunteering (MCYS Media Release No .
03/2008) to increase their mental alertness and at the same time tap on their wisdom to aid the community .
However , critics argue that citizens are unaware of these volunteering opportunities .
Also , they contend that most would be unwilling to volunteer during their 'golden years' , thus wasting the government's efforts to increase volunteering opportunities for the elder population .
This claim is flawed as the government has been stepping up its efforts to increase awareness of elder volunteerism through public campaigns and functions .
Fairs have also been organised to encourage active ageing through volunteerism (MCYS Media Release No .
03/2008) .
As a result , there has been a rising number of senior volunteers over the years .
The Retired and Senior Volunteers Programme (RSVP) is an example of an avenue that provides opportunities for retirees to volunteer and use their skills to help others and also nurture new skills along the way .
To date , it has over 500 , 000 volunteers (Senior corps , electronic reference) , thus proving wrong the notion that people are unaware and uninterested to volunteer in their 'golden years' .
The high membership is testimony to the fact that volunteering will give the elderly spiritual fulfillment in their later years .
Secondly , governments in affected countries have introduced incentives to encourage companies to hire and retrain older workers , thus boosting the workforce and easing the aging process .
This will ensure that the huge older population can contribute effectively to the workforce .
Also , they will be able to accumulate more savings and not be over-reliant on the government for pension benefits .
This policy has been effective as surveys have proved that with the retraining and incentives to hire older workers put in place , employers have been increasingly open about hiring older workers .
According to a survey conducted by Manpower Incorporated in October 2006 , 48% and 43% of employers had strategies to hire and preserve older Singaporean workers respectively , whereas in Japan , 83% of employers had strategies to preserve older workers .
This proves that the governments' strategies to promote the hiring of older workers into the workforce have been effective .
According to  Singapore's Ministerial Committee on Ageing (MCA) , employment of Singapore citizens aged 55 to 64 increased from 53 .7% in 2006 to 56 .2% in 2007 (MCYS Media Release No .
03/2008) .
This shows that the retraining of skills have indeed helped older workers to become more productive leading to the increased willingness of employers to hire them .
Lastly , the Singapore government has been encouraging citizens to retire later to accumulate more savings .
As a result , Singaporean working males aged 60 to 64 increased from 49% in 1996 to 63% in 2006 , while the number of  females increased from 15% to 26% (Ministry of Manpower Press Release , 22/2/07) .
This proves that the government's promotion of a longer working life have effectively influenced the mindset and convinced the older population to contribute to the workforce for a longer period of time .
Fiscal cost that was previously used to distribute pension benefits to retirees could now be diverted to funding retraining programmes and monetary incentives to companies to hire and retrain older workers , thus further boosting the economy .
As seen from the above , current social policies adopted by the government have indeed alleviated the ageing process significantly .
The elder population , equipped with better skills , now has greater ability to contribute to the workforce .
Companies , with increased cash grants from the government , can now afford to retrain and hire older workers .
Also , senior volunteer opportunities are abound to effectively tap on the skills of retirees and ensure their mental well-being .
Facing an ageing population , the Singapore government had done research and development to improve the ageing process .
This is so that we will be able to harness the social possibilities , while at the same time , prepare to tackle challenges arising from the ageing population .
The ageing process brings to mind deteriorating health  which requires lots of medical attention .
To make matters worse , social problems such as disrespectfulness and the lack of filial piety among the younger generations arises .
This would lead to emotional problems , where an elderly feels like the "leftover of society" .
Gerard Ee , chairman of Council for Third Age said , we have to deal with housing , health , financial needs and accessibility before older people can be fully integrated into society .
Singapore has looked into the development of infrastructure to create a barrier free society for the elderly .
The main areas of concerns were the Housing Development Board (HDB) precincts and public transport island wide .
Firstly , the government  launched the Lift Upgrading Programme for the benefit of flat owners without direct access to lifts .
By doing so , elderly can then conveniently leave their HDB homes to access shops and services within the precinct (HDB , 2001) .
Next , new buses are now designed with low floors step-free and wheelchair accessible .
According to the Committee of Aging Issues (CAI) , a barrier free environment is important to allow senior citizens to live independently and move out into the community to participate actively in society (CAI , 2006) .
The newly designed buses complement the elder friendly Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) systems , making Singapore an accessible city for all .
Hence , today's elderly has unobstructed access from homes to public amenities , communal and recreational facilities .
In recognition of what the government has done , people have begun to ask if these improvements could really ease the ageing process .
Now elderly are given more access to the public , but the ultimate choice still lies with them .
What could be hindering the decision is their children's disapproval or even themselves .
This is the case as most people will agree that elderly are not able to take care of themselves outside .
We cannot deny the fact that they require more response time and have certain constraints in physical movements .
A little carelessness on the road could cause accidents , thus creating more burdens to their love ones .
Also , they are usually the victims of crime .
However , the government has been creating awareness on looking out for each other especially the elderly in society .
For example , from young , schools teach civic and moral education to educate us on how to take care of the elderly , to be patient with them , to respect them and even offer help to them .
Television programs such as Crime Watch also increases the knowledge of elderly to be wary of conmen and to prevent crime by not wearing excessive valuables .
The second area of research and development is on dementia .
Researchers found that people who retired later are able to avoid Alzheimer's disease longer than people who retired earlier (The Straits Times , 2009) .
The first way of tackling this issue is to raise the retirement age to 62 years old .
This not only keeps the elderly mind active , it also helps them to cope financially with rising medical costs and brings in self-satisfaction for being able to contribute to the society .
Secondly , CAI emphasizes  having strong family ties across generations to ensure that the family continues to be the first line of support .
This is essential to the elderly so they will not feel so helpless and unwanted .
Lastly , the Government has also encouraged activities and interactions by setting up elderly corners at void decks with facilities such as chess tables .
The aim is to prevent the elderly from shutting themselves out of the society , resulting in mind-robbing Alzheimer's disease .
In conclusion , the current research and development approaches adopted by the Singapore Government are helpful to a large extent in easing the ageing process .
With the development of infrastructure and medical field as mentioned above , these problems are better handled .
The elderly can now move around independently and conveniently , decreasing the burden on working adults .
The aging population has been an ongoing problem in  countries over the world .
It is not much of a difference in Singapore as the Strait Times (2009) stated that there has been an increase in the aging population to about 300 ,000 people who are over the age of 65 today and this figure is expected to increase to 900 ,000 by 2030 .
This shows that more attention is required for the aging population  to prepare it to embrace these elderly in the near future .
Hence , the public spending on the aged should not be limited and  be spent on other areas of the country's development as the money is needed for the healthcare and financial needs needsr the aged .
As one gets older , one is more vulnerable to illness which explains the need of spending on the healthcare industry .
In the CIA factbook (2009) , the life expectancy for Singapore is 81 .98 years , which is ranked fourth in the world .
This means that the aged would live longer and drain their family's and their own savings as the hospital fees are costly and thus more subsidies are required (Friedland & Summer , 2005 , p .g .17) .
Moreover , money is also needed to provide the prevention and screenings programmes for the elderly and to educate them about the benefits of having a healthy lifestyle and ways to stay healthy .
These screenings can also help to identify potential health problems that they might have and get them to seek treatment before it worsens and disrupts their daily activities .
Hence , spending on elderly healthcare is necessary as it helps to educate the elderly on the importance of a healthy lifestyle while reducing the burden on the elderly and their family for the costly healthcare services .
Moreover , there is a high chance that the elderly may use up their retirement savings on healthcare and daily necessities despite the implementation of Central Provident Fund (CPF) to lessen their burden .
Dr Ng (2007) stated that CPF members would also use up their CPF account in time due to the higher standard of living in the future .
In addition , based on Statistic Singapore (2008) , the old age support ratio has decreased from 11 .8 in 1990 to 8 .4 in 2008 .
This shows that there are fewer young working adults to support the elderly .
It also signifies that the elderly has to either prolong retirement or increase their saving in order to support themselves after retirement .
Therefore , retraining is needed for the elderly as through  retraining , they can upgrade their skills and adapt to the demanding working environment to save  for the future and contribute to the economy .
Hence , spending on pension and retraining for the elderly is essential and should not be limited as it aids them in being financially independent after retirement .
On the other hand , money is also needed in the other areas of development like education .
Education plays an important part in the country's development and growth as it helps in nurturing the young who are the country's future .
Thus , the expenditure on education is also important instead of focusing on the aging population .
Nevertheless , the Ministry of Finance (2009) had stated that they are planning to provide quality education by setting aside $4 .4 billion for basic education for the young and $3 .5 billion for the higher educational institutions like the polytechnics and universities .
This is in the hope of improving the education sector and nurture the young better for the future of Singapore .
Moreover , the Ministry of Education (2009) had also stated that the budget for education had increased by 5 .5% .
Hence , this shows that despite the increase in the spending for the aged , it does not mean that the other areas of development will be neglected as each development plays an important part in the growth of the country .
In conclusion , spending on the aged should not be limited due to costly healthcare expenses and limited retirement saving for the future .
These expenditures can help to improve the lifestyle of elderly and being healthy the elderly will be able to prolong their retirement which in turn helps in improving the economy .
Hence , not only the country but its people will also benefit from the economic growth .
27 .3% of Singapore's GDP (Gross Domestic Product) is attributed to the manufacturing sector (Nah , March 2006) .
The manufacturing industry in Singapore is one of the important growth engines of the economy .
A large amount of money is diverted to the R&D (Research & Development) sector to give Singapore a competitive edge over its competitors .
But this has resulted in uproars from the people and they claim that more resources should be diverted into the welfare schemes for the aged instead .
So , who is defined as the aged ?
Currently there is no fixed age group where the aged is clearly defined .
Regardless of how the aged is defined , no human is able to survive without money in this current world .
Therefore in order for the aged to be better off , the Singapore economy has to be constantly growing and this can be achieved by diverting more resources into our R&D sector so the local products will be greatly differentiated and value added .
There is a common misconception that most welfare states end up being in debt and the people have a higher tendency to be over-reliant .
However there are no statistics to show that higher government expenditure on the social welfare leads to lower growth and lower productivity .
Well known welfare states such as Germany and Denmark do not necessarily do better or worse  economically than countries which have limited social expenditure such as Japan .
Denmark's welfare expenditure contributes to 37 .9% of the nation's GDP and the GDP per capita (PPPUS$) is $37 ,265 whereas Japan's welfare expenditure contributes to 16 .9% of the nation's GDP and its GDP per capita (PPPUS$) is $38 ,559 (Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development [OECD] 2001) .
From these statistics , we can conclude that it is also possible for Singapore to learn from these success stories and increase welfare expenditure while achieving economic growth at the same time .
Singapore is different from the welfare states in Europe such as Germany and Denmark .
Singapore is practicing the open market policy and thus is more susceptible to external factors .
A recent example would be when the United States's economy fell during the credit crisis , Singapore was badly impacted by the recession .
One of the major growth engines in the Singapore's economy is the manufacturing sector .
Unlike China which has abundance in labour , Singapore on the other hand has little natural resources and is unable to compete with China on a large scale .
(Singapore , a small country with limited resources can outperform others by) distinguishing our manufacturing goods by investing more money to invent cutting edge technology , to increase efficiency , to make our products unique and competitive in the market .
In order to finance the current schemes in Singapore , the economy has to be growing first so that it could support its schemes .
Currently Government Health Expenditure has been limited at 0 .9% from 2005 to 2007(Ministry of Health [MOH] , 2001) .
Since Government Health Expenditure is capped at a percentage of GDP regardless of boom or bust in the economy , therefore the amount of money diverted to Health Expenditure in a bullish economy is higher than when it is during a bearish economy .
As the saying goes "Give a man a fish and you feed him for a day .
Teach a man to fish and you feed him for a lifetime" This is especially true for the senior citizens whose skills are outdated in the current society but have an able body to earn an income for themselves .
Instead of diverting resources to finance the welfare schemes , the government should instead divert resources into retraining and integrating the senior citizens back into the work force .
Senior citizens possess a large amount of experience which is valuable to the younger generation now , thus they are more of an asset than a liability .
"For every working adult in Singapore , He/She has to support 8 .4 elderly residents aged 65 years and above (Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports [MCYS] 2008) .
Therefore to ease the burden on the younger generation who has to support the post baby boomers as they approach their retirement years , it would be a win-win situation if we integrate senior citizens back into the work force .
As countries differ both ideologically and geographically , there is no one solution that solves the current situation of an aging population .
Thus with different government's goals , the solution will be adjusted to suit the country .
But in Singapore's context , Singapore does not have any natural resources and (we) dependent on innovation and creativity to gain an advantage over its competitors .
In order to finance these welfare programs , we need to divert resources to other areas in order to have continuous growth in Singapore .
However government intervention alone is insufficient to finance the welfare schemes alone .
Thus it has included private charity organization such as National Council of Social Service (NCSS) to attend to the needs of the aged and the needy together with the help of the government .
Most importantly is the care and concern from the family which is vital to the well being of the elderly .
The aging process of the elderly is an on-going problem , as the first batch of baby boomers will reach 65 by 2012 .
"The number of elderly aged 65 and above is one out of every 12 Singaporeans .
By 2030 , it will be one out of five ."
(Building Construction Authority [BCA] , 2008) .
In view of this growing trend , government agencies and local service providers came out with some very innovative and creative designs to ease the everyday life of elderly .
The BCA has acknowledged the aging problems in Singapore and released a series of Home improvement designs to cater to the needs of an aging population in Singapore .
Those designs include the manoeuvring space for wheel chair bound elderly , visuals and vibration door bells for elderly with hearing impairment and additional safety features like emergency bells in toilets .
All these features will enhance the life of the elderly as they can perform daily duties with ease .
These also allow the elderly to be independent as they no longer need to rely on others' help in their daily life .
Bus service provider SBS transit took the lead to introduce the elderly and handicap friendly buses in 2007 .
The low floor and zero stepped bus is an initiative by the SBS to ease the travelling journey for the elderly .
"This means that the elderly and other less mobile passengers will be able to board and alight easily .
This is especially important given Singapore's ageing population ."
(SBS Transit , 2007) .
It is an important innovation by  transport company , as it showcases its determination to improve the local transport facilities to facilitate the transportation for the ones with special needs .
Land Transport Authority (LTA) did their part by introducing the new elderly- friendly traffic system in March 2009 .
Making use of the new Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) technology , "Traffic lights will open their eyes to keep a look out for elderly pedestrians" (LTA , 2009) .
With the new technology , traffic lights will detect any/an elderly that's still crossing the roads and adjust the timing accordingly .
With this system in place , fewer traffic accidents involving slower moving elderly are expected , as it allows the elderly to finish crossing before the drivers are signalled to go .
Preliminary rounds of test involving 30 elderly pedestrians show that the new system is welcomed by the elderly .
In this economy driven society , taking too much of the public's resources to support the elderly does not bode well for the future of the country .
Therefore , placing a cap on  public spending to support the aged should be implemented .
By limiting the resources used on the aged , other developments of the country can be better financed in order to drive the country forward .
The public spending used for the elderly such as healthcare , pension and welfare programs can be diverted into development sectors instead .
For example , the education for our youths , the nurturing of the country's youth is more important as these are the people who will eventually be the ones to carry the responsibility of maintaining the economic state of the country and to ensure a brighter future for her people .
A total budget of $8 ,701 million has been voted to MOE in FY2009 (Singapore Budget , 2009) , most of which goes into the subsidising of school fees for local students .
This ensures that Singapore youngsters get a chance at education regardless of their financial status .
By exposing every possible citizen to education , Singapore then , will she be able to continue in development .
Singapore being a resource scarce country , the only resource we can make use of is our people .
Therefore funds should go into the upbringing of the people who are able to drive the country forward in the future .
On the other hand , as mentioned , in this economy driven world , it would be impractical to focus our finances on the people who are no longer efficient in what they used to do .
The country will simply be burdened by placing more funds into rewarding or simply sustaining the elderly .
They should have had savings in either the form of cash or CPF to sustain them , alongside with subsides from the government to help loosen the dependency on others for help .
The rewarding of the elderly does not push the country forward , whereas it is the upbringing of our youth that will ensure a future for our country .
There is too much human factor involved when it comes to whether elders should get more funds to help them cope in their latter days , which should not be part of any equation when other development sectors can benefit instead .
In sum , the limitation of public spending on the elderly and diverting it to other developments would serve well in driving the country forward .
On one hand it is only moral that they are well taken care because of the fact that they are the ones who contributed to the society before a new generation took over , while on the other hand  allocating more public spending to them would hinder the growth of the country as a whole .
Trading the future for the past is simply not a practical choice .

Security and External Relation .

Singapore has one of the fastest aging populations in the world , with people over 65 years old estimated by 2030 to make up 23% of the population , making Singapore the country with the second highest percentage of this age group in Asia just behind Japan (Asia Times , 2009) .
With the growing number of the aged in Singapore , the government should establish its bottom line for financing public healthcare for the elderly .
However , the government should also plan and allocate its expenditures on other areas appropriately in order to fuel the country's development .
A country cannot afford to spend too much on the elderly because of practical realities .
Some people think that the government has a moral obligation to do all that it can to support the elderly .
The high standard of living in many developed countries causes greater difficulties for working adults to support their parents' medical expenses and still take care of their children's needs .
In addition , rising medical cost makes it more imperative for the elderly to receive help in order to support their medical needs in the future .
However , this is not a practicable solution .
Other than the elderly , there are also other groups of people equally in need of the government support to help them .
People like the handicapped , intellectually disabled and single mothers also experience great difficulty in living in Singapore where cost of living is relatively high .
The government should spread out its public spending to the various groups of people in need instead of just focusing on the elderly .
The government's moral obligation should not be supporting the elderly only .
Technology is an important area of development that will benefit everyone in the country .
Increasing public spending on technology would lead to an increased activity in Research and Development (R&D) and new advancement in technology .
Certain new innovations brought about by the rise of R&D activities would in turn help the needy people improve their living standards .
Some examples are the invention of a robot that is able to do household chores and the modification of public buses that can accommodate the elderly and the handicapped .
Advancement in technology will also attract more investors and business opportunities to the country that will contribute to the country's economic growth .
Investing in technology would not just benefit the needy people but also the people as a whole in the country .
Military spending is crucial in maintaining an 'insurance policy' with no buffer zone against potential aggressors .
In 2009 , more than a quarter of the country's expenditure , or $11 .4 billion , had been directed to defence - an increase of 5 .6 per cent over the previous year's budget (Singapore Budget , 2009) .
This has shown the importance the government places on the Singapore defence .
Singapore sees terrorism as one of the biggest threats to its security and economy .
Attacks in recent years in the United States and neighbouring countries such as Indonesia have prompted it to increase its vigilance against similar risks .
With the threat of terrorism intensifying , Singapore should never let its guard down but invest more on its defence in order to be more vigilant .
Military spending should be  one of the top priorities of the government as it concerns the safety and security of everybody in Singapore .
In summation , it is important that the government continue to provide financial assistance for the elderly due to the increasing number of senior citizens .
However , this public spending should not be done at the expense of other expenditures that concern the country as a whole such as technology and defence .
Investing in technology and defence will eventually benefit everyone in Singapore including the elderly and other people in need in terms of better living condition and greater security .
Singapore government should continue to be cautious about how it allocates its expenditure such that it will bring the utmost profit to the country .
