is considered to be a visionary step to see to our aging population of our near of far future .
And as far as I am concerned , to run a country , we need to take interest in long term more than short term .
In short , "public spending on the aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to the other areas of the country's development" .
Two areas that can be invested in more are education and science , which will make some differences in our aging population so that this problem would no longer be an awesome matter , but one of the proudest ones to be mentioned .
With the continued decline in fertility and the improvement in health in Singaporeans , Singapore faces a greying population (MCYS , 2005) .
In addition , the ageing phenomena are becoming more complex with rapidly changing social-economic-political and technological environments (Mehta , 2004) .
For example , Chow and Chan's study (as cited in Lee , & Mehta , 2004) states that as families become more modernised , the level of the family social support to the old will suffer deterioration .
Without new policies and further research and development in all fields of study , relating to the aged , they will face difficulties in living inheir current environment .
Despite the complex changes in the environment , there are theories on successful aging which could help us in our investigation on  the extent to which the current policies have helped to ease the aging process .
The following theories are role theory and social exchange theory .
The role theory suggests that people play specific roles in their families and communities throughout their life time .
social exchange theory suggests that the degree of interaction of elderly is determined by their ability to engage in social exchange .
We will focus on whether the current policies have made life easier for the elderly on the basis of these theories .
In Singapore , the existing policy on employing the elderly does not do enough to allow senior workers to continue playing their roles in working community .
Companies in Singapore tend to prefer employing younger employees , and when the company is undergoing restructuring , the older workers are usually the ones to be retrenched .
Despite the incentives given out by Singapore government to encourage companies to continue employing the elderly , companies still hesitate to keep them because of possible health problems .
Forcing them to accept less respected job , also mean lower income , to earn for a living as retirement age has increased .
This creates undue stress and negative psychological impact on the aged , at the same time a social stigma on them and also inadequate income .
A survey from MCYS (2005) shows that there is an increased in the proportion of those aged above 55 and above who found their income usually inadequate , 29 .9% of them credit it to low income .
Unlike Japan , the companies tend to treasure the experience of older workers and recognise their loyalty towards the company , allowing them to stay on to managerial position provided that they are competent .
The aged in Japan are very much respected as compared to those in Singapore , hence , aging with more dignity .
Taking a closer look , the success of the policy on employing the elderly is still inconclusive , as it takes years to change the perspective of a society .
At the very least , the elderly is still able to be part of the workforce .
To a large extent , most of the existing policies have helped to ease the aging process .
The HDB housing policy which encourages families to stay closer to their parents allows the elderly to continue their role in helping their children or even an additional role as a grandparent .
The HDB provides additional grants through CPF for families to purchase flats within a certain radius of their parents .
With the close proximity , family members can travel to and fro with ease , helping them in terms of household matters and even taking care of young children .
This allows bonding to increase between them and also increasing the self-worth of the elderly .
In terms of improving the ability of the elderly in engaging social exchange , mobility and places are the important aspect .
The government is creating a more disabled and elderly friendly environment by making improvements in housing estates and public areas .
For example , the transport authority aims to have lift facilities in every mass rapid and light rail transit stations .
In order to encourage active aging , the government is bringing activities closer to housing estates like the RC or CC .
These activities include not only physical activities , and also voluntary activities .
The government also set up the Council for Third Age to further promote active aging (MCYS , 2009) .
Presently , though , social policies are still solely drafted  by the government .
However , Singaporeans can be involved in improving these policies by providing feedbacks through government portals like Reach .
With such initiatives , policies are now more focused on improving the lives of Singaporean as a whole .
Aging population is now the uprising enigma that alarms the nation of its increasing elderly dependency and diminution of productivity .
The proportion of elderly Singapore residents aged 65 and above had increased from 7 .4% in 2003 to 8 .5% in 2006 .
The number shall increase further as the proportion of children below 15 years has steadily declined from 28% in 1980 to 19 .3% in 2006 .
It is undeniable that Singapore is facing the emerging healthcare ramifications due to the aging process .
Thus , the healthcare medical advancement indubitably has a pivotal role in easing the aging progression .
Additional healthcare facilities and services are to be provided in line with the aging process .
The escalating figure of aging population will certainly increase the numbers of patients afflicted to intricate diseases such as Ischaemic heart diseases .
With aging population , the likelihood of patients suffering from multiple organ failure will start to increase too .
Nonetheless , the number of hospitalizations due to such medical conditions may amplify as well .
In order to rectify the homeward bound predicament , not only more elder-friendly friendly facilities have to be constructed , but  critical care medical treatment and surgery is  required too .
However , this could prove  to be a major hitch as there is an emerging need for critical care programmes .
Various medical institutions should offer training and preparation to medical professional personnel to equip them with the necessity to counter the upcoming crisis .
The progression of aging could be also alleviated with new and hi- tech medical advancement .
Since the 2003 , Singapore General Hospital has performed numerous robotic surgeries ever since the robotic surgical system , known as Da Vinci Surgical was introduce .
This has significantly augmented the precision of intricate surgeries as well as trimmed down much of the risk faced by the patient during surgical operations .
With the marvel breakthrough of medical advancement , elderly members who are the ones that  health problems are better furnished with finer medication procedures .
However , technology and science cannot replace the need for healing relationships among the medical personnel and patients .
Dr Vivian Balakrishnan , Minister for States and National Development once says that while technology and science continue to alter medical procedures and techniques , health care at its core remains a high-touch profession .
Care is provided by people , not technology , buildings or drugs .
( Dr Vivian Blakrishnan , 2002) Through caring interactions , patients especially the old and needy members can be emotionally and psychologically motivated to fight against the associated sickness .
Thus , healthcare professionals are required to constantly enhance their ability to communicate and care , not just mainly rely on the development of technology and science .
In addition , with the robust production of supplementary healthcare products nowadays , the level of personal healthiness of the elderly can be much maintained .
Taking healthcare products such as natural vitamins and mineral salts is able to build up one's immunity system against viral and bacterial infections .
It is often said that prevention is better than cure .
These supplementary products not only can fortify one's immunity system , but also improve one's mind alertness and body vigor .
Elderly should be taking complementary healthcare products to strengthen their body against diseases as we well as retaining their mental alertness .
At this point one may wonder  whether the manufactured supplementary healthcare products are safe to be consumed as there are cases that the products are proven to be potentially health hazardous .
However , numerous measures have been imposed by authorities such as the Health Sciences Authority to insure that the merchandises are secured to be utilised .
Nonetheless , consumer themselves have to prudent when selecting the varieties of healthcare products .
In conclusion , progress of development in healthcare needs have to always be maintained at a high pace as the tempo of aging progression hastens .
More funds should be provided to increase more research and development in the pharmaceutical and medical sciences fields as well as importing more advance technologies .
This would largely aid in resolving the predicaments of declining personal health system that an aging population will encounter .
Peter G . Peterson concludes that global aging may still impose unsustainable fiscal and economic burden unless the developed countries confront the daunting problem of rising healtcare cost and how to set limits on healthcare .
(Peter G . Peterson , 2001) Yet , insufficient healthcare development spending may degenerate the health standards of the nation and so , in turn reduces productivity even more significantly .
Public spending should therefore be more focused on providing excellent healthcare facilities and services which would benefit and ease the growing health crisis amidst the aging population .
"As Singapore becomes accustomed to being an affluent and rapidly ageing society , the issue of financing the aged has become more pressing requiring reassessment of the existing arrangements ."
(Chan , 2002) Should the Singapore government spend more on the aged or should the money be diverted to other areas of the country's development ?
By generating economic growth for the country , the aged would also benefit .
Public spending on the aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
Public spending refers to expenditure by government .
A principal source of revenue or income to pay for public spending is taxation(Tiscali , 2009) .
Some of the other areas in the country's development that require public spending are like social services and benefits , education , infrastructure and development projects like transport , housing and employment (Anonymous , 2009) .
It is important for the government to spend in this area so that the country's economy and social condition will improve .
Many argue that limiting public spending on the elderly would only leave  their families to face with issues on education , housing , social services and transportation .
By cutting expenditure on welfare programs for the elderly , individuals and families are  responsible for a larger share of the cost incurred by the elderly . .
They would need to provide the cost for their own old age dependency , according to Robert B . and Laura S . in  .
Besides , such cost may even be greater than the original cost of running welfare programs for the elderly .
In addition , limiting public spending on the aged would mean that individuals have to provide the cost for their own old age dependency .
This is  beneficial for the country as people will learn to depend on themselves .
They would be able to able to work betterand attain higher income so as to help support education , housing , social services and rising cost of transportation for themselves .
It would be  useful  when there is an economic downturn and the government is not able to spend on the aged .
"An aging population will push up pension and healthcare costs , forcing major increases in public spending that could slow economic growth in rich and poor countries ."
(Fox , 2009) Clearly , as Singapore experiences the problem of ageing population , it is important to generate economic growth for the country to benefit the aged .
Higher expenditure on areas like infrastructure and education , allows the country to achieve greater economic growth which  in turn will solve the problems of aging population .
With better economic and social condition in the country , people would become richer and affluent .
This would then reduce the worries of individuals and their families about issues pertaining to education , housing , social services and transportation .
Even though family members are responsiblefor taking care of their elderly ,  many assume that the government would be responsible for it because of its vast resources .
.
Some took advantage of the situation and make use of the low-cost medical facilities , as can be seen in the long queues formed at the polyclinics in Singapore . .
This may lead to people who are in urgent need for medical consultation being delayed , which in turn , may cause serious consequences .
Financial help should be given to those who are really in  need , instead of allocating large amount of funds to all the elderly .
Many elderly are still able to work and support themselves , thus they don't need the help of the government .
According to the one article , PM Lee said that "the best way to keep health costs down is by maintaining a healthy lifestyle" (Channel News Asia 2009) .This implies that as long as the elderly keep themselves healthy , lesser burden will be placed on the government .
Therefore , part of the public spending on the aged can be diverted to developing other sectors of the country , so as to ensure that the public spending is well-allocated .
Even though there are schemes to make people save for their old age now , the older generation who have little or no education , are not able to comprehend what these schemes are about and what benefits they will get . .
Therefore they need the aid of the government to help them cope with their medical issues and their daily lives .
More elderly friendly facilities in the neighbourhood of the elderly should be built and good values such as giving up seats to the elderly should be taught to the public to help the elderly to cope  with their daily lives .
For example , in Singapore , there are priority seats for the elderly so that they do not have to stand for long hours .
If money were to be diverted to other area of developments ,  .
Therefore public spending is essential , and it  should not be limited to assisting the developments of other areas  and neglect the major problem of ageing population  .
However , many social problems caused by the elderly are mainly due to the lack of education .
More resources should be allocated to develop the country's education system so as to ensure the continuous supply of good labour and also to educate the public of the importance of self-reliance .
With more people receiving education , they will understand the importance of planning for their future and developing the culture of taking care of themselves and their elderly .
Therefore , funding for the aged should be limited , so as to provide more funds for the development of other areas , such as the education sector . .
"Over the past two decades , journalists and scholars have periodically commented on how rising public spending for older people is expected to threaten if not erode public commitments to other deserving groups ."
said Paul W . Newacheck (Health Affairs , 2004) .
Public spending is money expended from the government to pay for the country's expenses (Business Dictionary , 2009) .
The money can come from different sources , with the majority coming from taxation .
For instance , the tax policy in Singapore is drawn out based on the notion of guiding desirable behaviour towards different economic and social goals .
Therefore , public spending should emphasize not only the social , but also the economic development of the country .
However , there are many emerging concerns about the ageing society in many developed countries .
Limiting public spending for the aged may in turn bring about social problems , as well as other issues that concerned family responsibilities and dignity .
As the percentage of the aged increases , the percentage of people generating income in the country diminishes .
Without the government to shoulder part of the burden , most immediate families of the elderly will find it financially taxing on their part .
In worse cases , cash-strapped children will be unwilling to take care of them due to the high standards of living and healthcare costs increasing each year .
This problem falls back on society , as abandoned parents will be left to fend for themselves (Megawati Wijaya , 2009) .
A research in Singapore shows that the Geylang East Home for the Aged , a shelter for elderly abandoned by their family , said that its 37-bed home is always full .
In many cases , the families of these abandoned aged just passed their responsibility to another institution .
(Avia Collinder , 2008) Also , I feel that most elderly people have a strong sense of dignity and self worth , considering their lifelong achievements and efforts throughout the years (Nordenfelt L , 2003) .
These people are most probably not going to turn to government's aid even if their own families reject them .
Without the government's initiatives , the elderly people are going to go through a hard time coping in  society .
Nonetheless , it still can be argued that directing public spending to other areas of the country's development can indirectly offset these social problems .
By investing in other areas , we can empower these three groups of people: employers , families and the elderly .
Firstly , this amount of money can be used to help businesses and individuals struggling from the recent economic crisis .
For instance , the government implemented the Job Credit Scheme in Singapore .
This scheme was introduced to preserve jobs during the economic downturn .
Basically , participating employers will receive a cash grant based on the CPF contributions they have made for their existing employees(IRAS , 2009) .
It serves as a winning tool as the employers get to bring their businesses to a higher level , and  existing workers in turn retain their jobs .
In this way , these benefiters can fulfill their basic responsibilities better , such as in taking care of their own families with the higher purchasing power they have .
Secondly , education and learning are important factors contributing to a country's success .
With the society changing constantly , the monetary support which the government can provide is only temporary .
Often , people need to improve themselves to keep up with the demands and needs of their surrounding milieu .
For example , investing on current employees to advance their expertise in the workplace can land them with better promotion prospects and job security .
Equipping the younger generation with relevant skills can also allow them higher chances of securing better jobs of their preferences in the future .
Also , the government can educate these people about their responsibilities by emphasizing the role of the family in caring for the elderly (Megawati Wijaya , 2009) .
With better jobs and increases in income , they can help the families to cope with the high standards of living and spiraling healthcare costs for the aged .
As a result , social stability can be fulfilled while economic growth is being spurred .
Lastly , investments can be made on healthcare to empower the aged to take charge of their own health .
Research studies in New York showed that living a healthy lifestyle is very important to the elderly people in their journey of conquering new physical , emotional and mental challenges (Admin in Aging , 2008) .
The level of physical activity needed to be exerted for beneficial results is attainable by majority of the aged (Gerontology , 2002) .
The government can also hold "Healthy Lifestyle" campaigns to encourage the aged to engage more actively in activities , and promote healthy aging .
On top of that , the involvement of their immediate families in the process will be a bonus in helping them to cope with ageing .
With a blissful mind and a healthy body , these elderly will be less likely to seek emotional and social help from the government .
All in all , limiting public spending on the aged and directing the funds into other areas of development such as businesses , education and healthcare is more rewarding then just focusing on the needy groups .
Although the help is theoretically superficial , it is indirectly helping the society to deal with the ageing society more effectively as compared to  using  monetary support , which is a temporary solution .
This solution is made much easier when we understand the bigger picture .
If we do not pay attention to the long term effects the problem is going to cause , we will risk the possibility of allocating  limited resources for the wrong usage .
The aged might have devoted their youth and even their whole life to serving the society; and public spending on the aged is therefore necessary .
In fact , every one of us , regardless of doing mental or physical work , has made a significant contribution towards the development of society .
.
Hence , as long as a person has sacrificed for the social development of society ,  he should be looked after by the state when he is old , even if he could no longer contribute in his area of work . .
If the public spending on the aged is limited , the burden on the children or younger generation will be much heavier since they will have to bear with more expenses incurred by their parents .
It was claimed that families and individuals will face many issues if welfare programs are cut or restructured (Robert B . Friedland and Laura Summer , 2005) .
A survey in China showed that "living and working pressure makes people powerless to take care of their parents"; and this kind of pressure has become  a great difficulty for young people now (Wang Jun , 2009) .
In today's society , many people of working age , with their own careers and families , have to withstand considerable economic pressure .
Once the elderly reach their old age , they are afflicted with a variety of ailments .
Expensive medical and health care cost  , in addition to the very high daily cost , have indeed caused  serious difficulties .
So ,  when the children have to bear the medical expenses and the cost of everyday lives of their parents , they tend to live beyond their income .
The gap between the rich and the poor in  present society is still apparent .
When  the government subsidies are reduced , retired people from high-income groups may still be comfortable with their finances , but the relatively poor people will face  difficulties in livelihood .
Higher income people tend to have more savings , and so they can enjoy a carefree retirement .
However , people from the low-wage sectors in general do not have much savings , since they are often faced with the problem of having  insufficient money to spend .
In their later years , if they encountered ungrateful children who are unwilling to take care of them ,  Many people today spend money on their own  families , the needs of their children , as well as the pursuit of material comfort   , instead of  spending money on their parents .
At this point , a notion of "Parental Support Law" has been suggested to force the children to be filial to their parents (Huang Yu Shan , 2002) .
However ,  .
If a legal act is required to force people  to support their parents , does it mean that our moral values have deteriorated  ?
Clearly ,  public spending on the aged should be continued to protect the rights and benefits of the aged .
The aged have dedicated so much to the development of a country and they should be thanked .
Reduced public spending will increase the burden of the children and furthermore , poor people will become poorer .
.
In fact , we all will grow old one day .
According to the Singapore Department of Statistics , the life expectancy of Singaporean has increased noticeably to 78 .0 for male and to 82 .8 for female (as cited from Press Release , Singapore Department of Statistics , 2008) .
Although that is good news  , it also leads to some unpleasant problems for Singapore , such as increasing the financial burden for elderly-care .
From my perspective , economic development is not only the key factor in easing the aging problem  , but also is the key solution to some serious problems caused by this process .
First of all ,  it is commonly believed that a well-funded life which arises from economic success will help people to  purchase sufficient food for their own consumption .
At the same time , there are more facilities  , such as pools for swimming , courts for playing tennis , indoor gyms for various kind of sports .
With  financial sufficiency , people can live an easy life and  .
For instance , living in air-conditioning buildings helps us  or using  robots reduces death rates in some high-risk jobs .
In the other words , as a result of economic development , we have been enjoying better and healthier lives .
Secondly , economic development also encourages the improvement of services  .
Among  them , the entertainment industry should be mentioned as the most obvious one .
, more and more entertainment parks , visual and virtual products ,  such as films and games come into our life .
.
For example , a typical citizen in a globalised city , such as Tokyo or London , can now enjoy his or her weekendtime in a hundred destinations for recreation and some of them are known worldwide .
Alternatively , they can stay at home and choose among tens of local and international TV channels to watch or they can surf the internet to visit millions of websites .
Indeed , it is no doubt that  .
What is more , a prosperous economy can also foster further technological invention , medical innovation as well as educational improvement , which all are considered to be important factors in alleviating the aging process .
Once government sufficiently finances medical research , more diseases can be cured or prevented more effectively .
In the same pattern , once the educational level is raised , people can be more aware of how to take care of themselves , as  well as to live long and healthily .
In conclusion , today's developed countries have been increasingly confronted with the aging process and its consequences .
,  contribute to easing this process but economic factor  .
, a prosperous economy not only lengthens the of the general population  , but also allow people to live more healthily and lighten their social burden  on elderly care .
While the population is shifting towards a greying one , many would start to worry about the ease of aging in the current society , especially amidst a time of financial crisis and difficulty .
Current research and development such as medical advancement and barrier free housing estates are examples that have helped ease the aging process .
However , more emphasis should be placed on the development of social policy that will help to alleviate and address concerns such as the lack of financial support and social care , which affects the elderly more directly .
Meanwhile , there are already policies in place , such as the Central Provident Fund (CPF) , Lease Buy Back Scheme (LBS) and housing grants for married children staying near parents , which are all structured to aid the aged in terms of financial and healthcare issues .
The Central Provident Fund is a savings account for all workers in Singapore for them to set aside a sum of 33 percent of their wages for retirement purposes  .
This sum of money will serve as a source of income when one cannot work in the future due to old age .
On top of that , a subset of the CPF called the Medisave account , will serve as a backup sum to pay for any medical bills should the need arises .
Therefore , they would not have to strain their pockets to pay for their health care when they have already stopped working .
At this juncture , one may wonder how the Medisave account could be sufficient when medical fees these days are so steep .
Treatment for common illnesses , such as stroke would have already chalked up thousands  and things could be a lot more worse , should there be more than one illness to treat .
However , this could be solved by purchasing Medishield or third party healthcare insurance using the Medisave itself .
The insurance will serve to cover most of the medical expenses , if not all .
In the event that an individual is not being able to pay the minimum amount , they can apply for the Medifund , which is an endowment plan funded by the nation's economic growth , targeted to help those who still cannot afford to pay the bills despite already being heavily subsidised .
With these in place , the aged will be well taken care of and given a peace of mind in monetary ; and they could live in a more comfortable environment during old age .
For those elderly who have funds that are locked in the form of housing assets , there is a solution for them too .
Just recently , on March 2009 , the government introduced the Lease Buy Back Scheme (LBS) for elderly to sell off the tail end thirty years lease of their flats in return for a life-long monthly retirement income .
These elderly will stand to enjoy a supplement to their retirement income on top of what they will receive from CPF payout .
Depending on the age group , an amount ranging from $500 to $800 will be issued to them monthly after an upfront sum of $5000 .
Again , we can see how public policy has shaped to help the elderly to acquire a less financially taxing aging process .
Apart from being well taken care of in medical bills , the elderly needs to be looked after in their social well-being too . .
It is in the government's interest that these elderly do receive an appropriate amount of attention and care so that they will not be deprived of company at old age .
This is why the Housing Development Board (HDB) came up with a housing grant of forty thousand dollars to encourage the younger generations to live in flats close  their parents .
The policy will benefit not only the purchaser in terms of cost  , but it will also help to propagate the importance of filial piety in  society .
When  married children are housed near to their parents , they are more likely to visit them frequently due to convenience and simultaneously , the elderly will be taken care of physically as well .
Opponents of this scheme may argue that the opposite may take place instead .
Rather than having the married couple to look after their parents , it might be the couple  exploiting  their parents; such as living off them or   treating them as babysitters for their own children .
Nevertheless , this actually aligns with the government's aim: fostering mutual care between the young and elderly .
By housing them in close vicinity , it actually adds  purpose to the lives of the elderly as well .
"That's why fitness facilities , children's playground and elderly exercise equipment are put together" quoted Mr Mah BT (2008) in a housing speech .
All this contributes to making the aging process a more fruitful and meaningful one .
In the presence of these numerous social policies , many aspects of the aging process have been addressed by the government and this has served to mitigate some of the most common concerns among the elderly .
These policies have benefited the elderly and will continue to provide assistance to them in the future .
Therefore , it is evident that current research and policies have helped to ease the aging process and made retirement a less burdensome one .
The growth of the aging population is increasing at an alarming rate .
From research , in developed nations , people born in the twentieth century can live for 35 years longer than people who are born in the nineties .
The increase in aging population reflects the need for better healthcare and social services .
This is because as people aged , their health will deteriorate and this results in the increase of healthcare and social cost .
To ease this aging process , government and other industries initiated various efforts to reduce spending on healthcare and elderly dependency on the younger generation .
With continual advancement in the medical industry , current research and development in better healthcare services and facilities like building new community hospitals , providing long-term care services and developing electronic health record system (EHR) , can help ease the problems of healthcare cost and elderly dependency .
Therefore , I agree that current research and development in the field of medicine have eased the the aging process .
Firstly , the building of new community hospitals provide intermediate healthcare for the elderly who do not require consultation from the general hospitals .
With such developments , the elderly can save cost and receive appropriate healthcare treatments more conveniently .
However , convenience does not mean it is affordable .
Healthcare cost in Singapore is constantly rising with the advance in technology .
A single hospitalization can cost up to thousand of dollars .
If the elderly do not have enough savings  , they may depend  on the government or their children .
However , Singaporeans enjoy healthcare subsidies .
The amount of subsidies on hospitalization will be determined by means-testing .
This way , the government reduces the financial dependency of the elderly by providing help based on their financial needs .
In addition , there are also other financial subsidies available ,  like the Medisave , Medishield and Medifund to keep healthcare cost affordable for Singaporeans .
Secondly , Long-term care services like home care and rehabilitation can allow patients to recover in surroundings that are more comfortable and with their families around them . .
These Long-term care services involved two board categories: residential healthcare and community healthcare , which are managed by Voluntary Welfare Organizations (VWO) or by private operators .
These are cheaper support alternatives as compared to leaving elderly patients in hospitals .
In cases where the family cannot provide attention to or support for the needs of the elderly , they can seek for community healthcare services that are carried out at home or in a centre .
Such services can help to reduce the elderly's emotional dependency on their children too .
However , some volunteers for the elderly home care or rehabilitation centre may lack  profession skills , as compared to those provided  in hospitals .
The elderly may not be receiving the most appropriate medical help .
Fortunately , the government has already recognized the importance of such services to ease aging process .
In the 2009 budget speech , over $500 million will be spend in the next five years on training staff and improving this long-term care services for elderly Singaporeans .
Thirdly , the development of electronic health record system (EHR) helps to increase efficiency and accuracy of a medical diagnosis .
Many elderly with chronic illnesses may have complex medical backgrounds .
With this system , medical information of the elderly will be stored in the database and it is accessible to medical institutions island wide .
As a result , doctors and their staff can reduce the amount of  in gathering healthcare background information forthe elderly and reduce the amount of complicated paperwork .
There are arguments that the implications of this system would be excessive costs .
Just by setting up the system nation-wide , the government will be spending about SGD$200 million over the next two years .
However , based on research , the usage of the Electronic Health Record system can help to reduce duplication and error in medical prescription  , resulting in a cost reduction of  as much as USD$50 billion per year .
Therefore , we can conclude that  research and development can help to decrease healthcare spending and improve the quality of service efficiently .
Today , as our society is faced with the issue of ageing population , the needs for better healthcare and social services will increase .
Advancement in research and development within the medical industry has helped to ease the effects of aging population .
As a result , better healthcare services and facilities are created and they have effectively reduced healthcare cost and elderly dependency .
With the constant advancement in healthcare system , people can enjoy a longer life with better health without subjecting  the society to the adverse effects of aging .
To a large extent , I strongly agree that medical advancement has helped to ease the aging process .
In the Singapore's context ,  8% of the  population is over the age of 65 and by 2035 , it will increase to 20% .
Hence , medical advancement will prove to be beneficial for the aging population in Singapore .
However , I would like to stress that not the entire aging population can take advantage of  the medical advancement .
.
As such , a lot of aging population in Singapore will not be able to afford the high fees for advanced medical treatment that includes the use of advance technology in medicine and treatments .
This might also lead to  from part of the population who would choose not to seek any medical help due to  .
Nevertheless , this  problem has alerted the government to offer financial aids to the needy the aging population in Singapore .
The Singapore government has been actively promoting awareness of health care issues among the elderly population in general .
The Ministry of Health (MOH) has recently launched insurance financial plans for elder care .
The names of the insurance plans are called Eldershield and Eldershield Supplements (as cited from Central Provident Fund Board Ask Us , 2009) .
These programs will  provide helping hands for  aging population in Singapore .
This also  all the  aging population in Singapore to sign up these insurance plans  .
The reason for doing this is because the  needy elderly in Singapore will be covered by this insurance plan .
Thus , when they want to use this insurance plan for any emergency use , they can use it anytime .
Premiums for this insurance plan can also be paid from Medisave .
Thus , all the needy aging population in Singapore will be taken care of by the Singapore government .
Therefore , the families of the aging  group can also go to the respective hospitals to seek for financial aids  .
The Singapore government will providesubsidies for all the elderly when they seek for medical treatment .
Thus , with the solutions given by the Singapore government , they will help  the aging population to gain  .
In order to reduce this high medical advancement expenses , The Ministry of Health (MOH) has been reaching out to the senior citizens in Singapore by implementing mobile screening buses for the monthly health check (as cited from Health Promotion Board , 2009) .
Ministry of Health (MOH) has decided to make the efficient and accessible screening more affordable and convenient for all the needy elderly in Singapore .
All the needy elderly would just need to pay less than $10 for their blood test in ahealth check package comprising checks for diabetes and high cholesterol levels .
This also resulted that all the needy aging population in Singapore were given a chance to receive certain  in Singapore .
Not only that , all the residential committees (RC) and community centres in many neighbourhoods were promoting this meaningful and  health program to the needy aging population in Singapore  .
Thus , this will be beneficial to all the aging population in Singapore who could not afford any medical fees .
Last but not least , I strongly agree that medical advancement has eased  the aging process with the help of the Singapore government .
Thus , this also shows that  the aging population in Singapore is being well taken care of by the Singapore government .
With the budget given by the government , the aging population in Singapore will be given an equal entitlement to  medical advancement  to maintain a healthy lifestyle .
"Public spending on the aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development ."
Do you agree ?
Introduction
It is always a thorny issue when it comes to the allocation of the budget pie for the country's development .
Whether it is for educational , economical , societal or military advancement , it is of paramount importance that policy makers make suitable decisions in the best interests of the country and its people .
In my opinion , channeling too much government funds to taking care of the aged can have detrimental effects on the country's development .
Therefore , I am for the statement that public spending on the aged should be limited .
Uncontrolled government spending on healthcare or infrastructure for the aged could result in other groups of needy people not getting their share of the government's financial aid .
These include the handicapped , juvenile delinquents and low income families .
These less privileged groups of people are also members of the society who require our assistance .
Not attending to their needs may have serious impact on the society .
People from low income families struggling to make ends meet may be desperate and might resort to robbery and burglary to ease their financial burden .
Teenagers who engage in unlawful behaviours that defied established criminal codes or deviate from societal norms may continue with their misbehaviours , such as running away from school or home , or even committing petty crimes , if they failed to receive help from respective government bodies and the community .
These are complex social problems that might significantly impact other members of the society , and hence , the development of the country , if not handled appropriately .
Public funding is also required in the development of our education sector as Singapore continues to establish herself as an education hub .
In Singapore , the importance of education cannot be over emphasized .
Large amount of funds are pumped into the education sector so that the younger generation can receive the best education .
These could be in the form of better school sports and laboratory facilities , more funding for enrichment courses or even upgrading of school compound to accommodate more students .
In addition , funding could also imply subsidies for needy students .
Students under Finance Assistant Scheme (FAS) could be provided with school uniforms , school shoes and basic school materials .
Merit bursaries and scholarships can be awarded to students who excelled in their academic and exhibit positive traits and qualities in other aspects of their life .
Singapore also has a mandatory six years Primary Education for all Singaporean .
Financial aid will be needed to ensure that poor families , who cannot afford to send their children to school , could do so .
The ministry stands by the notion that no deserving student should be deprived of education .
As a former president of the United State of America once said , "Our progress as a nation can be no swifter than our progress in education .
The human mind is our fundamental resource ."
It is clear that education is one of the key aspects for the progress of a nation .
Without sufficient funds from the government , these plans cannot be implemented to their fullest extent .
People often mention that Singapore has only human resource .
Not developing our resources' full potential through education will indeed impede our country's development .
If significant amount of funds is needed in the education sector , there is then a need to limit expenditure on the aged .
It is difficult to draw the line as to who should be given how much of the government's budget .
But it is important to realize that , channeling funds into the education sector  may bring about more productive future generations who would in turn help to support the  aged in time to come .
In comparison , diverting funds to support the aged would appear to have no returns .
Diverting funds to other areas can be regarded as a better "investment" by policy makers and would aid in the country's development .
In conclusion , the government has to carry out careful planning on public spending .
Channeling excessive budget or limiting any one of the areas is not beneficial to the country's development .
The Government has to make critical decisions , reviewing their decisions regularly , so as to determine which aspects of the country's development should be the main focus at different periods of time .
In the long run , the government must seek to  for the older generation , at the same time less burdensome for the younger generation .
Perhaps government should introduce policies which could add value to the aged workers , in turn increasing their productivity .
The government should try to accommodate the aging issue while limiting public spending on the aged .
With their vast knowledge and rich experience from their many years of contributing to the society , the aged would definitely be an important resource the country could tap on .
In this highly modernized world , most democratic countries depend on their government for support in an array of areas , usually in the form of monetary support .
Such financial singular by the government is termed as public spending .
A principal source of income for public spending comes from taxation .
As widely known , taxation is very limited and thus public spending has to be circumscribed .
Hence the efficient allocation of funds on public spending is deemed important as  it is definitely not able to cover the amount of funds required by the entire society .
Hence , the question as to how much we should spend on an area compared to another emanates .
Public spending are funds that are used on the society and the aged certainly has a share of it as well .
Diverting much of the public spending to different areas of the country's development is certainly abominable as we would be leaving the defenseless aged to fend themselves against the numerous problems that surface while aging .
Hence , we should limit the spending on the elderly , but only to a small extent so as not to create another problem for the elderly which adds on to their already heavy burden .
In a pragmatic view , channeling large amounts of funds to the singular of the country such as research and development and education would in the long run benefit the country's economic growth .
However , it would be morally wrong to leave the elderly who are part of the society alone .
The elderly did contribute much to the country in their younger age and the society should be obliged to look after them when they are older and not cast them aside .
Furthermore , public spending is made for everyone in the society to enjoy and seek help from and we cannot limit the funds for the elderly just because they are not able to produce any returns after enjoying the funds .
Therefore we should not limit public spending to a large extent .
With changing values in the developed countries , people are giving birth to fewer children .
This change in mindset changes the percentage of young against the old .
As a result , the percentage of old is certainly rising rapidly .
With increasing amount of people turning into old age , the portion of the public spending on the aged should not be decreasing instead .
Nonetheless , the focus of a country is to grow and prosper and development in other areas are seemingly more important .
Therefore , the society has to maintain a high standard of living as a developed world and since the elderly form the bulk of the society; we should spend more to help improve their lives so as not to lower our overall standard of living .
Hence we should spend on other developments but not at the expense of forgoing that for the elderly .
The aging process is an inevitable part of life .
It brings about physical , emotional and social changes that affect individuals significantly .
Following developments and advancements around the world , governments of developed nations are faced with the challenge of a fast aging population .
For example , in Singapore , it was reported that by the year 2030 , one in five residents will be 65 years or older , a significant shift compared to one in twelve residents in the year 2005 .
CITATION The04 \l 1033 (The Committee on Ageing Issues , 2004) .
As Singapore has limited resources , there is much concern about how much of the resources the government should spend on the aged .
However , public spending on the aged should not be sacrificed even in the face of practical realities as society has a moral duty to take care of the elderly .
The significance of limiting public spending on the aged is the shift of financial burden to the individuals and their families .
When government spending on the aged is cut down , it leaves the individuals and their families to shoulder a larger portion of the costs involved .
The financial allocation for the different usages and needs in the family have to be reconsidered as a result .
Adults will face  the dilemma between providing for their aged parents or supporting their young children's education .
In most cases , the aged would be neglected or a few may even be abandoned in nursing homes .
incorrect in-text citation (Khalik , 2009) .
This gives rise to the social implications like the issue of filial piety that would have a negative impact on society .
The elderly made a commendable contribution to the society when they were younger and active in the workforce .
Being an active part of the workforce in their earlier days , the elderly had contributed to the country's economy in a way .
They had played their part in the economy by being  plural in the country and bringing investment to Singapore by being productive and efficient members of the workforce .
Furthermore , the elderly had undergone experiences that differed significantly from the younger generations .
The lessons , skills and knowledge learnt through these experiences could be important and useful to the younger generations in dealing with the present and future challenges .
Hence , the elderly made significant contributions to the country  , which provides a strong background for the government and society to provide for them .
Asian moral values involves helping and respecting the elders . .
The older population is seen to be knowledgeable with the ability to impart valuable lessons and experiences to the younger generation .
Furthermore , the elderly had worked in bringing up the younger generation .
Hence , in Asian culture , there is moral obligation to care and provide for the elderly .
While there is strong presence of moral obligation to care for the elderly , it cannot be denied that there are other groups of people who are similarly in need of government financial help .
For instance , the physically impaired population requires extensive medical needs which require government funding .
However , the elderly make up a large part of the population and is estimated to be on the rise as the years progress .
incorrect in-text citation (The Committee on Ageing Issues , 2004) .
Whereas , the physically impaired make up a relatively a small part of the population in comparison and is present in different clusters of people .
It would thus , be more feasible for the physically impaired to turn to communal help from charitable organisations than for the elderly to turn to these organisations for singular .
Hence , it would be a wiser choice for the government to provide for the elderly population as the huge population will require a significantly large amount of funding .
The challenges of an aging population will continue to increase as the years progress , and the issues arising from it are multifaceted .
However , this does not mean that we should limit public spending on the aged on the basis of their decreased efficiency and productivity to society .
Instead , moral responsibilities should be taken into consideration in policy planning , in order for planners to make acceptable policies for the community .

Thus , managing the economy should come first .

However , the question is , how much of a focus should a country place in it when there are other important areas to look into as well ?

In this ever competitive world , the idea of the weak being more susceptible to elimination and the strong emerging victorious is not unfounded .
Indeed , this concept is applicable to a real life context in our society - the old versus the young workers .
The society now has this notion that the old would eventually become obsolete , exhausted and unproductive .
However , the aged has come a long way before they hit the supposed end of their economic lifespan .
Without their contributions , the modern society might not even exist .
The state has a certain responsibility to provide for the old .
To simply cut back funds on the grounds that the elderly can no longer yield any economic profits is an irresponsible act .
The old are worthy of every resources spent on them as they are still important assets to the nation .

As this segment of the population becomes more significant , spending is unavoidable .

The society must avoid the pitfalls of classifying and relating old age to low productivity .
Ageing does not equate to redundancy .
The elderly have had accumulated a considerable amount of refined expertise that are still of societal use .
Instead of seeing them as a sector that would yield no returns , the old should be considered as an investment where providing them opportunities to share their experiences would enable the young to gain precious knowledge and learn from past mistakes .
This would pave the way for a more meaningful future for the subsequent ageing generation .
For countries with a small population such as that of Singapore , there exists the need to recruit foreign talents to fuel the economy .

However , this would not sustain the interest in foreigners if the country lacks an appealing living condition .
One way to retain these foreigners is to improve  the welfare system for the aged .
This is not a totally farfetched approach based on the previous case where Singapore established a comprehensive child care system that resulted in many expatriates moving their family over to work and dwell here .
We could similarly use an impeccable retirement scheme to entice them to settle down permanently .
By making Singapore a better place for old age , it could resolve the issue of a diminutive pool of human resources as well as boost the State's economy .
All in all , the elderly should not be viewed as incapable of providing any further services to the nation .
Rather than condemning their low productivity , we should incorporate the old into our community for they had garnered experiences which are of practical use to the young .

It is true that by doing so , a country's development and productivity will suffer .
Nevertheless , I believe that as long as the government is able to obtain a balance in the areas of public spending , the country's development can still progress without limiting public spending on the aged .
It is only right for us to take care of the aged as they contributed a great deal to what we have now .
Without the hard work of the older generation , we would not have the fundamentals of our society .
We can only prosper with a strong foundation , which the elderly had given us .
As a result , when they become feeble and require assistance , we should lend them a helping hand .
Not to mention , it is also a moral value to take care of the elderly .

The government should also engage in long term solutions , like Research and Development , to save money .
This would ensure the welfare fund is being distributed evenly .

The Maintenance of Parents Act is one good example of government intervention where taking care of elderly is  .
Under CPF Hosing Grant , there is now an incentive to live near parents too .
Thus , there is more likelihood for the younger generation to take care of their parents .
If the government can put in enough funds for the elderly and handle the aging problem holistically , this would benefit the country in the long run .
Working class Singaporeans would be motivated to work hard as they know the government would contribute in taking care of them as they aged .
This could stimulate economic growth .
Foreign talents would also be attracted to migrate here when we establish a welfare state image .

Since the aging population is one big issue now , necessary spending on the aged cannot be stingily kept away .
Not only is it due to moral obligation , ignoring the aging population would also result in other social problems that might be even more difficult to solve .

A nation's success does not solely depend on economic growth but the welfare aspect too .
Therefore with careful planning of expenditure , solving aging problem generously would benefit the country in long run .
The aging process is not a pleasant process for humans to go through .
However , the Singapore government had come up with some policies to help make the aging process a more comfortable one .
This is especially important , considering that Singapore had got one of the fastest aging populations in Asia , according to reports by the Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports (incorrect in-text citation) .
Some of the developments and policies are the construction of studio apartments specially for the elderly , the upgrading of the Housing Board (HDB) lifts which helps to improve the elders living area , increasing the retirement age to allow the elders to be more self-dependent and implementing more healthcare benefits and subsidies for the elder Singaporeans such as subsidies for community hospital stay .
All these developments and policies have contributed towards easing the aging process in Singapore .
One of the many important points to take note for an aging society is the fact that the elders' physical ability , such as walking and bathing , would tend to deteriorate over time .
Therefore attention needs to be paid , to ensure a safe environment for the elders to live in .
The Singapore government acknowledged this requirement by introducing the studio apartments and the HDB lift-upgrading projects .
In January 09 , HDB stated that they would be building more studio apartments for the elderly .
These studio apartments are equipped with elderly-friendly features such as non- slip toilet tiles , small grab poles , which are to upkeep delete this and replace with 'and' offered at an affordable price .
The upgrading of lifts in the older flatsdelete the highlighted and replace with 'where' the lifts stops at every floor of the HDB flats also helped to ensure barrier-free accessibility for the elders .
However , some problems cropped up for the lift-upgrading projects .
This was mainly . . . due to the fact that not every flat was suitable to undergo lift-upgrading project and money was needed from the elderly in order for the projects to take place .
To minimize these problems , subsidies were given out for the projects .
Overall , all these facilities would help to create a safer environment for the elders to live in .
During the aging process , it is easier for the elders to fall sick as we can see from the statistics shown by the Hospital Admission Rates by Age and Sex in 2007 .
The government has thus planned healthcare subsidies and benefits for the elderly .
This is important as not every elderly is able to pay for the heavy medical bills .
These healthcare subsidies would help to offload a certain percentage of the community hospital's fees .
There is one problem with this policy in thats there are quite a few criteria that need to be fulfilled before an elderly could enjoy the healthcare subsidies and benefits .
However , these criteria were meant to sieve out the elders who truly needed help as compared to those who were actually able to afford their own medical bills .
The Singapore government has put in place many measures to help ease the aging process .
The construction of the studio apartment , lift-upgrading project , extension of the retirement age and the implementation of healthcare subsidies and medical benefits have all gone a long way to help ease the aging process .
All these developments and policies have helped to ensure that Singapore will be prepared in both the short run and long run against the problems of an aging population .
However as the aging population in Singapore becomes bigger in size , more research and development policies will need to be carried out to slow down the rapid growth of the aging population instead of easing the aging process .
