One and a half decades ago , many countries had to support the aging population through ways like subsidies and public spending on health care services and facilities .
This has led to countries diverting some of the government revenues for the elderly .
As time passed , there is an increase in elderly in the society whereby 3 out of 10 people are elderly () .
The society finds it even more taxing to support the elderly in ways like subsidizing on healthcare or even facilities .
This leads to a continuous search for new research and developments/policies which can aid in today's aging population growth .
Emphasizing on the importance of filial obligation , encouraging greater productivity and improving in medical and science research are some of such examples .
Research generally targets the constellation of problems faced by the elderly , such as declining health - growing physically weak and feeble , emotional problems - living life in a shade of negativity , and social problems - feeling foreign and out of place in the society that they have once experienced .
However , the current research and development/policies unfortunately have provided more of a hindrance than an aid for the elderly .
An increase in emphasis on filial obligation can promote closer relationship within a family through policies such as rebates given to those living within certain proximity of their parents .
However , it does not cause the elderly to feel happier or even help to relieve the financial needs for medical treatment or basic necessities .
Firstly , working adults have a high cost of living which makes it difficult for them to pay for their parents' living expenses and at the same time afford their children's enrichment classes .
Moreover , working adults have very little time for themselves in this fast pace society , let alone for their parents .
As a result , the elderly often feel lonely as there is little or no interaction with their children .
They have no one to turn to when they need help , causing them to feel more negative .
Encouraging greater productivity among the non-elderly can increase the size of the economy and tax base .
This helps facilitate the public spending on the elderly .
For example ,  and attracting more foreign talents .
While these may seem to be plausible policies , they still cause the elderly to feel uneasy in the society .
Firstly , people would be pressured to accomplish more tasks in a given period which can lead to mental problems such as depression .
Elderly parents may end up looking after such working adults instead , imposing a heavier burden onto the elderly and government .
Furthermore , more elderly would be unemployed as they are unable to work as efficiently as the working-age adults which cause their social circle to shrink .
They will feel outcast by the society as they have the mentality that they are useless , and unable to contribute to the society .
There is an improvement delete highlighted and replace with 'in' medical and science research to cure illnesses which are usually associated with old age such as research on heart diseases and the invention of  artificial pancreas to replace any which fails with age .
However , these breakthroughs hardly ease the lives of the elderly .
Firstly , many low and middle income group elderly are unable to enjoy such medicines and healthcare treatments because such treatments tend to be long term care which can be very expensive for them to afford .
In addition , operations/ drugs have side effects which the elderly might not be able to recover from due to their failing health .
As a result , they might end up having more illnesses that can cause health to deteriorate .
Medical cost will be much higher than before .
In conclusion , the current research and development/policies has not quite fulfilled its aim of helping the elderly cope with their aging process .
The government is helping the general population of the elderly in terms of providing subsidies on research and development such as emphasizing on the importance of filial obligation , finding cures for illnesses that plague the elderly , and encouraging greater productivity .
All these ideas are good but in today's world , it is actually not feasible in helping the elderly to cope with aging process .
Very often , the elderly would be left feeling sad , weak and even outcast even with these current research and development .
The new research and development/policies in the future should be well thought so that they will provide aids for the elderly instead of hindrances for them to go through the last phase of their life .
Aging has been an issue in many countries and especially developed countries .
The declining workforce not only causes problems to the countries' economy but also brings along social problems as well .
Therefore , the governments shoulder the heavy responsibility of easing the aging process through helping individuals and in turn helping the public as a whole .
However , policies implemented by the Singapore government have mostly been unable to relieve the aging problems faced by the country due to their impracticality .
The Parent Maintenance Act is one of the many policies aimed at helping the elderly with their financial needs .
However , this policy does not solve the root of the problem , which is the erosion of filial piety value amongst the younger generation .
Being in an Asian country , many of the older generation have traditional views which hold that it is a family shame for an aged to be abandoned by their own children .
Furthermore , it would be emotionally traumatic to the old if they had to bring their children to court .
Thus , many would choose to suffer in silence than to sue their children .
In addition , implementing the Parent Maintenance Act does not benefit many of the illiterate aged as they have insufficient knowledge about it , yet they are the ones most in need of financial assistance as they would have little savings with their low-income due to their low education level .
A recent survey shows that the median annual income rises with the level of education of individuals (Digest of Education Statistics 2005) .
Also , the needs of an elderly are not only limited to financial ones but also emotional and physical ones as well .
Older people are more prone to having health problems .
Thus , care and concern from their family is just as important as money in order for them to survive .
The biggest issue is the willingness of the elderly in taking up the help rendered by the government .
Therefore , the policy is unfeasible and unable to fulfill the needs of the elderly .
Policies aimed at improving the employability of older workers may prove to be ineffective , thus creating economical problems apart from the existing social issues .
Retirement age of all Singaporeans was raised from 55 to 62 with effect from 1 January 1999 , as announced by the Ministry of Manpower .
Employers are also allowed to reduce the wages of employees beyond the age of 60 by up to ten percent .
Furthermore , the Central Provident Fund contribution by employers decreases with the age of the workers .
Some would argue that this policy would help older workers retain their job and get employment as the cost to employers is lowered .
However , employers may still not be willing to accept older workers due to their lower productivity .
As workers grow older , their health deteriorates and becomes less agile and thus less productive .
In the event where a company needs to lay off several staff , the older workers would usually be the ones retrenched as they would most likely draw the highest salaries .
Therefore , unemployment amongst elderly would be a common sight , increasing the number of financially dependent elderly .
The Government would have to tap into its budget to support the needy aged , resulting in a heavy burden on the working class .
Thus , these policies are ineffective without first changing the mindset of employers 
Evidently , the policies aimed at easing the aging process of a country have various aspects to be fulfilled in order for it to be effective .
Governments have to look into the economical and societal impacts an aging population brings along .
Apart from that , they have to satisfy the three different needs; i .e .
the financial , social and emotional needs of the elderly .
If any one of these aspects is compromised , Singapore would risk losing her foothold in this competitive world .
Scholars argue that it is more worthwhile to spend on other areas of development in a country such as defense , education , tourism and technology .
In Singapore , as well , emphasis is placed on these other areas .
For instance , in a recent Business Times article , it was mentioned that "government spending on Infocomm technology is set to rise 8%"delete full stop .
(2009 , February 19delete close bracket The Business insert clasoe bracket after Times .
Such development is indispensable for a country to survive in a rapidly advancing world .
If the government has to spend on the aged , fewer funds will be channeled into these areas , which is a cause for concern .
It may be a better decision to spend on the young as there are higher odds of return in this investment .
The young are more productive and equipped with updated skills .
The elderly are deemed to be less valuable to the society as they are weak and dependent on others .
An ageing population may cause a low productivity rate as seen by the Annual Growth in Labour Productivity figure; currently at: -7 .8% .
(2008 , {www .singstat .gov .sg}[HYPERLINK: http://www .singstat .gov .sg])
It is also our duty to take care of the aged before acknowledging our society as an ethical one .
In fact , counsellors have observed an increasing trend of the elderly living alone or being left under the care of charities or old folks' homes by their families (The New Paper , 2009) .
In such situations , the government has to play a part to provide for and protect the aged .
Also considering that the elderly had contributed to society during their working years , there is a moral responsibility on the government to pay them back .
It is not always necessary to measure everything in dollars and cents , and we must recognize that the aging process is not a simple one and accentuate on the development of 'elderly-friendly' facilities to ease the aging process for them .
An aging population may prove costly to the society and economy if the country fails to prepare for the situation .
Public spending on the aged is therefore deemed necessary to avoid such a crisis .
Despite the drawbacks , an aging population is linked closely to the development of Singapore .
The issue is also set to worsen in the future considering the low birth rate .
Nevertheless with proper planning , Singapore is currently handling the situation very well without compromising on the other areas of development .
Furthermore , with an increasing emphasis on filial piety , the government is able to ensure that the aged are taken care of even as they concentrate on defence , education , tourism and even the needy who require aid and are all in all vital to the growth of Singapore as a nation .
Thomas Love Peacock (1786-1866) once said , "The waste of plenty is the resource of scarcity" .
This quotation implies to everyone , including the government to make a wise decision when allocating limited resources in order to reduce further , unnecessary wastage .
There is much concern about the government's decision to allot a huge sum of the national budget on the elderly as it is uncertain on whether the investment on the aged will attribute or be to the country's development .
The best alternative is therefore to make a more sizeable investment by limiting the spending on the aged and divert the budget to other areas of the country's development .
The present paradigm of care for the elderly is a partnership between the government , community and family .
However , children often forgo their responsibilities to care for their parents and often point the thrust to the government because they believe their parents had gotten everything from the government .
Besides , children tend to abuse their parents' privileges allotted by the government by maximizing the usage of those privileges even though it is unnecessary .
For an example , elderly with little ailment often seek the best treatment as they are provided with either free or subsidized treatments .
Thus , those with chronic ailments are unable to seek the proper treatment they are supposed to get .
If the public spending is limited , children will have to send their parents for the appropriate level of  treatment and this will reduce wastage and increase efficiency in quality of care at the same time .
Thus , judging from the explanation , it is convincing to limit the public spending on the elderly .
Government should divert the budget initially allocated for elderly to the Research and Development (R&D) sector instead .
Investment especially in enhancing the medical research will make everyone better off and also indirectly help the elderly in a way .
Since elderly are prone to chronic ailments such as renal disease or heart failure , medical research will be able to produce new drugs and more flexible treatments for them .
This will eventually increase the life span not only for the elderly , but also for the other generations .
Besides , investment in R&D will be able to develop new technologies and new sectors will be introduced to collaborate with the usage of the technologies .
More job opportunities will be provided and everyone will be able to live a higher standard of living .
Thus , diverting the budget from the elderly to R&D will provide mutual advantage for both the elderly and  economic development .
The Government should invest more in the current education of the youth instead of investing the budget in the elderly .
This is mainly because youth are more progressive towards economic development in comparison to the elderly .
Thus , the opportunity cost to invest in the education is lower than to invest on the elderly .
Besides , moral value especially to make the children beholden to their parents can be inculcated by introducing the appropriate modules in their education .
This will help the elderly indirectly as the children are trained to embrace the Eastern value to respect and take care of their parents .
Investment in education will also lead to development in the country as education serves as a platform for further development in all other sectors such as R&D and Health .
Thus , such investment will definitely pay off in the future economic growth .
In view of providing mutual advantage to both elderly and economic development , it is best for the government to revise  its budget allocation so that the right proportion of budget is divided wisely among the ministries in the country .
Elderly should not be granted a lump sum but instead the fund should be diverted to other areas which will lead to future economic growth .
This is because administrating the budget to the elderly is only a one-way benefit but if the budget is allocated to other areas such as Education and R&D , everyone including the elderly can enjoy the advantage .
What is therefore needed is both a wise policy planning and a closer look at how the allocation will influence our future and society as a whole .
Statistics have shown that by 2030 , 20% of the population will be aged 65 and above (AoA 2009) .
This has raised concerns about the issue of our ageing population and how we could allocate our limited resources efficiently .
During the recent years , the increasing competition between the old and other groups in  society for scarce resources has been on the political agenda of many countries  .
How much public spending should the aged receive is a widely debatable topic .
Public spending should be channeled into developing infrastructure that caters to the needs of the aged , subsidies to lighten the financial burden of the medical bills of the aged and also activities to help bridge the elderly and society .
Ideally , there should be no restrictions to how much resource is diverted to the elderly .
However , due to practical reasons , spending needs to be limited .
Many may argue that public spending on the aged should not be restricted .
Restriction on the public spending may raise ethical debates; after all we have the responsibility of taking care of the aged to credit them for past contributions to society .
Although we have the obligation to look after the elderly , we have to limit the public spending on the elderly .
This is because it might result in detrimental social problems in the long run as other more beneficial developments might inevitably be neglected in the process .
Public funds could be channeled into education , military and other vital sectors of the economy , instead of to the aged .
These sectors may be critical to the nation's progress .
Hence with society's interest in mind , we should limit public spending on the aged so as to not impede the country's economic growth .
The changing demography of the population has led to many concerns regarding the large health expenses on the aged .
We tend to need more health care as we age , in addition to this , medical advancement has led to  rising health care cost , these have led to an increased pressure on the nation's budget .
The government cannot afford to bear the huge cost of public spending on the aged , as it would drain  government resources .
If we fail to limit  public spending on the aged , the pressure is likely to have an effect on public spending for other priorities , and also affect economic growth .
Moreover , from a pragmatic point of view , public spending on the aged would yield little or no returns .
Public spendings on the aged may be beneficial for the society's welfare in the short run; however , it might incur a huge cost on the economy in the future .
If we reasonably limit the spendings on the elderly , we could divert it to other investments , such as education and development of infrastructure , which improve the nation's competitiveness and global position , it would yield long-term returns and even generate revenue .
The products of the investment could then be used as public spending for the aged .
Public spending could be diverted to other areas , which could in turn sustain the aged in the future .
Therefore it is critical that we limit government spending on the aged now .
In conclusion , public spendings on the elderly should be limited due to the social problems which may arise from the lack of limited resources , the huge cost of the these public spending and the sustainability of the spendings .
We should not shortchange other groups of society and other developments of the nation , for the needs of the elderly .
Nonetheless , we must not fail to help the aged , but we could prioritize the expenditure such that other developments are not shortchanged in this process .
The community should do its part to help the elderly as well , after all the well being of the aged is our responsibility .
Charities such as the Community Chest can help to reach out to the elderly and hence lightening the financial load of the aged .
Individuals should fulfill their filial obligations and take care of their elderly parents or relatives .
No doubt , countries  are working on policies that can help to ease the aging process .
However , for policy makers their main objective is to think of policies and developments which can help the country in expansion or to ensure that it will not hinder economic growth .
In order for a country's expansion , policy makers are working on developments that can provide a valuable "public product" such as education and infrastructure .
The development of the education sector will enable  further generations to be more educated and to possess a higher level of skills .
Next , development on the infrastructure will attract more foreign investors to set up companies in the country .
With development in both education and infrastructure , foreign investors will choose to set up their companies in a country with a pool of talents and with great infrastructure with this it can boost  the country's economy .
Nevertheless working policies and development to assist the aged can help with the The Country's expansion .
This can be achieve by  placing emphasis  in increasing and raising more productive children in  futurer generations as  "by raising more productive children so that the cost burden is spread over a larger and more affluent future generation" (Paterson , 2001) .
Raising and increasing productive children not only can , attract foreign investors to invest in a country with pool of talents and the burden of looking after the aged population is being spread out with prosperous further generations .
As such , a win- win situation can be achieved as we not only ease the aged population but also assist in country expansion .
Next , advancement in technological tools is required to ensure the sustainability of the health care system .
These technological tools are developed to make life of the aged easier , less stressful and even healthier for them to continue living independently .
For example , monitoring systems are currently researched to allow the aged to remain in their homes longer even if they are being treated with chronic diseases , rather than moving them into a nursing home which may incur more costs .
Lastly , research in life science areas has shown ways  prolonging human life and to prevent illness .
A recent research shows that lighter meals may prolong human life by having calories-restricted diets .
Calorie restricted diets can induce a slowdown of the aging process and  increases survival , resistance to diseases , prevents brain deterioration and lastly reduces muscle loss .
additional research states , that oxidative stress may not help prolong life as oxidative stress has links with aging , cancer and other disease .
Researchers have suggests minimum exposure to oxidative conditions actually offer protection from acute doses .
With  research and advancement in life sciences to prolong human life and prevention of illness can help to reduce the fiscal costs on heath care .
In conclusion , research , development and policies that help to ease the aging process is relatively important .
For instance , increasing and raising productive children not only can reduce the t burden  but also  attract foreign investors to invest in the country with a pool of talent .
Secondly , technology advancement will enable the aged to live independently even if they suffer with chronic diseases and their children can spend more time to focus on their work .
Lastly , research in life sciences to prolong life can help to reduce the fiscal costs on heath care and prevent illness .
Therefore , we must pay attention  on current research , development and policies to ease the aging process .

A Graying World .
Harvard International Review , 66 .
The dawn of the twenty-first century has not slowed down the technological progress that man has been pursuing for so many decades .
New products and innovations are produced by the day .
These advances in technology have , most importantly , eased the lives of our aged citizens .
With the world consisting of an ever expanding aged population , there has been a greater necessity for simple household appliances that can be used by the aged and the disabled .
In addition , social policies are constantly evolving and changing , with some newly implemented policies greatly easing the aging process of the elderly .
Researches in economics have also resulted in new policies , as will be discussed below .
The policy that resulted from economical research stated that the size of today's economy and tax base could be increased by encouraging the inflow of employable immigrants .
This fact is proving to be false .
For it must be kept in mind that these immigrants will also grow old and require pensions some day .
Furthermore , evidence shows that there is no relationship between immigration and economic growth whatsoever .
This , therefore , does not solve the problem of the present , but worsens future prospects too .
On another note , some social policies may not be beneficial in the long term .
For instance , the policy that advocates late retirement means that the working period of citizens is extended beyond the usual age of 55 and 60 .
Although it aims for the greater good , by providing the elderly with greater self sufficiency , it is more harmful in the long term because the most critical issue here is the health of the elderly  .
They are often unable to withstand high stress of the mind and the body that these work require and fall ill frequently .
The policy of passing laws that make it a must for children to look after their elderly parents is also much speculated over .
I feel that this is not the correct approach to the problem .
Taking care of one's parents is not a straightforward transaction , like paying one's taxes .
Instead it is one which also involves time and constant emotional attention .
This does not ease the problems of the aged or their children who are coping with the rising prices of goods and services and  who must care for their children  .
Hence , the banes of today's new policies .
However , it is unquestionable that technology has contributed on a massive scale in helping the aged .
The SANYO technical review reveals the existence of "systems that remind the elderly person to take their medicine; systems that detect when he/she is in the room , so that electricity costs can be minimised .
There are systems that will assist you in various day to day activities without the presence of another person including washing oneself , dressing up and using theoilet .
Another invention is a telephone that utilises voice speed control technology .
This technology allows the aged person to slow down the speed at which the person on the other side is speaking ."
This is especially useful for the older citizens , for one's senses become less acute with age , and they cannot comprehend what others are saying , at the rate at which they are speaking .
"The medical alert system is another good example .
This system is set up in the aged person's house and consists of a speaker that is able to know where you are in the house , and guides you simply by tracking the signals emanated by the wristlet you wear on your hand ."
In addition , it alerts the health authorities and your closest relatives in the occasion of an emergency .
It is particularly useful for those who are old and who live alone .
The possibilities of technology are endless .
In addition , I am an advocate of the social policy that deems it necessary for all citizens to put aside a small percentage of their monthly salary , during the working period of their lives .
For this seems to be a rather effective policy , with the value-added element of being able to lighten the economic burden supported by the government  .
It consequently does ease the aging process , for the elderly  need not be at the mercy of others to obtain full medical care and other comforts .
Another policy suggests that money be invested in the educational system , so that more productive children are raised , "resulting in a larger and more affluent future generation" (Peter Peterson , 2001) .
I feel that this is the key solution to easing the aging process , for a more productive younger generation means that all costs required to keep the aged healthy and comfortable can be borne by this efficient younger workforce .
Hence , the progress of the world in aspects of technology , economy and social policies have by far proven to be beneficial to the elderly  of today's society .
It has made their life after retirement one of relaxation , with comforts close at hand ,  .
It has made them more independent from others , and ceased to be seen as a burden in the eyes of their children and society .
Progress will always have its hindrances and flaws , but progress is always the correct path to success .

The trend of an ageing population is here to stay .
At present 7% of Singapore's population is over the age of 65; however , by 2030 this will increase to 19% (Inter-Ministerial Committee on Aging Report 1999) .This is especially so for developed countries where people are living longer and are less willing to give birth due to the high costs of living .
Therefore , as much as other problems , mainly those dealing with the economy , may seem to demand and need more immediate attention , the ageing population issue cannot be ignored and the spending on this area should not be reduced in order for a a majority of the population to benefit .
Some people may argue that elderly dependency should be reduced through various means  (Peterson , 2001) to make way for other developments in other areas , especially the economic sector .
In lieu with the current economic crisis , many have found themselves unemployed or retrenched and are finding it difficult to survive , particularly those who live on credit or have a household to provide for .
Even with various upgrading schemes such as the Skills Programme for Upgrading and Resilience (SPUR) , it is still difficult for the economy to regain its vigour to the state before the economic crisis .
This is due to the lack of job opportunities and not because of the lack of proper skills among workers .
Therefore , more budget should be channeled to the economic sector to boost the country's economic situation .
Indeed , the above issue warrants a substantial amount of concern .
However , this does not affect majority of the population .
In addition , the people who belong to the working class are not the ones who are most vulnerable to the economic crisis .
The elderly are the more vulnerable group in this situation due to the fact that they are not capable of generating income to provide for themselves .
This is attributed to the fact that employers are constantly seeking people with higher productivity .
Besides , stressing on filial piety at this point in time is not going to be of any help since the working adults would probably be busy fending for themselves .
Hence , the government should not reduce public spending in this area to protect the vulnerability of the aged in terms of health care cost and enabling them to be self-sufficient through elder-friendly facilities in the housing districts .
Furthermore , there is also a need to continue to provide such support to the elderly for the government to retain support and instill a sense of belonging amongst the citizens to  prevent people from migrating .
There is an increasing trend of young people migrating to countries such as Australia and Canada due to lower stress levels and also the welfare benefits available for the aged .
At this rate , the country is going to lose a large pool of talented people since those who migrate overseas are usually more affluent and better educated .
As much as the policies being implemented currently are able to attract foreign talent to become citizens of Singapore , native Singaporeans still seem to be unsatisfied .
The current net migration rate stands at 5 .82 migrant(s)/1 ,000 population ) .
This means that there are more people entering than leaving the country .
Even so , this figure is attributed by the influx of foreign talent .
This implies that more and more Singaporeans are moving out of the country than before .
Thus , in order to keep her citizens in the country , welfare benefits have to be maintained or even increased such that people do not turn to foreign lands to enjoy their retirement .
In a nutshell , government  spending on elderly should not be reduced as it would potentially be unfavourable especially since the current aging trend involves the "baby boomers" , a substantial amount of people .
In fact , there should be an increase in such spending as the aging trend is set to increase in the future .
This is a crucial issue and not one that can be ignored .
To add on , the government has not been neglecting other sectors but instead , it is trying its best to make economic conditions more favourable for the country to prosper .
Hence , public spending for the elderly should not be reduced .
Public spending on the aged should not be limited although the money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
Tremendous demographic changes in aging will create many unprecedented problems .
An ageing population does not cause problems only in wealthy and developed countries such as the USA Japan and Singapore , but it is also faced by developing countries such as China and Thailand as well .
Therefore , solutions that will help to ease the aging process are much needed .
If the public spending on the solutions are limited , thus effects of these solutions will not be able to meet our expectations .
First of all , we must understand that a country is built by its people's hard work and effort .
The significant contributions of the aged towards a country's infrastructure , economics , and many other things should not be forgotten .
The younger generation should be grateful to their senior citizen's contribution because the prosperity of today's country is built by the older generation when they are young .
Although now the people who strive for our country are aging and could hardly contribute to the country , still , we should always remember their contributions and take good care of them when they need help .
Senior citizens should be regarded as an asset rather than a liability to a country .
Frequently , we will need to heed advice from them because they have more experience than us .
For example , Mr Lee Kuan Yew , the Minister Mentor of Singapore , who always gives advice to The Singaporean Government .
Hence , the welfare of the aged must be assured .
Public spending on the aged such as health care should not be limited .
In fact , the aged are more vulnerable to fall sick than young people as their immune systems are degenerating .
Peterson (2001) has mentioned that healthcare  once meant an occasional visit to the doctor , but it has today become a lifelong process .
Furthermore , their declining productivity has also lessened their income .
So governments should aid them .
For instance , The Government can subsidize their medical expense so that the aged can have lower rates on health care spending .
This will definitely benefit the aged because with the current increasing health care cost , the medical bills are always shocking .
As a result , the aged with low income are usually reluctant to see a doctor when they are not feeling well .
As a consequence , an illness may not be discovered at an early stage and will only be discovered when it becomes severe .
However , if the illness has became too severe , it might be life threatening and it will be much more expensive to cure it .
Next , public spending on pension should not be decreased .
As we all know , the senior citizen is one of the groups with the lowestt income .
More than that , some senior citizens are retired or unable to work .
Even if they work , their meager income is insufficient to support themselves , especially with the high inflation rates now .
It follows that we often hear that the aged are living in poverty .
Therefore , if they are in need of help , why not just help them ?
After all , they are the ones who brought our country to prosperity .
It is perfectly right that we ought to ensure their living quality in return .
On the contrary , the increase in public spending on the aged by the government will increase the fiscal budget .
This will inevitably increase the government's load .
Therefore , the spending in other essential areas such as infrastructure , financial , and education will have to be cut down .
The cut down of spending in these essential areas might hinder the growth of a country .
Considering these important factors , many people will eventually support that public spending on the aged should be limited .
However , in my opinion , every choice we make will incur some cost , which means something has to be given up in order to attain the objective we want .
So , I think with proper planning on the spending by the government , we should be able to meet the balance between public spending on the aged and other essential spending .
In conclusion , the public spending on the aged should not be limited because it is as important as other areas of the country's development .
The country's budget is generated through taxpayers' contributions and returns on investments made .
At present , a substantial amount is spent on the elderly every year through direct and indirect ways , such as giving out subsidies or building elderly-friendly infrastructure .
This compromises spending that could be used  , namely on education , health care and creating economic growth .
Public spending on the aged , should thus be limited in a country , for the money can be used to further enhance societal growth as a whole , and not just focus solely on this particular age group .
Health care should be one of the government's top priority as well .
As people get wealthier , their waistlines get bigger as well .
Obesity , high cholesterol levels and diabetes are diseases that increased in the last century due to greater wealth and easier access to unhealthy diets and lifestyles .
These health problems will inevitably affect the productivity of these workers , and the time and resources spent to remedy them are costly , both to the individual and the country .
Thus , it is more cost-effective and sensible that we should divert our budget towards prevention and treatment of patients .
Money can be spent on educational messages and guidelines on prevention of contracting diseases , coupled with subsidies for health care providers and medication .
Certainly , such spending will benefit the elderly , but it should not be exclusive to them , for there are other age groups who require assistance in this sector as well .
Economic growth is crucial to any country .
It ensures the majority of the population finds employment and inflation stays under control .
A country with a flourishing economy finds investors more willing to invest there and the people stand to enjoy the range and variety of material comforts that a thriving market economy is able to provide .
The government can attract foreign investment ventures and increase the competitive edge of firms by reducing tax and rent abatement .
The government can also create a more competitive labour force without compromising their wage level .
This can be done through upgrading the skills of our workforce .
For instance , the Skills Programme for Upgrading and Resilience (SPUR) programme introduced in Singapore enhances its workforce's abilities to compete in the global market , Another option is to allocate part of the budget to Research and Development for local institutes to attract and develop the best talents .
This can be exemplified by the efforts the Singapore government had been making to finance the Agency for Science , Technology and Research (A*STAR) .
All these evidence show how money can be effectively diverted towards generating greater economic growth .
Proponents of substantial public spending on the aging population issue will argue that the problem will escalate due to a declining birth rate , resulting in a proportionately larger population of elderly in the world .
Thus , we should solve the problem we are facing now , rather than allocate resources to other areas .
However , is it not short-sighted if we are to solve only the problems we can see now , rather than investing in and conceiving possibilities to solve the problem fully ?
We definitely have to allocate resources towards this growing issue of a greying population , but we should limit the spending to only what is sufficiently necessary , and not to the extent that it restricts the society with a large financial burden .
Instead , we should allocate use of the resources towards betterment of the society , bringing up ideas and opportunities that can possibly solve this problem eventually .
Recent studies have  shown that Singapore is becoming one of the fastest aging populations in the world (Bryan , 2008) .
The elderly people are already amounting to a quarter of the population in Singapore .
Therefore , the rapidly aging population is a problem that the government needs to address .
There is a concern regarding the rising health and living costs which will become a risk to economic growth and social security .
What is then needed is that the public expenditure towards the needs of the aging population should be carefully looked into instead of diverting it to the country's development .
Firstly , slow population growth results in an increased  burden for children in having  to take care of their parents (Peterson , 2001) .
For example , when  families have an average of one child instead of two or three children , the single  child will have the task of taking care of his or her family in the future .
Elderly people always tend to depend a lot on their children and it results in a strain in family relationship .
The rising health care costs make it even tough for the child to cope with it and some are not willing to support their parents .
The elderly people will then need to support themselves which is impossible without the government's help .
Secondly , there is a scheme called the Central Provident Fund (CPF) , which is to make Singaporeans start saving when they are young , but it is not enough for them to survive with having CPF alone .
Although the government enforces individual saving through CPF , not every person will benefit from it .
Self-employed people do not have CPF as they are not working under an employer , so the employees and employers do not contribute part of the employees' salary to the CPF .
Many elderly people do not have much CPF left as they have used it to pay for their house or child's education .
This causes them to not have much savings when they grow old .
Lastly , the elderly tend to have different needs and behaviours to that of younger people .
Older people tend to work and save less and also require more health care .
In many countries , they depend on retirement pension to live through their remaining years .
Therefore , it is difficult to cut down on health or retirement benefits , as the aging population is becoming so serious .
Those people aged 70 and above have even weaker health than people aged 50 to 70 .
They need money to support their increased health care costs because they have already used up their savings .
As a result , they will place further demand on government funds .
At this point , one may wonder if the aging population is the most important issue to take note of .
However , the Country's development is also a matter that Singapore needs to be concerned about .
The country's trade , finance , transport , sports and education are key factors to drive a country's economy which cannot be neglected .
Having to maintain good trade relationships with  other countries such as having free tax and levy on imports and exports will help to grow the economy and benefit the people of Singapore .
Spending on education will help to nurture the people to have a good education from young and make Singapore a good place to seek education .
Development in sports such as hosting the Youth Olympic Games will be a great boost to the tourism sector as the Games is expected to generate a minimum of more than 150 ,000 visitors per night for Singapore (Patwant Singh , 2008) .
All of this will boost the county's economy .
Singapore is transforming into an aging society .
The challenge is to encourage healthy and productive life for the the ageing population and find ways for them to contribute more to the society so that they can play a valuable role in the country .
The government should not use aging population as a reason to limit public spending as they always encourage productive and healthy living for the elderly people .
They are still very important to the country and the government must play a part to take care of them .
Demography is shifting today .
People are having fewer children and living longer .
By 2050 , our median age would increase from 36 years to 56 .
Singapore would be among the demographically oldest countries in the world and there will be fewer working adults looking after more aged dependents .
The issue of an ageing population should be taken seriously , and more has to be put in place in addressing the issue .
As such , judging from Singapore's current demography , the an aging population will be a long term situation .
Despite the government's constant effort in introducing and crafting attractive policies and benefits to her people , the bid to boost child bearing still remains bleak .
Thus , public spending on the aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development such as Education and Architecture , so as to focus on the long term situation .
First of all , money can be diverted to Singapore's education system so as to increase the productivity of the younger generation to acquire sufficient wealth for the future f (Peterson , 2001) .
It is essential to build on the development of the country's future - the younger generation - since the aged rely on the young and the young rely on the younger when old .
Clearly , a cycle is formed .
Raising the productivity of children via education can take place in the form of meeting the different needs and learning capabilities of them .
This includes reducing the ratio of the number of students to a single teacher , allowing the teacher to better focus his attention on the students .
Also , the government can direct more technological resources to schools so as to better equip the younger generation for a technological-edged world , improving their economical worth .
In addition , the government can instill filial obligation (Peterson , 2001) or family values and encourage early marriage by diverting money in crafting new programmes via the education system .
These ensure while the younger generation is able to contribute economically , they do not neglect the filial obligation towards the aged and at the same time raise the fertility level .
Economically , by raising the productivity of the children via diverting more money to the education system , it increases the younger generation's opportunity to increase their economic worth , and hence their future income .
Since the government's ability to provide social and welfare services for the aged is based on the tax revenue gained , diverting money to Singapore's education system would indirectly aid the aged and improve the aging population in the long run .
Secondly , money can be diverted to Singapore's architectural developments in terms of increasing the accessibility of physical facilities for the aged .
By improvising on Singapore's physical infrastructure , it not only benefits the current generation of the elderly , but also future generations in time to come .
This is considered a long term investment by the government .
One of the most significant improvisations is the lift upgrading programme .
New lifts are being installed in both new and old public housing blocks so that it now stops on every floor instead of the old system , which only stops on every third or fourth floor .
Other than the lift upgrading programme , the Singapore government can direct more money into enabling housing estates to be barrier-free .
The refurbishment is clearly beneficial as recently residents at Nee Soon South were rejoicing about the fully equipped barrier-free access they are enjoying at Khatib MRT station .
Before work on the two new ramps began , it was a chore for the estate's elderly folks to climb the stairs to get to the station .
Drawing from these two examples , money should be diverted to Singapore's architecture developments as it acts as a long term investment the government has towards the issue of aging population .
However some may argue that public spending should not be limited .
This is because it does not address the current and impending situation of the aging population , and at the same time the aged are the most vulnerable in the society .
Hence the government should do more to help , instead of cutting down on the resources .
The aged not only require financial support , because of their inability to sustain themselves , but they also require emotional and social support .
Many social agencies in Singapore run on the basis of government and public funding .
If the government is to cut back on its funding , social agencies will face difficulties in sustaining their operation , not to mention the support they are able to provide for the aged .
In contrast , I feel that in Singapore's context , limiting public spending and diverting money to the country's Education & Architecture in order to address the long term aging population issue is viable .
This is due to the policies that the Singapore's government has put in place , before the aging population surfaced .
The two most significant polices are , the Central Provident Fund (CPF) and home ownership .
CPF has required people to save up for their retirement , and hence old age , while home ownership has allowed at least a basic shelter and home sanitations for the aged .
Thus , the Singapore government has provided a safety-net in which the aged can fall back on while diverting money to other areas of development .
In conclusion , in Singapore , limiting public spending to divert money to other areas of the country's development is a feasible option to address the long term aging population issue .
This is largely due to the compulsory legislations that are enforced upon by the government .
At the same time , cutting back on public spending does not equate to cutting off public spending , with careful planning and considerations , there can still be efficient allocation of money in aiding the aged .
Diverting money to Education and Architectural development will prove to be beneficial for the aged and the generations to come .
Since the aging population will be a long-standing issue , it is time the government put in place long term measures .
Therefore , public spending should be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
Every year , governments seriously consider  the allocation of their limited public spending .
In Singapore's Financial Year 2009 , the expenditures allocated had been revised and redistributed .
They are social development (41 .5%) , security and external relations (34 .3%) , economic development (20 .4%) and government administration (4 .0%) (Ministry of Finance , 2009) .
One of the reasons why social development has the highest percentage is because governments are facing the problems of an aging population and are looking for ways to resolve them .
However , other than directly diverting the money on the aged , there are other ways to resolve these issues .
Majority of the public spending should be directed to areas that can assist in the country's developments such as the improving of the education system and creating of more job opportunities , so substantially , lesser public spending on the aged should be set aside .
However , some have argued that public spending should not be limited to the aged .
Some aging issues included economic reduction and workforce inefficiency (Peterson , 2001) .
With these rising issues , there is an urgent need to pump in more money for this group of needy people .
For instance , Singapore should consider subsidizing more of the costly medical bills for the aged .
When one gets old , one tends to have poorer health .
This results in the need to undergo several medical treatments .
Consequently , majority of the savings will be directed to the payment of their medical treatments .
This further strains their financial burden if they still have children who are depending on them .
Furthermore , the elderly tend to be less efficient than the younger working adults .
As a result , companies are not willing to offer a higher salary rate even if they manage to secure a job .
Hence , it is vital that the Government does its part by diverting more of its spending to help the aged .
Although these issues can be address by not limiting the public spending , there are still other ways to resolve them by diverting the money to another area - improvement in the education system .
Education prepares the younger generations for the future workforce , making them more affluent and teaching them to achieve success .
In addition , it emphasizes the importance of filial piety which encourages children to have the full responsibilities to take care of their aged parents when they grow up .
The provision of a higher standard of education also encourages the children to be more independent for their own survival in the future .
It also creates a "work more and save more" mindset so as to reduce government dependency .
Most importantly , improving the education system helps in developing the country socially and economically , so diverting the money to this area is a more effective and efficient way to help the aged indirectly .
Secondly , creating more job opportunities is another area whereby money should be diverted to .
In order to reduce the need for the aged to fully depend on the government , the government should encourage the aged to support themselves instead .
It is impossible to support them in the long- run as there are many other areas of concerns which the government needs to look into as well .
Hence , with the creation of more jobs , the government can assist the aged to secure a job and allow them to support themselves , on the condition that they are still  healthy  .
It also allows the younger generations to easily secure a job and support their aged parents independently .
All these promote social and economic developments of a country too .
Looking ahead , jobs creation is a more resourceful way in developing a country with its public spending .
With regards to all the points mentioned , it is concluded that public spending on the aged should be limited .
The idea of limiting the spending on the aged and diverting the money to the improving of the education system and creating of more job opportunities is to prevent the over-reliance of the aged on the government , eliminating the wrong perception of "I will still survive with this 'free' money from the government" .
Therefore , since the improvement of education system and creation of more jobs bring about more long-term benefits than having an unlimited public spending on the aged , money should be diverted to these areas as part of the country's developments which eventually , will impact the aged positively .
* "To a large extent , current research and development/policies have helped to ease the aging process ."
Do you agree ?
Discuss this statement in relation to your particular field of study or interest (e .g .
economics , science , medicine , social policy , architecture , psychology , technological inventions) .
N .B You can draw examples from more than one field of study or interest .
However , your essay should demonstrate in-depth analysis .
As a result of the growing aging population , public spending on the aged has increased in an attempt to minimize the negative impacts of a fast aging population .
Such a strategy translates into increasing pressure on national budgets and economies which could be used in other areas of the country's development .
Some have argued that public spending on the aged is redundant as the productivity and contribution of the aged to the nation is questionable .
Thus , public spending on the aged should be diverted to other areas of the country's development due to the potential fruitful returns from these investments .
However , the assumption that the aged are non productive is untrue due to the increasing emphasis on healthcare .
This has has allowed the aged to remain healthy , continue working and remain productive despite their age .
Therefore , public spending on the aged is crucial in ensuring the continued productivity of the aged which in turn benefits the country .
Firstly , the high medical and healthcare service fees can "substantially drain the resources of many elderly" (Friedland , & Summer , 2005 , p .17) .
Without healthcare benefits for the aged such as subsidized medical fees , most elderly are unlikely to afford the high medical expenses incurred .
Despite having insurance coverage , it is still possible that  medical bills are insufficiently covered .
As a result , the health of the elderly can deteriorate as they may not seek treatment due to the inability to pay the medical bills .
The economy in turn suffers due to the threats on the productivity of the aged .
Therefore , the government should not neglect  healthcare benefits for the aged as the consequence is undesirable .
Secondly , a fast aging population would mean that "growing numbers of elderly persons are supported by relatively fewer younger persons" (Peterson , 2001 , p . 7) .
This indicates a lack of resources , whether monetary or non monetary to support the large numbers of elderly .
Moreover , the younger generations will come under heavy pressure due to the disparity ratio support of the aged .
To lighten this pressure , public spending such as healthcare benefits can help lighten the financial burden faced by the younger generation .
Besides , it brings us back to the aspect of high medical expenditures which the younger generations are probably unable to afford as well .
An example would be an only son having to support his aging parents and elderly grandparents .
He is likely to face financial constraints due to  high medical expenditures .
To solve this problem , public spending on the aged can provide an alternative resource to support the aged which therefore lightens the burden of the younger generations .
In addition ,  additional healthcare resources can improve the health of the elderly hence , enhancing the productivity of the aged .
Thirdly , the shrinking ratio of younger generations in the future indicates the importance of elderly remaining productive to the economy .
Generally , it is assumed that the young should support the elderly .
The younger generation should remain in the workforce while the elderly tend to retire at a stipulated age .
However , this scenario may change in the future due to the lack of human resources in the job market .
To prevent the disruption of the labour market , the elderly are likely to remain in the work force in the near future .
Thus , an elderly friendly environment is essential to enhance the efficiency of the work force .
As the country ultimately benefits from the productivity of the aged , it is rational for the government to utilise public spending on the aged .
Therefore ,  public spending on the aged is as crucial as other areas of a country's development .
The aging process has indeed become a phenomenon in Singapore .
This is mainly due to a shift in the country's population .
The government has responded to this issue by establishing policies and programs to manage the aging process .
Most of the policies aim to reduce the problems associated with an aging population .
One crucial problem is the increase in government expenditure for the aging population which in turn strains the future working population .
Although some policies do facilitate in reducing the expenditure towards the elderly to a certain extent , it may still prove to be insufficient in easing the aging process .
One segment of policies that the government has implemented is to increase the overall fertility rate of Singapore .
These policies aim to produce a higher rate of productive children for the future workforce .
They will be the ones to support the large number of the future aging population .
However , the policies have proven to be ineffective (Wong & Yeoh , 2003) .
For example , the Baby Bonus Scheme which was introduced in April 1 , 2001 , was established to reduce the financial costs of raising children by providing cash grants .
The cash grants can be used to pay for child care , preschool and healthcare expenses .
The scheme caused an adverse effect as it only focused on the explicit costs .
The government failed to include the implicit costs of raising children .
Some of which include giving up one's career to take care of one'sr children .
Therefore , with the  , many prefer to establish their careers before having children .
The cost of raising children has also risen in the past years due to the need to enroll them in numerous programs .
Parents in this modern society want their children to be equipped with numerous  skills to prepare them for the future workforce .
Another policy implemented by the government involves providing for oneself through life-long savings .
This policy is implemented through the Central Provident Fund , CPF scheme .
The CPF scheme is a compulsory savings meant to meet one's basic living needs upon retirement .
Under the CPF scheme , the Medisave scheme is developed to lessen the impact of medical and hospitalization expenses .
However , the Medisave scheme has proven to be insufficient because medical expenses for the elderly are simply so high that people's Medisave savings can be used up within one week (Popatlal , 2009) .
Moreover , with longer life expectancy , the Medisave savings may not be adequate .
This problem becomes worse if the elderly do not have any children or children who choose to neglect their responsibilities to support their elder's healthcare finances .
Thus the National Housing policies were introduced to encourage filial responsibilities of the adult children .
However , it has been proven to be unsuccessful .
This may be due to the change in culture and values of the modern adult generation since they prefer to live further from their parents .
On the other hand , housing policies may have the opposite effect as some couples may misuse the policy by using the grant for their own benefit .
One example of a housing policy that has proven to be unsuccessful is the Multi-Tier Family Housing Scheme which encourages parents and married children to live together (Hill and Kwen , 1995) .
Nevertheless , some developments that the government has implemented do ease the aging process .
The current development of new community hospitals which link up with the main hospitals is an example of a measure that will ease the aging process .
Community hospitals are built to allow the elderly patients , usually with chronic illnesses , to recover with the assistance of a professional medical team but at a lower cost .
This will reduce medical expenses for the elderly .
In addition to that , community hospitals will free up beds in the main hospitals for acute illnesses .
Easing the aging process by establishing policies that solve explicit problems has proved to be inadequate .
These policies may be useful only as a short-term solution .
The government may need to consider the social changes and needs of the younger population to improve the aging process on a long-term basis .
This may include the impact of the rise in living expenses and the influences of  western culture .
Without considering these social changes , the aging process may increase government expenditure and the burden of the future workforce generation .

Robert B . Friedland and laura Summer , Demography Is Not Destiny , Revisited .
Center on Aging Society , Georgetown University , March 2005 .
The baby boom period did not happen without reason .
It was a worldwide phenomenon that took place as a quick solution for population growth .
However , many countries now , are experiencing its consequences .
As Peterson (2001) has aptly titled his analysis , we are in a "Graying World" (p .66) .
Singapore is no exception , but to quite a large extent , many policies and community services have been developed over the years to help ease the weight of an aging population .
Singapore has noticed the growing pressure of an aging population .
Our population pyramid (The Singapore Department of Statistics , 2008a) is one that is constrictive , with "fewer people in the younger age categories" (Richmond , n .d . , p .64) .
As reported by SDS (2008b) , we have a decreasing old age support ratio , with 17 residents aged 15 to 64 years old supporting one senior citizen aged 65 and above in 1970 , reduced to just 8 .4 in 2008 .
According to the Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports (2009a) , in 20 years' time , "one in five residents in Singapore will be aged 65 and above" , which would make us "one of the fastest ageing populations in Asia" .
At this rate , sustaining our country's silver generation cannot just be the duty of the children , but as far as possible , a great work of cooperation , with the help of policies .
Instead of just 'feeding' , the government aims to get senior citizens to learn a new way of fishing emphasizing self-reliance  .
To oversee the progress of how the nation can ease the aging process , the Ministerial Committee on Ageing was set up to ensure "an inter-ministry approach to prepare for rapid population ageing" (MCYS , September 12 , 2009a) .
For starters , the elderly can approach their district's Community Development Council , which can help in job-matching , recommending government assistance schemes , applying for skills upgrading workshops and assisting in healthcare issues .
To encourage job security , they can receive the Chinese Development Assisting Council (CDAC) Skills Training Award when they successfully complete their skill upgrading courses (MCYS , 2009b) .
These initiatives are supported by the fact that it was reported four years ago , "63 .1 per cent of senior citizens aged 55 and above had their own source of income" (MCYS , 2006 , p .4) .
Another example is that many districts also hold regular free health screenings for the elderly .
While the country has to bear the initial costs , it helps seniors pick up telling signs of illnesses in order to be treated early .
In 2005 , "more than half (64 .2%) of senior citizens above the age of 55 went for regular health screening" (MCYS , 2006 , p .9) .
If the majority of our senior citizens are able to be  independent and pro-active , it helps to ease the dependency on our younger working population .
Even with the plethora of schemes , policies and aid , there will always be some who are unable to be  independent .
This  can be due to a range of reasons , such as disability , health , old age and even their mentality towards post-retirement work .
In many traditional families , it is a social expectation for children to support their elderly parents after retirement .
This obligatory gesture is seen as filial piety .
Based on the findings from 2005 , it was found that inevitably , "dependence on financial support from children increased with age of senior citizens" .
It was reported by MCYS that more than half of those aged 55 to 64 years old were given help by their children .
As expected , the percentage "increased to 77 .9% for those aged 75 and above" (MCYS , 2006 , p .9) .
At the same time , it could be the mindset of some senior citizens , who feel the government should be footing their bills , as a right for the country's elderly .
An aging population is a reality that cannot be postponed and it is happening now .
With the foresight of our country's leaders , sociologists and policy makers , Singapore has many solutions to help alleviate the problems and hopefully , will towards sustaining the country better .
However , policies and solutions can only work if they are tried and feedback is given to continuously improve them .
Everyone has a part to play , regardless if they are a working adult , a retiree , an elderly person or more importantly ,  just a citizen .
As the effects of an ageing population are usually associated with "impending" problematic issues such as the need for "publicly-financed health and welfare packages" (Friedland & Summer , 2005) , it is considerably detrimental to the economical progression of a country .
Furthermore , the process of ageing itself can be a traumatic affair .
To experience a changing state of the body , generally for the worse , an individual could undergo tremendous amounts of psychological stress .
Thus , besides the critical assessment of allocating and maximising the use of the country's resources , the government also have a part to play in ensuring that  people have a smooth transition into old age .
There have been many proposed strategies , policies and research that act to target people of all ages in alleviating the effects of a greying population .
However , , because such approaches tend to operate with the concept of initial loss and future substantial gain , the majority may be unwilling to accept such propositions .
As such , critics disagree with the statement that the current policies have helped to ease the aging process to a large extent .
Without inculcating social responsibility to both the aged and the young , these propositions may only lead to a paradoxical effect .
Indeed , some policies may serve its sole purpose in reducing the fiscal issue but not entirely easing ageing as a whole .
As purposed by Peterson (2001) , "requiring people to provide in advance for their own old-age dependency" is one solution which is evident .
This concept is very much like the Central Provident Fund (CPF) of Singapore , aiming to prepare the people through imposed sanctions on savings for retirement .
Although this method follows an "institutional-redistributive model" (Metha & Wee , 2004) that is beneficiary to all citizens of Singapore , it involves the compulsory allocation of a portion of the salary , which in a short-term perspective is unfavourable .
Goals like car ownership may be disrupted by such interventions since the supposedly 'extra income' is used to cover the individual for insurance and possible medical costs .
Through a holistic approach of both attitudes and actions towards such policy ,  .
have to align their ideology with that of the government to reap the equal benefits of such policies .
Another problem we have to address is people's compliance to the proposed strategies .
Peterson suggested "to increase the size of today's and the future's economy and tax base by encouraging greater productivity among the non-elderly" , the workforce and children (2001) .
He believes that through the upgrading of the people , they can contribute more to  society with their newly imparted skills .
In contrast , by creating policies to boost productivity of the workforce , the government would firstly have to set aside resources for upgrading and incentives , posing more potential of cutting welfare programs of the aged to fund the new regime .
Since the intended result is also not substantial , imposing these policies may then cause aggravation to the people as most may prefer  resources to be put into more beneficial and tangible uses like funding welfare programs .
people may not work more despite the fact that they became more qualified in multiple professions .
Thus , in order for such policies to ease the issue of a greying population , the paradigm of aiding the country must be observed by  society .
in the National Day's Rally 09' speech made by PM Lee , he  re-emphasised  the significance of social responsibility .
He mentioned that though Singapore is  new hospitals and strategies of saving cost in the recovery of the economical downturn , the community itself should be obliged to maintain a healthy lifestyle (2009) .
The aged have to acknowledge that community hospitals are recommended for rehabilitation while  general hospitals are meant for acute problems .
Families and communities should also supervise the wellness of  people through regular medical checks or even maintaining a healthy social network .
There are many existing initiatives that  society can implement in the absence of such policies to ease the ageing process .
In order for any development or strategies to work , it must incorporate the social responsibility of the people .
By campaigning pro-activeness as an integral part of  people's lives , it is certain  that  any policies implemented will be embraced by the majority's positive perceptions .
Thus , with societal and governmental support , the process of ageing will be eased not only through the dampening of fiscal consequences but also very importantly , through the willingness of  society in comprehending the greying issue .
