But nonetheless , countries that are already dealing with the problem of their aging population have identified the limitations of the policies that are implemented .
For example , in the context of Singapore , we have been holding pro-natalism campaigns since the 1980s , but there is still an insignificant rise in our replacement rate .
This indicates that perhaps the emphasis towards the investment of the country's revenue should be diverted to other area such as economic investments and improving the education system to further boost the rate of advancement of a country .
Firstly , public spending on the elderly should be limited and not be reduced .
in additionl , a pool of reserve funds should be available to cope with the rise in aging population as well .
This is because the problem of an aging population affects the rate of development of a country in the long run .
And if this problem persists , it will gradually become a roadblock for the future advancement of  society .
As such , the country should still pay attention to the proper handling of the issue .
The approaches that countries usually adopt to solve the aging issue include the prolonging of the working lives of the elderly and the provision of an array of welfare pension schemes for them .
Secondly , medical science has also come up with many types of  anti-aging drugs such as Deprenyl , one of the best anti-aging drugs currently available .
People will look younger and surprisingly , not just women but also men are now using the drugs .
Anyway , not all the drugs are good and cheap  so finding a suitable drug is a tough task  .
Furthermore , the nutrition industry has also jumped in this battle against the aging problem with milk and other products like Quintessence that  .
As people , especially the youth , feel healthier , they will work harder and earn more money for their future life .
It would not only help  government to reduce the amount of money they have to spend on the welfare program for the elderly , but also provide the elderly with a chance to have a rich old-life .
If people have to work for themselves , they will try their best to earn as much as possible .
Therefore , they may get even more money on their own rather than receiving money from the government welfare .
However , taking too many anti-aging medical products like medicine in general is not as good as supporting yourself with a suitable and healthy diet .
Natural solutions to the anti aging process  include fruits and vegetables .
Fruits like apples , strawberries , etc contain ellagic acid that has the capacity to hinder the growth of tumors within the body and those such as cantaloupe , peaches , etc contain lycopene gthat guard the body's cells and organs like the heart and bladder from damage caused by free radicals .
Vegetables would also demonstrate the same benefits in antioxidant capabilities , for example , Genistein in soybeans works as cancer gene enzyme inhibitor .
Besides , people who usually do gymnastics will live longer and healthier than those do not .
Some may argue that fruit and gymnastics do not play any part in easing the aging process .
In fact by doing physical exercise , their immunity increases , making them immunized against lots of bacteria and viruses .
A healthy diet along with gymnastics will prevent  .
To countries with old populations , medical science needs to be considered and invested more in so that we will have more and better ways of easing the aging process .
With the achievements of medical science , treatments , medicine and dietary habits , humans get not only happiness and health but also a better longer life .
Furthermore , medical science is one of the effective solutions for the aging process , which helps ease the economic burden for the country by reducing the money for old people's welfare , diverting it to other areas of the country's development .
The aging population in Singapore has been growing .
The percentage of residents aged 65 and above has increased from 6 .8% in 1998 to 8 .7% in 2008 (Population in brief , 2009) .
This is expected to reach 20% in 2030 (Seah , 2007) .
Thus , measures for aiding the increasing aging population in terms of healthcare subsidies and daily expenditures should be proactively prepared .
Some strategies can be introduced to deal with the aging population .
Firstly , greater productivity should be encouraged with the younger generation being cost-efficient and productive .
Secondly , filial obligation should be stressed among the younger generation .
Lastly , people could be encouraged to have proactive savings when they have a job to save up for a rainy day (Peter G . Peterson , 2001) .
Therefore , the aging population is not an insurmountable problem , funds could be sub-divided for  expenditure in other sectors such as education , tourism and Research and Development (R&D) .
Firstly , education is  important  in Singapore as it secures the future of the younger generation .
Singapore has institutions with outstanding records of interactive learning and a bilingual education system .
At tertiary level ,  the National University of Singapore (NUS) , and the Nanyang Technological University (NTU) are leading local universities .
Funds are constantly pumped into the education system for the financing of students and also for constant improvements in the education system .
For example , the Tuition Grant Scheme is provided for the subsidising of high school fees .
Therefore , by investing in the education sector , the future of the younger generation will be secured .
In turn , they would be able to support the aged thus reducing the dependency of the aged on the government .
Secondly , the tourism sector is a revenue generator for Singapore through the various tourist attractions such as Sentosa and the upcoming Integrated Resorts .
Hence , funds have to be constantly injected for new tourist attractions and contingency plans in the case of an economic crisis .
For example , in February 2009 , the Singapore Tourism Board announced that an incentive of $90 million has been provided for the BOOST (Building On Opportunities to Strengthen Tourism) which is targeted at aiding the tourism sector duringchallenging times (Singapore Tourism Board , 2009) .
Thus , funds are essential to ensure that the tourism sector is filled with vibrant attractions and is prepared for any crisis .
This ensures a constant flow of revenue for the economic stability of Singapore .
Lastly , R&D is extensively utilized  in major institution projects , for innovation and creativity in new developments and for environmental concerns .
For example , R&D is supported by the National Research Foundation which focuses on areas such as  Environmental  , Water Technologies and  Interactive and Digital Media .
A total of $1 .55 billion is invested in these areas (Singapore Budget , 2009) .
In addition , R&D discovered  NEWater and ensured its consistent high quality for the past few years (Channel News Asia , 2009) .
Although , the R&D sector is important , the aging population must not be neglected as a portion of the old may still remain vulnerable .
Due to globalization , the aged have become richer and of better health .
However , a portion of the population could still need financial help such as those with lower incomes .
Thus , financial benefits should be provided to those that are in need of help .
In contrast , schemes such as the Central Provident Fund and the Medisave schemes do cover a large proportion of expenses .
Hence , funds spent on the aged should be limited in order to accommodate any high expenses in the three sectors that contribute a large proportion of revenue to the economy .
In conclusion , R&D brings about innovation and inventions , hence bringing various business opportunities and revenue to Singapore .
On the whole , the aging population is not an insurmountable problem .
Hence , public spending on the aged should be limited in order for funds to be sub-divided among the education , tourism and  R&D sectors which are the main sources of revenue .
In turn , with more revenue being generated , more benefits and financial aid could be provided to the aged which benefits the country as a whole .
Aging population is a global issue nowadays , especially in  developed countries .
This will soon affect  Asian countries with serious repercussions .
According to Jackson and Howe's major findings , today , 8 of 16 nations of Western Europe have a median age of 40 or higher (The Graying of The Great Powers , May 2008 , CSIS) .
By 2050 , 6 will have a median age of 50 or higher , so will Japan , the East Asian Tigers , and 17 of the 24 nations in Eastern Europe and the Russian sphere .
Due to the size of the increasing aging population , public spending on the aged has been rising .
Hence , this has exerted more pressure on  society , which could lead to problems such as low social security , economic depression and inadequate education .
Hence , it is essential to limit  public spending on the elderly , so more money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
It is essential to set spending limits on healthcare .
As healthcare services gradually increase ,  public spending on the aged also increases .
In 2000-2001 , seniors accounted for 43 percent of total health care spending but represented only 12 .5 percent of the population .
In 2026-2027 , seniors will represent 22 percent of the population and will be responsible for close to 60 percent of total health care spending (Population Aging ,2009 .
An aging population has placed the federal budget on an "imprudent and unsustainable path" and that "passage of time only serves to worsen this situation(Congress Daily , 2009) ." .
To maintain the healthcare system for the elderly , a significant amount of money will have to be spent on it , which may have serious consequences for society .
Therefore , the government should adjust  spending on healthcare to an appropriate level .
Setting limits on  spending on the aged would raise indignation among the elderly , especially among people without  savings , poor single women , and the illiterate .
Some may say it is inhumane to limit  spending on the aged .
However , policy makers should always look at the interests of the whole country rather than just focusing on one particular area .
Additionally , the government can conduct specific tests such as the means- test for those who really require financial support .
In conclusion ,  .
Money saved from reduced spending on the aged can then be invested in other areas for instance education .
When  education is enhanced , graduates  have a higher chance of getting a job and hence contributing to the economic development of the country .
In addition , together with the development of economy , the young adults would be capable of supporting their parents .
Furthermore , they could enjoy high living standards and security in life .
Generally , the government would have enough budget to empower the stable development of the country , and to maintain the welfare and pension system at an acceptable level .
To illustrate that these are only some  of the many benefits which  can be achieved from reducing spending on the aged .
To conclude , it is vital for the government to limit  spending on the aged to a reasonable level , so money can be invested in different aspects of the country's development .
In the short run , the country may face difficulties , but in the long run it will be beneficial to  society .
Medicine nowadays gives us a strong belief that the aging process is something we can alter .
Medically speaking , we can expect longevity if our body is able to continuously re-generate living cells .
Results of different research have revealed that there are certain components which help to maintain a healthy cell like antioxidants , enzymes , hormones or "no cellular waste" (Dr . Grey , 2005) . "
Together with cell collapse , diseases like heart disease or cancer ,  speed up the process .
Luckily , modern medicine can provide  procedures to cure  serious diseases and to prevent aging .
For example , doctors nowadays can  build a complete plan to slow down the aging process; such a plan includes an individualized nutritional , hormonal , dietary and exercise program .
After six months of joining the program , the biological age of a man can decrease by 20 years .
With currently available anti-aging strategies , people can confidently look forward to a longer lifetime .
Besides , there are also some drugs which can be used as an anti-aging treatment like the Estrogen hormone (for women) .
In other words , medicine can be used effectively to ease the aging process .
Although almost everyone agrees that economics is a vital component in the world's life , not many people realize that it also plays an important part in easing the aging process .
The effects caused by the global economy indirectly control the speed of aging .
In developed countries with strong economies , health issues and other social services are sure to be cared much more about than in undeveloped ones .
With a simple comparison between Western societies with those from Africa , significant differences in life expectancy and actual lifespan can be seen . .
While Western people tend to live long happy lives with a small number of serious diseases , people from African countries usually have a much shorter life expectancy .
However , economic problems may have a very bad impact on  efforts to slow down the aging process .
As the economy goes up , there are more concerns to be taken care of and people get busier .
This will be reflected in their bad habits like over-working and also harm their mental health , which will shorten their lifespan .
After much research , it is not surprising to know  that , usually , the richest man is not the happiest man .
But again , these are individuallifestyles so a person should be able to change it easily by himself putting some understanding into it and by making an effort .
Hence , economics , in some ways , is providing a useful helping hand to ease the aging process .
In conclusion , aging is nowadays a global issue .
Human beings , with their intelligence , can find  ways to ease the aging process .
The only problem left is that with a longer life , what will a person do to give back to  society and the next generations ?
Aging population and longer life expectancy will inevitably lead to rapidly increasing elderly residents .
Housing , which is one of the basic needs of elderly people , is significant because the elderly need a safe , pleasing and interactive environment for their old age .
Current housing developments and policies have provided better choice to enhance the quality of life of older people .
Government agencies have strived to promote an elderly-friendly physical environment .
Policymakers have implemented various strategies to ensure older people own a home while enjoying sufficient retirement income for old age dependency .
Some housing schemes are also introduced to facilitate mutual care and support for elderly .
Housing policies and schemes play a critical role in easing the aging process .
Most countries have provided various housing schemes to ensure an adequate supply of affordable accommodation for the aging population .
Under these schemes , housing developers are subsidized with lower land costs to build  retirement housing , while needy elderly are given priority  access to public housing .
It may be argued that  a number of elderly people are "asset-rich , cash-poor" .
They own a house but do not have sufficient funds to meet their basic needs in old age (Ministry , 2006) .
Nevertheless , there are policies that allow the elderly to monetize their housing assets .
These people are encouraged to sublet their house or to downsize to a more affordable one .
In Singapore , the Lease Buyback Scheme helps the elderly in smaller flats to monetize flat value whilst continuing to stay in the same flat .
Hence , it can be noticed that the housing needs as well as the financial needs of elderly have been effectively tackled by various public policies .
Finally , a harmonious and caring elderly society has been promoted through housing schemes as well can be looked forward to in the future .
On the one hand , policymakers have carried out a range of policies to encourage younger children to take care of their elderly parents by staying with them .
In Hong Kong , the Harmonious Families Priority Scheme allows families to live in one flat or two nearby flats when they apply for public housing .
On the other hand , senior activity centres are also developed in housing estates to encourage the elderly to remain integrated in society .
These centres provide social and recreational activities , as well as community-based care and support services for elderly residents .
Indeed , these strategies have effectively enabled elderly people to lead a fruitful and meaningful social life .
Clearly , the quality of life of elderly people has become more enjoyable through various housing developments , policies and improvement programmes .
These efforts have successfully eased the issues of an aging population .
A blending of housing schemes and developments  that help  older people to live as independently as possible .
Today , many governments around the world are particularly concerned with problems brought about by a fast ageing population .
One cause for this is related to the  baby boomers , who are mostly now in their late fifties or early sixties .
In Singapore , this constitutes to 31% of its population and approximately half of the workforce .
born in 1946 to 1964 , they are fast approaching the national retirement age of 63 .
In other words , in 10 years' time , half of the citizens who are currently employed at work would have been retired .
Such manpower shortages are examples of how an ageing population would have a detrimental effect on the economy .
Among some other issues that the elderly face are those of deteriorating physical condition and old-age sickness , which might cause a strain on the local healthcare system and financial system of the country .
In anticipation of this , governments have set in place policies as well as  initiatives to ease the ageing process for both the individual and society .
In the context of Singapore , some of these include mandatory personal retirement funds , development of the health sector to better manage an ageing population , as well as encouraging longer working lives .
Despite some of the limitations of these policies , they have certainly eased the ageing process in Singapore .
One such policy in Singapore is the Central Provident Fund (CPF) .
Set up by the government in 1955 , it serves as a retirement fund for all Singaporean citizens .
The CPF is a mandatory savings plan for workers , where a portion of their income is being set aside in this fund , and will be being made available to them once they have retired .
This policy provides for financial security for the elderly as they would be financially dependent , and need not rely on public initiatives or their children for money in their golden years .
With this policy , the government is then able to redirect  resources to more vital sectors .
Critics of this position point out their concerns over the misuse of the funds once it is made available .
Being unsure of their future financial requirements , the elderly might be unable to plan for their expenditure , and might drain their finances too quickly .
However , a recent introduction by the Singaporean government has eliminated this problem .
Participants of this new and compulsory scheme named "Lifelong Income for The Elderly"  (LIFE) will receive lifelong monthly payouts from their CPF accounts .
Instead of being granted with a lump sum of money upon retirement , this ensures that the elderly do not exhaust their retirement funds too quickly , thereby easing reliance on public funds .
Lastly , developments in medicine have also helped in the ageing process .
With new technological advances , the elderly now have a variety of medical treatments for most old-age related illnesses .
For example , advances in surgery have helped developed a non-invasive surgery technique for glaucoma , one of the main leading diseases among the elderly  .
This non-invasive technique will help to minimize any potential surgical risks .
One impending problem with such rapid technological advances in medicine would be the rising cost of healthcarewhich is brought about by the intensive research processes to develop new cures and treatments .
With most of the elderly retired and having no source of income , they might be unable to fund their medical expenses should the need arise .
In view of this , the Singaporean government has in place a variety of measures to minimise the occurrence of this situation .
One such measure would be Medisave .
Introduced by the Ministry of Health in 1984 , Medisave would set aside a portion of an individual's income to  be made available to fund medical expenses should the need arise .
With this fund , most Singaporeans will  retire with a sum of money  which can be used to pay for medical expenses .
This reduces the possible reliance of public funds for funding  medical expenses for the elderly .
In conclusion , this essay has illustrated that the current policies in Singapore have helped ease the ageing process to a large extent .
Policies such as implementing the CPF , raising the retirement age and developing  healthcare policies have helped to ease the ageing process in the society , thereby reducing the  effects of an ageing population .
It is unethical to embark on the developments of a country at the expense of the aged .
By limiting the fiscal spending on the elderly , the extra funds created can be diverted to areas such as education , which has potential long-term benefits for a country .
As such , it will be even tougher for the government to cater to the growing needs of the elderly due to a constraint budget , and this problem will affect countries  facing an ageing population , such as Japan .
Opponents of this position argued that there is no need to divert too much resources to the elderly because they are no longer contributing to the society  .
Instead , these resources should be used in other areas that provide long-term benefits to the country .
For instance , the investing of funds for research and development will raise the productive capacity of the country , thereby attracting more direct foreign investments .
However , it is wrong to regard the aged as a burden , because the aged is a national asset that should not be neglected by the society .
Even after they have retired , they continue to contribute to the society  , but  in  different ways , such as taking care of their grandchildren on behalf of their children who are  at work .
In this way , they help to coordinate the work life and family life of the working adults (Conference of European Churches 2007) .
Consequently , the aged , with their insights and experiences , is a valuable asset to the society and thus  public spending on the aged should not be limited .
Lastly , the limiting of public spending on the aged will increase the financial hardship of the elderly .
This will affect the elderly who are either single or have no children , and those who have low educational level .
In their younger days , their earnings might just be sufficient for them to cope with their daily living expenses and hence they have negligible or no savings .
When they fall ill , the high costs of medical fees may discourage them from seeking medical care , and as a result , their health conditions may deteriorate over time .
As they age , they become more susceptible to diseases , such as osteoporosis .
Thus , it is inevitable that their demand for healthcare will increase with age .
It will come to a time when they are left with no choice but to seek medical help for their illnesses; but since they are left with little savings , they are unlikely to be able to pay for the medical expenses .
It is one's social responsibility to be healthy , and to be accountable for one's  medical expenses should one seek healthcare services , instead of relying on the government for subsidies to lower one's financial burden  .
Jenson (2007) mentioned that the ageing population has accelerated the growth in healthcare spending , and this will lead to a fiscal crisis as increasing pressure is exerted on the fiscal budget .
However , the presence of a fiscal crisis might not necessarily be attributed to  fiscal spending on the aged .
The facilities built for the elderly should not be seen  negatively because these facilities  provide long-term benefits to every individual in the country  , since ageing is an unavoidable process .
This applies to the healthcare subsidies , as one will hope that one can be entitled to such privileges when one has limited savings , regardless of one's age .
Hence , it is infeasible to limit public spending on the aged .
Aged citizens will  require for basic healthcare and treatment .
According to the National Institute of Aging (2007) , experts predicted that there will be a huge rise in disability resulted from increases in age-related chronic disease in all regions of the world .
This implies that public spending should not be limited as it will be required to subsidise  costly healthcare expenses .
This is because the aged population will not be able to afford the financial burden for the recurrent treatment of their illnesses .
Truly , aged citizens accounted for greater than 40% of the total hospitalisation days in  public sector hospitals in 2006 (Ministry of Heath , 2007) .
On the other hand , it is fortunate that the Singapore Central Provident Fund (CPF) , which is the fundamental pillar of our social security framework for the aged , lends itself readily to provide  for the needs of aging population .
Healthcare in Singapore are made affordable through the administration of the Medisave , Medishield and Medifund framework .
Each citizen's CPF account consists of Medisave , Medishield and Medifund , which help individuals to put aside portions of their income to meet their medical expenses  when they are old .
The medisave accounts assist older Singaporeans to pay for  their expensive medical bills .
This would help to ease the public spending on the aged and money can be spent on other area of Singapore's development .
However , Singaporeans still enjoy heavy subsidies in public hospital , especially in the lower class wards .
Direct subsidies borne by the Singapore government have increased from $850 million in 2001 to more than $1 .6 billion in 2007 and are forecasted to exceed $2 .2 billion by 2012 (Ministry of Health , 2009) .
As the population ages , the need for healthcare services will increase .
Public spending will keep increasing and should not be limited as the aging population in Singapore progresses .
In conclusion , fertility rates are declining while life expectancies are increasing around the world .
As a result , populations are aging rapidly and Singapore is not exempted from this trend .
The ratios of Singapore citizens aged sixty-five and above will climb from one in twelve in 2007 to one in eight in 2020 (Ministry of Finance , 2008) .
Therefore  public spending on the aged should not be limited and should fluctuate according to changes such as impending demographic shift , population growth and healthcare expenses .
However , it is also important  for Singaporeans to plan ahead so that they can depend on several sources of income to sustain their old-age livings and at the same time ease the burden of public spending on the aged .
Employers should also do their part in changing their traditional perceptions that aged employees are unproductive and potential burden to society (Harper , 2001) .
Employers should try to retain and retrain older workers for them to be retained in the labour force; this will extend theirorking lives  and they will be in a better economic position to sustain themselves .
Public spending is the amount of money expended by a government to pay  the maintenance of  defence , development projects , education , social security , health , infrastructure , law and order   .
It represents a large share of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) and has a major impact on the productivity of the whole economy .
Public spending on social security and health care will directly benefit the aged people in the country .
This essay argues that the public spending on aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to other area of the country's development .
The elderly in a country are usually supported  by public spending .
It is argued that the government should provide more public assistance to the elderly and not to limit the amount of spending on them .
However , some people may not  realize that there are many countries which are already having high public spending .
Schuknecht and Tanzi (2005) stated that many countries have peaked at almost 52% of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) over the past twenty years .
Most countries tend to spend more than half of the public funds on social protection  , health and  the aged .
Mahal and Berman (2006) mentioned that several studies have indicated that  expenses of health and social protection for the elderly are usually much greater than those non-elderly .
If countries are to increase their public spending on the aged further , it may cause the proportion of public spending to be spent on other important areas , such as infrastructure and education , to be  lessened .
This could eventually slow down the productivity of the whole economy .
Therefore , public spending on the elderly should be limited and controlled to prevent it from increasing further .
Population aging is progressing rapidly in many countries and in the near future , this may push up the public spending on social security and healthcare costs .
In view of  the aging population problem , some people argued that we should not limit  public and financial assistanceto the elderly because of  the increasing number of elderly in an aging population .
However , the increase in public spending means that working people may need to pay higher taxes , as public spending is supported mainly by taxation .
Minford and Wang (2008) stated that researches have shown that the increase in tax to GDP had reduced GDP growth and lowered the output per worker .
In an aging population , having increasing tax contribution from the shrinking workforce can be a burden to the working people .
The Straits Time (2009) mentioned that the huge increases in public spending could slow down countries' economic growth .
In an aging society , it is important to limit and  control  the increasing public spending on the aged .
If not , there could be a drop in the GDP and eventually  the percentage of public spending  on the aged could be reduced too .
It should be the responsibility of the country to ensure that all the aged , who have contributed to the society , to be properly assisted in their old age .
However , when public spending on the aged is not limited and allowed to be raised continuously , everyone in the country is going to suffer in long run .
There might be one day when the to country's work force can no longer support the extremely high an amount of public spending .
This may cause the the working people to be under pressure and financially strapped .
It may then cause them to fail to take good care of their elderly parents and neglect their needs .
Toh (2009) mentioned that researches have shown that during the global economic recession , there are more elderly abuse cases reported .
Thus , one of the ways to prevent this from happening is to have control over the public spending on elderly , so as to prevent further increase in tax contribution .
Besides that , a country should try to divert a higher percentage of public spending to other areas that might contribute the country's growth and development , such as  infrastructure and development projects .
By investing more money in these areas , a country may generate higher return and has a higher GDP growth .
This may again increase the amount of public spending  on the aged .
It is no doubt that a country should do its best to assist and support the elderly .
However , countries have to be mindful on the amount of money that has to be spent on the social protection and health for the elderly .
We have to ensure that they are efficient and effective in spending this large amount money and preventing it from rising too high .
To spend too large amount of public funds on the elderly will definitely  burden  both the country and working population .
Thus , we should try to divert more money to other areas of the country's development and promote higher GDP growth .
This can definitely benefit the aged  and without adding anyurden to the country's economy and the next generation .
Singapore has one of the fastest aging populations in the world and is expected to be considered a country with an aging population by the year 2030 (Chan , 2001) .
This alarming trend is stimulated by declines in fertility rate , medical advances , and better health care which have resulted in longer life expectancy .
With this rising aging population , many issues related to old age become significant , especially the public spending issue .
Even though this trend would most likely affect Singapore negatively , the government must not only concern themselves with the increasing expenditures on the aged and try to divert the budget for the aged to other areas of development .
They must also consider the impact on the elderly if there were no financial support for the elderly .
In addition , they should also consider the contributions that the elderly could give and had given to the country .

The Korea population is graying rapidly , and the proportion of elderly with the aged of 65 and over is expected to reach 13 .2 per cent in 1960 .
Korea needs to reform its national policies if it hopehoped to create a better and sustainable future society as there will be a lot of negative impacts on the country  , such as the inevitable labor shortage , increase in public spending and healthcare problems if the ageing population continues to grow disproportionately with the country's fertility rate .
This is supported by Jones (1995) , stating that the increase in  population will have strong physical , psychological , social , cultural , economical and cultural implications .
Therefore , in view of this  , current research and policies have been carried out by the Korean government and have helped to buffer the ageing process .
A government pension system , namely the National Pension (NP) , which is financed in part by employee's contributions and employer's liability for general workers was introduced in 1988 for retirees over 60 ("Silver jobs in lieu of golden years , 2009) .
It is the main old- age pension program covering the majority of Korean workers .
However , this policy executed by the government did not attain its goal when many of the retirees chose to take their pension in a lump sum at retirement .
This implies that the financial security for these elderly in the future will be strongly affected if they do not use their pension wisely .
Considering this matter , in 2004 , the National Pension Service started finding jobs for the elderly and the project was made permanent in 2006 .
There was an overwhelming result when job placements rose from around 30 ,000 in 2004 to more than 83 ,000 in 2006 and 196 ,000 in the first half of this year .
Despite this progress , there are still  not enough openings for the baby boomers .
So , local governments have established "silver jobs" fair like chaperons for children returning home from late- night cram schools , gas station attendants , opinion survey interviewers and wedding officiators to recruit elderly job seekers as part of the government effort to assist a rapidly growing population of older Koreans in a changing society .
Phillips .D .R (2000) .
Ageing in the Asia- Pacific Region: Issues , Policies and Future Trends .
New York: Routledge
Social service programs have been introduced for the welfare of the elderly .
It can be divided into two groups: the recreational programs and community programs .
Under these programs , the elderly are able to obtain personal needs and social- psychological developments needs amongst others .
For example , under the community program , there is this sub- program called the Home- Help Program which provides home- help services to the elderly without any fees incurred .
Around 35 ,000 volunteer home helpers were active , linked to 552 voluntary organizations in 2001 with the provision of government in financial assistance for recruiting , training and maintaining volunteers .
Although many beneficial services have been provided to the elderly , this program  does not seem to be so effective as volunteers may or may not render their services whenever the elderly need them .
It is not a mandatory  for them to always lend a hand to the elderly .
Therefore , the government should think of a better way to tackle this problem so that the society will have a  domestic routine to serve the elderly who need its assistance .
Due to the low fertility rate and the growing number of elderly in the society , there is a shortage of workforce in certain occupations .
To keep an ideal and constant working age group (15-64 years) and ensure the stability of manpower in Korea , the government has been inviting immigrants to join the workforce .
The number of foreign labors has grown from a few thousand to estimates of 168 thousand in 1999 (Bureau of Medium- Sized Industries , 1999) and 358 thousands in 2005 .
This replacement migration  has not only helped to ease the ageing process when  older Koreans started to retire , which resulted in the decrease of manpower in certain specialization , it also has helped to buffer the current shortage of labor in the market .
Unfortunately ,  there are around 65 percent of the immigrants  in 1999 who are working illegally (Bureau of Medium- Sized Industries , 1999) .
The large volumes of immigrants to fill up the labor shortage due to population aging has also aroused fears of the loss of national identity (UN , 2000) .
Thus , even though the adoption of the immigrant policy has helped to ease the ageing process , it might not be the best policy to conquer the problem .
Intyre (1977) once said that old age throughout this century has been seen as a 'social problem' and this is true when the government has to adopt  all kinds of policies to overcome the problem .
With the  ageing  population , the priority of constructing a sustainable socioeconomic system at the beginning of the twenty- first century  must be given .
Peterson (2001) commented that in many developed countries , an ageing population will lead to a shrinking workforce , long- term stagnation and  a decline in real GDP .
Nevertheless , we agree with Frieden (year) , who concluded that ageing is not lost youth but a new stage of opportunity and strength .
Therefore , leaders  must design a desirable socioeconomic structure under the pressure of an ageing population and environment constraints by identifying the necessary  tools to attain stable and sustainable growth before taking any effective actions .

Firstly , the aged have contributed their youth to the advancement of the society .
More than half a century ago , they have fought to restore peace to our country .
They worked hard to rebuild and develop the war-torn country into what we are living in now .
We owe them for the peace  and we have to thank them for  developing the country and the safe environment that we are living in .
Public pension , healthcare and all the services for the elderly symbolise our debt of gratitude to what they have done for us .
Won't it make us inhumane if we made our benefactors struggle when they are near the end of their lives ?
Is this really a decision coming from a civilized world ?
And how do you feel if the younger generation did this to you ?
Secondly , limiting  public spending on the aged means leaving out in the cold these vulnerable sub-groups of elderly people: single women , the uneducated and those who cannot save during their young days .
In the report "Demography is Not Destiny , Revisited" (2005) , R . B . Friedland and L . Summer pointed out that single women have particularly low average incomes .
The report also said that the uneducated have lower income and worse health than people with higher education .
Furthermore , it is not assured that all  are able to save up money during their younger days .
Therefore , they are the people who will suffer the most if we limit spending for the aged .
"Those who do not work do not eat" (author , year) .
However , what if they worked hard but still cannot afford to eat ?
In these situations , they really need a helping hand from the government to get by .
Critics of this position suggest that means-testing should be applied to limit the spending to just these vulnerable sub-groups .
However , things are not always simple and we will consider in the next paragraph the effect of reducing public spending on the society , even if means-testing is applied .
In conclusion , we should not limit spending on the aged because it is our way to express our thanks to their contributions to the societyand this allows the under-privileged old people to live on  to maintain  economic and social stability .
Global aging population is one of the most critical and pressing issues that the leaders of the twenty first century face .
According to the United Nations report , the proportion of population aged 60 or above in  developed and less developed countries is projected to reach 33% and 25% respectively by 2050(United Nations , 2002) .
The change in the age structure of a country's population will have a profound impact on the political , social and economical conditions of that country .
In view of the increasing number of elderly , governments across the globe have implemented various policies to help them cope with the aging process .
Aging process here refers to the problems that will come about as one grows old , such as healthcare issues , financial problems and many more .
Although there are already policies in place , much changes and improvements have to be done to effectively help the elderly address their growing concerns and improve their quality of life .
Advocate of the government policies often argue that many countries have provided financial security and support for the aged through policies such as social pension and compulsory savings (Wesumperuma , 2009) .
While this may be true , such measures are ineffective in reducing old-age poverty as many elderly have little understanding of how the system works and do not possess the necessary financial knowledge to manage their savings and allowance .
As such , government has to put more emphasis and effort in imparting financial education and providing money advice and information to help the elderly to better finance their savings and incomes .
Due to the complexity of these policies , some elderly do not even know how to use them to their benefits , hence rendering them worthless .
In addition , a study by (Age UK  ,2009) shows that old people often do not know how to optimize their savings and spend their money carelessly .
As a result , their savings and incomes are exhausted quickly .
In another separate study by Chu &Yuen( 2008) , it is stated that around 67% of the respondents think that the compulsory saving in Hong Kong cannot provide them with a happy retirement life as they do not understand about the benefits of Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF) scheme and hence do not care about it .
Therefore it is necessary that the government highlight the availability and benefits of their financial policies and equip the aged with basic financial education to increase the effectiveness of these policies .

Secondly , there is a need to increase the efficiency of the social and health care system by curbing the rising cost of health care service and making it more accessible to the aged .
Critics of this position often point out that there are already established health care system and policies in place to subsidise the cost of health care and that changes are frequently introduced to improve them .
Despite the changes that are being implemented , such measures are insufficient to help the aged as the root problems of rising cost and increasing inaccessibility are not addressed .
As pointed out by Tanner (2008) , rising health care cost is a global phenomenon .
Costly health care system is highly unsustainable as it strains government budget and imposes a great burden on the aged and their families' finances .
As a result , the savings and the income of the elderly may be used up quickly or large portion of their finances have to be spent on health care services .
One possible solution is to encourage people to buy more health insurance (University of Maine , 2001)  .
Many elderly are uninsured as they fail to realise that many of the illnesses that can be prevented or treated cheaply in the early stages very often worsen into critical conditions .
In addition , although there are health care systems in place , there are still many who do not have access to them .
This is due to the confusing systems that access the elderly base on ambiguous criteria that make it harder for them to obtain the service  , as well as  information and advice ( Help The aged we will , 2007) .
Hence , containing rising health care cost and increasing accessibility are essential to help ease the aging process .
Lastly , more should be done to increase the labour participation rate of the aged in the workforce .
An argument against this is that adequate effort has been put in to encourage later retirement and longer working lives .
Despite the effort , employment level of the aged still remain low as the elderly continue to face discrimination at work .
Older workers are often viewed as less dynamic and less creative as compared to the younger workersand thus they are less preferred .
Unless there is a change in attitude towards the older workers , it will be difficult for them to be find jobs , which can keep them active and support their financial needs .
Discrimination towards the older workers is more evident during the recession .
There was a 46% increase in the number of unemployed people in the UK whereas the biggest increase was those aged 60 and above with an increase of 65% (Wallop , 2009) .
A possible solution for this is to scrap the national default retirement age which often gives the power to employers to retrench those above this retirement age .
Also the government can give benefits or incentives to older workers to encourage them to go for re-training in order to increase their employability .
Employment can reduce elder dependency and provide some financial support for the aged to finance some of their activities .
In conclusion , current policies are inadequate in allowing the elderly to retire happily .
Changes should be made to the current financial , health care and employment policies for the aged so that they can better help the elderly .
There is a need to equip the elderly with the proper finance management to make the financial policies effective .
Also , cost reduction and increasing accessibility are vital for an efficient health care system .
In addition , reducing age discrimination in the workplace must be enforced to better help the elderly secure jobs .
Subsequently , these policies should be revised and improved frequently as the needs and concerns of the aged will change over time .
