"Until recently , the ills of old age interested only poets and philosophers .
However , this has changed because governments and policy makers in the developed world are now confronted with the unprecedented problem of a fast aging population"   (Peterson  , 2001) .
The aging population has become a major issue in many developed countries , including the United States , Japan and Singapore .
Increasing population of the aged created many problems on the society .
Clearly , both governments and the public are becoming more aware of this issue .
Governments in various countries have come up with different policies to address the problem of an increasingly aging population .
As the problem of the aging population worsens , governments have to spend increasing amount of money to counter the problem and at  the expense of other areas of the country's development .
It is important that governments take note of this and control their spending so as not to neglect  other more important areas such as  education and the economy .
Governments are stressing on filial obligation and hope to increase the willingness of tomorrow's grown children to support their own elderly parents .
However , such practices are not common .
It is crucial for the government to spend money on the aged  , as not doing so will lead to social problems .
Already , we are seeing a breakdown in extended families .
The young no longer see filial piety as being important .
The elderly who are unable to support themselves and are being abandoned by their children will have nowhere to turn to if the government turned its back on them .
This will lead to increased crime rates , begging and vagrancy in the country , which are harmful for society .
However , this is not the only area where government spending is required .
As countries spend more money  on the aged , other important sectors such as defense and education may get neglected and become under budgeted .
These sectors are as important as , if not more important than , spending on  an aging population .
For example ,  in an increasingly challenging global economy , it becomes increasingly important for countries to focus on education to maintain a skilled workforce .
An educated workforce increases productivity , which drives the economy  to increased wealth .
By increasing public spending on an aging population , governments risk overlooking other areas of the country's development  .
Moreover , healthcare cost has been increasing .
New technologies and treatments for the aged are relatively expensive .
Governments have been spending too much money on the subsidies to help the aging population .
People may take advantage of the the government subsidies to pay for  expensive new technologies which are not necessary .
Governments should specify the types of treatments that it considers essential and subsidise these treatment , while leaving non-essential treatment cost to be borne by the consumer .
Limiting public spending will make sure that government does not overspend on treatment that is not essential  , so that the money can be diverted to other areas .
It is important and  governments plan their finances well to benefit different sectors of the country .
Public spending is increasing rapidly with the growing aged population that governments are losing control of their spending .
Governments should adopt a wider perspective to ascertain whether the spending is necessary or  the money should be diverted to other areas .
Public spending should be controlled to establish a balanced outcome for both the young and the aged .
If the usage of public funds is not well balanced , it will not only affect the country's development , but also put the country's future into jeopardy .
On the other hand , there are also researches done on illnesses which most commonly affect the  aged .
Researches on healthcare are being done to help maintain or improve the health of the elderly .
Better solutions are hoped to be found in order to help the elderly with their health issues .
For instance , in the United Kingdom , researches on dementia are being done to find a better solution to cure the patients , who are mostly the  aged .
According to Rebecca Wood , the Chief Executive of the Alzheimer's Research Trust , the population living with dementia is forecast to double within a generation .
To help ensure less elderly from suffering from dementia in the future , researches are now being done by the UK .
Much investment have been put into this research to defeat this illness which is currently and will to continue to haunt the  aged .
Some may argue that these researches do not help to ease the aging process because most of the time and money are wasted as the proper solutions are never to be   .
But it is better to try rather than to allow the devastating disease continue to haunt  the older generations .
Besides researches and developments in the field of medicine , social policy also plays a  role in helping to ease the aging process .
Many countries have taken this step to  lighten the burden of the elderly  .
In Japan , the government has imposed the "National Pension Scheme" on all its citizens  .
In this scheme , a basic  pension is provided for all citizens who are above 65 years of age and have contributed for 25 years or more to the country .
This scheme is helpful in easing the burden of the elderly as it provides financial security for them .
The  aged can then be independent and they do not need to rely on their children for money .
The  aged can live a comfortable life without worrying or without seeking for financial aid  .
On the other hand , with these schemes , children need not do their duty to take care of their parents .
This may result in social problems in a country .
The younger generation will not be filial to their parents and will not bear the burden to take care of the older generation and will  push the burden onto the government .
Although such thoughts may arise ,  there are no better ways to guarantee a better life for the  aged .
Clearly , all these researches , developments and policies have helped the aging population to get a better life .
This effort should be continued  as this would guarantee the living standard of the  aged .
Thus , with the living standard of the elderly guaranteed , the social problems can also be avoided in a country .
In conclusion , the issue on the "graying world" can be solved and well taken care of if necessary steps are taken to prevent it .
Caring for the aged is definitely an act to be applauded for and encouraged .
Some might have the perception that caring for the aged is the theiresponsibility of the country .
Nothing could be further from the truth; to care for the aged is to be taken upon by respective dependants , such as their children .
In fact , the ideal situation would be that they should actually take the initiative to be responsible for their own welfare .
If the country were to spend its budget entirely caring for the aged , then many citizens would shove responsibilities and  would  not care for their own health , since the healthy , as represented by the country , would care for them .
While it is important to care for the aged , it is just as important to take into consideration and not neglect other areas of the country's development .
Thus public spending on the aged should be limited .
To rely on ourselves would still be the best option  .
For a start , prior planning is crucial  , when from young , one should  be  actively saving .
This would be  beneficial in the short run , when facing emergencies , or in the long run , when facing retirement .
Policies that encourage skills upgrading have also been introduced to enable the aged to re-enter the workforce .
This is further enhanced by incentives being offered to companies that hire them .
Instead of grieving with regrets of having to work after reaching the retirement age , they could actually be optimistic and take this as an opportunity to be active in the society  , where they could  establish friendships through interactions at work .
Not only could they be able to sustain living through earnings obtained from working , the aged could also keep a healthy mind and body .
Although it would be ideal if the government need not  be 'burdened' with expenses to care for the aged , it is not feasible .
There are those who are without any dependants and savings to see them through their retirement years .
In addition , it could also be dreadful for those who are not well equipped with education or skills to work and who really needs the country's help .
Even so , the country should not be obliged to care for them entirely .
Help given could be in many other forms instead of just monetary  .
With policies such as those that encourage the aged to acquire new skills , the government could also provide aid by compensating the loss in
income during that period of 'learning' .
Although help is given , it is not encouraged for the aged to continuously be reliant on it .
Instead , with the skills acquired , they should 'venture' out and earn a living of their own which would in turn reap many returns in both monetary  and health .
It is also true that  "work can help us stay physically active , mentally alert , socially connected and financially self-reliant" (Yap , 2009 , p . 7) .
Bibliography Yap , E . (2009) .
ADDING LIFE TO YEARS !
Happy , Healthy , Active Seniors .
Singapore: Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports .
A country always has to be ready to with any form of challenges .
One such challenge  would be the ageing population .
To find a solution to that problem , certain amount of the public spending has to be diverted to it .
However an ageing population is not the only concern of any government .
Therefore public spending on the aged should be limited to allow diversion of the funds to other areas of the country's development .
One of the reasons why public spending on the aged should be limited is due to the emergence of other better alternatives .
According to Robert B .Friedland and Laura Summer (2001) the working population would be able to share a large proportion of the responsibility , with the government taking care of the aged primarily .
One of such initiatives would be the baby bonus package which has been introduced in several countries .
In the case of Singapore , the government has increased the cash gift for the first two children from $300 to $400 .
This is one of the long term efforts that the government has decided to invest in so that their public spending on the aged would be reduced in years to come  , as the future working population starts to emerge .
Another temporary measure would be to increase the working population by encouraging immigration into the country .
Canada has experienced the highest per capita immigration rate in the world and expects an increase of 23 .1% of population growth over a period of 25 years (Wikipedia , 2009) .
An increase in the working population will then allow more resources to be channelled  to other areas which demand such funds .
This proves to be a better solution because it allows the government to limit the public spending and  fellow citizens to take responsibility .
This ageing population problem can be dealt with  by increasing the working population  , so that it could share the burden  of caring for the aged .
Public spending should also be limited because areas like R&D need more  funds to ensure constant progress of the nation .
Without a on spending the country would then experience a decline in economic growth .
Therefore , public spending on the aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
It is an ironic truth that Singapore is facing a demographic challenge as the population aged 65 and older is anticipated to more than double by the year 2030 .There is much concern about the current development and policies  , of which older people tend to be the principle beneficiaries .
Many policies such as  the Maintenance of Parent Act , Baby Bonus Scheme and later retirement agreement have helped to ease the aging process significantly .
Last but not least , an aging population brings about a shrinking workforce  and  a significant decline in real GDP .
The critical challenge of the government is to ensure the productivity of future workers .
The main root of this problem is because of low birth rate .
Modern parents prefer to have fewer children  , as compared to the past generation .
They claimed that the living cost now is very high and they could not ensure a quality life style with more children .
Therefore , the government introduces the Baby Bonus Scheme which lightens the financial cost of raising children .
The parents will get a cash gift of up to $4 ,000 each for their first and second child and $6 ,000 each for their third and forth child .
Furthermore , all the children born on or after 17 August 2008 will also enjoy government contributions in the form of a dollar-for-dollar matching  .
As a result , the birth rate increases from 2 .1% (2006) to 2 .55% (2008)  .
In a long run , it is believed that the Baby Bonus Scheme would increase the population  .
With the implementation of the Maintenance of Parents Act in Singapore , it is arguable that the younger generations are not only morally responsible for , but also compelled to taking care of their aged parents  .
However , the low fertility rate in Singapore challenges this argument because the financial burden resulting from the provision of aged parents is currently increasing on  fewer offspring .
It is definitely taxing for an only child to bear the financial cost of his orher parents .
Moreover , the rising cost of  healthcare  adds  further strains to the limited income of the younger generation , which often lead to  children being unable to fend for their parents and thus abandoning  them .
This is  shown in year 2008 , in which approximately 172 senior citizens  filed applications to the tribunal against their children (Wijaya , 2009 , ) .)
Hence , this shows that even with current government assistance such as healthcare subsidies and tax reliefs , , the low fertility rate in Singapore continues to urge the government toc speng on the aged in order to meet the needs ofane ageing society .
Singapore is a well-established country  with advanced healthcare facilities .
Many perceive the current public spending  on the development of healthcare facilities as being sufficient to meet the ageing demands .
However , this is often not the case .
Singapore faces a sharp shortage of medical specialists in the areas of geriatric field and palliative care and to the extent of importing foreign nurses into the medical industry .
This implies that the government has to invest more on training local medical specialists in these fields to meet the growing ageing needsand thus , more expenditure is required .
Furthermore , hospitals are constantly facing  shortages of beds and long average waiting time; the major factor of this problem is the geriatric patients .
The geriatric patients are often the ones who occupy the majority of  hospital bed space and they suffered from chronic illnesses that require regular follow-up consultations .
Therefore , in the recent 2009 National Day Rally speech , Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for step-down care such as  more community hospitals , day-care centres as well as nursing homes .
In this way , more competent healthcare is provided satisfy the  demands , since geriatric patients can receive treatment in acute hospitals and then recuperate in the community hospitals .
Therefore , the development of healthcare facilities to meet growing ageing demands would inevitably raise public expenditure on the aged .
All in all , it has become a fact that Singapore is currently facing a rapidly ageing population   .
Many problems will arise should public spending on the aged be limited and this include  increased financial burden on the fewer offsprings , insufficient funds for rising healthcare development costs and weakened economic competiveness .

On November 13 , 2006 , the Prime Minister of Singapore ,  Lee , said in a speech: "Singapore has treated social welfare as a dirty word .
The opposition and the Worker's Party have called for a permanent unconditional needs-based welfare system .
I think that is an even dirtier five words ."
In Hong Kong , welfare is seen as an individual's responsibility and the government will only step in to help those who are proven incapable of helping themselves (South China Morning , January 13 , 2007) .
The four economies in East Asia--- Singapore , Hong Kong , Taiwan , and South Korea have taken the approach to being a 'light welfare state' , in which they have achieved high standard of living without burdening the state with heavy social expenditures (Midgley , 1986) .
In contrast , the western welfare states that fund heavily on social expenditure have hindered the functioning of the private market .
Public spending on the aged should be limited to avoid heavy social expenditures and money can therefore be diverted to other areas for the country's development .
The old age dependency ratio is estimated to increase with longevity and the decline of fertility .
With no limits set on the expenditure of welfare for the aged , a country  will face enormous financial burdens in the funding of the public pension system , expensive healthcare system and long-term dependency expenditures .
The higher the expenditure of a country's welfare , the higher the tax rate will be to finance it .
It may undermine investors' incentive to invest .
Currently Japan is facing financial difficulties in gathering funds for their National Pension and Employee's pension insurance .
The Japanese government is now emphasizing on achieving economic growth rather than increasing welfare expenditures to support its growing aging society .
The Hong Kong government reluctantly implemented deficit financing from 1998 to 2004 to meet the growing expenditures of caring for the aged .
It is estimated that if the deficit budget continued , Hong Kong's $369 billion fiscal reserves would be wiped out by 2008-2009 (South China Morning Post , February 23 , 2002) .
Instead of limitless spending on the aged , funds should be diverted to develop economic growth , and in turn use the revenues gained to finance aging welfare .
In conclusion , public spending on the aged should be limited  to curb heavy financial expenditures , and t 'welfare diseases' that would undermine any incentive to work .
It will not be a feasible plan to drain  money from national reserves to fill up a bottomless pit .
Money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development to earn revenues in order to support the aging population .
The responsibilities of caring for the aged are divided  between the private and family sector to lessen the burden on the state .
Help is readily available to those who are incapable of providing for themselves .
In conclusion , I agree to a large extent that  government policies that have been implemented  helped to alleviate the aging process .
Developments in the future will be expected to be much  better , and though aging process is inevitableits inconveniences  can  be minimized  .
To ease the aging process , the governments have to put in a great effort in the research of medicine to provide the best treatment for the aged .
Since there is an obvious advancement in technology when compared to previous years , there are more inventions in medicine and equipment to treat  illnesses .
However , some people may think that the aged will not be able to afford  the treatment  as better equipment and treatments will increase the cost  .
To prevent such a situatio from happening , governments have introduced  insurance schemes to reduce the cost of treatment .
For example , the Singapore government has introduced the CPF Medisave Scheme and Medishield Scheme which can cover part of the treatment fees: the patient need not pay any fees for outpatient treatments and Medishield will pay 80% of the actual expenditure up to the claimable limit .
Through this , government ensures that the aged get the proper treatments to reduce their sufferings  .
Thus far , The governmenthas introduced some new economic policies  to ease the aging process .
This includes lengthening the age of retirement  , so that the aged have longer working lives (Peterson , 2001) so that they can earn more money when they are still working to support themselves .
The strategy of lowering the barriers to elder employment is effective in increasing the rate of employment among the aged .
However , some people may think that the aged is a burden to  society as they believe that the physical condition of the aged cannot cope with the development of the country .
While this may be true ,  facts have shown that the aged can still contribute to the economy as they have more experiences when compared to the others .
They share their experiences with the young and this can help to improve the economy of the country .
The government  could use the money to help the  aged and ease the aging process .
In addition , community centers or community clubs have their policies to ease the aging process  .
For instance , An Area Agency on Aging (AAA) is designated in each of New Jersey's 21 counties to serve as the primary entity responsible for developing comprehensive , coordinated systems of community-based services for the aged .
It analyses the needs and existing services within the county and prepares a comprehensive plan for the delivery of services to the aged .
The community centers organize  activities such as performances , games and feasts to help them feel less lonely , cheer them up and make them happy and this has eased the aging process in the society .
There are also many enthusiasts and volunteers in the society who are willing to spend their time accompanying  the aged  , as they know that they can give mental support to the aged .
Peterson (2001) mentions that  aging process in a country will cause a shrinking workforce , long-term stagnation and decrease in real GDP .
As a result , the whole societ ,including the aged , will face a lot of problems as some of them are still seeking aid from the government .
Leaders of countries must rise above ideology and engage  practical realities to cope with the problem of a fast aging population .
Therefore , governments and policy makers have implemented some  policies  in easing the aging process  .
by doing this , governments can ensure the development of their countries and provide a better living environment  to all their people  .
For a country to do well , the government has to ensure that all areas of its development are well funded .
Healthcare , military , education , and research and development are just some of the key areas affecting a country's development .
With so many issues to be considered , it is certain that the funding available will never be sufficient .
Thus , it has always been a tough choice for the government to decide how much budget should be spent on the various areas of the country's development .
In recent years , the increasing severity of the aging problem has brought about yet another problem that requires action to be taken promptly .
One of the most direct solutions to the aging problem is to allow more public spending on the aged .
However , with the limited budget the country has , it is essential that the more important priorities are first taken care of before large scale policies are implemented to help the aged .
Secondly , the government should allocate its available resources wisely so as to obtain the most effective use of them .
To achieve this , money has to be channelled into  research and development  instead of spending excessively on the aged .
By doing so , our country will be able to progress more quickly .
New technologies and more efficient production methods will be discovered .
With these , the country will be well-equipped to ensure  sustained economic growth and to head towards a prosperous and progressive nation .
No doubt , some may argue that the nation should always show its gratitude to the elders of the nation by making sure that they are well taken care of .
However , if the country were to divert most of its public spending to the aged now , it is almost certain that it will face an arduous problem in the near future .
Neglecting the other areas of the country's development will hinder its progress and lead to limited economic growth and thus  a shrinking budget .
As mentioned by Friedland and Summer (2005) in "Doomsday Predictions about Population Aging Are Exaggerated" , with little economic growth , there are fewer choices about how to care for the elderly thus intensifying the problem on hand .
Therefore , it is  essential to ensure  healthy economic growth as it will provide many alternatives to the problems Singaporefaces .
As can be seen from the above arguments , due to the limited resources available , and the ever growing number of issues that need to be tended to , it is impossible to ensure that all areas of Singapore's development are well funded .
Thus , the government has to prioritize and allocate  resources wisely so that the goals of having a stable and prosperous nation can be achieved . .
With more emphasis placed on healthcare by governments today and the advancement of  medical technology , people get to live longer .
Cancers are not as deadly as in the past and new vaccines are constantly being developed .
People , including the elderly , are made less vulnerable to  diseases , and in a way , people become biologically stronger .
This also means an increase in the productivity of the aged physically .
McClatchy Newspapers (2008 , October 20) suggested that with the miracle of modern medicine , 60 might be the new 40 .
However , most treatments do not come cheap and chronic illnesses , especially , take a toll on their finances as people live longer .
"One hospitalisation , for example , a stroke can set you back  tens of thousands of dollars ," as stated by Associate Professor Paulin Straughan , sociologist , National University of Singapore in Channel NewsAsia (2009 , August 19) .
In fact , most elderly are not rich and many cannot afford the treatments .
Friedland and Summer highlighted that some segments of the aged population might be overlooked and remain very vulnerable .
For this group of people , most governments intervene to help  subsidise  treatments they genuinely need .
5 .R .
B . Friedland and L . Summer .
Doomsday Predications about Population Aging Are Exaggerated
Modern governments promise old age security , which ensures that their citizens can fend for themselves during old age .
The approaches , however , may vary from society to society .
In some like The United Kingdom and Canada , government pensions are distributed to the elderly .
In some others such as Singapore , the people are compelled to provide in advance for their old age  .
Some societies have laws in place to enforce children to take care of elderly parents .
For example , in Singapore , elderly parents may file in  court if their children do not provide for them .
However , there are various financial concerns about these methods .
In the case of government pensions , the heavy spending of public funds on the  aged may take a toll on other areas of the nation's development .
Thus a method that works in one society may not work in another and sometimes , multiple approaches have to be taken .
The aging process has been eased with the modernization of our society as better healthcare technology and government welfare are available to serve the elderly .
However , this revolution has generated a rising aging population which may be a problem to all levels of the society .
Governments in developed countries should look beyond temporary solutions to the rising aging population and focus on getting people to reproduce .
While there are initiatives like maternity welfare and the baby bonus to encourage reproduction ,  more can be done  for the better .

A Graying World
4 .R .
B . Friedland and L . Summer (2005) .
Demography Is Not Destiny , Revisited
Many people have argued that public spending on the aged is a must for countries facing the problem of an aging population as an ageing population has dire social , economical and cultural consequences on the country .
True as it seems , the question posed here is how  should  the government allocate its resources to cope with this problem .
As the saying goes , 'Give the man a fish and feed him for a day , teach the man to fish and feed him for a lifetime' .
Therefore , the use of the country's resources should be well diversified to different areas of the country's development so that no one area is compromised on .
With  elderly care hugely subsidized by the government , the aged will tend to be reliant on the government  providing for their old age .
This has caused the aged to be heavily dependent on the government and thus has developed a negative practice of the aged not saving for their own retirement .
It may be argued that the money which is not saved for retirement can be better spent elsewhere .
Adam Smith argues in his book Wealth of Nations that 'each individual is continually exerting himself to find out the most advantageous employment of whatever capital he can command' .
Although it is argued that the 'extra money' that the elderly possess will be better spent elsewhere , it may not be spent in the most efficient way possible .
Adam Smith also points out that individuals will act in their own advantage , not that of the society .
Therefore , the 'extra money' that the elderly possess at the expense of the government may not result in the most efficient allocation of resources .
With more money from public spending spent on the aged , this also means that there  is less money for the  other areas of development in the country .
Other areas of development that will increase the economic growth of the country will then be compromised .
One justification for economic growth is that with little economic growth , society faces fewer choices on how to care for those who are least able to care for themselves (Friedland and Summer , 2005) .
Critics of this position point out that when more money is spent on the aged , it  generates economic growth .
With better and more affordable healthcare services provided for  , the elderly can be healthier and more economically productive .
This will allow the elderly to be able to work for longer  and delay their retirement .
This will then increase the labour force of the country and result in economic growth .
However , this growth is limited .
There is a limit to the economic growth brought about by delaying the retirement age of the elderly .
Therefore , government resources should be allocated to areas of development that will generate potential economic growth which can be sustained .
This includes Research and Development (R&D) where more efficient healthcare methods can be devised .
By designating the role of the caregiver of the elderly to the government , "Asian values" such as filial piety will be eroded as children may shed the responsibility of taking care of their parents to the government .
It may be objected that these values are innate to one's identity and are not easily influenced or changed by other factors .
However , real life scenarios do actually show that these values can be influenced or eroded .
In Singapore , one is compelled to undertake the role of the caregiver and this  is backed up with law of maintenance of parent's act to ensure one fulfills one's filial obligations .
It is true that there are multiple advantages supporting public spending on the aged .
But in view of the many problems that a country would face if large amount of public spending are spent on the aged , it is only wise that the government  diversifies its public spending to other areas of development and strikes a balance among the other priorities .
The growing number of ageing population is an inevitable issue worldwide , especially in developed countries (Peterson , Fall 2001) .
Technological advancement enables humans to live longer .
On the other hand , the younger generation are chasing after 'an individualistic and 'live life to the fullest' lifestyle . .
This new generation would have the perception of enjoying life and not having family and children because they see it as a burden .
In the long run , this will translate into a low fertility rate in the country .
In the case of Singapore , the growing elderly population should not be accompanied by restrictions in public spending on the aged , which may come in the form of pension schemes , medical insurance , healthcare benefits and disability allowance .
This paper recommends that public spending on the elderly should not be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
This is because the current benefits that are provided for the elderly are still inadequate .
In terms of welfare and poverty ,  less than 5% of households in the low income group  are beneficiaries of the state-funded system .
Only 0 .07% received public assistance in 2004 (Asher & Nandy , 2008) .
If public spending on low income groups is limited , there would be fewer elderly who could benefit from government aid .
Therefore , an increase in social disparity and healthcare problems would be an issue for the country .
Although public spending on the elderly is an endless process as they don't generate much productivity to the country , social responsibility as a nation needs to be promoted . .
There are many elderly people who are unable to support themselves and have to take up jobs like road sweeping and toilet cleaning .

In summary the government should not limit  public spending on the elderly and divert it to other areas of the country's development .
This is due to the ascending numbers of elderly in the coming years that need to be dealt with (Friedland & Summer , 2005) .
These elderly were once the people who helped in building up the nation and the government should show their compassion and care for this vulnerable group by not restricting public spending on them .
It is vital that the expenditure on the elderly is delegated according to their needs so that wastage can be avoided .
Hence , more elderly people can benefit through this act and it would not be seen as wastage of the country's funds .

(2005 , March) .
Demography Is Not Destiny , Revisited .
The aging processes in Singapore with its ensuing serious impacts , has caught people's attention . .
The aging process requires special attention because due to the low birth rate , Singapore has became an aging country with a large fraction of its population being aged .
The government is currently carrying out research and implementing policies to help to ease the aging process for both the elderly and the country .
Researchers are mainly focusing on healthcare and infrastructure .
The former involves finding out the types of age-related illness that are likely to arise when people reach a certain age and measures that can be taken to reduce the occurrence of the illnesses .
The latter involves developing public facilities that cater to the needs of the elderly who are physically weak .
Besides that , various policies have also been introduced to aid the elderly .
These policies include granting subsidies that help to reduce the high cost of living , various HDB schemes to encourages children to live close to their parents as well as the upgrading of housing estate for the elderly .
The research and policies that have been continuously implemented for the aged in Singapore have worked well because of the pragmatic approach that has been taken .
Therefore , although all these approaches have  only provided limited ways of easing the aging process , they still offer a feasible and practical approach  .
Only a small group of the aging population faces these limitations and the government may also come out with other policies to solve these problems so that the approach implemented can be workable without any flaws and limitations .
Besides relying on the government , Singaporeans must also pay attention to the aging issue and help to play a part in reducing elderly dependence on the government .
For instance , they can help to take care of their aged parents ,or be a volunteer to contribute to a society that is gradually aging  .
People must put themselves in elderly people'sshoes and realize that one day they will also be aged and  need the support of their children and others .
It is believed strongly that one will be repaid for their kindness in treating others well .
Likewise , , peoplemay receive the same treatment  .
Firstly , despite the fact that the CPF is a flexible scheme to enforce savings for individuals , it has shown signs of weakness and has been seen as being insufficient to last for one's retirement years (Tsao , 2008) .
One of the fundamental reasons for insufficient funds in one's CPF is the need of the population to finance their public housing  .
Additionally , it is especially hard for elderly people  ,whose wages were low during the early 60s and 70s , to keep up with the rising cost of living (Burton , 2007) .
Furthermore , the CPF does not protect certain segments of the population who were not able to work and save during their younger days .
For instance ,  housewives were not able to contribute to their Medisave because they had to raise their family and chose not to work as a result .
In fact , Medisave will provide little or no protection for them in the event of illness .
Eventually , this does not only burden the aged with insufficient funds to support their medical expenditures but it also strains the relationship with their children as they need to provide more monetary contributions to their parents .
These reasons continue to urge the government to expand  public spending on the aged so as to sustain the needs and livelihood of the aged within the population .
Secondly , while the government has emphasized the concept of filial obligations in children , the underlying truth is that children are going through a hard time trying to provide for their elderly parents sufficiently throughout their retirement years .
In a survey , it was reported that 66 .0% of senior citizens aged 55 and above were provided with a regular cash contribution from their children .
Additionally , it has been shown that  dependence on children to finance their healthcare expenditure increased with age and only 35 .8% of senior citizens aged 55 and above have a clean bill of health (Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports [MCYS] , 2005) .
In other words , most elderly people are rather dependent on their children to support them , particularly those who suffer from chronic illnesses .
This dependence is coupled with rising health care costs that is taking a toll on their children's finances .
Besides , the decline in the number of children supporting elderly parents due to smaller family sizes ,puts further strain on  children (Wijaya , 2009) .
Therefore , the government ought to increase its public spending to assist and ease the strain of the children supporting their aged parents .
On the whole , as Singapore's population ages rapidly , it accentuates the need to increase  public spending on the aged in order to meet greater healthcare demands and the rising cost of living .
As discussed earlier  ,  rising healthcare costs coupled with longer living parents puts pressure on  cash-strapped children to provide for their elderly parents .
Apart from that , the aged are also burdened by  inadequate funds in their CPF accounts due to various reasons . .
In short , the aged need more financial help from the government so as to ease the strain on the elderly as well as their children .
Nowadays , the aging population is increasing and the problem is  more serious .
In  2008 , the proportion of the elderly in Singapore was 8 .6% and it is estimated that the proportion of the elderly in  2003 will increase to 18 .7% .
From another perspective , an increase in the aging population will lead to an increase in  government spending on the elderly .
According to statistics , the elderly dependency ratio in Singapore is 11 .9 per 100 in 2008 .
However , public spending on  senior citizens should be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development such as taking care of the needy , the unfortunate , the young and infrastructure .
Public funds that are saved can be used to develop the economy because economic growth will increase the  standard of living .
However , resources are limited .
The government cannot choose to develop everything because of the scarcity of resources , such as land , funds and workers .
Therefore , the government has to choose the most beneficial areas to invest in .
In addition , the government can also invest in areas where  profit and social welfare can be improved so that the  standard of living will be increased .
For example , investment will bring more job opportunities to the market due to the economic growth .
Therefore ,  citizens have more job options and find it easier to be hired .
Moreover ,  citizens can request  higher salaries as the economy has improved .
Higher salaries will encourage citizens to purchase more goods .
Therefore , the  standard of living will be much better compared to the past .
Accumulated public funds can be used to finance research and development .
Research and development is needed to discover new products and processes or to improve existing ones .
New products and technology will benefit  citizens by giving them satisfaction and convenience .
For example ,  new  medicines for the elderly to improve health , electronic wheelchairs for handicapped people and robots to take care of the children and elderly .
Moreover , some of the research and development is not only beneficial to the economy , but is also environmentally friendly .
Solar power is an example of environmentally friendly technology .
Solar power is an energy source obtainable by converting sunlight into electricity using photocells .
Therefore , environmental pollution can be lessened by reduced fuel usage . .
Have you ever asked yourself , How will we live in the old age ?
Who will take care of us ?
Our descendants , ourselves or the government Nowadays , more and more people have to concern themselves with these questions as the fast aging population is becoming a serious problem  which many countries are confronted with .
In my opinion , because there are a lot of effective methods to solve the agingproblem , except for medical and welfare programs , the government should limit spending on the aging population in order to develop other areas .
Firstly , public spending diverted from the aged to other important areas of the country's development can contribute to promote economic growth .
When the economy grows , fewer old persons need to be helped because of the following reasons .
The first point that should be taken into consideration is that the more economic growth there is , the more chances the elderly have to find jobs .
As a result , they can cover their everyday needs by themselves .
Moreover , with sufficient economic growth , more services are supplied to care for the old .
For example , people can invite nurses to their homes to look after their old parents everyday , or the elderly can live in rest homes with creature comforts and a lot of care .
So , to ease the aging problem , economic growth should be accentuated .
Last but not least , reducing public spending on the aged helps to stress filial obligation .
Because few medical and welfare programs are launched when government expenditure on the aging populationdecreases  , many people may have not enough money to send their old parents to rest homes .
They have to spend more time taking care of their parents by themselves .
So , there are more opportunities for descendants to express their love and gratitude to their parents and grandparents .
As a result , family sentiment is enhanced significantly within societyin society
In conclusion , because of enhanced economic growth , ensuring better lives for future generations of older people and stressing filial obligation , limiting public spending on the aged in order to invest in other  areas of the country's development is a good approach to solve the global aging problem .
In order to make the most of the limited budget for the aging population , the government should concentrate on supporting people who really need aid such as older single women .
An aging population is a common situation in many developed countries .
With the number of elderly increasing rapidly there are numerous problems like deterioration of health .
There is a need for governments to focus on these problems , in order to improve the welfare of the aged .
However , this may lead to an issue of whether the governments should limit their public fund on the aged .
One argument is that , instead of limiting spending , it is morally right to spend money on the aged who contributed most of their life to nation building .
The public funding spent on the construction of medical infrastructure as well as the building of elderly friendly houses are beneficial to all  human beings .
The reason is that the process of aging occurs to everyone .
It is just a matter of time .
Since there is no way to escape aging , the government needs to pay a lot of pay a lot of attention to the issues relating to aging .
During the Singapore national day rally , Prime Minster Lim Hsien Loong pointed out the need to improve the health care system for the aged .
There is a need to make health care more accessible and affordable to the aged .
Therefore , the government has implemented the three M policies -Medifund , MediShield and Medicsave .
In addition , the government is focusing on  care too .
For example , the co-operation between the Changi general hospital and St Andrew's community health care .
These measures help to reduce expensive medical fees for the aged as well as catering to the needs of the elderly .
These measures will benefit the younger citizens in times to come .
Therefore , it is rather wiser to focus on the aging issue and solve it before it backfires .
On the other side of the coin , if the needs of the elderly are well taken care off , they will still be capable of contributing to society .
The elderly bring years of knowledge , experiences and business contacts with them .
They are just like encyclopedias which provide wise advice for the younger worker who may not be experienced .
In acting as the role of advisor , they will help the company to progress economically .
For example , Lee Kuan Yew , Minister Mentor of Singapore , is still active in politics by advising young politicians .
The requirement for Mr . Lee to remain active in politics is good health .
Thus , it is crucial for the government to spend more public funds in dealing with medical problems of the aged .
In conclusion , public spending on the aged should not be limited .
Critics may argue that other areas such as education require public funding as well .
I agree that other areas do need public funding , and indeed money has to be spent on it .
However , a developed country will have the ability to take care of all the areas .
Moreover , by taking care of the aged , it will portray the country to be a gracious and caring nation .
This positive impression will in turns attract foreigners to choose the country as a destination for pleasure .
This will benefit the country economically .
An aging population is a problem affecting many global countries .
With an increasing aging population , countries will face lower productivity and increased social and health care costs .
Therefore , part of public spending should be placed on the interest of the elderly and the rest should be diverted to other areas of the country's development to help boost economic growth .
First and forth most , education is one of the aspects that could greatly help to boost a country's economy .
Though it is a long term investment which takes many years to  help generate income for the country ,  it is definitely worth the investment .
When the government steps in to provide subsidies for eligible students to further their education , the country has a population with higher qualifications as it covers more of those less fortunate families who could not afford the huge amount of school fees  .
Next , research and development is another important aspect that could help boost a country's economy .
For example , the European Commission has contributed 2 billion to ICT research projects as ICT is one of the areas that underpin Europe's economic performance and it is pivotal to its economic growth (Europe's Information Society , 2008) .
It is stated in the article that "it is essential to have continuous investment in research and development when  difficult policy decisions to support the real economy worldwide" (Europe's Information Society , 2008) .
Another example , 2 .4% of Singapore's GDP; amounting to 3 billion euros , is spent on research and development (Gafoor , 2008) .
Nevertheless , Singapore is planning to increase its spending to 6 .8 billion euros by 2010 and targets to spend 3% of their GDP (Gafoor , 2008) .
The main objective of the investment is to build knowledge in three areas; bio-technology , environmental technology , and digital media and information technology , for the rapid growth in Asia .
Last but not least , business opportunities can be created with government effort .
A well constructed environment where visitors enjoy good Internet connectivity and teleconferencing facilities in most hotels , convention halls and exhibition venues , opens up the opportunity to attract local and foreign corporations .
For example , Singapore put a lot of effort inton constructing a place for business travellersOne of their notable examples is the Novotel Clarke Quay Singapore , which is an ideal venue to hold MICE events that had just recently renovated its facilities (Uniquely Singapore , 2006) .
Thus , in  2006 , Singapore won the award of 'The Corporate Meeting of The Year' (Uniquely Singapore , 2006) .
This Award helped to enhance Singapore hotel positioning as a venue for business travellers and MICE events (Uniquely Singapore , 2006) .
Coupled with a good education systemand powerful research and development ,  creating business opportunities is  part of the key to attracting more businesses and foreign talents into a country , as people are always interested in working in a vibrant country .
By doing so , a country's development will be improved as there is circulation of wealth when trading is performed .
On the other hand , if most  public spending is used on easing the aging process , it will slow down economic growth because it's more of a cost than income for the country .
The cost of  more suitable healthcare , infrastructure , transportation , housing , pensions and financial aid for the elderly is necessary to help ease the aging process However , spending should be limited as the  health and economic value of the elderly decline , and emotional and social problems increase .
This is because in the long run , if most money is spent on accommodating the older population , there will be little economic growth , and society will face  fewer choices on how to care for those in need (Robert & Summer , 2005) .
On the other hand , with sufficient economic growth , there will be more choices available to help those in need and there will also be fewer persons in need (Robert & Summer , 2005) .
In addition , governments will be able to ensure the continuation of welfare programmes for the elderly .
It is widely known that the source of the government's money comes from the citizens .
Where is all the money invested ?
It has always been for the development of Singapore and its people .
However , Singapore is faced with an inevitable crisis: a growing aging population that is affecting the country's economy (Lee , 2008) because of the assistance the government has to render for the elderly .
The elderly have been perceived as the nation's burden .
Should the government pay more attention to a specific group when their children are financially stable and forsake the country's future ?
Hence , it can be argued that the government should limit their expenditure on the elderly so that money can be directed to other aspects of the country's development .
On the contrary , the elderly need the government to support them and the government should do so .
This is because the elderly do not have the capability to work and fend for themselves .
The cost of medical and healthcare is increasing and this causes problems for families especially those earning a low income .
The cost of living in Singapore is high such that children have resorted to abandoning their parents .
It is the responsibility of the government to take care of and ensure that their citizens are not suffering and to ease their plight , especially in times of recession .
The elderly have played their part in their younger days by paying for taxes and it is only reasonable for the government to repay them .
With the inflating cost of health care in Singapore , the government cannot avoid implementing schemes such as Medisave and Medishield .
However , Singapore should not be dependent on the government for fiscal aid .
In the context of the elderly , the reason why the government has to spend a lot of money on them is due to the fact that children nowadays are abandoning their parents either in hospitals or old folk homes .
Why are children doing so ?
Burress (2007) argues that we should care for our parents and shower them with undivided love and attention because we will want the love and care when we are in our golden years .
However , unpleasant and traumatic experiences from childhood may be the reasons that push children to desert their parents .
The children now hold a grudge against the parents and refuse to provide for them now that they are grown up .
However , not all parents are like that .
Children have an unprecedented obligation to care for their own parents .
They have cared for us when we were young .
Looking back and considering living conditions in the past , the sacrifices they made then are no match for anything we would ever do in the present .
The value of filial piety has no significant meaning in Singapore's "individualistic world view ," as mentioned by Assistant Professor Joonmo Son from National University of Singapore (cited in Liew , 2009) .
However , the children have to realise that  not assuming their responsibilities to care for their parents , affects the whole society .
Tax prices may need to be increased to meet the needs of providing financial aid for the aged .
The elderly should also consider ageing actively and with dignity .
They should not be too reliant on the government or their children for help .
Instead , they should look for avenues which allow them to maximise their abilities and talents in their golden years .
For example , the Council for Third Age is an organisation that strives for "an active ageing culture" (Active Ageing , 2009) .
This is achieved through events that allow the elderly to organise activities for themselves .
Additionally , the Council organises Grandparents Day to "celebrate and honour" (Active Ageing , 2009) our grandparents for their significant contributions for us .
With this , hopefully our elderly could regain a positive light in life and have a circle of friends whom they can trust and depend on .
Moreover , they should try and find means of working part-time jobs that are suitable for their age so that they could provide for themselves and also meet new people and make more friends .
This  will help increase  psychological and emotional well being .
In conclusion , public spending on the elderly is necessar .
However to a certain extent ,  the government cannot be relied on as they too have other areas of development to look out for .
Furthermore , not every parent is lucky enough to have children who could love them and fulfil their wants and needs .
Instead of helping them with monetary schemes , the government should implement new initiatives such as psychological and emotional support that encourages the elderly to get out of their misery and age actively .
Singapore , well-known for its top city infrastructure , has been ranked 26th in a quality of living survey done by Mercer (2009) .
The criterion for being a city with top infrastructure includes having excellent airport facilities and an extensive transport system (Mercer , 2009) .
Singapore has one of the best education systems in the world , thus attracting students from all over the world .
With regards to the controversies on how public spending should be distributed , the main focus should be on creating a more conducive environment for the old since Singapore's reputation as a global education hub is unrivalled .
The fact remains that education helps individuals gain knowledge and insights into life , which is the basis of civilisation and is vital for a nation's political stability in the long run .
Learning from the mistakes of past politicians , current leaders will avoid making the same blunders .
With proper education , leaders will know which policies are good for the country , when they should be implemented and how long the policy should be in place .
In spite of having a world-renowned education system , the leaders should strive to make improvements instead of just being contented with the current situation .
For instance , the government should adopt a more holistic approach so that the skills learned in classrooms can be adapted to the globalising world .
With its well-reputed education system , the focal point of public spending should instead be placed on the elderly .
Prime Minister Lee pointed out in a newspaper report (Mathavan , 2009) that the country should not overlook the issue of caring for the elderly and provide health care subsidies .
Due to the high standards of living , the huge medical expenses incurred by the elderly not only strain their children emotionally , but financially as well .
To address this issue , the government came up with the Primary Care Partnership Scheme (2008) where subsidies are given out accordingly after an income assessment is done .
However , this may be insufficient due to the stringent criteria placed on the Per Capita Income Rate of Subsidy .
The income assessment overlooks details such as a family having more than one elderly person that requires medical attention  .
In this case , they might encounter difficulties in paying for the medical fees as they have more than one elderly person to look after .
As such , the income assessment should be revised to provide a more concise evaluation of a family's financial situation .
In this way , public spending can be used to provide more medical subsidies for the elderly .
In this growing society , younger generations are getting more educated .
Unlike in the past , younger generations nowadays are more work oriented .
They are reluctant to start a family and even though they are married , they do not wish to have any children .
They feel that having children will hinder their progress in their careers .
On the other hand , life expectancy  has increased because people have become more affluent .
Thus , the aging population is now an increasing problem globally .
A very good example is Japan .
A case study in 2008 has shown that 20% of the population now in Japan is sixty-five years old and above .
By  2030 , the percentage of the population who is sixty-five years old and above will rise to 38 .1% .
An aging population will be a never ending problem in this modern society .
Increasing  public spending on the aged will not be able to solve this problem .
Thus , public spending on the aged should be limited and the money should be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
Firstly , increasing public spending on the aged will only make the aged dependent on the government .
The government should encourage the aged to extend their service to the workforce .
In Singapore , the government extended the retirement age from 62 years old to 65 years old .
People may think that it is time for the aged to enjoy their life because they have slogged for many decades  , but they do not know that most of the aged are still fit and healthy .
If a person is employed , it is beneficial for their physical well being .
In addition , it will also benefit the country's economy .
This proves that it is not necessary for the government to increase  their budget on the aged if their aged population are able to cope financially .
The money on the other hand can be put to good use by improving on their research and development .
Lastly , policies have been implemented by  countries to help the aged .
In Singapore , the government has enforced individual savings through mandatory Central Provident Funds (CPF) , which mandates that the population saves for old age .
However , people might argue that the aged have their children to depend on  , but this dependence is straining on family ties as average health care costs rise .
Having a saving fund for them would be a better choice .
Hence , by having this CPF scheme , the government is able to cut down on  spending on the aged and  put it to better use by diverting it to  other areas of the country's development , thus improving the country's economyeconomy of the country
In conclusion , public spending should be limited and money diverted to  other areas of a country's development . .
Through research and development and having the correct policies , a country not only will take care of their aged , it will also improve its economy .
This will not only help the current aged , it will also enable the present generation to be able to enjoy healthy and fulfilling lives into their sunset years without putting a heavy burden on their children and grandchildren .
To a large extent , current policies have helped to ease the aging process .
Being one of the top aging populations in Asia , Singapore has to be prepared for the challenges to be faced currently  ,or in the future , when Singapore turns into a prominent ageing society .
In order to take care of the challenges , the Singapore government has implemented several policies  ,such as housing , health and employment policies , to overcome the obstacles of the aging phenomenon as well as to provide  .
One of the policies is the housing policy , which strongly encourages extended families by providing incentives and  elderly-friendly housing for  senior citizens .
A report bythe Government of Singapore 2000 , shows that in the year 2000 , around 9 out of 10 senior citizens who were above sixty-five years old were living together with their children (Government of Singapore 2000) .
This may due to the various housing schemes which resulted in a high rate of elderly staying with their children .
Some of the housing schemes implemented by the Housing Development Board (HDB)  include the Multi-Tier Housing Scheme , the Joint Selection Scheme , and the CPF Housing Grant Scheme (Kalyani K . Mehta , 2002) .
The Multi-Tier Housing Scheme iwas introduced to encourage married children to live together under one roof with their parents or vice versa .
This scheme allows extended-family applicants to be given priority allocation on the flats they want to live in .
The Joint Selection Scheme  allows families to choose the flats in priority order so that  married children and parents can stay in separate HDB flats but close together ,  in the same neighboring town or estate (Kalyani K . Mehta , 2002) .
Finally , the CFP Grant Scheme was also introduced to encourage married children to live near their parents by offering a higher grant if their flat is near their parents' home compared to those who are either staying alone  , or not staying close to their parents .
Apart from these schemes , Singapore is also trying hard to create an elderly-friendly environment by: modifying lifts to stop on every floor;using non-slip floor tiles to minimize the danger of elderly people slipping and falling; having support hand bars in toilets; installing alert alarm systems; and building  ramps and link ways to facilitate wheelchair access .
Housing schemes and building an elderly-friendly environment would definitely allow the elderly to live more comfortably 
Health care policies for the aged have been getting noticed in recent years .
The government has been aggressively promoting awareness of health care issues among the ageing society .
For instance , old people who do not have any health care indemnity have been advised to have  Medishield accounts with support given from the government (Chan , Angelique 2002) .
This account permits individuals to pay for their medical bills .
Besides , the government helps in subsidizing health screening programs for senior citizens .
A person aged over 60 is allowed to perform a basic health-screening test with just S$5 (Kalyani K . Mehta , 2002) .
Despite having various schemes for health care  , there are still numerous  underprivileged senior citizens who cannot afford their medical expenses especially for  prolonged illnesses such as strokes and rheumatism .
Thus the Medifund was established to provide aid for those who are unable to pay for healthcare services (Ministry of Health ,2010) .
Needy patients are hence , able to apply and use this fund to pay for their healthcare services .
In general , healthcare policies have been contributing a lot to meet the needs of the 'aged Singaporeans' .
Last but not least , it is important to make the elderly an asset to Singapore's society by giving senior citizens who are physically capable the opportunity to work .
The government has started to put emphasis on the re- training of the older workers to work more efficiently and productively (Chan , Angelique 2002) .
Not only that , the government has also extended the retirement age of  individuals .
This permits the aged population to continue serving society and also in certain ways helps to build confidence in the elderly .
In any case , a lopsided spending will only compromise progress for other sectors which in turn will lead to other social and economic problems .
First , Education spending is a long term investment that a country cannot neglect .
If the budget over emphasizes on the aged , this will result in insufficient funding for Education  , greatly compromising the academic intelligence of the younger generation .
This will create a huge economic cost to the country .
When the population is less educated , the country's general growth declines , , especially in the area of Research and Development that requires highly educated personnel to function .
The correlation between economic growth and spending on the aged must be understood .
With economic growth , the budget available will increase and the government can afford to spend the same portion of the budget yet providing a larger real sum .
Robert B . Friedland and Laura Summer (2005) mentioned that with economic growth , there will be a lower demand for government handouts and there will be more funds made available for elderly welfare programmes .
Thus education , which helps to sustain future economic growth , is an aspect where  spending on the aged must be carefully limited in order to prevent any compromise .
To conclude , the role of government in providing assistance to the elderly , either to show its appreciation or simply to those who are in need , cannot be denied .
Robert B . Friedland and Laura Summer (2005) , point out that a group of uneducated or single elderly remains vulnerable as they did not have the means to save up for a decent retirement when they were working .
But it should be remembered  that while  sympathy and appreciation for the aged must remain , it must not be overdone because there are more than just the aged to look after .
Thus spending on the aged is necessary  , however , it should be carefully limited so as not to compromise other sectors and overall national interest in the long run .

In this modern era , ageing populations have become a phenomenon in many countries , especially those which hold records of past baby boom and present low fertility rates , like Singapore and Japan .
This rising trend in the median age of the population has drawn much attention to the welfare benefits of the elderly .
While liberals view social welfare as a legitimate function of government and provision of welfare as citizens' rights , it can be argued that the welfare state may end up heading towards a 'bottomless pit'- one which requires relentless public spending , in this case , on the aged and is indifferent to a person's capability in attaining self-sufficiency .
Also , to ensure a nation's continual economic growth and social development , much of the fiscal earnings  should be utilized on other areas like investments and education .
Therefore to maintain a healthy balance between various demands and to reduce dependency , , there should be a boundary set on the public expenditure for care for the elderly .
Nevertheless , some may argue that it  one's "entitlement" to receive a pension and other forms of material benefits upon retirement  (Fernandez , 1994) .
To deprive one of his privileges is an inhumane act .
However , this may create an impression that one can rely on the state during old-age , and result in the sapping of  incentives to work and save for retirement  .
Since an ageing population would translate into a growing number of 'beneficiaries' , the figures of public expenditure would thus be expected to multiply and eventually become such a vast amount that it could go beyond the financial capability of the welfare state societies .
To avoid such social repercussions , free-flow expenditure on eldercare that can draw individual dependency on the nation should be prohibited . .
On the whole , public spending on the aged should not be made at the expense of the progress of other sectors .
Also , restrictive expenditure will avert the formation of "welfare dependency" but promote the building of a "compassionate society" through family-centred policies  (Chua , 1993) .
The concept of a welfare-state should be especially avoided in countries with scarce resources like Singapore , because in times of financial difficulties , they will have no resources to tap on but have  to rely solely on themselves (Clasen , 2001) .To be on the safe side , policy-makers should allocate fiscal earnings in a diverse manner , and not solely on maintaining the aged .
The aging problem is an important issue that governments areworrying about .
Peterson (2001) even claims that the aging problem will worsen as the median age of the elderly will reach around 50 by 2050 in many first world countries .
This prediction is further supported by a survey conducted by the World Bank ,  .
With the growing population of the elderly , governments have put in a lot of effort , by providing financial assistance and grants for example , in order to ease the issue effectively .
However , some people disagree with the government's policy and claim that there is a need to limit  public spending on the aged so thatt the money is diverted to other areas to attain a balanced  economic and social development .
Moreover , it can also be argued that the government's approach is not a good remedy to cope with the aging problem permanently .
Public spending on the elderly should be limited .
Some people may argue that limited public spending on the elderly  .
The aged have contributed a lot to form and shape  society .
Limiting public spending has a deeper meaning , that the government doesn't acknowledge their contributions to the country .
However , this is not entirely true since spending money on other suitable sectors may be a better and perhaps permanent solution to solve this aging problem .
Education is a good example that helps to solve this issue more effectively .
It ensures that the young generation is well educated , full of knowledge and able to think critically .
This may indirectly help them to think and spend wisely in their future so that they are less dependent on the government as their future is financially secured .
Besides , instilled moral values remind them of the importance of taking up the filial obligation with  their parents .
Moreover , it benefits more citizens rather than the elderly .
For example , it actually helps to ease the poverty problem since the lack of formal education among the poor contributes to the poverty issue directly .
Hence , public spending on the education should be stressed as well since it helps to solve the aging issue more effectively , rather than keeping on spending money on the elderly 
In conclusion , public spending on the aged should be limited .
It does not mean that the government doesn't take good care of the elderly or doesn't acknowledge their contributions in the past .
However , from another  perspective , the money diverted to other areas or sectors such as industry , tourism , social work professional associations and education , help to form a more rigid and structured society .
Moreover , public spending on these areas has a wider coverage rather than focusing only on the aged .
Hence , for a better future , public spending on the aged should be limited .
The aging issue  worldwide was not pressing until  the large population of the Baby Boomers generation began to welcome their golden years .
As medical facilities and technologies have continued to evolve , so have the lifespan of  modern mortals prolonged .
Global life expectancy at birth , which is estimated to have risen from 58 years in 1970-1975 to 67 years in 2005-2010 , is expected to keep on rising to reach 75 years in 2045-2050 (United Nations , 2007) .
Demographic changes due to the rapid aging population will post serious consequences on health issues as well as the economy of the country .
In recognition of this problem , current policies as well as research and development that have been implemented has yielded to ease the aging process .
An aging population is often associated with a decline in the workforce and the productivity of the country .
For example , Denton and Spencer (1998) noted that the rate of growth  per capita GDP is certain to fall significantly over the coming decades unless either the immigration rate or the productivity growth rate increases  dramatically .
It is the ageing of the population that lies behind this concern (as cited in Scarth , 2002) .
Therefore , policies such as Angel Policy 1989 , New Angel Policy 1999 and the "Angel Plan , Plus-One" 2003 , have been introduced and implemented in  Japan to increase the birthrate and expand the workforce of the future as to maintain productivity of the country (Cardiosk , 2008)(Devasahayam , Yeoh , 2007)  .
The size of tomorrow's economy and tax base  should be increased by raising more productive children so that the cost burden is spread over a larger and more affluent future generation (Peterson , 2001) .
Another alternative carried out by Japan is to use their advancement in science and technology to curb the aging issues by using robots in their workforce .
Japan has innovatively modified robots to put them in production lines and the service industry  as substitutes for their aging workforce .
These two measures have attempted to reduce the reliance of the workforce on the aging population and to soothe the pressing matter of the aging population .
