The world's population underwent rapid growth in the 1950s and 60s .
This was the period of the post-war 'baby boom' as there was peace and stability .
Today , these 'baby boomers' form the majority of our population .
It is expected that by 2030 , about nineteen percent of the world's population will be over the age of sixty-five .
Indeed , this illustrates a concern for an ageing population .
However taking a look around us today , current research , development and various policies have evolved to an extent large enough to dismiss  concerns about a greying population .
These measures and policies  have greatly aided the elderly with their ageing process .
This is especially so in the area of social policies , namely government grants and healthcare benefits .
Other social policies established to help ease the ageing process include the Central Provident Fund .
This comes across as forced savings where members can withdraw their savings on reaching the age of fifty-five years , leaving a minimum sum in their retirement account .
From the age of sixty-two , members receive a monthly sum from their retirement account , ensuring they still have money left to fund their old age .
This social policy has helped many to remain self-sufficient in their elderly years .
Also , this has achieved the reduction of elder dependency by encouraging later retirement and longer working lives .
Such is an example of raising the eligibility age for public pensions and government incentives .
At the same time , when people work longer , they will be able to accumulate more wealth which they could use to support themselves in their old age .
In the area of healthcare policies , there are a handful of available measures which have essentially helped ease the ageing process .
Firstly , one such example is the Medisave fund , whereby a portion from a member's central provident fund is channelled into their medisave account where the money can be used to pay for hospital bills and certain medical treatments which are expensive .
This measure curbs elderly people's worry of escalating healthcare costs , which they find themselves more liable for in their older years .
Secondly , direct subsidies are given to government hospitals , polyclinics and some nursing homes for the elderly to ensure that basic healthcare services are made available for all Singaporean senior citizens .
The ageing process is made easier as worry about health issues and expenses are greatly reduced .
As illustrated , currently , many social policies exist which have become widely available .
These policies cater to the varying needs of the ageing population be it in financial terms or healthcare .
Today , the concerns involved with the ageing process  and a majority of people's concerns about a greying population have been dismissed .
The elderly are greatly aided with their ageing process through government grants , healthcare benefits and many other social policies made available to them to be easily utilised .
People today are able to  ease the aging process because of current research and development .
One area of focus is on psychology .
In psychology studies , scientists analysed human mental functions and behaviours and came out with solutions to help the elderly ease their process of aging .
[1]
Through research , psychologists found out that elderly people get depressed easily .
This is mainly due to ageism .
For instance , in the work place , some young adults develop prejudice and discrimination against the older people because they feel that the elderly are less efficient and no longer productive .
Therefore , the aging process  can be eased by helping the elderly develop a positive attitude towards life .
The elderly tend to think that they are incompetent and useless as they no longer contribute to society .
Firstly , life long learning  is emphasized to help them .
They can upgrade their skills by taking up enrichment courses like computer classes .
At the end of the course , a certificate will be awarded to them if they have successfully attained the skill .
This can boost their confidence in securing a .
Secondly , "a community work approach can change old people from passive clients into active and empowered individuals with a positive self-image ."
[2] According to one study , 20-25 percent of the elderly in nursing homes are clinically depressed .
[5] They often feel lonely and helpless as they have no one to confide in .
Now many community service clubs like NUS CSC have gathered volunteers to visit these elderly at least once a week .
In this way , the elderly can get involved in community activities which in turn make them look forward to the next session .
On the other hand , critics feel that these solutions can only help the elderly to a certain extent .
It only eases aging temporarily .
However , it is not true .
Easing the aging process is just about making them feel better .
As long as the elderly are engaged in their busy lives , they will actually feel not much different from the young ones .
For retired elderly , they may even feel better as there is no stress from work .
The saying goes: "You're only as old as you feel" .
The solutions from current research and development can help elderly people to feel young and create a positive attitude towards life , and to a large extent help to ease aging .
Caring for the oldcontroversial topic has been put forward .
It is about whether public spending on the aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
As far as I am concerned , we should not limit the public spending on the aged .
The reasons are as follows: Firstly , put first thing first .
Secondly , cutting down public spending may arouse the complaints of the public .
Thirdly , limiting the public spending on the aged will surely increase the load over the youth .
Aging populations are a global phenomenon which affects economic growth , sustainability within families and public spending .
It is caused by declining fertility and rising life expectancy .
It reduces economic growth as the size of the workforce shrinks as more elderly people leave the workforce and less people are recruited into the workforce  .
Another impact is the sustainability of families , because there are far less children supporting far more elderly .
This results in severe financial stress for the working population .
Public spending  is also stressed to provide pensions , building infrastructureand healthcare catered for the elderly .
Therefore , Public spending for the aged should be limited because 
It is impractical for public spending on the aged not to be limited .
If it is not limited , then it will increase indefinitely .
Either other areas of public spending have to receive less funding  , or taxes have to be raised to allow for more funds to be spent on the aged .
These two solutions are both impractical .
Firstly , public funding on other sectors is also limited and cannot be reduced as they are equally important .
Housing and healthcare are basic needs of people .
The military is needed for the defense of the nation .
Public spending on technology cannot be reduced as it is a substitute for the decline in productivity of a shrinking workforce .
This is because , technology provides the automation and machines to increase productivity solving the problem of a shrinking workforce .
Secondly , the main income for public spending is from taxes , especially income taxes from the working population with services tax forming the largest proportion .
If taxes are raised substantially , it would  worsen the severe financial stress for the working population and adversely impact the consumer market .
Therefore , public spending on the aged definitely has to be limited , ensuring enough funding goes to other sectors such as education , military , technology , transport , housing , healthcare , sports , etc which are equally important so as  not to increase taxes for the working population .
The government should limit  public spending on healthcare for the aged , and the limit should satisfy the healthcare needs of all the elderly .
Healthcare has become more of a want rather than a basic need .
The government has to distinguish between needs and wants .
Needs are consultation and medication upon falling ill .
Wants are usually specialist services that perform detailed checkups to determine the underlying cause of the illness , analysis of patients' symptoms to predict illnesses they might contract and certain pharmaceutical medicines which act as supplements .
The wanted healthcare costs are significantly higher as specialist services and pharmaceuticals use high technology equipment and expertise .
Therefore , individuals should pay for what is wanted and only needs should be subsidized by the government  to reduce public spending on healthcare for the aged .
The government should also support healthcare costs for those elderly in families with financial problems as poverty  if basic healthcare is not provided to everyone .
The elderly are extremely susceptible to certain illnesses due to age .
These illnesses or diseases could be non-communicable or chronic which include cardiovascular disease , dementia and Alzheimer's disease , cancer , arthritis and diabetes .
Hence , self reliance such as retirement savings has to be in place first to allow the elderly to be able to pay for illnesses which they might contract later .
Otherwise , it would be a huge drain on government resources to pay for all their medical expenses .
In conclusion , the world should shift towards fostering an elderly friendly society that values their contribution and allows them to be part of the community .
It should also inculcate a strong sense of self reliance among the workforce to prepare them for their old age .
This would reduce their dependence on children or government to support them and not hinder the growth of other areas of the country's development  , as these other areas currently receive fewer funds due to the increasing amount of funds being diverted into helping the growing aged population .

As psychology develops , it has benefitted human a lot , helping people know more about themselves .
Furthermore , current psychological research and development have indeed helped to ease the aging process by dealing with elderly depression , promoting life-long learning and eliminating ageism .

With the population of aged getting larger in society a big sum of money is involved in helping the aged .
If this huge amount of spending is reduced , but in turn , spent on other areas of the country's development , the wealth of the country can reach a  .
To many people , limiting the amount of money to be spent on the elderly can be perceived as being cruel to them .
However , it is necessary  to be realistic and pragmatic .
A country's development is the key element to bring wealth to the country , so as to improve the living quality of the future generation .
With sufficient funds , the country can spend on manpower , education , investment , construction and other aspects to aid in its development .
A well-developed country can bring wealth and boost the economy of the country .
With that , the citizens can get to improve their living standards and quality of life .
For that reason , spending on areas that serve the purpose of helping a country's growth is essential to the country .
If the government continues to splurge a lot in funding the aged , the country's capital would ultimately become unbalanced and would be insufficient to spend on the other areas , for instance , education .
Imagine a country  that has slower development in education .
In the near future , children in the country would have a lower chance to be educated .
With little knowledge and skills , the country would be poor and would not grow .
In a nutshell , a country's funding for both aged and young should be balanced out .
People need to be more practical and far-sighted to  consider the next generation in the country .
This can be done by building up funds for the country's development , while not overdoing funding for the aged .
The main focus should be on the country's development .
Therefore , public spending on the elderly should be restricted .
Public spending on the aged should not be limited because this is part of the country's development and social well being .
It is equally important as the other aspects of the country's development .
Some countries are experiencing an aging population , for example Japan , which is facing rapid change  , had a 5 .1%1 increase in aging population over the last 30 years .
This figure is expected to increase as more elderly  reach 65 years old .
Countries such as Singapore are also facing rapid aging population growth with a decreasing fertility rate  of 0 .31%1 over the past 7 years .
If this trend continues , Singapore will be second after Japan  .
An aging population  affects the country's economy because of the high retirement rate and the increased need for providing healthcare for the elderly .
therefore public spending should not be limited  because it is still part of the country's responsibility to take care of the aged population .
Secondly , as the country's aging population increases , health problems become one of the concerns for the elderly .
For most developed and developing countries , healthcare will become an issue .
As the cost of living increases , the cost of healthcare also increases  .
For instance , healthcare is an issue in the United States  .
Any healthcare cost will become a burden to the elderly as well as to their family members .
On the other hand , countries such as Singapore have policies which help the elderly to cover their medical expenses .
ElderShield plan , an insurance scheme , covers medical treatment expenses for severe disabilities especially for the elderly .
This will not be possible if a limitation on public spending on the aged is imposed .
However , a significant amount of the country's funds should be spent on improving the country's economy , which in turn creates more job opportunities .
For instance , during the current economic downturn , public funding should be diverted to developing more facilities , which will in turn improve ththe economy .
One example is the recent government project of the integrated resort , which will create job opportunities and attract people to spend money when it is completed .
If the economy of the country is not growing , it may affect  businesses  within the country , which in turn affects the employment rate .
Therefore , public spending on the aged should not be limited as they are still part of the country's development and social well being .
It is still part of the country's social responsibility to take care of the aged population .
As a Chinese saying goes , the aged population is actually a treasure to the country .
However a significant amount of funding should also be diverted to other  to stimulate the economy and help the country and its people to survive the economic downturn .

In conclusion ,  many technologies  have helped to ease the aging process by a large extent .
Aging would become much more difficult and uncomfortable without these technologies . 
One of the most challenging issues in the world now is  the ability to meet  the increase in energy demand .
Current resources like  fossil fuel , which is used to generate electricity , will eventually be depleted in a few centuries' time (Mitenkov , Kodochigov , Vasyaev , Golovko , Ponomarev-Stepnoi , Kukharkin & Stolyarevskii , 2004) .
One of the solutions to this problem is the Generation IV nuclear reactors .
Among all the proposed reactors , the Very-High-Temperature Reactor (VHTR) is the most suitable option in terms of its design (Mitenkov et al . , 2004) .
Although there are public opponents who do not wish for the nuclear reactors to be built due to potential threats , past incidences and cost , the Generation IV VHTR aims to overcome these negative aspects with funding for its research and development  .
Nuclear reactors are known to be a potential terrorist target .
This is one of the reasons why opponents among the public do not wish for nuclear reactors to be built .
However , according to Butler (2004) , the VHTR has the capability to decrease its own temperature should there be any accident , with minimum operators' involvement .
Therefore , the likelihood of reactors melting down because of terrorists shutting off the coolant to the VHTR is minimised .
Furthermore , terrorist attacks could also come in many other forms; one well-known example is  terrorist attack upon the United States on 11 September 2001 which did not involve nuclear reactors .
Therefore , it can be concluded that if terrorists are determined to destroy a country , they could still use different methods even if nuclear reactors are present in the country .
In addition , since terrorists know that there will be extra precautions taken to safeguard the nuclear reactors , it will be more difficult for them to sabotage the country by means of the nuclear reactors .
In order to make the VHTR  much less attractive as a target to the terrorists , funding for research and development is necessary  to develop simpler safety interlock systems and  materials which can withstand very high temperatures to build the reactor .
The public being nuclear-averse is also the result of the past accidents at Three Mile Island and Chernobyl in Pennsylvania and Ukraine respectively .
The former was caused by operators not being able to respond to a sudden shutdown of the reactor .
Moreover , the cooling system of the reactor was not properly set up; hence , overheating caused the reactors' core to melt and become severely damaged (World Nuclear Association , 2009) .
The VHTR can reduce the occurrence of this incident by incorporating a simple cooling system which does not need skilled operators (Butler , 2004) .
Thus , with careful , well trained operators and better cooling systems , the probability of accidents happening will be reduced .
As for the other accident which happened in Chernobyl , it was a result of operators , who were not well trained in operation and safety , operating on a reactor which was inadequately designed (World Nuclear Association , 2009) .
These factors led to 56 deaths by 2004 as a result of the reactors' explosion and therelease of radioactive materials into the surroundings (World Nuclear Association , 2009) .
It was noted that the explosion was due to the coolant used , which was water , turning to steam and thus suddenly increased the power produced and set off a nuclear reaction (World Nuclear Association , 2009) .
It was the inappropriate handling of this sudden increase in power which led to the tragedy .
In the case of the VHTR , the coolant will be helium .
Being chemically inert , helium does not influence the nuclear reactions with a temperature change or  .
Hence , power surges of the reactor will be minimized , resulting in a decrease in the probability of reactor explosion .
This goes to show that nuclear reactors have become safer for operation .
Although the cost of hydrogen replacing gasoline is huge , there will surely be more benefits to mankind due to  high efficiency .
According to Butler (2004) , approximately 400 nuclear power plants , each requiring about US$1 billion , need to be built in order to fully be dependent on hydrogen instead of gasoline .
In addition , research and testing work is required to look for materials which are able to resist the high temperature of the VHTR and the rapid impact of high energy neutrons in the reaction (Butler , 2004) .
Opponents may comment that the initial capital cost is very high , but the VHTR is able to produce 50% more energy than the typical reactor using the same quantity of fuel (Butler , 2004) .
This could help to meet  the rising energy demand .
Although there might be future technologies which will be better than the VHTR , this is not definite as yet .
Therefore , rather than wait for a new technology to fully emerge , we should continue to carry out research work on enhancing  feasible technology present now , which is the nuclear reactor .
Talking about the most serious accident ever in the nuclear power history , the 1986 Chernobyl Accident will come to everyone's mind (UNSCEAR , 2009) .
According to an authoritative report (WNA , 2009) , there are 56 deaths confirmed to be directly related to the Chernobyl Accident by 2004 .It is officially suggested that the Chernobyl Accident was the result of inadequately trained operators , a flawed design , as well as the lack of proper regard for safety (WNA , 2009) .

Nowadays , the scarcity of energy has increasingly become a severe problem .
Compared with other kinds of power generation , nuclear energy is relatively cost competitive and eco-friendly .
Thus , more and more countries have put the construction of nuclear plants on their agendas .
With the development of nuclear industry , the proliferation of the generation reactors will become a certainty .
among all the generation reactors , I believe the supercritical water reactor should be the most applicable for most countries , especially those developing countries without advanced technology and tremendous capital .
Firstly of the supercritical water reactor is not only very highly thermal efficient but also quite economical .
The construction cost , the supercritical water reactor is rather low .
Due to the simpler structure , many of the traditional Light Water Reactor components such as the coolant recirculation pumps , pressurizers , steam generators , and steam separators and dryers can be eliminated in the supercritical water reactors(Buongiorno & MacDonald , 2003) .
And as for material engineering , according to the corrosion and stress-corrosion cracking (SCC) susceptibility tests in supercritical water by scientists from MIT (Massachusetts Institute of Technology) and the University of Michigan(McKinley , Teysseyre , Was , Mitton , Ki & Latanision , 2003) , two traditional austenitic steels (304L and 316L) can be used as high temperature components in the SCWR .
On the other hand , as for the Very High Temperature reactor , big safety provisions have to be considered to ensure its stability under high temperatures and a multitude of coolants are needed .
Since the coolant for the VHTR is aninert gas such as Helium which is not recyclable , a lot of energy and money will be required to separate it from air .
Moreover , a large amount of money needs to be spent to design and develop new related materials which can bear high temperatures , high{neutron}[HYPERLINK: http://en .wikipedia .org/wiki/Neutron]doses , and{corrosive}[HYPERLINK: http://en .wikipedia .org/wiki/Corrosion]operating conditionsinside the VHT reactor (IAEA 2004) .
In addition , it is very costly to build the VHTR because of its excessively complicated inner structure .
However , the SCWR can be installed not only withina shorter period but also by fewer workers , which will dramatically save the fixed costs of plant construction .
Thirdly , the Supercritical water reactor is more eco-friendly and safe .
Different from Light Water Reactors used around the world today , the Super Critical Water Reactor is more likely to slow down and catch 'fast neutrons' , which means it would burn less nuclear fuels in a more thorough way .
Therefore , less radioactive waste will be generated and need to be land-filled .
Thus , the time for breaking down nuclear wastes will be decades instead of millenniums after the SCWR is applied .
Further , compared with the VHTR , the primary and secondary coolant of the SCWR is  the same supercritical water which can be relatively easy to get and recycle .
In addition , because of the super enthalpy of supercritical water , more energy will be transplanted but less unexpected by-products will be produced , which will certainly decrease the risk of contamination to the environment and enhance the integral efficiency of transplanting , which will effectually reduce  carbon emissions by burning less fossil fuels .
To conclude , although some technical issues of the Super Critical Water reactor are still being researched ,  I reckon that the SCWR would be the most promising reactor against other generation IV ones , in terms of performance , cost , feasibility , and impact on the environment .
With the development of science and technology , the SWCR will not only be able to efficiently produce clean energy but also significantly address the severe global warming challenge today .
To further explore the potential of nuclear energy , the United States , Argentina , Brazil , Canada , France , Japan , South Korea , South Africa , Switzerland and the United Kingdom , have come together to form the Generation IV International Forum(GIF) .
(Butler , D 239) GIF's criteria for including a nuclear reactor design for consideration include: sustainable energy , competitive energy , safe and reliable systems and proliferation resistance .
( "Very High Temperature Reactors" , section 5) The Very-High-Temperature Reactor (VHTR) is one of the six generation IV reactor concepts proposed by the GIF .
The VHTR requires an operating temperature of 1000oC and high pressure with helium being the coolant  used .
(Butler , D 239) Critics have argued that the current nuclear plants in operation are susceptible to terrorist attacks and doubt that the plant is worth the high cost of funding .
Lastly , they are concerned with the safety level of the plant .
All these critics are against the funding and development of nuclear power plants .
However , I strongly support further research and development funding of nuclear reactor plants .
This is because nuclear reactor plants have many advantages such as being able to produce both hydrogen fuel and a large amount of electricity from a small amount of fuel at the same time .
(Butler , D . 239)
Ever since the 9/11 incident , protection of nuclear plants has been a heightened national priority .Yet , some anti-terror experts have commented that the current criteria do not protect the plant from a threat equal to the one posed by the 9/11 hijackers .
A report released by the Government Accountability Office even mentioned that it is critical of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) , finding that the latter has not increased standards enough to ensure plants are genuinely secure , but only as much as industry officials believe is necessary .
("Nuclear-plant security: Is it enough ?"
par .3)This has instilled a lot of fear in the citizens and they have no confidence in the security of the plants .
As such , they oppose the funding of nuclear plants .
On the contrary , the security problems of nuclear plants have already been tackled .
One solution is the "Design Basis Threat" (DBT) which specifies the severity of the attacks that has to be prepared for .
The NRC requires each nuclear plant to periodically conduct security exercises to test its ability to fight against the DBT .
("Nuclear Power Plants: Vulnerability to Terrorist Attack") Last but not least , the nuclear industry has spent more than $1 .25 billion in the upgrading of its security operations and the increasing of its armed guard force from 5 ,000 to more than 8 ,000 .
("Nuclear-plant security: Is it enough ?"
par .9)In conclusion , the security of the plant is now sufficient to repel  terrorists and therefore the funding of nuclear power plants should be supported .
The high cost of the funding for the development of nuclear plants has also met with much public discontentment .
They claim that nuclear power is uneconomical .
In the USA , since its beginning , nuclear power has cost the country over $492 , 000 , 000 , 000 , which is nearly twice the cost of the Vietnam War and the Apollo Moon Missions combined .
Since 1950 , nuclear power has received over $97 ,000 ,000 ,000 in direct and indirect subsidies from the federal government .
No other industry has enjoyed such a privilege .
("Some Important Facts about Nuclear Power ."
par .3)The high cost of nuclear plants is transferred to the citizens so they have to pay more on utilities .
Hence , they reject the idea of funding nuclear plants .
On the other hand , many differ in opinion .
Even though the cost of building a nuclear plant is very high , the operating cost is relatively low .
Therefore , nuclear power actually costs about the same as power generated from coal .
("Energy Resources: Nuclear Power .
")This means that  nuclear energy can be charged at an affordable price that is competitive to coal and gas .
In addition , nuclear energy , though expensive , can be produced in abundance to meet the ever increasing demand for energy .
In short , nuclear power plants should be funded as their benefits outweigh the shortcomings such as the high cost .
After the Chernobyl and Three Mile Island nuclear accidents , which took away many innocent lives due to the explosions as well as exposure to excessive radiation , people are now very concerned about the safety of  nuclear plants .
In Texas , the citizens have again succeeded in opposing  the development of two proposed nuclear reactors at the South Texas Project .
The opposition came about as the citizens are fearful that the environmental effects of radioactive compounds may lead to health problems if contamination or leakage was to occur .
("Citizens Gain Ground in STP Intervention over Water Concerns Atomic Safety and Licensing Board Panel Admits Four Additional Water Related Contentions for a Hearing") However , there is evidence to support the claim that the safety aspect of nuclear plants are up to mark .
According to the World Association of Nuclear Operators(WANO) , performance indicators show that the U .S . nuclear plants have managed to sustain  high levels of achievement in safety performance , industrial safety , unplanned automatic reactor shutdowns and programs to protect workers from radioactive exposure .
(" Nuclear Industry's Safety , Operating Performance Remained Top-Notch in '08 , WANO Indicators Show") Since the nuclear plants are now of higher safety standards and with agencies to regularly check on the status of the plants , the further funding of nuclear plants should be supported so that this safe and reliable source of energy can be made available to everyone .
In conclusion , I support the notion of  research and development of nuclear power plants .
Even though there may be problems and public opposition along the way ,  by bearing in mind three main factors , namely , the benefits of nuclear energy , the importance of a strong defence and most importantly , the importance of having a set of safety protocols , we are able to push the development of nuclear power to greater heights .
Thirty years after the Three Mile Island nuclear meltdown in the United States , nuclear energy seems poised for a renaissance .
The world can expect the number of nuclear power plants to double by 2050 , spreading across the Middle East and Southeast Asia , particularly in China , India , South Korea , and Japan (Butler , 2004) .
In 2008 , Kaplan (2008) reported that more than 40 developing countries have expressed their interest in launching nuclear power programs to United Nations officials .
The issue of whether developing countries should first handle unemployment and poverty in rural areas rather than provide huge funding to build nuclear reactors is still controversial .
Some argue that a nuclear reactor is too costly to build and that they should adopt other renewable energies instead of nuclear power (Totty , 2008) , while others argue that developing countries do not have enough skilled labour to cope with the  needs of building and operating nuclear reactors (Squassoni , 2009) .
Although there is much opposition to the idea of building nuclear reactors in developing countries , there is some evidence that building nuclear reactors , such as the Generation IV reactors , yields positive outcomes for these countries .
Opponents of nuclear reactors claim that building a new reactor can cost a country between $6 billion and $9 billion each (Totty , 2008) .
Although proponents of nuclear reactors agree with the fact that the reactors are expensive to construct , they argue that it is comparatively inexpensive to operate because nuclear fuel accounts for only 27% of the variable cost of a kilowatt-hour as compared to  alternatives like natural gas which accounts for 85% .
In fact , any new design of reactors today will be pre-approved for lower construction costs , which include the cost for decommissioning and waste management (Johnston , 2008) .
Furthermore , developing countries that have insufficient funds to build nuclear reactors can seek assistance from Alternate Energy Holdings (AEHI) that has offered to provide skills and funding in constructing nuclear reactors (AEHI , 2007) .
The Nobel Peace Prize laureate , Mohamed ElBaradei , proposed that these countries could alternatively construct hundreds of small-scale plants for a single town , each one built using a fraction of the cost used for a large-scale plant and without using expensive power grids (Bullis , 2005) .
Opponents also maintain that developing countries should adopt other renewable energies such as solar and wind energies rather than building nuclear reactors (Totty , 2008) .
However , despite the fact that studies show that the use of solar and wind energy is more economical than nuclear energy , opponents completely ignore the limitations of these energies in producing electricity for the decades ahead (Healthy Environment Alliance [HEAL] , n .d .) .
Moreover , solar power is limited to daylight hours and  there is no continuous supply of wind .
The International Energy Agency (IEA) forecasts that , even with continued subsidy and research , and a landscape full of solar panels and windmills , these renewable energies can generate only about 6% of the world's electricity by 2030 (Silverio , 2008) .
Thus , the key difference is that nuclear energy can supply electricity on a global scale .
The final argument advanced by opponents of nuclear reactors is that jobs created by nuclear power plants require highly skilled workers that developing countries , like China and India , are lacking .
As a result , opponents maintain that building nuclear reactors would not address the problem of unemployment (Squassoni , 2009) .
However , the research is inconclusive .
In fact , by 2010 , Asians residing in Asia will dominate 90% of all Ph .D . physical scientists and engineers in the world .
And among the Asian Ph .D . engineers and scientists , most will originate from China (Li , Whalley , Zhang , & Zhao , 2008) .
In addition , to better meet the demand for skilled workers , nuclear industries in the developing countries could set up on-site training centres that recruit and train the locals to work in the nuclear industry (Freeman , 2009) as each plant creates about 400 to 700 permanent jobs and 1400 to 2400 jobs during peak construction period (Nuclear Energy Institute [NEI] , 2009) .
In summary , developing countries should develop  nuclear reactors for several reasons .
First , nuclear reactors operate using cheaper nuclear fuel that accounts for only 27% of the variable costs of a kilowatt-hour .
In addition , a new nuclear reactor design will only be approved if it presents a relatively lower construction cost .
Moreover , if developing countries have insufficient funds , they can approach AEHI for financial and labour support but an alternative way would be building smaller-scale plants without the need to use costly power grids and thus incur lower costs .
Nuclear power is also capable of supplying electricity for the whole world as compared to wind and solar energy .
Besides that , developing countries like China and India have sufficient highly-skilled workers to contribute to the nuclear industry and the unemployment rate can also be reduced , as approximately 2400 jobs are made available in each new plant .
Therefore , in my opinion , developing countries should first provide huge funding to build generation IV reactors in order to combat unemployment and poverty in  rural areas .
Group issue: Should there be R&D funding for the development of SuperCritical Water cooled Reactors ?
According to Butler(2009) ,  researchers have been pondering on whether to use  nuclear funding for the development of generation (IV) reactors , which are projected to be better than the current generation (II) and (III) reactors , or to retain the nuclear funding for existing generation (II) and (III) reactors .
Moreover , for the generation (IV) reactors , there is a debate on whether to channel the funds for the research of SuperCritical water reactors (SCWRs)  , which scientists have claimed  would benefit mankind more in most aspects  like cost and efficiency compared to the other five generation (IV) reactors .
Although there are reasons that seem to support the funding of the SCWR , the development of the SCWR should not be funded as there are other factors like economic and social feasibility to consider before we can conclude that the funding for the development of the SCWR should be approved .
One of the many reasons given to support the claim for SCWR funding is that the SCWR is a combination of two proven technologies , which are Light water moderated reactors (LWRs) and supercritical-water fossil plants (Buoniorno , 2002) .
Supporters of the SCWR claim that the SCWR would have a reduced capital cost as a result of plant simplification and high thermal efficiency .
Although I concur with their view to a certain extent , they have overlooked the problem of the SCWR being capable of reaching the commercialization stage of an innovation (Rogers , 2003) .
The likelihood of the SCWR reaching the commercialization stage is low because even though the SCWR is the combination of two proven technologies , research is still required to merge the two technologies together .
Furthermore , the simplification of the SCWR involves the usage of materials that are either expensive , rare , or do not exist (Absolute astronomy , 2009) .
This reinforces the possibility that the SCWR cannot enter the commercialization stage of innovation , proving that there should not be funding for the development of the SCWR .
Another reason proponents give is thatthe SCWR uses water which is cheap and easily obtainable as a coolant (Butler , 2009) .
In addition , supporters of the SCWR also state that the SCWR takes up less space than current Generation (II) and (III) Reactors (MacDonald , 2003) .
I have to acquiesce to the two points raised by the supporters of the SCWR .
However , these two arguments  do not consider that both water and space are vital to mankind .
Although water is easily obtained and affordable ,  only 1% out of the 97% water available is usable (West , 2007) .
Thus , it is astute not to use water as a coolant because the world population is constantly rising , so there might be a possibility of water shortage .
This implies that funding should not be channeled for the development of the SCWR .
Instead , funds could be directed to the development of the Very High Temperature Reactor (VHTR) which utilizes helium which is not important for human survival as helium is not found in the human body (The Encyclopedia of Earth , 2008) .
In addition , although the land required to build the SCWR is less than for the existing reactors , the area needed to build a new SCWR would be better utilized as area for agriculture instead , especially in the future .
It is projected that in the year 2050 , there could be 9 .2 billion people in the world (BBC , 2009) .
This signifies that there will be a high possibility of a food shortage which is a more pressing problem than energy shortage .
Therefore , there should not be funding for the development of the SCWR as the SCWR utilizes two key ingredients for human survival .
The last reason that advocates  funding for the development of the SCWR  is that the building of the SCWR  could generate desirable jobs for the society (Nuclear Energy Institute , 2009) .
According to the Nuclear Energy Institute , the operation of a nuclear plant generates 400 to 700 permanent jobs and these jobs offer a salary that is 36 percent higher than average jobs .
Although this may be beneficial to society ,  after the completion of the construction of a nuclear plant , there would be job losses involved .
During the construction of a new nuclear plant , around 1400 to as high as 2400 jobs are created .
However , after the completion , only 400 to 700 jobs will be available .
This indicates that a job loss of around 1500 will be incurred .
Furthermore , the 400 to 700 jobs require personnel that are highly skilled which developing countries are unlikely to supply .
Therefore , the validity of generating desirable jobs needs to be redefined .
In a few more years ahead , the world's population will be expanding exponentially from around 6 billion people to approximately 10 billion people worldwide .
We speculate that the demand for energy in future will be greatly increasing for future development .
In order to support and supply the growing population , ten nations , namely Argentina , Brazil , Canada , France , Japan , the Republic of Korea , the Republic of South Africa , Switzerland , the United Kingdom and the United States , had formed the Generation IV International Forum (GIF) .
There are six nuclear reactors that are in research stage , and one of them is the Supercritical-Water-Cooled Reactor (SCWR) , which is the most ideal nuclear reactor in concept .
(NERAC and GIF , 2002) .
Nuclear power is the most prominent and reliable energy source today .
It is the energy of the future generation , and I support the use of nuclear power for alternative energy of the future .
First of all , nuclear energy is an environmentally friendly energy .
It is stable , reliable , and clean in which does not emit any carbon compounds and toxic pollutants to the environment .
Many people claim that the nuclear energy is unsafe to the environment and health .
It is true that the nuclear reactors generate radioactive waste , with high doses of these substances can kill and cause cancer to human .
Besides , these radioactive substances will pollute the earth and poison the living organisms on the earth .
However , nuclear power plants do not require any fossil fuel for combustion; therefore , there will be no emissions of carbon waste to the environment .
(NEI , n .d .) .
Using SCWR as an example , the generator is using water as the main coolant .
This definitely will not pollute the environment .
Secondly , most people are concerned about the safety of running a nuclear power plant .
The public resists to nuclear energy due to the aftermath of the incidents at Three Mile Island in 1979 and Chernobyl in 1986 .
It is a psychological effect on human , whereby the aftermath will result in opposition to nuclear energy by the public .
Nevertheless , we cannot deny the truth that scientists and engineers have actually thought about the safety precautions of nuclear energy system .
This is to make sure the risk of operating nuclear power plants can be minimized tremendously .
Nuclear power plants are to be designed , built and monitored carefully in order to prevent any accident to happen .
The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) work together to govern of radiation emissions periodically .
(NEI , n .d .) .
There is also a safe storage for the waste to be stored up , namely the Yucca Mountain , Nevada .
Therefore , nuclear energy is safe to be used as an alternate energy .
Thirdly , for most people's impression , nuclear energy is way too expensive for the unworthy efficiency .
The capital cost of nuclear power plants construction is extremely high and it is increasing as years go by .
There are people who claim that nuclear energy is a mature technology , where it is definitely will not become cheaper in future usage .
Besides that , the management of the radioactive waste is expensive .
For example , Sweden has spent about $14 billion to manage its radioactive waste .
(Smith , Hargroves , Palousis and Paten , 2006) .
But in realistic , this idea is very unlikely .
There are studies shows that the production costs of the nuclear power plants have already dropped and the efficiency is high in long run .
It is the efficiency that saves time and cost .
With good maintenance practices , time and cost will be save and unplanned shut downs can be reduced .
For example , SCWR is a high efficient nuclear generator that will save a lot of cost when the maintenance is well-practiced .
The Chernobyl Accident , the most notorious disaster of nuclear history , took place on 26th April 1986 at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in Ukraine , and released a considerable amount of radio-nuclides over a large neighboring area .
Subsequently , various groups of experts from the nuclear and chemical industry investigated into this case , and some of them came into a conclusion that the most essential way to prevent such catastrophe from happening again lied in the enhancement of psychological education to people; whereas the others opposed that the main problem was actually the design failures of the plant , and the prevention could hardly be simply regarded as a psychological issue .
Those experts , who were against of the psychological point of view , further claimed that even though the human factors were all amended through psychological approaches , possible accident still stands a chance of happening .
They concluded that the actual primary causes of the 1986 accident were nothing but the engineering factors , and permanent avoidance of such accidents could only be achieved through more advanced technology development .

With the increasing demand of energy and the rapid depletion of currently available energy resources , nations are now trying to look for new , alternative ways of energy generation .
One of such alternative methods currently under consideration is the generation of nuclear energy .
Presently , thirteen countries have come together to set goals on nuclear energy generation research on six reactor designs; namely gas-cooled fast reactor , lead-cooled fast reactor , sodium-cooled reactor , molten salt reactor , supercritical-water-cooled reactor and very-high-temperature reactor .
the very-high-temperature reactorOf these six reactors , the forry-High-Temperature Reactor (VHTR) and the Lead-cooled Fast Reactor (LFR) are the more promising reactor designs .
The conceptual design of the VHTR will be the first to be defined and optimized by the year 2015 (OECD Nuclear Energy Agency , 2009) , while LFR is , judging from the existing schemes , more feasible because of its low costs and good security features .
In compari ,on with the gas-cooled fast reactors the lead-cooled fast reactorttthe sodium-cooled reactor tthe molten salt reactorr the supercritical-water-cooled reactor
Both LFR and VHTR have their advantages and disadvantages over the other in terms of performance .
The VHTR will be operating at temperatures 900 to 1000 degree Celsius .
This high outlet temperature allows it to have high efficiency (> 50%) electrical generation and also givesalthoughhthe LFRbility to produce hydrogen (OECD Nuclear Energy Agency , 2009) .
Even though LFR is estimated to have a comparatively lower efficiency in energy the LFReration than VHTR (Chand isn  , et al . , 2004) , it is more suitable in cmorecountries due to its flexibility in its scale of operation .
Currently , the reactor is envisioned to have 2 sizes: a small transportable system of 50 to 150 MWe and a medium system of 300 to 600 MWe .
(OECD Nuclear Energy Agency , 2009) The small system design will be useful for providing energy for developing countries and remote communities due to its size .
(Idaho National Laboratory , 2007) Also , researches have shown that LFR will also be able to generate hydrogen (Bouchard , et al , 2008) .
Hence , it is evident that though LFR is predicted to be poorer in terms of efficiency as compared to VHTR , LFR seems more useful and suitable for many countries due to its other features .

Within the past half century , two major accidents at the Chernobyl and the Three Mile Island nuclear power plants have caused the public to have a negative view of the operation of nuclear reactors and also , the future of nuclear energy generation .
Presently , the most common energy source , which is  coal-fired power generator , has been causing detrimental effects on the environment by releasing tremendous amounts of greenhouse gases and subsequently causing a rise in global warming .
Furthermore , with increasing concerns regarding the future of our environment , there is also an increasing need to search for alternative sources of energy which would not cause as much harm to the atmosphere .
As a result , leaders of environmental organisations , such as Patrick Moore who is a cofounder of Greenpeace , are beginning to realise that nuclear power generation is one of the most secure , economical and environmentally- friendly energy sources available (Yousefzadeh , 2007) .
In 2001 , the Generation IV International Forum introduced six different generation IV nuclear reactor concepts which had been designed in such a way that when accidents occur , the damage will be contained (Butler , 2004) .
Out of the six reactor concepts , the Lead-cooled Fast Reactor (LFR) looks to be the most promising one .
With the past accidents in mind and considering the advantages that nuclear power has to offer , if sufficient research efforts are to be channelled to the development of the LFR , we humans can certainly benefit from it in the long run .
When the Chernobyl accident occurred in 1986 , thirty-one people were killed immediately and many more died due to the radiation-related effects of the accident ("Chernobyl Accident" , 2009) .
This accident , especially , had caused many to oppose the nuclear power system as they feel that the extent of damage incurred by such systems would be massive and unacceptable .
However , future thorough research and development towards the safe operation of nuclear plants may prove to be worthwhile .
For example , the accident which occurred on the Three Mile Island did not involve any deaths or injuries as the radioactive particles were successfully contained within the reactor itself (Yousefzadeh , 2007) .
This simply shows that with advanced technology , even if an accident-free nuclear plant may never be achieved , at least the technology incorporated into the reactor system would be able to ensure that radiation is contained in times of accidents .
In addition , LFRs are relatively safer as compared to other generation IV reactors due to the inertness of the lead coolant .
Lead is chemically inactive with air and water , ruling out the possibility of accidental fires and explosions (Wider et al . , 2005) .
Hence , with more funding directed towards the research and development of the LFR , it may one day become one of the safest forms of energy generator .
Critics also claim that nuclear power plants and nuclear waste can be potential terrorist targets as a great extent of damage can be done when the plants are attacked or exploited .
Therefore , a strict set of security procedures have to be put in place and the use of advanced technology should be incorporated into the security system .
Another factor to be considered is the sustainability of the LFR .
Critics of nuclear energy claim that nuclear energy generation produces a large amount of radioactive waste products and eventually , storage spaces will run out , making nuclear energy unsustainable .
However , a characteristic of LFRs is that they are fast breeder reactors that carry out nuclear reprocessing of nuclear waste .
With this reprocessing feature in LFRs , uranium and plutonium , which make up 96% of the nuclear waste , can be extricated and reused in the reactor (Butler , 2004) .
As a result , the final amount of waste product would be reduced to a very large extent .
In addition , nuclear reprocessing also increases the efficiency of the usage of uranium and hence makes nuclear power a sustainable source of energy .
Moreover , lead is abundant (The Lead-cooled Fast Reactor , n .d .) , and uranium resources can last us for the next 250 years or so (Wider et al . , 2005) , making the LFR an excellent reactor in terms of sustainability .
In conclusion , the LFR has much to offer to mankind especially in terms of safety , security , sustainability as well as environmental effects .
The LFR is a nuclear energy reactor that is environmentally friendly with zero greenhouse gas emission .
Furthermore , the resources required in an LFR are in abundance , making it a sustainable source of energy .
Most importantly , humans can benefit from the LFR in the future if thorough research and more developments are to be made on it so as to make it safer and more secure from accidents or terrorist attacks .
The public has been concerned about the danger of radiation leaks from nuclear plants , especially after the Chernobyl incident in 1986 when the massive radiation exposure directly caused approximately 250 deaths (WHO , 2005) .
The incident raised security concerns about nuclear plants becoming a terrorist target , where an induced meltdown in terms of present-day operating scale will have catastrophic consequences .
The US administration , though , has recognized the potential of nuclear energy and has committed US$40 million to support research and development (R&D) for Next Generation Nuclear Plants (NGNPs) (DOE , 2009) .
The very-high-temperature-reactor (VHTR) , with  and the extensive R&D conducted on it , has been selected over other reactor concepts such as the supercritical-water-cooled-reactor (SCWR) as the reactor choice for the US' next generation nuclear power plants (DOE , 2008) .
Federal funding should be channeled for the R & D of the VHTR concept as it promises enhanced safety and inherent security designs , in addition to a highly efficient production process .
An estimated 4000 cases of thyroid cancer cases in children were attributed to the radiation leak from the Chernobyl incident , with the long term effect of the radiation exposure expected to continue over the years (UNSCEAR , N .D .) .
The slow but fatal effects of radiation have made radiation leaks from nuclear reactors a major safety concern among the public .
The VHTR addresses this concern by using helium gas as the choice of coolant for the reactor .
The inert nature of helium means it will not react with the radioactive materials of the VHTR to become radioactive , eliminating a source of radiation in the event of a coolant leak (CHM333 , 2007) .
Another safety feature of the VHTR is the use of uranium fuel pellets multi-coated with graphite .
These reinforced pellets are extremely heat resistant and do not crack easily , so even in the case of a meltdown , the uranium pellets will be able to retain the radiation and fission products within its core with minimal release to the surroundings (CHM333 , 2007) .
Questions have been raised by opponents of nuclear power technology regarding the security of the fuel pellets , which are rich sources of uranium .
When extracted and processed , enriched uranium can become a key material for the manufacture of nuclear weapons .
However , the multi-coated uranium fuel pellets used in the VHTR require a temperature of more than 1600oC before the fission products within its core can be removed and this arduous extraction condition deters potential weapon proliferation using its radioactive core (GIF , 2008) .
In addition , unlike traditional reactors , the VHTR is designed to minimize fissionable material in its spent fuel by running the fuel pellets through the reactors for consecutive cycles until its fissionable material is exhausted .
The spent fuel pellets will then be safe for disposal and not pose a security risk should there be any intention from terrorists to extract fissionable products from it (CHM333 , 2007) .
Detractors of nuclear power technology also have doubts on whether nuclear power plants can match the cost effectiveness of existing coal and gas power plants .
However , NGNPs are not only capable of generating electricity like coal and gas power plants , they can also simultaneously produce hydrogen (GIF , 2008) .
This co-generation of electricity and hydrogen is made possible by the high operating temperature of up to 1000oC for the VHTR which allows for the efficient production of hydrogen by thermo-chemical processes .
Hydrogen fuel cells have been identified as the energy source of the future , so the capability to produce hydrogen gives NGNPs an edge over existing coal and gas plants .
By future proofing its technology , NGNPs can ensure their relevance to the power industry in the future .
Moreover , the high operating temperature of the VHTR also results in higher fuel burn-up ratio of the fissionable materials in the uranium pellets (DOE , 2008) .
With its highly efficient fuel burn-up , NGNPs will have a lower carbon footprint than coal and gas technology and at the same time , havingless radioactive material remaining in the spent pellets reduces the amount of radioactive waste to be treated , improving the overall process economy .
R&D work done on nuclear power technology to date has shown promising prospects to justify the US$40 million financial support from the US administration .
However , additional funding for the VHTR will only be available if both the US government and the public can be convinced about the viability of NGNPs replacing coal and gas power plants as the main supplier of US electricity .
To achieve this , the VHTR has to stay on track through sustained R&D work in the coming years so that it can meet its expected delivery deadline in 2020 (Butler , 2004) .
The world is encountering an unprecedented challenge which requires urgent global action to prevent the risks of climate change (Stern , 2008) .
To do so , the global greenhouse gas emissions have to be reduced by half relative to 1990 by 2050 , which means to reduce to less than 10 Gigatonnes of emissions (Stern , 2008) .
Many countries rely on fossil fuels as their source of energy and fossil fuel is known to be the major contributor of  greenhouse gases .
In the United States alone , greenhouse gas emissions mainly come from the burning of fossil fuels for energy use .
Energy- related carbon dioxide emissions from the combustion of petroleum , coal , and natural gas contributed to eighty-two percent of total U .S . anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions in 2006 (Energy Information Administration , 2008) .
By using the very high temperature reactor (VHTR) , hydrogen can be used as the fuel of the future to replace  fossil fuels .
In addition , more electricity will be produced with the help of the VHTR .
Therefore , for a better environment to live in , countries should support further research and provide large funding for the development of the VHTR even though the public is concerned with the cost and security of the VHTR .
VHTR plants are able to produce hydrogen for fuel using high-temperature steam electrolysis , which breaks apart the bonds of water molecules; this process is 50 percent more energy-efficient as compared to  existing hydrogen production methods (Svoboda , 2009) .
Thus , hydrogen can replace fossil fuels as a source of fuel .
However , until now , there is still no material that can withstand the high temperatures and pressures required for the VHTR to operate , and even if such materials are found , they might add millions of dollars to the still- unknown cost of constructing a VHTR power plant (Svoboda , 2009) .
The public is then concerned about the huge funding needed for development of the VHTR and thus feel that developing countries should first handle poverty and unemployment .
However , the developing countries will account for around eight billion out of a world population of nine billion by 2050 (Stern , 2008) .
and so they need to be involved in achieving global emission reductions .
In addition , poor people around the world also need abundant , affordable and modern energy .
1 .6 billion people in the developing countries do not have excess to electricity so they have to end their day earlier than those in richer countries due to lack of proper lighting (Bradley , 2009) .
With the VHTR , developing countries will be able to meet their energy demand and will thus lift millions of people out of poverty .
Therefore , similar to those rich countries , developing countries should also provide funding for the development of the VHTR .
The the VHTR is able to produce fifty percent more electricity from the same amount of fuel as compared with conventional plants (Butler , 2004) and is also able to produce electricity about forty percent more efficiently than most reactors in the United States (Svoboda , 2009) .
In addition , INL researchers also believe that nuclear energy will be important in maintaining the nation's electricity supply as  (Svoboda , 2009) .
However , given memories of the partial reactor meltdown in 1979 at Three Mile Island , Pennsylvania and of the 1986 accident at Chernobyl in Ukraine , during which the reactor core exploded , killing some 31 people instantly and spreading radioactive debris across Europe (Butler , 2004) , the public is concerned about the safety of the VHTR .
Furthermore , the Department of Energy and the National Nuclear Security Agency found that reprocessing increases nuclear waste and the dangers of proliferation and terrorism (Lieberman , 2009) .
However , in actual fact , VHTR is able to function without having to rely on the reprocessing of plutonium waste (Butler , 2004) .
Nuclear reactors would then become less of a terrorist target .
The VHTR also has safety features to prevent core overheating and the release of radioactive material , in hope that these new approaches will eventually erase the memory of Three Mile Island and Chernobyl (Svoboda , 2009) .
Therefore , countries should provide funding for research and development of the VHTR .
Building of the VHTR means that countries will no longer need to depend on fossil fuels as a source of energy and the emission of greenhouse gases will also be greatly reduced .
In addition , the controversial reprocessing of nuclear waste will be solved .
Generating sufficient hydrogen to totally replace gasoline for  transport purposes would mean building more than four hundred nuclear power plants ,  (Butler , 2004) .
However , there are only 441 nuclear plants in the world today (Butler , 2004) .
It is evident that  countries should proceed with the research and development of the VHTR .
Developing countries should also invest in the development of the VHTR as satisfying their energy demand is essential for their economic growth .
Nuclear power has been a source of energy since the 1960s .
Nevertheless , the world has always been concerned about the safety and security issues of  nuclear reactors .
Thus , researchers have come up with generation four reactor concepts , hoping to ease the public's worries .
I personally support the molten salt reactor concept for further research and development based on the following factors: safe operation of the plant , global security and  cost efficiency .
Besides safety issues , the security of the nuclear reactors is another point brought up by critics .
The location of a nuclear reactor is to  terrorists an ideal bombing target .
In addition , in molten salt reactors , plutonium , a key ingredient of advanced nuclear weapons , is actually created during the process before it is reprocessed .
Critics fear that the plutonium might be stolen by terrorists to make nuclear weapons .
However , Idaho National Laboratory (2005) claims that the plutonium  remains in the salt and has high critical mass that makes it less desirable for use in weapons .
According to Butler (2004) , supporters are also positive that the plutonium obtained can be spiked with other chemicals or elements to make it  to steal .
This further supports the need for research and development on molten salt reactors .
As for  , the World Nuclear Association (2008) states that the basis of the design of the reactors assumes these threats .
There are sensors in the reactors that will shut down the entire reactor when there is any abnormality .
Having to incorporate all the safety and security measures makes the cost efficiency of the nuclear power plant  another concern .
The World Nuclear Association (2009) states that the cost of nuclear power generation has declined since the 1990s .
They also show statistics proving that although the construction cost of nuclear reactors is significantly higher , once the reactors are built , the nuclear generation cost is comparable to other energy sources .
In addition , Thornley (2009) claims that as compared to other energy sources ,   nuclear energy has the highest average capacity factor .
This means that nuclear power is the most efficient energy source .
Efficiency means lower costs .
Taking the MSR as an example , previous designs for the MSR used steam cycles for electrical production .
The current proposal uses the Brayton cycle which has advantages such as lower cost and improved efficiency .
According to Forsberg (2006) , there is a 4 percent increase in efficiency .
However , the MSR uses fluoride salt , which is more corrosive at high temperatures .
Thus , there are doubts about whether the MSR is a good choice .
Nevertheless , there is currently the carbon-based material which , according to Forsberg (2006) , is compatible with molten salt at high temperatures .
In other words , the corrosion will not be an issue .
In conclusion , I have to agree that the molten salt reactor is not perfect , but the benefits of the molten salt reactor outweigh the cons and supporters are optimistic about finding solutions to the problems , showing their potential .
This is proven from its low excess reactivity to decreasing maintenance costs .
Thus , I support the further research and development of the molten salt reactor .
A serious train calamity took place in Eschede on 3 June 1998 and claimed the lives of 101 innocent people while 88 were left severely injured (Sckhman , 1998) .
It was proclaimed to be the world's deadliest train accident .
Investigations proved that the derailment of the train was due to a single fatigue fissure in the wheel .
The steel tire had gotten loose from the wheel and was wedged in the rail carriages .
As the train passed two rail switches , the loosened tire knocked against a switch lever and pulled the train off the railway track , causing one of its carriages to crash into a bridge .
It is unimaginable that this minor fault is the main cause for this catastrophe .
At hindsight , it seems that this whole accident could have been prevented if more precautionary measures had been taken into consideration .
The numerous controversies over the actual cause of this accident revolve around the unsuitable design of the wheel , the inability and misconception of the conductor , the inadequate train repairs and the company guidelines for investigating the accident before addressing an issue .
After reviewing this accident , some experts have felt that incorporating a psychologist into the developmental process could have aided in preventing it .
This writer feels that the introduction of a psychologist in a team of design engineers would not have prevented the accident .
Nevertheless , the psychologist could have contributed to the design process by reducing the rate of accidents  .
A point to argue about is regarding the wheel design .
The train company , InterCity Expss (ICE) , had received complaints regarding the original train wheels causing serious resonance and tremors whilst travelling at high velocity .
Engineers resolved this problem by inserting a rubber damping ring between the wheel and the tire .
However , this design had never been used on high-speed trains before and thus failed to adhere to safety standards .
It is evident that had the engineers waited for the approval of the new wheels before  , this accident might not have happened .
A psychologist roped in to help the engineers may have been able to foresee this impending structural failure of the wheel and intervened before it was too late .

Another point lies with the company and the conductor .
Company policy stated that thorough examinations had to be done before taking any necessary action .
This led to the conductor refusing to stop the train even after a passenger raised concern regarding a damaged coach .
In addition , even after the conductor had verified the problem , he still  refused to stop the train and insisted on adhering to company regulations .
It is shocking to realize that this unique policy that ICE complies with differs from the traditional 'stop and examine' one .
This accident could perhaps have been averted if the conductor had used his personal judgment and halted the train when an unexpected problem was discovered .
It must have been pressure from the organizational management that made the conductor follow ICE orders and refuse to do what was right i .e .
stall the train .
In part , it can be said that the cause of the accident was ICE for forming this rule and the conductor's erroneous judgment .
After conducting a root cause analysis on the accident , a psychologist could perhaps have aided the company by vetting the flawed regulations to grant train conductors the power to make an assessment to stop the train should they receive any complaints from passengers .
Yet another point is  a simple fault found in the train's wheel .
This brought forth attention to the frequency of maintenance checks carried out by the train company .
ICE had claimed that they had conducted checks on the train on a regular basis using conventional flash lights .
This proves that checks were only conducted on the external structure of the train and not on the internal hardware and sustainability of the wheels to support the train's weight .
It is evident that ICE was too complacent and did not use more advanced technology to maintain their trains .
The aid from a psychologist in this aspect would have been limited as it deals with technical equipment and the views of psychological design would not have been implemented in this field .
After various considerations , this writer concludes that only one factor cannot be blamed as the sole cause of the accident .
Instead , it was various factors working together to create a chain reaction which led to the dire consequences .
In this train accident , the problems began from the preliminary wheel design that design engineers came up with , to the insufficient maintenance of trains and the operation mode ICE used .
The aid from a psychologist would have been inadequate in preventing the accident as the majority of the causes for this accident dealt with technical  aspects that psychologists do not have experience in .
However , the psychologist could have contributed to the intangible aspects of the company's routine like spotting the mistakes engineers sometimes overlook .
Hence , with the help of psychology design , the rates of accidents may reduce drastically .
