Public opposition regarding the issue of nuclear technology has been evident ever since the Chernobyl and Three Mile accidents .
People are mostly concerned about public health and safety caused by radioactive exposures .
In the case of Shoreham , the nuclear plant faced strong opposition from both the people and the government .
Although Shoreham had a license for nuclear power testing , the plant was fully decommissioned in the end in 1998 .
Light Water Reactors (LWRs) make up the majority of nuclear plants in the United States .
Uranium is the primary fuel source in these nuclear plants .
Unfortunately ,  .
In addition , nuclear waste repositories require geological isolation  .
On the other hand , the concept of fourth generation nuclear power addresses the issue of  .
They are capable of combusting nuclear waste and leaving a minimal volume of waste with insignificant half-lives , thus addressing the nuclear waste problem .
The Molten Salt Reactor (MSR) is a type of fourth generation nuclear reactor .
The coolant comprises  a molten salt .
The concept of the MSR involves nuclear fuel dissolved in the molten fluoride salt as uranium tetra fluoride .
As such , the fluid would be able to rely on fuel that is dispersed in a graphite matrix with the molten salt providing low pressure and high temperature cooling , unlike in today's LWR's .
Thus , the MSR has the ability to work at high temperatures , at low pressures and at high power densities .
At higher temperatures , most of the reactor heat can then be transformed into electricity which ensures complete combustion of the uranium fuel .
Operating at lower pressures reduces accident risk  and  in the event of an accident .
The MSR can be air-cooled , making it capable of using waste heat for water desalination .
The turbines have also excellent thermodynamic efficiency due to the relatively high temperature it functions at .
Secondly , unlike traditional LWRs , refueling of the MSR can be done while the system is still in operation .
Fission products are removed and new fuel is added to portions of the fuel at a time , drastically reducing the cost operating the MSR .
The Obama administration was initially opposed to the idea of the Yucca Mountain nuclear repository .
The amount of money needed to build a nuclear repository isolated away from civilization cost up to $25billion .
There are better methods of using this sum of money collected from taxes from its people to solve the waste disposal problem .
The government should exploit the funds available to develop MSRs .
These reactors are capable of consuming existing nuclear waste in the production of electricity , and prevent nuclear waste from accumulating .
Accelerated development of MSRs will result in the US  successfully managing the nuclear waste problem and revolutionizing an entire new level of carbon-free energy that can last longer than just centuries .
Furthermore , MSRs are up to 300 times more fuel-efficient compared to  LWRs .
They actually provide a bit more than what most scientists expect from fusion as an MSR can be built in small 1 .2MW electric units .
A 7 .4 MW thermal reactor was built in the 1960s and operated for years ,  .
MSRs are also much more efficient than  helium-cooled Very High Temperature Reactors (VHTRs) operating at similar conditions , in terms of electricity conversion .
Apart from that , MSRs are capable of operating for several centuries with only uranium that is already present .
Thus , the claim of nuclear fuel mining using up fossil fuels and adding to the greenhouse effect is unjustified .
However , the high temperature and corrosive operating conditions of the MSR require materials that exceed the limitations of current nuclear reactors .
Materials used for these reactors require high dimensional stability and most importantly corrosion-resistance , due to the molten salt of MSRs being corrosive itself .
Some materials that are suitable include nickel-base super alloys , silicon carbide , specific grades of graphite and refractory alloys , which are expensive in nature .
Hence , the cost of operation will not be as price-friendly as claimed .
Nevertheless , the introduction of MSRs still deserves strong support as they are likely to prove to be the best solution for improving energy efficiency and developing renewable energies .
Prompt development of MSRs is especially required for  countries such as China and India .
These countries are unable to satisfy their energy needs  solely  based on the current available avenues for energy sources  .
In conclusion , nuclear energy from fourth generation nuclear reactors is the best substitution for coal and natural gas .
Current emissions of carbon dioxide from automobiles and industries are furiously contributing to global warming .
We have already crossed the threshold of acceptable greenhouse gas emission levels .
Thus , preventing accelerated climate change beyond human control is of the greatest priority .
According to a study done by the Sunssex Energy Group based in the University of Sussex , the world's fossil fuel supply is currently dwindling and will be running out within the next 20 years (Walker , 2009) .
Moreover , the increasing emission of carbon dioxide from the burning of fossil fuel has been proven to be one of the factors  causing climate change (Jager , n .d .) .
These two major issues will lead to more people accepting the use of nuclear energy .
However , there remains doubt of the safety of nuclear reactors' operation and hence , the public might not fully  .
In order to make the nuclear reactor safer , cleaner and cheaper , the Generation IV International Forum (GIF) was established in mid 2001 to further research  the III generation nuclear reactors .
In late 2002 the GIF announced the six best reactor technologies which they believe  will become the future nuclear reactors .
The six technologies are the Very High Temperature Reactor (VTHR) , the Super-Critical Water-Cooled Reactor (SCWR) , the Molten Salt Reactor (MSR) , the Gas-Cooled Fast Reactor (GFR) , the Sodium-Cooled Fast Reactor (SFR) , and the Lead-Cooled Fast Reactor (LFR) .
The few paragraphs below explain why you should support further research and development on the super-critical water-cooled reactor (SCRW) in terms of safety , security and performance .
The second reason are  security issues such as nuclear proliferation .
Nuclear power leads to potential security risks , as plutonium has to be separated out during the reprocessing of nuclear energy production .
Plutonium is a key ingredient of advance nuclear weapons .
Although the U .S .A . has decided to dump all the plutonium waste at  Yucca Mountain , the government never mentioned the level of safety that can be achieved .
Consequently , the public claims that nuclear power wastes create a high degree of proliferation risks and until today there is no solution for it .
Among the six generation IV nuclear technologies , only the SCWR and the VHTR do not require waste recycling .
In the super-critical water-cooled reactor (SCWR) system the waste recycling is optional , which means that the SCWR can operate without having to depend on the contentious reprocessing of plutonium waste (Butler , 2004) .
In conclusion , this technology is free of  proliferation risks .
Last but not least is the performance of the super-critical water-cooled reactor (SCWR) .
The SCWR is considered one of the most promising future nuclear reactors because of its high thermal efficiency .
The use of the multi-pass flows system in the SCWR allows the production of process heat on demand and improves the thermal efficiency .
The thermal efficiency of SCWR is about 45% , which is much higher than the generation III light water reactor of 33% of thermal efficiency (Supercritical-Water-Cooled Reactor (SCWR)) .
Moreover , the distributed fuel channels in the SCWR allow the system to optimize fuel bundles into each channel .
Thus , an appropriate fuel cycle , flow , cladding temperature and independent power distribution can be achieved , which ensures the stable and predictable performance of the reactors .
In conclusion , the super-critical water-cooled reactor (SCWR) has been proven to be cleaner , safer and better performing as compared with the generation III nuclear reactors .
In addition , to reduce the emission of carbon dioxide from  burning fossil fuel , we should now support further research and development for the super-critical water reactor (SCWR) .
The super-critical water-cooled reactor is the best future reactor to generate sufficient energy to fulfill the energy needs of the public .
Nuclear power is an energy produced from controlled nuclear chemical reactions .
Commercial plants in use today use nuclear fission reactions , which is a result of a large molecule breaking into its smaller fragments .
Nuclear fusion reactions are believed to be much safer than fission and appear potentially viable , though technically it is difficult to take place .
Fusion power has been under intense theoretical and experimental investigation for many years .

In the Chernobyl nuclearworld's electricity came from nuclear power , despite concerns about safety and radioactive waste management .

This waste from nuclear energy is extremely dangerous and can be used for the production of nuclear weapons .
In carrying out the ERIS , many training courses and regular exercises are essential in order to make the nuclear worker able to deal with radiation leaks or other accidents .
These essential courses and exercises will cost a lot of money to carry out .
Besides the cost of training , money is also needed for introducing  advanced technology skillsas well as modern facilities and equipment into the nuclear power plants .

This is a big amount and thus needs a consortium to raise .
However , there are many obstacles and contradictions in finding a big consortium to raise these funds .
Hence , the ERIS is not feasible enough to be carried out .
To sum up , theEmergency Response Information System is a effective system that protectsthe public if an incident happens .
However , it has to be improved on and developed more in-depth to ensure its safety and enhance its feasibility .
The countries that are developing this nuclear power (only five countries-China , France , Russia , the United Kingdom and the United States) must make good use of the nuclear power as the energy source for people's daily use .
People will definitely not give up this nuclear power as it has a lot of potential as an energy source .
Therefore , developing a design to enhance the safety of nuclear power plants becomes a long-term project of the world .
Consequently , the nuclear power source will be extensively used by the public  .
Firstly , all stages of the nuclear fuel cycle involve potentially harmful effects on the environment or mankind due to the high reactivity , the radiation emitted by nuclear wastes and the huge heat dissipation during nuclear processes .
Any flaws in the reactor design or processes could result in disastrous circumstances .
For instance , the Chernobyl accident is still causing deaths years after the accident , with victims mainly dying from cancer caused by exposure to radiation from the highly radioactive waste products released after the massive steam explosion , which occurred due to system flaws , and a second non-nuclear explosion (International Atomic Energy Agency , 2006) .
A 2005 report entitled The Chernobyl Forum , prepared by the International Atomic Energy Agency and World Health Organization , attributed 56 direct deaths and estimated over thousands more deaths among the most highly exposed people .
Another example is the Three Mile Island accident , which occurred due to a partial core meltdown in one of its units (Corey , n .d .) .
The above examples illustrate the potential dangers of nuclear power due to its explosive and radioactive characteristics .
The radiation coming from the nuclear wastes will not only produce  instant harm , but also a long-term effect on residents in affected areas , spreading across generations .
Keeping that in mind , the gas-cooled fast reactor , one of the generation IV reactor concepts , which requires research on irradiation- resistance material ,  .
Furthermore , the need for research on heat resistance material and security in the various generation IV reactor concepts is also worrying in terms of the possibilities of nuclear accidents in the future .
Secondly , arguments are that nuclear power is the best alternative because of the characteristic of not producing combustion-related air- pollutants that will lead to global warming , and because of the huge power supply it provides .
In addition , nuclear power uses uranium , which is a scarce resource that is only expected to last for another 30 to 60 years , as fuel .
Therefore , uranium will soon deplete and we will need to search for a new form of energy supply .
Thus , the huge amount of funds pumped into research and development on nuclear power , which will not support us for the long run , is not cost-effective .
Moreover , renewable energy technologies are now expanding faster than nuclear power technologies (Natural Resources Defense Council , 2007) .
They are equally environmentally-friendly and the depleting of resources for renewable energy is of no worry since the reactants are renewable .
Last of all , one of the most promising and nerve-racking reasons is the risk of development of nuclear weapons in an era of transnational terrorism (Gaukler , Barnett , & Rosinski , 2002) .
Terrorism is one of the most troubling global issues in recent years .
The improvement in technologies of the nuclear power would also provide  in handling nuclear weapons , so any leakage of details could result in development of nuclear weapons , which in the time of translational terrorism is almost inevitable .
It is also worrying that nuclear power plants may be the target of attack for terrorists due to their destructive nature .
Therefore , there will be a higher risk of  nuclear warfare .
The result will be disastrous .
In addition , the need for research on security in various reactor concepts of generation IV is also disturbing .
To summarize , nuclear power has various  that could affect the well-being of our environment and health that cannot be neglected despite its numerous benefits .
In addition , there are better alternatives such as  renewable energy that will be able to support our energy needs in the long run .
Hence , the funds pumped into the development of nuclear power should instead be used in the development of renewable resources that are more cost- effective .
In Singapore , according to the Ministry of Manpower (2009) ,  about a total  of 11000 cases of fatal and non fatal  occupational accidents occur in Singapore and 60 people die in these accidents per annum .
The accident of the Nicoll Highway Collapse in  2004 , which is one of the most catastrophic accidents in the construction sector of Singapore ,  took away 4 lives .
According to the accident investigation report (Ministry of Manpower , 2005) ,  found that the main cause of the collapse was due to under-designing of the retaining wall which could not handle the stress of holding up the tunnel .
Although some people might think that the effectiveness of psychology in preventing accidents from occurring is controversial ,  I believe that the use of psychology during the design process could have prevented this accident from occurring .
Many people think that not only the Nicoll Highway Collapse incident , but also most of the major occupational accidents were unexpected and  mainly caused by errors in human judgment .
They believe that psychology could have done nothing to prevent the accident from occurring (International Labour Organisation , 2000) .
However , in certain aspects , accidents can be prevented if psychology is introduced to  during the design stage .
According to the Heinrich Domino theory ,  an accident is caused by the chain reaction of a series of factors .
Moreover , "Heinrich proposes that the removal of unsafe acts and unsafe conditions will prevent accidents , as  his research it was found that these were the direct or immediate causes of most accidents" (Singapore Polytechnic , 2008) .
In the United Kingdom , the approach of understanding human behaviour was used in a practical set of Human Factors Analysis Tools (HFAT) which was developed by Mr Ronny Lardner & Mr Richard Scaife .
This made significant enhancement in the steel- making , chemical manufacture and construction industry in preventing accidents at work .
Besides that , with this Human Factors Analysis Tools (HFAT) , the originatorsalso won the Occupational Psychology Practitioner of the Year award in  2006 (Division of Occupational Psychology , United Kingdom , n .d .) .
In conclusion , although accidents are unexpected , it is possible to minimize and preventthem from occurring  by using the psychology approach in design processes .
It has also been proven to be effective in accident prevention as the MOM has made an obligatory requirement that all work sites must employ a Work Site Safety and Health Officer before the commencement of a project (Singapore Polytechnic , 2008) .
30 years after the Three Mile Island accident , and 23 years after the Chernobyl disaster , the horrors and fears of a nuclear reactor meltdown might have died down considerably .
But the general public is still cautious about accepting nuclear power as a viable energy source .
Although we should never forget the painful lessons of Chernobyl and Three Mile Island , we should also be open-minded about the possibilities that generation IV nuclear reactors brings .
Of the 6 generation IV reactors earmarked for further development , the gas cooled fast reactor design is both innovative and dedicated to becoming an efficient and sustainable nuclear energy option .
According to a recent US poll , a significant 44 .7% of the respondents think that nuclear is somewhat dangerous or very dangerous .
And they are not wrong in thinking that , given However ,t the radioactive uranium used as fuel is inherently dangerous , being extremely lethal to human health and polluting to the environment .
To address the safety concerns of the public , this design envisioned many safeguard systems .
A NEA report stated that a 'three barrier pbringle' will be implemented , and there will be 'cladding at fuel levels; vessels and primary circuit' .
This means that the radioactslatedar fbecomel be well contained by three separate layers of shielding material , greatly reducing the chances of leakage .
Furthermore the report emphasized the employment of 2 separate and redundant heat removal systems .
One is a passive system that uses natural convection while the other is an active system that uses circulators to pass the gas through the reactor core .
The coolant will be helium , an inert gas that is much safer than the sodium liquid used in sodium-cooled fast reactors .
A major constraint of nuclear power is the tricky issue of waste disposal .
Nucleanuclear energy productions need to be stored in deep geological repositories for thousands of years .
Hence the treatment of nuclear waste will be a major public concern .
A key feature of the gas cooled fast reactor is that it is a fast neutron reactor that fully recycles actinides .
According to 'Nucthe designgas cooled fast reactorincludes published on Nature , '96An of spent fuels consist of uranium and plutonium' in other words more fuels can be generated if the wastes are to be reprocessed .
In the gas cooled fast reactor , radioactive byproducts are recycled and the waste eventually produced will only be a fraction of that produced by reactors with once through uranium fuel cycles .
In addition , as the design is a fast neutron reactor , it produces excess neutrons which can be used to transmute the nuclear waste to isotopes of shorter half-lives , reducing the toxicity of the waste .
This design also addresses a security concern of nuclear waste reprocessing .
Currently , in the logistics of reprocessing , nuclear wastes are transported to reprocesHence ,facilities which recovers the urisnd plutonium before sending them to another mixed oxide fuel (MOX) reactors to be burnt as fuels .
This involves frequent transportation of highly dangethe article , 'Nuclear Power's New Dawn' , over long instances .
This exposes a security risk as an accidentplutonium'; in other words ,dioactive materials or a hijack can send these ials into the hands of terrorists .
However a report by Hussein Khalil from the Argonne National Laboratories in USA envisioned 'an integrated , onsite spent fuel treatment and refabrication plant' .
This essentially obliterates the security risks involved in transporting radioactive wastes and allows security efforts to be focused on plantintotself .
the plantLastly , this design is commthetted to becoming asurroundingustainable form of nuclear power .
Contrary to popular beliefs that nuclear energy is renewable , uranium is actually a rare element that carecoverleted .
In this aspect , the gas cooled fast reactor is attractive as it boasts higreactorciency in converting heat energy into electricity than conventional nuclear reactors .
This is achievable by running the reactor at 850 C , a temperature that is kept in check by the helium heat removal system .
The higher efficiency if this reactor design together with the recyclHowever ,wastes , meant that the same amount of fuel will produce electricity mathe USAtenvisionsthan the conventional reactor .

It addressesbeliefblic's concern about safety with a very comprehensive safeguard system .
Although nuclear waste remains as problematic , it is reduced to a minimum .
Above all , it shows the potential to be sustainable , an advantage that can allow it to be built on a large enough scale to shoulder a significant portion of the world's energy needs .
Therefore its research and development should supported and properly funded so that one day it can reach its full potential and alleviatemeans of the world's energy problems .
The Generation IV International Forum (GIF)  , a research and development group organized by ten nations to carry out research on the next generation of nuclear concepts , is identifying and selecting six nuclear energy systems with a variety of reactors , energy conversion systems , and fuel cycle technologies .
With GIF's nuclear technology , the concerns of the public mentioned above would be addressed .
Among the six generation IV reactor concepts , the most advanced concept is the VHTR (very high temperature reactor) which is a more efficient way of converting heat energy to electricity and which can provide 50% more energy from the same amount of fuel compared with other conventional nuclear plants .
Hence , with VHTR technology , nuclear energy can be a very reliable energy source for electricity in many countries .
Regarding nuclear power plants , the safety features of the plant is the greatest concern of the public .
There were nuclear accident hazards all over the world  a few decades ago; for example , the reactor core explosion at Chernobyl in Ukraine killed many people , with two people dying in the initial explosion and other deaths resulting from radiation poisoning (Gramling , 2009) .
The VHTR system has its own safety features such as a very high system temperature , enhanced goals for safety and reliability , low decay heat load , low power density with  and so on (Idaho National Laboratory) .
The core is composed of non-combustible nuclear grade graphite which has a very stable structure even at high temperatures and high heat capacity .
Thus , the possibility of explosion due to the very high temperature becomes extremely low .
Moreover ,  additional safety features such as how to minimize  damage and protect lives if an accident occurs will also be developed further (Lee , 2005) .
Another concern regarding nuclear power plants is how to dispose of the nuclear wastes which are long lasting , radioactive and toxic .
As the VHTR operates at a very high temperature , there are fewer wastes to reprocess than those of other systems .
Moreover , the reprocessing will  96% of the nuclear waste produced , which consists of plutonium and uranium , and only about 1% of long lasting elements are left as residue .
There are also additional steps of processing to convert those long lasting wastes into elements with shorter half- lives , i .e .
they may take just centuries to decay instead of more than 300 ,000 years (Butler , 2004) .
Hence , nuclear waste disposal will not be a great concern in the future .
Nuclear terrorism has always been a threat to the world since the sudden attack on Hiroshima in 1945 .
The VHTR is carefully designed to discourage weapon proliferation and to increase assurance that  are very unattractive and are the least desirable route for  ,  .
Moreover , the plutonium , which is the main ingredient of advanced nuclear weapons , produced from the nuclear waste cannot be picked up safely with a pair of gloves like pure plutonium as it is spiked with radioactive and heat-producing elements to make it easier to handle .
Hence , it would be harder for terrorists to steal or use the material  .
Since the VHTR is still undergoing research , the earliest delivery will be in 2020 (Butler , 2004) .
Further security features can be added before the delivery time .
With the  security system developed ,  nuclear terrorism can be prevented .
In conclusion , in view of the increasing global need for more energy globally , nuclear energy will become essential in the future once issues such as safety  , waste management and potential exploitation of plutonium proliferation by terrorists areaddressed .
This , in fact , has become possible after the development of the VHTR which incorporates  features that minimize the risks of accidents and enable safer disposal of nuclear waste .
Therefore , research for VHTR technology should be funded for further development to reach its optimal potential .
In our modern technological society of today , people make substantial use of electricity for their daily needs .
In the United States alone , people use close to 4 million  kwh of electricity daily .
In addition , as society grows , the demand for such energy grows as well .
The usage of fossil fuel as a fuel at power plants is projected to increase by 44 percent from 2006 to  .
In this new dawn , nuclear power is a new technology set to replace fossil fuel .
With promises of lower cost , less waste and a safer alternative , it may seem that nuclear power with the introduction of generation IV reactors such as the super-critical-water- cooled reactors is the next generation of power plants .
However , these promises are revealed to be empty promises if one looks deeper into the issue of nuclear Power .
Therefore , support of further research and development funding for nuclear power should not be continued .
With regard to safety , it has been reported that there are more cases of fatalities for coal powered plants than their nuclear counterparts .
In the last 40 years , 6400 individualshave died due to coal power plant related accidents while only 31 have died in nuclear powered ones .
Therefore , it is claimed that nuclear plants are a much safer choice .
However , we cannot ignore that Murphy's Law will still hold .
There will be a point in time when there will be an error which could result in an accident in anuclear power plant one day .
This single incident will have catastrophic effects and the fatality rate will be  substantial  .
In the Chernobyl disaster alone which happened on 28 April 1986 , 47 people died on the spot with 4000 more who subsequently died from cancer .
The effects of the incident are still greatly felt today with the radio activeness of the area still at a record high despite three decades of clearing up .
Hence , we only need one nuclear accident to cause the kind of damage  a coal plant would take more than 50 years to cause .
Further to what has been pointed out , nuclear power will also evoke security issues in the region .
While used as a a form of deterrence , it is also seen as a threat by neighbouring countries .
This will lead to an arms race which might inevitably cause some conflicts in the region .
An example is the nuclear program of Iran .
Iran has developed its nuclear program as form of deterrence and to build up national pride .
However , many neighbouring countries see these reasons as an excuse for the building of nuclear weapons so they feel threatened .
Hence , many conflicts have resulted .
From this , we can see that nuclear power  brings issues to not only the country which is developing it but other neighbouring countries in the region as well .
To conclude , with so many flaws in the claims of benefits from supporters of nuclear energy , it will be a wiser choice to delay if not stop further research and development funding for it .
The price for a small mistake in the pursuit of nuclear energy is too much for mankind to pay .
Alternative sources of energy should be considered instead .
Electricity has become an important component of the human world since it is needed to power and sustain technology .
However , since a large amount of electricity is needed , commercial power generators have been built to convert  fuel into electricity .
While there are many types of fuel that can be considered , coal has been the popualr choice .
Another option , which is nuclear energy , had been explored with moderate success but currently only holds a 17% share as a global energy supply (Butler , 2004) .
However , development of the technology used by nuclear reactors are still on-going with the recent introduction of Generation-IV nuclear reactor concepts , one of them being the molten salt reactor .
The molten salt reactor , while not exactly a new idea , has resurfaced after the introduction of the generation IV concepts of nuclear reactors .
The major draw in continuing the research of molten salt reactor is its potential to make converting electricity from nuclear energy much safer , more environmentally friendly and more economically viable as compared to current reactors .
One reason that impedes the continuation of research of the molten salt reactor is the general caution on the issue of nuclear waste proliferation .
A key step in current nuclear power generation , which is separation of the by-products in the nuclear reactor wastes , would yield materials usable in the creation of highly destructive weapons .
However , the design of molten salt reactors allow for on-site reprocessing of the reactor waste , followed by a direct feed of the recovered and reusable fuel back into the energy generating cycle (Uhlir , 2007) .
This will ensure that the majority of the fuel is burnt in the process , leaving very low levels of remaining enriched fuel that can be extracted for use for the manufacture of nuclear weapons .
The  alternative to replacing coal is arguably the use of solar or wind energy .
This will alleviate the current problem of emission of greenhouse gases from the burning of coal , but unlike nuclear energy , solar and wind energy is highly dependent on the weather , making it unreliable .
The heat and high amount of electricity generated by the molten salt reactor , on the other hand , can be said to be constant and can be further tapped into for the production of hydrogen (Duffery , 2005) .
The hydrogen produced by the reactor will have further uses as fuel for other systems where its combustion will not produce any greenhouse gases .
The continual research of the molten salt reactor will also result in the use of nuclear reactors being more economical compared to the current situation .
For example , the amount of uranium currently mined from the earth's surfaces have been approximated to last for another 100-200 years as fuel for the reactors (Lightfoot , Manheimer , Meneley , Pendergast , and Stanford , 2006) .
Molten salt reactors can also use thorium as fuel , reserves of which are estimated to be four times larger than that of uranium (Duffery , 2005) .
However , since the fuel is expected to be close to , or completely , burnt up in the molten salt reactor as opposed to the case for current reactors , this higher level of fuel efficiency can drive the duration for which the uranium reserves can sustain the global energy comsumption longer than estimated .
The increase in fuel efficiency will reduce operational cost since there will be less need for storage of long life radioactive waste products .
In addition , considering the development of advanced materials in the further research of molten salt reactor , the actual amount of materials needed in the building can be reduced , thus reducing overall cost .
For example , by replacing the stainless steel commonly found in reactors with other alloys that are equally strong or alloys that are stronger and more durable , and that do not use nickle , the cost of building the reactor can be reduced since the price of nickle has been increasing in recent times (Busby , 2009) .
While the use of nuclear energy raises some concern in terms of security and cost , the continuous research of molten salt reactors can address these concerns through the recycling of fuel and the use of a different variant of fuel .
However , while the research cost of a reactor is very high , this can be solved through the cooperation of more countries , especially the larger  countries like China .
In the long run , one of the benefits of using molten salt reactors would be that it can meet  energy demands while maintaining a clean environment .
In the recent two decades , whether to adopt nuclear energy as a sustainable source of energy has become one of the heated arguments in the world .
scientists state that coal and fossil fuels on earth are depleting at an alarming rate and would be running out in the next century .
Nuclear energy has thus emerged as one of the most viable solutions .
However , due to the strong oppositions from the public about the safety of nuclear power plants , many countries are caught in the dilemma of whether they should build a nuclear plant or not .
It is indeed true that a country must not ignore the safety factors of building a nuclear plant .
However , in the current situation where there are no better alternatives , nuclear energy seems to be the most suitable energy for the future and therefore one of the generation IV reactors , the lead-coaled fast reactor , should be adopted as the solution .
Firstly , the argument raised by most opponents is the safety issue .
They declare that the nuclear reactions which may be termed as nuclear fission and nuclear fusion are extremely dangerous and even fatal to human beings .
The Chernobyl accident in 1986 was a reminder of the importance of  safety .
30 people were killed (mostly by high levels of radiation) during the accident and many more were injured or adversely affected .
It was indeed a disastrous accident which subsequently made nuclear plants appear to be scientific devils .
However , the reactor used in fact lacked some basic engineering provisions for safety , probably due to technological constraints at that time .
However , with advancements in science and technology nowadays , the level of danger of the nuclear reactors would be minimised to the lowest degree .
The generation IV reactor , the lead-coaled fast reactor , is the safest one among the four being proposed .
It is operated under low pressure which means that the nuclear reactions are less vigorous .
In addition , the operating temperature allows a range of 550 to 800 degrees .
This medium range of temperature increases the functional capacity of the reactor as compared to those which only operate at a fixed temperature .
On top of that , lead which is used as the main source is a less reactive metal compared to sodium for sodium-coaled fast reactors .
Therefore , safety is ensured to the greatest possible level .
another opposing view is that the cost of building a nuclear plant is rather high .
They insist that fuel is still a cheaper source of energy than nuclear power reactors .
The fact is , however , the other way round .
Gas-fired power plants are very cheap and quick to build , but  very expensive to operate due to the cost of their fuel .
In contrast , nuclear power reactors are expensive to build but relatively cheap to operate .
It might take millions of dollars to build the lead-coaled fast reactor , but once it is constructed , it will be operating at a reasonably high capacity over many years .
Furthermore , the cost for mining out and transporting  coal and fuel is also very expensive due to their scarcity whereas the sources for nuclear power plants are much cheaper since plenty of uranium can be extracted from the earth's crust .
The abundance of uranium on earth also means that it is a more powerful way of generating electricity .
Most importantly , the waste generated by the lead-coaled fast reactor can also be recycled and thus there is virtually no pollution to the environment .
Hence , in the long run , it is more economical to adopt the lead-coaled fast reactor which is also an environmentally friendly source of energy .
The final argument advanced by opponents is that there are other  sources of safer energy such as solar energy and wind turbines , so there is no need to adopt the nuclear power reactors which are still untested .
Recent research indeed shows that the sun is a variable source of energy .
In addition , thermal energy can be stored in a system so that solar energy will still be available even at night .
However , can we really solely rely on  ?
What will happen during the rainy seasons and will there be enough solar energy to sustain our daily usage ?
The answer is most probably not .
We would still have to rely on other sources when solar energy runs low at times .
On the other hand , unlike solar energy , the provision of nuclear power by lead-coaled fast reactors does not depend on weather or location .
As long as the nuclear sources such as lead and uranium are provided , energy will be generated .
Therefore , the lead-coaled fast reactor is a more efficient and reliable energy source .
All in all , with the depleting sources of coal and fuel , lead-coaled fast reactors will be the most likely alternative energy source in the future .
With advanced technology and engineering designs , the safety of nuclear reactors will be ensured  .
It is also a relatively economical and yet efficient source of energy .
Therefore , such  nuclear power reactors should be adopted in the future as a promising source of energy .
The world depends largely on external energy to operate all activities in the society .
The world's main energy resource , which is  fossil fuel , is slowly depleting .
As a result , there is a need to depend on  alternative energy resources to satisfy our high energy demands .
Nuclear power has proven to be an effective energy source as it can generate electricity efficiently to satisfy the world's energy needs .
However , there are many controversies over the use of nuclear power , and many critics criticize its use .
Some of the gravest concerns that are widely mentioned are safety , costs and  performance .
Safety issues raised by past nuclear accidents still strike fear in the public's heart .
An example of such an accident is the "the 1986 accident at Chernobyl in Ukraine , during which the reactor core exploded , (killed) some 31 people immediately and (spew) radioactive debris across Europe ."
[1] The high cost of building nuclear plants is also a main concern .
Articles have shown that many experts agree that nuclear power costs significantly higher  relative to the other major energy sources .
[5] Moreover , there are still many doubts about whether nuclear power has a competitive edge over other  energy providers in terms of performance .
With all these concerns on the use of nuclear power , it seems that nuclear power poses more of a problem than a solution as a beneficial energy source .
However , with the building of generation IV reactors such as the VHTR , problems that the old generation reactors faced will be greatly reduced , making nuclear power a viable energy source .

In conclusion , nuclear power is most preferred as an energy source in terms of its performance and efficiency .
In comparison to older generation reactors , Generation IV reactors will have better safety and cost effective features .
The VHTR is one of the best generation IV reactors , making it one of the most reliable energy providers in the future .
Hence , further research and funding for the VHTR will definitely benefit the future generations .

In conclusion , the Very High Temperature Reactor would be the best nuclear reactor concept to implement .
Whether it is about safety  , cost or performance level , the VHTR is a notch above its peers such as the SFR  .
The VHTR's potential as the best nuclear reactor is recognized by many countries like France , Japan and the United States of America .
It is given the most funding and research attention by these countries .
Future world energy consumption is well taken care of .
Nuclear energy sources have various benefits over other energy sources .
Firstly , a nuclear power plant is more cost effective to operate as compared to other energy sources .
For example , although the start-up cost of building the VHTR plant is very high , which is up to US$10 billion  , it is cheaper as compared to other fuel , such as bio fuel , in the long run .
This is because hydrogen gas is produced during the nuclear reaction process(Burthler , 2004) .
Hydrogen gas can be used as a fuel to power vehicles .
Consequently , many countries have regarded VHTR as the energy source of the future , because it produces hydrogen gas as a complimentary energy source that is reusable .
the reactor can separate hydrogen gas from water thermodynamically during the nuclear reaction at an extremely high temperature of about 700-900 degrees celcius(Burthler , 2004) .
Additionally , according to the economics concept , there is less third party cost incurred by others if nuclear power is used instead of other fuels .
It is also relatively cleaner to the environment as compared to other sources of fuels .
Thus , the sum of all the variouscosts of producing nuclear power is relatively lower than  other sources of energy .
Thus , further improvement should be made to the VHTR to increase its efficiency .
Secondly , a nuclear reactor , especially the VHTR , produces less waste as compared to other  energy sources .
It is known that a large percentage of the greenhouse gases present today is due to the use of petroleum and  combustion of fossil fuels .
The burning of fossil fuels also produces other waste products that are harmful for the environment .
On the other hand , even though the VHTR produces nuclear waste which will emit harmful radioactivity , the industry has come up with effective ways to dispose of the nuclear waste .
One such method is to bury the nuclear waste in the ground .
Research has shown that the radioactivity that is produced by the nuclear waste under the ground is equivalent to the radioactivity emitted by  cosmic rays .
Thus , humans are safe from the radioactivity produced by the nuclear waste .
That is , nuclear power , especially that produced by the VHTR , is a much cleaner source of energy to the environment , so further research and development should be done on it .
In essence , nuclear reactors , especially the VHTR , are more cost effective in the long run as compared to other energy sources .
In addition , nuclear energy is less harmful to the environment and it is safe to humans .
Moreover , it has been shown that the VHTR is 40% more effective in producing energy as compared to  other sources of energy .
Thus , in my opinion , more funding should be provided for  research and development to further improve the production of nuclear power , and the research should focus more on the VHTR .
The usage of nuclear plants to generate electricity has been a controversial issue since decades ago , due to the disastrous incidents on Three Miles Island and at Chernobyl , which have resulted in major health issues caused by radiation exposure .
The public  has been rejecting the construction of nuclear plants due to safety concerns .
However , as technology has evolved with time , the Generation IV power plants are better in terms of security , cost and performance .
Hence , more people are accepting the usage of nuclear energy .
In 2008 , a survey showed that the number of Americans that supports nuclear energy has increased from 10% in 2001 , to around 50% in 2008 (Jones , 2009) .
Half the public is still opposing the usage of nuclear energy .
One of the main reasons stated by the opposition is that nuclear plants consume uranium and produce nuclear waste , which could be used to manufacture nuclear weapons .
Furthermore , the nuclear waste emits radiation that is harmful to humans and the environment .
However , these situations can be prevented with Generation IV molten salt reactors .
The molten salt reactors are capable of recycling the nuclear waste to produce more electrical energy , so the waste created from the recycling process will not be available for creating nuclear weapons .
This process also helps to prevent the existing practice of spending large amounts of money  to store the nuclear waste .
In addition , the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) has set up necessary guidelines for  governments to ensure the highest level of security for their nuclear facilities .
The Generation IV plants are built to shut down automatically in the event of a meltdown or terrorist attack (Butler , 2004) .
To prevent the escape of radiation which resulted in the Chernobyl incident , the new plants are built with shielding that can prevent radiation from escaping into the surroundings in case of a meltdown .
Opponents have also argued that renewable energy sources are better sources of energy as theyproduced cleaner energy when compared to nuclear reactors , which produce radiation and nuclear waste .
In addition , renewable sources are also unlimited , whereas uranium will last another two centuries at most (Fetter , 2009) .
Thus , they believe that governments should spend the money on research for renewable energy instead of nuclear energy .
On the other hand , with the technology of Generation IV reactors , the radiation and nuclear waste can be eliminated .
Furthermore , the electricity produced from renewable sources like solar energy is measured in Mega watts per hour , while the electricity produced from nuclear plant is measured in Giga watts per hour , so one thousand times more energy is produced .
In comparison , the biggest solar power generator located in California is able to support half a million users , less than two percent of the city population (Wolff , 2007) , while a single nuclear plant is able to provide electricity for a few cities .
The vast difference in energy produced supports the funding for research in nuclear energy .
Another issue is that uranium is finite like fossil fuels .
By allocating more funds into the research of nuclear energy , scientists can look for possible alternative elements to fuel the nuclear plants .
Another reason mentioned by the opposition is the extremely large amount of money spent on research and construction of nuclear reactors .
Every year , governments that are supportive of nuclear energy have spent billions of dollars on it .
In 2008 , the United States Government increased their budget allocation for nuclear energy and the research and development for Generation IV power plants to twenty-five billion dollars (Barnett , 2008) .
The opposition has stated that the power generated is not worth the cost , as the cost is accumulated from  .
However , in the long term , the power generated will be worth the large amount of money , as the usage cost from nuclear plants is lower than the usage cost from fuel plants .
Furthermore , no greenhouse gas is being produced .
It is definitely worthwhile spending more to protect the environment .
In conclusion , governments should support further research and development on nuclear energy as the security concern regarding nuclear waste can be eliminated; moreover , nuclear plants are the most efficient energy source and the cost of nuclear energy is the cheapest in the long term  .
With further funding on the research , humans will be able to produce energy  in the long run without damaging the environment .
robotic surgical technology is a prototype and a new breakthrough in the field of engineering and medicine .
It enhances surgical procedures through improvements in dexterity and precision .
The robotic system uses fine , precise robotic arms and its three dimensional high resolution computed image guides the surgeon during an operation .
This advanced dexterity and precision of operation will eliminate the need for large incisions on patients .
CNN international Health News 24 September 2009 "Landmark in Surgery , Past , present and future" {http://edition .cnn .com/2009/HEALTH/09/23/future .surgery .robots/index .html#cnnSTCOther1}[HYPERLINK: http://edition .cnn .com/2009/HEALTH/09/23/future .surgery .robots/index .html]

However , although the initial clinical outcomes are positive , safety is a major factor why the robotic surgical system still remains fearful to the public .
Safety concerns involve technical credibility , surgical liability and operation performance .
Even though there is no guarantee that the robotic surgical system can absolutely ensurethe safety of patients , the design of the robotic system can nevvertheless improved to enhance safety .
Currently , the robotic surgical technology has not been widely accepted by the public mainly due to its uncertainty in safety .
During an operation , the condition of the patient is unpredictable;  many tasks and decisions need to be made involving the surgeon , the nurses and the robotic system .
For example , when tools are changed , the robotic system needs to be paused in order to replace a surgical tool .
During this process , the surgeon has no direct access to the situation; the system relies largely on verbal exchanges between the nurses and the surgeon to coordinate the surgical procedures .
The differences in perspective  with respect to the patient's condition and the robotic system create safety issues , mainly due to the potential of miscommunication .
In order to enhance safety , a common ground needs to be built through ensuring similar speech patterns .
Therefore , communication between surgeons and nurses can be improved by the sharing of a common set of statements and ideology .
Although the robotic system has improved greatly in its dexterity ,  its full potential in terms of instrumental design and sensory sensitivity has yet to be developed .
This poses uncertain dangers during an operation .
According to Zorn (2009) , no credible system is currently available to assess the capability of a surgeon while operating the robotic surgical system .
Dr Kevin Zorn recalled an incident where a patient died from complications after long hours of operation using the robotic surgical system .
In order to improve the system's safety , the future of the robotic system can be expanded using ultrasound and infrared .
More ideal mechanical surgical tools are to be developed .
In addition , the surgical equipment occupies a large space which may restrict the movement of nurses and cause delays during an operation .
miniaturizing the equipment will help address the problem and also save cost in making room for the accommodation of this expensive equipment .

During the past few years , there have been discussions on whether nuclear power plants should be built or not .
For the past few centuries , most of our electricity has been generated from coal , fuel or oil refineries .
However , as the population increases , there is a higher demand for electricity , so more raw resources such as fossil fuel have to be used .
Recently ,  the rate of depletion of fossil fuel has been increasing , leading to a higher electricity cost .
As a result , more people are turning to nuclear power  as a solution to the high electricity cost .
However , before we change to nuclear power  , there are some factors we need to consider .
The factors which would be discussed are  cost , security and performance .
Some of the reasons why people are opposed to the idea are  the high construction cost and level of danger of nuclear power plants .
However ,   because of the lower electricity cost and the ability to meet the world's demand in the future .
Despite  opposing views ,  further research and development funding for the Very-High-Temperature-Reactor (VHTR) should be encouraged .
The second factor is security . .
According to Bulter (2004) , the public has highlighted the accidents which occurred in 1979 at Three Mile Island and in 1986 at Chernobyl  .
Some of the reasons that these accidents occurred are due to poor technology at that time .
However , in the case of the generation IV reactor , it has been claimed that there would be a security feature called the "Meltdown" Proof which would reduce the temperature to a minimum in the event of an accident .
As technology advances over the years , we can foresee that the chances of accidents  occurring will be reduced .
Thirdly , in terms of the performance factor ,  Bulter (2004) claims that the VHTR could squeeze 50% more electricity from the same amount of fuel compared with conventional plants .
Engineers have agreed that in order to reach such efficiency , higher temperatures would need to be generated , thus causing a higher chance of accident .
Once again , this could be resolved by the "Meltdown" Proof mentioned earlier .
In conclusion , we can see that even though there are some disadvantages of the nuclear power plant , it is still beneficial to the public if we  operate it in the long run .
The advantages of the nuclear power plant outweigh its disadvantages .
The Very High Temperature Reactor (VHTR) is one of the six generation IV reactors which need to be developed .
The six generation IV reactors are the vision of the future of the Generation IV International Forum (GIF) .
GIF looks at the future with nuclear reactors in its mind , because it believes the current coal-burning source of energy would not be sufficient for the world's need by 2050 (Butler , 2004) .
In addition , GIF believes the coal- burning is contributing to global warming by  carbon dioxide (CO2) into the air .
The six generation IV reactors are believed to be able to replace coal mines .
These six generation IV reactors are still in the testing and research phase .
GIF is researching them in terms of their safety  , their cost effectiveness and their effect on the environment because these are the public'sconcerns about them .
First of all , the safety factor of  nuclear reactors has been highlighted over the past decades by the nuclear-averse public .
This is due to  memories of  past accidents involving the partial meltdown of nuclear nuclear reactors .
Looking back at a few decades ago , there were two accidents which brought the world's attention to the importance of safety in the nuclear reactors .
In 1979 , on Three Mile Island , Pennsylvania , there was a malfunction in a cooling system which caused part of the reactor core to melt and some radioactive gas to be released into the airwas , fortunately , not enough to cause any radiation dose  .
In 1986 , at Chernobyl , Ukraine , a flawed reactor design that was operated by untrained personnel and without proper regard for safety , exploded and released at least five percent of the radioactive reactor core into the atmosphere and the surrounding area .
The two accidents  caused people who lived nearby the nuclear reactors to suffer from the radiation .
Since then , no new nuclear power plants have been built .
The nuclear-averse public oppose the development of generation IV reactors because they are afraid such accidents will happen again and cause more damage to the people who live nearby nuclear reactor plants .
However , such an argument ignores the fact that generation IV reactors have a 'meltdown proof' feature .
This feature would simplify safety features; hence we would not need to rely on sophisticated backup systems or experienced operators .
This is because generation IV reactors can cool themselves down in the event of an accident with minimal human intervention (Butler , 2004) , thus preventing the meltdown accident from happening again .
The second factor is the cost of building  nuclear reactor plant .
The nuclear-averse public oppose the development of generation IV reactors because they are too costly to build .
It is true that a country needs to put billions of dollars into the research and development of nuclear reactor plants .
This is because it is beneficial for the country in the long run .
With the increasing  population , the demand on  energy sources will increase .
One alternate energy source which has been suggested by many  scientists is nuclear energy .
This is because with the same amount of raw materials , a nuclearreactor plant can produce up to ten times more of the energy produced by a the fossil energy plant .
Lastly , the third factor is the effect of nuclear reactors on the environment .
The nuclear-averse public oppose the development of generation IV reactors because they are worried that its waste will pollute the environment .
The waste of the nuclear reactors will last for a few years on earth before it starts to deplete .
It will pollute water and air .
However , if it is handled with a proper method , we can recycle it .
GIF is researching a proper method for recycling the waste from nuclear reactors .
When GIF have found out the proper method of recycling , the public can live with ease nearby the nuclear reactor plants .
To conclude , the nuclear-averse public oppose the development of generation IV reactors because they do not fully understand the concept of generation IV reactors .
Once GIF is able to produce the generation IV reactors , the nuclear-averse public should be able to understand and support their development .
Hence , the very high temperature reactor should be further researched and developed .

Nuclear power  is electrical power which is produced from controlled nuclear reactions (France , 2005) .
Although nuclear power can produce a much more significant amount of electrical power compared to other forms of electrical energy , its safety  makes the public concerned about nuclear power production .
Moreover , cost and environmental issues should also be considered .
Among many nuclear reactors built all over the world , one type of reactor is the "Sodium-cooled fast reactor" which is operated at a temperature of 550 degree Celsius under low pressure .
The power output of this reactor is electricity  .
However , nuclear power is not an efficient way if we consider the storage and safety issues of nuclear materials as well as the huge cost of nuclear power plant construction (Hannity , 2009) .

Since nuclear power plants do not release any harmful materials , nuclear energy is ideal  .
A nuclear power plant emits significantly low carbon while fossil fuel pollution kills around ten thousand people per year in the United States due to respiratory problems .
However ,  some opponents also claim that an average nuclear power plant creates twenty to thirty tonnes of high level waste per year and that waste has to cool on site for at least five years before they are moved .
According to oneenvironmental  group , Yucca currently fills up 2495 tons of nuclear waste  (The Charlotte Observer , Hauter , 2004) .
Some people claim that the chances of accidents at  nuclear reactor plants are very low because of advanced technology .However , the accident at the Three Mile Island Unit2 nuclear power plant which has been the most serious in the US ,  as well as the explosion at the Chernobyl power station , prove that nuclear reactors are still dangerous and not 100 percent secure .
Besides killing people on the spot , increased radiation was also detected around the area of explosion .
The number of deaths by cancer also increased because of these incidents .
Not just health and environmental facts , but psychological factors should also be considered .
The worst situation is using nuclear power as a weapon (Walker , 2004) .
In conclusion , nuclear power should not be widely produced because of security as well as environmental issues .
Alternative energy sources such as wind , solar , hydrogen as well as water should be used instead for a more secure future for the next generation .

Recently , there has been an increasing debate about the safe operation of nuclear reactors .
Evidence also shows that very few new reactors have been built since serious accidents took place due to explosions or meltdowns of nuclear reactors in the 1980s (Butler , 2004) .
To date , people are still suffering a lot of the repercussions from these past incidents .
However , with the expected increase in energy demand worldwide and the growing awareness of global warming , climate change  and sustainable development , the new Generation IV (Gen IV) nuclear reactors seem to be the ultimate solution to these problems .
According to Gerstner , the Gen IV nuclear reactors will promise  safe , economically competitive , proliferation-resistant nuclear power without the danger of increasing greenhouse gas emissions .
Many developed countries are starting to express interest in this new nuclear technology and some have even formed a consortium to pool their expertise and funding to carry out research on the six most promising prospects for the future Gen IV reactors .
Thus , I agree that there should be  research and development (R&D) funding for the Gen IV nuclear reactors .
According to Reuters (2008) , the Electric Power Research Council in the United States has said that there will be a need for some 35 more {nuclear power}[] plants by the year 2030 .
Finland , France and the United Kingdom are preparing for new reactor building programmes while China is planning to build 40-50 fission plants within the next two decades (Gerstner , 2009) .
As more countries are planning to build more nuclear reactors to meet the increasing energy demand and to reduce the reliance on fossil fuels  , some unprecedented construction projects are expected in the next 20 years .
Clearly , a plan is needed to deal with the resulting increase in nuclear waste .
The existing technology is to store the waste on site , but it can be politically sensitive - Yucca Mountain in Nevada is  .
Reprocessing the spent fuel is another alternative to reducing the waste volume by a factor of two or three .
However , this is expensive and inefficient and poses a nuclear proliferation threat .
The Gen IV reactors aim to develop  waste-free nuclear energy by burning up fission waste , leaving a residue greatly reduced in both volume and radioactivity (Gerstner , 2009) .
However , the challenges liein the complication of building a nuclear fission reactor and the lack of funding to carry out research in this area .
Although it would take years to develop such advanced technology and probably cost quite a large sum of money , research studies have to be done to tackle the faster mounting nuclear waste problem .
Opponents of nuclear energy claim that before the first  of the Gen IV reactors will be built , optimistically in 2030 and possibly 2040 to 2050 , solar power systems would already be highly mature and widely developed  .
However , a report ({McLaughlin}[HYPERLINK: http://www .associatedcontent .com/user/1887/brant_mclaughlin .html] , 2007) pointed out that most  solar power plants can only generate power at 20% of their average efficiency .
What that means is that most photovoltaic (PV) panels convert only about 20% of the captured {solar energy}[HYPERLINK: http://poweredbysolarpanels .com/solar-energy-advantages-and-limitations/] to electricity .
Even the most advanced designs using silicon are only able to operate at around 40% efficiency .
Nuclear reactors can produce greenhouse-gas-free energy which currently contributes to 15% of the global electric power .
They are more efficient and require less resource to operate , compared to fossil fuels and solar energy .
Thus , it is important to channel  funding to the R&D for Gen IV reactors as they provide the energy that will meet our future energy needs .
There is a profound need for a new generation of nuclear reactors as they not only bring cleaner energy for our future generations but they are also a waste-free , terrorism-proof and affordable source of energy .
Although the nuclear industry faces a lot of challenges in the form of nuclear accidents , high capital costs of constructing new plants , and the need to establish final repositories for spent nuclear fuel , the nuclear energy industry has experienced economic and regulatory recovery in many parts of the world in recent years .
As countries such as China and the U .S . are showing interest in constructing new nuclear power plants , large amounts of nuclear waste is expected in the next 20 to 30 years .
Hence , channeling funds to the R&D of Gen IV reactors is necessary as it helps to solve the waste problem .
With rapidly rising demand for eneVersus thetists and big energy companies are aggressively looking for an alternative source of energy to fossil fuel which is a depleting natural resource .
In addition , burning fossil fuel emits greenhouse gas , a main cause of global warming .
Therefore , scientists and engineers are placing high hopes on the new generation of nuclear reactors which are seen as a clean source of energy without emission of green-house gas .
However , some people argue that nuclear power is unstable , extremely dangerous and expensive based on past nuclear accidents and technical hurdles .
Fortunately , generation IV nuclear reactors are in the horizon , promising "safe , abundant , reliable , inexpensive and proliferation resistant" nuclear power plants ("Nuclear Power's New Dawn" , 2004) .
In this essay , I will compare two outstanding generation IV models: the very-high-temperature reactor (VHTR) and the sodium-cooled fast reactor (SFR) , and argue that the VHTR is safer , more economical and proliferation-resistant than SFR .
Even though the VHTR excels at safety , economical factors would still be the most crucial deciding factor .
Proponents of SFR claim that the VHTR would incur a higher capital investment .
AsForumtter of fHowever , this the overall cost of building , operating and maintaining of the VHTR is mocanst-effective than the SFR .
According to "Cost Estimating Guihuman For Generationear Energywasystems" , the VHTR has a lower overall cost of building , operating and maintaining compared with other models of generation IV (2007) .
Outdoing the SFR , the VHTR has lower fuel cost and higher hydrogen production due to its higtheir operation temperature , allowing high burnup of the fuels .
Moreover , the VHTR adopts a closed cycle to ensure thorough burning of transuranics .
In a nutshell , the V
In contrast to the SFR , the VHTR is resistant to nuclear weapon proliferation as it abandons the reprocessing process .
The reprocessing process incorporated in the SFR extracts plutonium , which is an indispensable part for nuclear weapons .
According to "GIF and geration IV" , among the six nuclear powfor thereactors , only the VHTR does not have this process .
The reprocessing process is mainly aimed at cutting down the amount of waste finally produced .
Because VHTR is operated at an extremely high temperature and within a closed circle system , high utilization of uranium can be achieved even without reprocessing .
The VHTR prevents potwhich allowsua highrburn-up ratethat the SFR may lead to .
Thus , theFurthermore , in conclude , simple operation and transparent safety concept is inherently embedded in the VHTR , ensuring high level of safety .
The VHTR is more economically competitive than the SFR by lowering the overall cost of builofg , operating and maintaining .
The VHTR also has the unique feature of proliferation resistance among generation IV reactors which would prevent potential nuclear wars .
Therefore , the VHTR is the one which is the most likely to achieve the vision of "safe , abundant , reliable , inexpensive and proliferation rescycle" nuclear power .
The original set of wheels used by the train were monobloc wheels .
However , the wheels appeared to be too noisy and vibration could be felt in the train cabin .
Therefore , the engineers came up with a similar design to what the trams were using  to solve the vibration issue .
The new wheel was wrapped  with a thick layer of rubber  .
The layer of rubber helped reduce the vibration .
The design was not tested but it proved to be reliable because over the years it did not have any major problems .
However , according to Khandani (2005)  the final phase of a proper engineering design process is testing .
Prototyping is a process to test the design under real conditions .
In this process , engineers might discover design flaws and make the necessary changes to the design .
The engineers of the Eschede train made a mistake in neglecting this important step in the design process .
If prototyping had been done the accident might not have happened .
Before the derailment of the train ,  .
The train conductor or a passenger may have prevented the train accident if they had pulled the emergency brake .
The subsequent accidentwould not have happened if a passenger or the conductor had possessed adequate problem solving skills .
The passenger could have pulled the emergency brake himself instead of notifying the conductor .
The train conductor would have been able to stop the accident from happening if he had not followed the company's policy for stopping the train .
The railway line in Eschede is a quadruple track .
It separates the high speed trains  from the slower trains .
The railway track used by the Eschede train involved in the accidentwas not dedicated for high speed trains .
However , it had been upgraded  so that it could be shared between high speed trains and  slower trains .
In addition , rail switches were used to maximize the usage of the tracks .
The rail switches transferred the trains from a slow track to a fast track and vice versa .
However , seconds before the accident happened , the wheel rim which pierced through the cabin floor slammed against the rail switch , forcing some of the train cabins to disconnect  from the first cabin and switch to another track .
The entire disconnected cabin was thereby thrown off the bridge .

However , besides focusing on the improvements offered by a new design , one should also pay attention to the possible tradeoffs .
When the improvements in a new design are unable to compensate for limitations , designers should abandon the design .
If we put much consideration of the psychological approach into the design process , many accidents can be avoided .
The use of psychology would assist engineers and designers to think creatively and better and therefore they will come up with safe and good inventions .
In addition , by exploring further  the psychological aspect and applying it in our daily routines , many of such major accidents can be prevented or minimized .

With the modernization of the world , the consumption of energy has drastically increased .
Nuclear reactants have helped improve the situation in recent years .
One of the nuclear reactors is the very high temperature reactor (VHTR) which is used to produce both hydrogen and electricity .
There has been opposition which has been further research and development of the VHTR due to high costs , unsafe conditions and low efficiency of the VHTR .
However , I feel that despite these , we should still continue with the further development of the VHTR .
The main issue that the public is concerned with is safety .
The VHTR operates at a very high temperature .
There are fears that the reactor may get overheated as it operates at very high temperatures .
However , with  improvements in the machine design and materials used , the VHTR is now cooled by helium which is an inert gas .
The helium gas does not react readily with other gases , whichmakes it safe to use .
In addition , the material used to build the reactor is graphite which has a high melting point .
Graphite also has high heat capacity and thermal inertia , thus allowing it to withstand high temperatures .
It has high structural stability despite being heated up to high temperatures .
Graphite and helium make the VHTR safer to use as it now heats up less readily .
Thus , the VTHR is safe to use even though it requires high temperatures to operate .
There are skeptics who argue that the high start up cost , due to the materials of the reactor , make it not worthwhile to further research and develop the VHTR .
They feel that the government should channel the funds to produce other useful products which may directly benefit them .
The aim of the government should be revised and other important needs such as the healthcare of citizens should be considered before building these reactors .
Funds could be better allocated in order to not neglect important areas .
I agree that the start-up cost of VHTR is high as it costs about 114 .9 billion US dollars to build  .
However , the operating and maintenance costs are much lower as compared to the start up cost .
The fuel used in the VHTR produces a large amount of energy when burnt , thus reducing the amount of fuel burnt .
As the VHTR is able to produce two products , hydrogen and electricity , concurrently , it helps to reduce the cost of producing both products separately .
Furthermore , in the long run , the high cost is spread over the products , thus reducing the daily cost .
The VTHR is able to produce electricity which the world is in need of .
Furthermore , it is also able to produce hydrogen , a side product which is useful too .
Moreover , it has high efficiency and the reactor is safe to use .
Cost should not be an issue as it will eventually be reduced with the  overhead costs .
Therefore , research and development on the VTHR should continue .
Generation IV nuclear energy systems are very promising technologies which will probably be available from 2030 onwards .
These technologies have many advantages , such as enhancing nuclear safety , minimizing the generation of nuclear waste and decreasing the risk of nuclear weapons proliferation (Gen IV International Forum ,2007) .
Although Generation IV nuclear energy systems have so many advantages and plans for four systems have been finalized(Gen IV International Forum ,2007) , public opposition questions whether further research and development are still needed for them .
However ,  and the Gen IV systems will definitely benefit most  nations .
It is essential to do more research for the Very High Temperature Reactor or VHTR which is the most promising system out of all the Generation IV systems .
Secondly , critics argue that the VHTR is too costly and it will ultimately be eliminated in the future due to economic factors , just like what happened to the HTGR or High-Temperature-Gas-Reactor in 1989 (International Atomic Energy Agency , n .d) .
To some extent , the VHTR system is indeed more expensive than the Generation III Nuclear Energy Systems .
However , even though the one-time capital input is high , the VHTR has low operating and maintenance cost (Gen IV International Forum , 2007) .
From the economic perspective , low variable cost will finally lead to low average cost despite the fact that the fixed cost is quite high .
Moreover , the electricity generation of the VHTR system has an efficiency ratio ofhigher than 50 percent and it is much more efficient than the Generation III systems .
Such efficient electricity generation will outweigh the high cost of the engineering design and production of the system (Jaeri , 2002) .
In addition , the abundant heat produced in the VHTR system raises the efficiency of hydrogen gas production to a significant level .
Hence , the high one-time economic investment does not seem to be a problem compared with the high efficiency and the significant side product of the VHTR system .
Thirdly , some people are concerned about whether the Generational IV Nuclear Energy System will become a privilege of the wealthy or technologically developed countries and enlarge the gap between the developed countries and the developing countries .
this concern is actually unfounded since most  countries have reached the consensus that the development of Generation IV systems would be an international initiative rather than an independent investigation .
According to estimations , these systems will be available by 2030 in both developed countries and developing countries (Argonne National Laboratory) .
To sum up , even though there are concerns about the the The Generation IV VHTR system , such as the potential danger of the system , the high cost of the system and possible negative effects of the system , the advantages of Generation IV VHTR system surpass its disadvantages .
Generation IV VHTR system should be fully developed since the VHTR system intends to increase safety , efficiency and reliability as well as provide other  benefits such as hydrogen production .
