Global warming and energy shortage are two of the most discussed topics nowadays .
We are earnestly looking for solutions to these problems , and nuclear energy , has been proposed as a solution to solve these two problems at once .
The production of nuclear energy does not have carbon dioxide as a by-product; thus  it can reduce the effect of global warming , which is the reason for many other problems , like rising of sea levels .
Nuclear energy can also satisfy the increasing demand of energy , thus solving the problem of energy shortage .
However , choosing nuclear energy as an alternative here has many drawbacks in the areas of cleanliness , safety and cost , this can also be reflected in the very-high-temperature reactors (VHTR) .
Hence , I do not support the building of new nuclear plants and use of nuclear energy .
Some people argue that nuclear energy should be used as it is a cleaner source of energy compared to coal and fossil fuels .
It is true to some extent as no carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases are produced during the production of energy through nuclear power .
Nevertheless , we should not neglect the unique wastes which can be produced by nuclear power plants alone during its energy production process .
This refers to nuclear wastes .
The unique thing about nuclear wastes is that it is radioactive , like naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) , which is not only radioactive itself , but will also produce highly dangerous radioactive radon gas .
(What is nuclear waste , n .d .) It is very hard to recycle or dispose of those wastes due to their unique nature , like the wastes produced by VHTR .
The radioactive wastes will affect the health of man-kind , animals and plants when they are exposed to it .
The consequences are hazardous .
Even if it is buried underground , it will take hundreds of years for its effect to go off due to its long half-life .
The land used by nuclear power plants cannot be used for other purposes after the plants are decommissioned , as excessive radioactivity is present in the area .
There have been suggestions to solve this problem by using helium , which is not radioactive , and abundant helium can be found on the moon .
However , there are a few things we should address: the practicality  of mining on the moon and the cost of mining on the moon .
There is no doubt that it is extremely expensive to fly to the moon and do the mining there .
At the same time , the technology to dig on the moon , and even use helium as a fuel is still not available yet .
Thus , nuclear energy is not a good alternative .
There are also some other people who argue that nuclear energy is safer .
However , looking at the incident of partial reactor meltdown in 1979 , which took place at Three Mile Island , Pennsylvania , and the notorious nuclear accident at Chernobyl in Ukraine in 1986(Butler ,2004) , people may rethink  the statements they have made .
The result of Chernobyl accident is disastrous as the radioactive debris spread across Europe and affected many people in different countries .
Some infected people later developed all kinds of diseases , and some new born children are deformed as well .
Generally , they die at a very young age .
Nuclear power plants also pose safety problems as they are always targeted by terrorists .
( Carl B . and Mark H .  ,2005) .
Some people argue that the deaths per year in nuclear plants are much fewer than that in coal mines .
Nevertheless , once a main accident in nuclear plants occurs , the impact will be enormous , long term and wide spread  , while the impact of a coal mine accident is immediate , which takes place in limited areas only .
Hence , nuclear energy should not be accepted .
One more argument for nuclear energy is that it is cheap .
However , the nuclear power plants are all operating at low temperatures now , rendering them inefficient , due to limitations of technologies .
The cost advantage of nuclear energy is not so obvious here .
However , if we take into account  the set up cost of the nuclear plants , which are more high-tech than coal plants , they are definitely much more expensive .
The equally expensive maintenance cost covered will in the end together contribute to the average cost of producing nuclear energy , which is now much higher than that of coal and other sources .
Optimists say that the cost will be greatly reduced when generation IV reactors are developed as they will work with much higher efficiency .
Nevertheless , the technology required is not readily attainable and it will take a long time to be realised .
Thus , nuclear energy should not be accepted .
In conclusion , nuclear energy may have some seeming advantages; however , the problems associated with it are not negligible , specifically the high cost , radioactive wastes and the safety concerns .
Therefore , nuclear energy may not be a desirable  alternative .
We should put more of our focus on better energy sources like solar power .
Many accidents happened over the past decades , some related to design flaws while others to human errors .
Reasons for human errors range from emotional wellbeing , to the inability in handling the pre-accident situation (Charles , 1999) .
These accidents may have been prevented should psychology be encompassed into the design process .
The Chernobyl nuclear accident in 1986 illustrates this notion .
On the 25th of April 1986 , reactor 4 was scheduled for a shut down , and an experiment was planned to test a safety feature during this process .
delayed the test past midnight resulting in it being conducted by a less proficient night team .
Before the test , an unexpected drop in power resulted in operators retracting control rods in an attempt to restore power .
The reactor however , appeared stable after the retraction although it displayed abnormal readings .
The operators ignored this abnormality and proceeded with the test .
Subsequently two explosions occurred resulting in massive losses (CHERNOBYL ACCIDENT , 2009) .
Supporters related the accident to a lack of understanding in human psychology during the design phase (Reason , 1988) .
The test was approved only by the director of the plant , without the coordination of the reactor's chief designer or scientific manager (Nuclear Energy , 2009) .
Opponents claimed that approval was appropriate as the reactor was muffled at the start of the experiment and should not have devastating effects on its safety (Reason , 1988) .
Proponents however , argued that the plant director had insufficient specialised knowledge .
The use of psychology would enable designers to acknowledge that operators may encounter faults beyond their abilities and thus gear the design towards user friendliness .
Moreover , a psychologist should be able to relate a high competency requirement to the test and thus limit its handling to upper management .
In this manner , there is a high chance that the accident would not have occurred since the most qualified personnel would have been managing the test .
In addition , these reactors require highly skilled professionals (Reason , 1988) .
Opponents were firm that should the test be conducted by the more proficient day team , the accident was unlikely to occur (CHERNOBYL ACCIDENT , 2009) .
On the contrary , proponents refute this , stating that psychology encompasses the understanding of human reaction during panic stages (Wilpert , 2007) .
The design of the reactor could thus include simple idiot-proof automated safety mechanisms without relying on operators' competency .
This way , the operators would not have retracted the control rods during the pre test stage since the system would have been automated .
Therefore , the accident may not have occurred .
Opponents countered the use of psychology as they felt it stifles creativity in the design process (Wilpert , 2007) .
They believed that feedback may end up counterproductive and deter engineers from verbalizing their creations in fear of evaluation .
Moreover , they stood firm that the psychologist' lack of relevant knowledge may divert the focus of engineers and lead them away from designing a relevant product .
Proponents agreed to the possibility of limiting creativity should psychology be used in the entire design process .
As such , they suggest the intermittent intervention of psychology or simply the introduction of psychology only after the main design outline is formed (Wilpert , 2007) .
This way , the main focus of the product would not be altered and the critical design phases could be assessed through the use of simulation or operators .
This would possibly uproot errors during the entire design sequence thereby preventing the Chernobyl accident .
However , as highlighted by opponents , usage of psychology would inevitably lead to increase in research and consequently production cost (Charles , 1999) .
In addition , resources for research would now have to be redistributed , thereby diverting focus from the core engineering design .
Proponents argue that the added cost is justifiable should the use of psychology prevent the accident .
The economic cost incurred in the entire aftermath cleanup process amounted to an astounding USD 43 billion not inclusive of intangible cost related to social and psychological effects (Chernobyl .info) .
Therefore supporters stay firm on the notion of prevention being better than cure , and hence propose the use of psychology in the design process .
In conclusion , it is undeniable that the use of psychology would lead to the increase in production cost or the reshuffling of resources allocated to core engineering design .
However , it would translate to designs encompassing user friendly backup systems non reliant on the competency of operators .
It would also match the test complexity to the appropriate management level .
As a result , the use of psychology in the design process may have prevented the Chernobyl accident thereby justifying its cost .
A Germany's Inter-City Express (ICE) train derailed and slammed into an overpass , killed 101 people and injured 200 people in June of 1998 , (Castellano , 2007) .
The causes of the accident were traced back to a damaged wheel that disintegrated just before the train passed over a switch track .
Upon further investigation , people discovered the evidence of poor wheel design , poor bridge construction , insufficient failure detection system , ineffective emergency procedures and insufficient design verification testing .
As a result , safety improvements and major engineering changes were implemented in order to prevent such disaster from happening again , which include the studies of psychology in design process .
Hence , the use of psychology in design process could have prevented the accident .
First of all , the use of psychology in the design process could have prevented the accident by revealing the need of adding several failure detection systems on the train .
According to the research that has been done by the German national railway company , Deutsche Bahn (1998) , the ICE train did not have a system installed to detect wheel failure and bring the train to an emergency stop .
According to Wilpert (2007) ,  inherent safety which links the design process to safety concerns must be taken into account .
However , in this situation , the engineers did not identify the inherently safer options (as cited in Wilpert , 2007) which led to a lack of failure detection systems that were installed in the train .
One example that highlighted this situation is the bullet trains from Japan .
The Japanese bullet trains are equipped with a detection system that can alert the train operator about wheel deformation and failure during the operation so that the operator may manually activate the emergency brake .
If the train had been installed with this system , the accident might not have happened .
Secondly , the use of psychology in the design process could have prevented the accident through activating the emergency brake despite the company's policy that did not allow the train manager to do so .
During the journey on the train , a large piece of metal came up through the floor and was witnessed by a passenger .
The passenger tried to warn the crew but was refused by the train manager due to the reason that he needed to investigate the problem  himself first .
As a result , valuable time was lost and the accident happened .
In this situation , the problem of psychopathology of design was revealed .
According to Wilpert (2007) ,  the designer 's and the user's conceptual model of a system or a device must be matched in order to reduce the problems that might occur during the time of using it , in this case , the train .
If the company policy was made with reference to a common sense that was agreed by everyone , such as , the train services in Singapore and the United Kingdom that made the control of emergency brakes available to the travelling passengers , the chain of failure would have been broken .
It is unlikely that the subsequent events could have occurred had the train been stopped immediately .
The third and most important thing to use psychology in the design process in this accident is that , it could have revealed the poor design of the wheel that caused the accident .
The ICE trains were equipped with single-cast wheels; after the accident , the engineers realized that the design of the wheels could make the metal to fatigue and cause out-of-round conditions that vibrate at cruising speeds .
According to Norman (as cited in Wilpert , 2007) , the appropriate system image must be ensured by the designer and this is one of the problems of psychopathology of design .
According to the research by Deutsche Bahn (1988) , the design of the wheels that were used did not reveal the actual durability and reliability of the wheels .
Hacker (as cited in Wilpert , 2007) points out that the quality of co-operative performance depends on the nature of the task at hand .
He says that a design task cannot be solved individually since each person has his own limitation in knowledge .
In this situation , if there were more designers involved in the design of the wheels , the poor design of the wheels could have been spotted and the accident would not have happened .
To sum up , with the use of psychology in the design process , the problems such as lack of failure detection systems that were installed in the train , company's policy that did not allow the train manager to stop the train , and the poor design of the train wheels would not have occurred .
To conclude , the train accident that happened  in Germany could have been prevented with the use of psychology in the design process .
A major accident does not usually happen with merely one error and the accumulation of all the errors will be catastrophic .
For instance the Nicoll Highway incident which occurred on Tuesday 20 April 2004 is the result of this which in turn caused four deaths .
The collapse was due to the retaining wall not being able  to handle the stress of supporting the tunnel and it gave way (Andrew , 2005) .
Hence , the opposing party argues that this failure is largely due to the technical aspect rather than the human errors .
Nevertheless , there are substantial points to suggest that psychology  can prevent the accident from happening if it has been implemented in the design stage .
As stated , the opponents claim that the collapse was due to the design of the structure .
The design of the structure itself was not well-built and the use of the weaker materials further exacerbated the failure (IES , 2005) .
Moreover , the opponents insist that the design was in fact approved by the Land Transportation Authority (LTA) .
Though the design was approved , the blueprint was in fact designed by engineers .
According to Wilpert .B (2007) , engineers do make design mistakes and this is known as an erroneous individual action .
The Nicolle Highway incident clearly illustrates this action when the contractor's engineers of Nishimatsu-Lum Chang (NLC) use the inappropriate soil simulation model for the design calculations (Andrew , 2005) .
As a result , the structure failed the safety criteria .
In addition , the use of the weak materials is due to the wrong mindset of the NLC wanting to earn more profits by cutting input materials cost , which is seriously a wrong attitude and perception .
Besides , the problem of psychopathology of design also arises when the NLC's engineers overestimated the basic technical ability of the LTA's personnel (Wilpert .B , 2007) .
Therefore , the lack in engineering knowledge of the LTA's personnel resulted in the approval of the blueprint which in turn resulted in the collapse .
Nonetheless , the supporters still argue another fact about the structure being used merely for a short period of time .
Thus there is no strict law imposed by the government about how a temporary structure should be built .
Furthermore , the supporters insist that the higher management within LTA and NLC had stringent control of the design phase despite the fact that the structure was used temporarily .
.
The wrong attitude about temporary structure causes them to let down their guard and become ignorant of the risk that the weak structure might pose .
Besides that , the NLC's design engineers ignored its failed risk assessment and continued to proceed with the blueprint without revealing the actual data to LTA (IES , 2005) .
This behavior is considered dishonest and immoral .
This is because NLC would want to complete their job within schedule  to avoid paying penalties to LTA (IES , 2005) .
Thus the over-eagerness and the time pressure exerted on them often lead to short-cuts and worsened the failure further (Wilpert .B , 2007) .
Lastly , the opposing party argues that all workers involved in this project had a strong sense of safety culture since it is compulsory to attend the Construction Safety Orientation Course (CSOC) before commencement of any construction work (MOM .Compulsory , 2007) .
Therefore the opponents emphasize that the failure was not due to the inadequate knowledge about the safety aspect but the failure of the technical aspect .
Although they had attended the CSOC , there were dysfunctional relations within the organization (Wilpert .B , 2007) .
The incapable the project management team failed to address the warning signs present in the early stage and implement corrective measures .
Thus , the failure was further aggravated .
Hence , the negligence and breaching of the project management team statutory duties indeed caused the collapse (MOM .Committe , 2007) .
In conclusion , one would realize the collapse of the Nicoll Highway is mainly due to human errors rather than the technical aspects .
Nevertheless , one would also recognize that failure of the technical aspect is due to the presence of human errors .
which is important in all human endeavors .
Thus , having certain knowledge about it will definitely aid in the understanding of human behavior and the reasons  why human makes mistakes .
As a result , it is vital to implement psychology in the design stage so to prevent the occurrence of any catastrophic accident .
Every nation is caught up with energy shortage problem .
If man continues exhausting natural resources at the present rate , the day is not far off when human beings may run out of coal or oil .
Nuclear power stands out as one of most prospective alternate source .
In the case of nuclear power , the allure is clear: abundant power , no carbon dioxide emissions , no blots on the landscape except an occasional containment dome and cooling tower , according to Michael P .(2005) .
However , problems come with nuclear power such as accidents of leakage , waste reprocessing and storage , high construction costs , and even the possible use of nuclear fuel for weapons .

The Chernobyl disaster  was a major engineering accident that occurred in the year 1986 .
The causes of the accident were classified to be design flaws of the nuclear reactor system as well as violation of safety regulations by the operators before the accident .
Some people believe that the use of psychology during the design process might have corrected all the flaws of the system , thus preventing the tragedy while others argue that this incident occurred due to severe breaches of safety regulations by the operators .
Therefore psychology plays no role in preventing this accident as the causes were due to human errors .
In my opinion , I trust that the use of psychology during the design process would have prevented the accident .
The use of psychology would rectify the design flaws and safety mechanism implemented to counter human errors .
Opponents  might argue that human errors occur on a random basis; therefore they could not be prevented .
It was this violation of safety rules by the operators prior to the accident that caused the explosion; thus  psychology during the design process would not contribute anything beneficial to the operations .
An experiment was conducted before the nuclear reactor was due for maintenance .
Before the test , the emergency core cooling system was shut down .
The first human error committed was to continue with the test .
The power of the reactor continued to drop below the lower limit for the experiment .
Control rods which act as absorbers were withdrawn from the core to increase the power of the reactor .
This was human error two .
All the circulating pumps were connected to the reactor that had its control rods withdrawn .
This caused an unstable thermo-hydraulic status .
The experiment started in these undesirable conditions .
Power began to rise and the absorbers were sent back to the core to control the reaction; however  they were unable to plunge fully into the lower stop due to mechanical fault .
The decision to cut off current that holds the absorbers to ensure the falling of rods caused the explosions .
It was through this series of human errors committed prior to the moment that caused this incident .
The impact of human errors could be minimized if appropriate safety mechanisms were installed on the system .
Psychologists could brainstorm for possible human errors that could be committed by the operators and recommend counter measures .
One possible counter measure against human errors could be to configure the system in such a way that whenever safety has been compromised , the system will be automatically shut down .
The use of psychology will bridge the gap between designers and operators as the system will not be overly complicated for the operators to work on .
All operation knowledge and training should be properly imparted by the engineers to the operators so as to guarantee system operation efficiency and safety .
All these measures taken will reduce the human errors to an insignificant level; thus those mistakes committed might not cause such a huge impact and Chernobyl accident might not have occurred .
A report published by IAEA Nuclear Safety Advisory Group stated that the actual causes were due to design errors .
The reactor constructed for the Chernobyl Nuclear Plant was the second generation nuclear reactor which was almost identical to the first generation .
Engineers failed to rectify the design errors found in the first generation; thus  all shortcomings were modeled into the second generation reactor .
The reasons that engineers failed to challenge the errors could be their large working group .
Studies have shown that considerable productivity loss is found when people of different background work together .
Factors affecting a group include evaluation apprehension , free riding and blocking .
The result of all the problems faced by the design engineers was a nuclear reactor which carries several design flaws .
The water channels run through the core vertically where a temperature gradient will be built up .
This causes the reaction within the core to increase greatly .
The control rods end tips were made of graphite which is a more potent neutron moderator and greatly increases the rate of fission reaction when the rods are initially inserted into the reactor .
This defeats the purpose of the control rods .
The use of psychology from the start of design process would rectify all the faults found .
Psychologists are able to give a more objective view on the integrity of the project .
Psychologists , being the middleman , will connect all the engineers together to design the new reactor .
Therefore all the features that compromise safety would be eliminated during the design process .
Therefore the use of psychology during design process would reduce design errors in the new reactor created .
Human errors are unavoidable .
Psychologists must be present to give their safety judgments to incorporate additional counter measures against possible human errors .
The use of psychology could also remove all the design flaws and add in a desirable mechanism to the system , thus creating a more efficient reactor for both the engineers and operators .
Therefore the use of psychology during the design process could have possibly prevented the Chernobyl incident .
Almost every day when we read the newspaper , articles about energy saving or increasing oil price will jump into our sight .
Actually , global warming and energy crisis have been  extremely popular topics these years and large proportion of the governments'  revenue has been spent on the research and development of new energy resources , such as solar energy and tidal power .
Among these new energy resources , nuclear power is highly favored by researchers due to its abundant base materials , low quantities of waste and comparatively cheap fuel costs .
CITATION Why06 \l 2052 (Why use Nuclear Power ? , 2006) Such a situation indicates that the new dawn of the nuclear power is at the corner although it means that the public have to struggle to restore their confidence ruined by the past appalling accidents of nuclear power plants .
Hitherto , scientists have successfully proposed the Generation IV nuclear reactor concepts , namely , gas-cooled fast reactors , lead-cooled fast reactors , molten salt reactors , sodium-cooled fast reactors , supercritical-water cooled reactors and very-high-temperature reactors .
CITATION Nuc04 \l 2052 (Butler , 2004) In my opinion , the very-high-temperature reactors (VHTR) are the best among the six .
In this essay , I will talk about the reasons from the perspectives of safety , work efficiency and cost .
Safety is always the thing that matters most .
After the Chernobyl disaster in Soviet Union , many people started to reject the proposal of wide usage of nuclear power .
But actually , no energy sources can be said to be free of risk .
Coal and oil have brought us problems like global warming and acidic rain; hydro projects have deteriorated the environment of  flooded and downstream areas and can lead to great economical loss and mortality once dams collapse; the mirrors and panels used for solar energy production can affect the environment too .
CITATION Com09 \l 2052 (Comparisons of various energy sources  , 2009) Hence , what we should concentrate on now is how to make the nuclear power production safer instead of arguing whether to reject it or not .
The good news is that the basic technology for VHTR has been well established and has been tested by many nuclear plants vendors and national laboratories .
Furthermore , the VHTR concept requires "the lowest risk technology development" to "achieve the needed commercial functional requirements" CITATION Ver09 \l 2052 (Very-High-Temperature Reactor (VHTR)) among the six Generation IV reactors .
Therefore , safety is highly guaranteed in the development and application of VHTR .
Besides safety , people are concerned much about the work efficiency .
Nobody wants to spend so much of their resources to develop something operating poorly .
In fact , "the VHTR system is designed to be a high-efficiency system and that can supply process heat to a broad spectrum of high-temperature and energy-intensive , non-electric processes ."
CITATION Ver09 \l 2052 (Very-High-Temperature Reactor (VHTR)) The pebble-bed and prismatic design of VHTR makes no intermediate refueling necessary .
And due to high temperature , the reactor generates electricity and hydrogen simultaneously , superior to the sodium-cooled fast reactors and critical-water-cooled reactors which can only generate electricity .
In addition , the high temperature exchanger and electrical heater of a VHTR system prevent significant efficiency loss .
Therefore , the VTHR system can meet our efficiency requirements undoubtedly .
Last but not  least , every technological innovation should be feasible not only technically but also economically .
As far as we know , the ultra-long life VHTR systems can be developed with minor actinides .
Minor actinides used can incinerate burnable poisons or fuel materials to obtain high levels of burn-up , which could "facilitate development of new fuel cycles and support sustainability of a fuel source for nuclear energy" .
CITATION Pav09 \l 2052 (Tsvetkov) So the cost of maintenance and fuels for VHTR can be highly reduced compared to other Generation IV reactors .
Besides , the earliest delivery time for VHTR is 2020 , earlier than that of other Generation IV reactors except Sodium-cooled fast reactors .
The earlier delivery means the earlier alleviation of these impending problems and more payback .
Hence , the VHTR systems are highly practical economically .
In conclusion , to solve the global warming and energy shortage problems , we need the exploration and better utilization of nuclear energy .
And among the six proposed new generation nuclear reactors , the VHTR systems are the best in consideration of various factors .
The strong technological backup provides adequate safety; the specific innovational design of the system ensures high work efficiency; the ultra long lifetime and early delivery brings comparatively lower cost .
Therefore , VHTR is the one which deserves further research and development funding most .
On the 6th of March 1987 the freight ferry 'Herald of Free Enterprise' capsized just ouside the port of Zeebrugge .
The accident took the lives of 150 passengers and 38 crewmembers  .
(Pijnenburg &Duin ,1990) .
Could this accident have been prevented or to be specific could the use of psychology during the design process prevent this accident from happening ?
Major accidents besides Zeebrugge such as the 'Three Mile Island' incident and the 'Chernobyl 'disaster are said to be caused by human error .
Statistics show that close to 90% of all accidents is caused by human error .
(BI-ME staff ,2009) The major companies have given the excuse of cost and time as the reason why they have not considered implementing psychology during the design process .
Although these major companies have not shown a high enough level of interest to invest in the use of engineering psychology , I believe that engineering psychology can help improve on the safety of operation in their industry and eventually reduce accidents .
I will look into the 'Zeebrugge' incident in detail to prove that it could have been prevented if psychology were used during the design process .
In the case of the 'Zeebrugge' incident , there were many things wrong with the design of the ferry .
For instance the ferry's design is a huge hull for which its purpose is to load and unload cars at a very fast pace .
Although it might seem a good idea at first  having a huge hull means that the boat can easily turn over when there is water on deck (Noyes  & Stanton ,1997) .
This matter has been brought into attention to the Board of Directors but they were not willing to waste money to have the engineers sketch up a new design .
Another design flaw is there were no light indicators to give notice of the status  of the bow doors .
Once again  ,the idea was rejected because of cost issues .
Considering that one of the reasons that the accident happened is because the bow doors were still open when the ferry left the port  ,it makes us wonder whether the accident could really have been prevented if proper precautions were taken .
During the design process , it is important to ensure that the product design is safe and user friendly (Wilpert ,2007) .
When designing a product or even a system , engineers must make sure that there are safety measures or considerations taken in the design .
Another cause of the ferry capsizing is the lack of communication within the organization .
Critics claim that it is important to establish a professional relationship between the workers and make sure the workers do not step over their scope of work .
This way of thinking however is inexcusable as when working in an engineering industry , most departments rely on each other .
When water started to flood in the 'Herald Of Free Enterprise' , one deck hand noticed it but did not report the matter because he thought that others may have noticed and it was not his job .
If there were proper interaction between the workers the 'Zeebrugge' incident could have a different ending .
Apart from that there is also the matter of the management's role into the 'Zeebrugge' incident .
The management is said to be pushing their workers to work double shift just for their own profits .
Critics mentioned that the welfare of the workers is not important .
As long as they are being paid for their extra work , it is fine .
That way of management is very harsh as the workers' safety and their health are very important .
Looking in the 'Zeebrugge' incident , the worker who was supposed to make sure the bow doors were closed , was asleep .
Because the higher-ups forced the workers into exhaustion an engineering accident happened .
The workers' psychological state and physiological state must be good in order for him to perform his job .
When the workers' mind is in the right place , then he will be happy and content when working (Carpentier & Cazamian ,1977) .
This will undoubtedly reduce human error .
It is without question that the 'Herald of Free Enterprise' would not have capsized if psychological approach is taken during the design process .
Not only the incident at 'Zeebrugge' , but many other major  from this approach in design .
The fundamental issues when designing is that it should match its expectations and also be safe to operate (Wilpert ,2007) .
Although it is impossible to totally remove human error from operations , the  next best thing we can do is to reduce it and by using psychology such a goal can be achieved .
In the past few decades , nuclear energy has been considered as a futuristic and exotic technology which requires much research and experimentation in order to develop these farfetched ideas .
Nowadays , reactors in operation around the world are generally considered second or third generation systems , with the first-generation systems out-dated some time ago .
Our next step will be to innovate generation IV reactors which are cheaper , safer and cleaner compared with the current nuclear reactors .
This mission is put under the responsibility of the Generation IV International Forum (GIF) where ten nations will come together to research and plan the nuclear reactors of tomorrow .
Among the six generation IV reactors concepts , the Very High Temperature Reactor concept deserves further research and development funding for it .
As an introduction , the Very High Temperature Reactor concept uses either a prismatic-block or pebble bed reactor design graphite-moderated core with uranium fuel cycle to generate electricity and produce hydrogen through a thermochemical process .
This high temperature reactor uses inert helium to keep the reactor cool and can be considered as passively safe .
Experiments have been carried out by Japan's Atomic Energy Research Institute based in Kashiwa to test its feasibility by operating a similar high-temperature engineering test reactor at Oarai , Tokyo .
Its first test run had a quite satisfactory result by achieving its goal of 9500C without having any sign of partial reactor meltdown .
Hence , this reactor is practical and has a high potential to be the next generation nuclear reactor .
Generally , nuclear power is a sustainable energy source that does not pollute our environment with tremendous amounts of toxic gases such as nitrogen oxides , sulfur oxides and carbon dioxide .
Compared with fuel oil and coal combustion , nuclear power not only meets the increased global energy demands in the future but also avoids global warming issues .
In Taipei , Taiwan , the government would rather  extend its oldest nuclear plant's life and is willing to take the risk of public safety just to cut down the greenhouse effects .
However , we cannot deny the fact that nuclear energy will produce radioactive wastes that raise the concern of the public .
In fact , nuclear power plant will only emit a very small percentage of radioactive wastes to the air during its operation and the possibility of nuclear wastes leakage is very low .
This safety issues arises because of the huge information gap besides the lack of communication and understanding between the experts and the public about the safety measures taken during the operation of nuclear power plant .
In terms of performance , the Very High Temperature Reactor  is able  to generate 50% more electricity compared with other conventional plants such as Pressurized Water Reactor .
This is because this reactor is designed to run at temperature 10000C which is the highest temperature used among the generation IV reactors to generate electricity  using the same amount of fuel .
Basically , high temperature operations are more efficient to convert heat energy to electrical energy and can avoid wasting of energy in other forms .
This reactor does not have a waste recycling process  and instead , the waste goes directly to the repository .
Although reprocessing can decrease the quantity of waste produced , the generation of weapons-grade plutonium is still not a beneficial product to human kind .
We should cut down the amount of plutonium present and not increase its quantity for further development .
There is no doubt that up-front cost of nuclear power plant building is relatively expensive compared to those associated with fossil fuels .
In fact , there are many ways to mitigate these costs .
The Very High Temperature Reactor is considerably cheap compared to other reactors .
It does not run the conventional reprocessing which is rather expensive and it is among the earliest delivery of generation IV reactor .
Hence , this reactor does not need a very long research period and cuts down the unnecessary development funding .
In conclusion , nuclear energy brings many advantages to our society .
It not only decreases the world's dependency on fuel oils to generate electricity , but also acts as an environment protector .
Although there are a few drawbacks of nuclear power , we can reduce these negative effects by using the latest technology in newer reactors and placing emphasis on public safety .
As long as we use it wisely and efficiently , I believe that nuclear power greatly surpasses other type of energies .
The world is facing an energy crisis .
Current means of generating electricity such as burning of fossil fuels are getting less viable by the day due to its depleting source .
Hence , there is a need for new alternative methods of generating electricity that is capable of satisfying the energy demand of the growing world population .
One such alternative would be nuclear energy .
Nuclear plant takes advantage of the heat generated from nuclear fission and uses it to heat up water , producing steam .
The steam produced is then used to generate electricity .
Although the whole process does sound simple , there is actually more to it than meets the eye .
In fact , most people are not comfortable with the idea of using nuclear reactors to generate electricity , for good reasons .
However there are six new generation IV reactors being developed at the moment that promises to resolve many of the issues posed by generators of the past .
Of these six reactors , the most promising reactor would be the very-high-temperature reactors (VHTR) .

The reaction itself , unlike other generation IV plants , is moderated by uranium oxycarbide coated graphite , a naturally safe choice , capable of retaining radioactive waste .
